title: NHBA Bird Outing
description:
Contact David Anderson at d47anders@gmail.com with questions. The location will be New Hope Bottomlands. The trail is accessed by The Old Chapel Hill Road Park on 3791 SW Durham Dr., Durham, NC. Follow the road into the park all the way to its end near the soccer field.  We will head from there over to the trail. 

This outing is sponsored by the New Hope Bird Alliance (formerly New Hope Audubon).

Outings usually last 2-3 hours. No reservations or sign-up needed. If there is a large turnout for any particular outing, we may split into two groups. We do recommend carpooling for families or friend pods; while we love pets, there is a ‘no-pet’ policy for bird outings. New birders and birders of all skill levels are welcome. 

Please wear long pants, socks, and sturdy shoes (ticks and chiggers may be present). Sun and bug protection are also recommended. Bring snacks and water if you like. Heavy rain will result in cancellation. Source: New Hope Bird Alliance

title: Blue's March: An Overmountain Men Tale StoryWalk
description:
Join park staff in celebrating America's 250th anniversary with a StoryWalk® reading  “Blue's March: An Overmountain Men Tale". The StoryWalk® will be up throughout the week on a portion of the Bay Trail. Check for signage or with park staff for more info. America 250 NC is North Carolina’s commemoration of the United States’ 250th anniversary and is led by the N.C. Department of Natural and Cultural Resources. For more information about America 250 NC, visit america250.nc.gov. 

The StoryWalk® Project was created by Anne Ferguson and developed in collaboration with the Kellogg-Hubbard Library in Montpelier, Vermont. StoryWalk® is a registered service mark owned by the Kellogg-Hubbard Library.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Bird is the Word!-NC Backyard Bird Count
description:
Fly on over to the park Visitor Center to take part  in the 2026 NC Bird Count! This community citizen science opportunity is open to all ages and birding skill levels. We will collect park bird data for the Great Backyard Bird Count. Bring your binoculars and dress for the weather!

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt
description:
The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt showcases how the biblical story of heroic Queen Esther, depicted by Rembrandt and his contemporaries in art and popular culture, expressed ideas of political and religious freedom during the Dutch Golden Age. Charting this history through objects and artworks, The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt provides an original perspective on one of the most studied periods of Dutch prosperity.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Trail Festival Weekend: Paths of History
description:
Join Bladen County for their Annual Trail Festival Weekend. This year, we are focusing on the history and stories of the beautiful Bladen County landscape in celebration of America's 250th Anniversary. From a Revolutionary War Battle to naval stores and ingenious farming techniques, the story in Mother Nature's Playground is the story of growth in America. Hike a trail through a longleaf pine forest, paddle across a Carolina Bay, stroll the historic downtown of Elizabethtown, or explore our new Driving Tour of Historic Places. 

The annual Trail Festival Weekend in Mother Nature’s Playground will take place from February 13-16, 2026.

As part of America’s 250th celebration, we will honor the great outdoors in Bladen County with a nod to our longleaf pines, naval stores, Carolina Bays, and rich agricultural heritage. Be a part of history as we announce the first-ever Historical Driving Tour of Bladen County!


Their goal is to bring people together to explore trails and relax in our naturally beautiful places here. Join us for guided hikes, fun family activities, local music and southern cuisine, and lots of chances to explore why we call this area – Mother Nature’s Playground.

Basecamp on Saturday is the Cape Fear Farmers Market. Trails take place though out Bladen County.

For more information, email tourism@elizabethtownwhitelake.com or call 910-862-4368

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Hammered Trivia w/ Thor
location: Durty Bull Brewing Company, 206 Broadway Street, Durham, NC, 27701, United States
description:
Award winning Trivia Hosted by Thor himself! Your Sunday Funday just got that much better, with a delicious slate of beer offerings and the best best trivia in the triangle! See for yourself why Hammered Trivia has won best trivia in the triangle on the Indy Weekly readers poll and WRAL Out & About!

Source: Downtown Durham Inc

title: Fort Macon Daily Tours – 1:00 p.m.
description:
Guided tours of Fort Macon are available daily at 1:00 p.m. during the Park's slower season between mid Oct. and Mid April.

The tours will last about 45 minutes.

Meet at the fort entrance. Pets are not allowed inside the fort.

 

Photo by C. Peek: The fort at Fort Macon State Park

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Sunday Stroll with a Park Ranger
description:
1.5mile moderate hike along the Rumbling Bald Trail, a loop trail that meanders through a beautiful hardwood forest along the south face of Rumbling Bald Mountain, revealing huge boulder fields and the base of the cliff areas.

Bring plenty of drinking water, wear appropriate clothing for the weather and closed-toed shoes.
In case of inclement weather, the event will be cancelled.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: TOUR: A Closer Look at the Collection
description:
Join Ackland educators for a lively half-hour look at a small handful of artworks. These engaging conversational tours offer a closer look at and new perspectives on works on view at the Museum. 
This is a free, walk-in event – no RSVP required. 
  
This event is part of UNC–Chapel Hill’s Campus Life Experience (CLE) program. Students who attend can scan the QR code provided at the event to receive CLE credit.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: University Worship
description:
Join us in worship that offers stirring preaching, inspiring sacred music, and faithful prayer. Held year-round amid the beautiful, soaring architecture of Duke Chapel, this interdenominational Christian service is characterized by vibrant faith, intellectual depth, diverse cultural expressions, and a welcoming community.

To attend a service, navigate to 125 Science Drive, Durham, NC. Parking is available at that address in the Bryan Center Garage with ADA parking in the adjacent surface lot. Parking in the garage is free on Sunday until 2:00 p.m. when using the standard ticket issued upon entering the garage. Regular attendees of the service are encouraged to receive a pass for free parking on Sunday mornings at the visitor desk inside the Chapel.

Resources for the service:
* Make an offering online: https://chapel.duke.edu/offering 
* View an online version of the hymnal here: https://hymnary.org/hymnal/UMH

A national leader in the theological study of the art of preaching, Chapel Dean Luke A. Powery preaches regularly at this service, along with a rotation of other Chapel ministers and renowned guest preachers. The acclaimed Duke Chapel Choir and Chapel organists lead the music, supplemented by student chamber groups, professional instrumentalists, and visiting artists.

Services are streamed live on YouTube and broadcast live on channel 12 of the Duke Hospital TV system and on the radio on 620 AM WDNC. Subscribe to the Duke Chapel Sermons podcast on Spotify or Apple Podcasts. Find an archive of Chapel sermons on our website and a more extensive digital archive in the Duke Chapel Recordings collection on the Duke Libraries website.

For a listing of Christian education offerings held before the service, see the Duke Chapel website calendar.

Source: Duke University

title: Sights and Sounds on Sundays Concert Series: Cleveland Celtic Ensemble
description:
Presented by Collegiate Capital Management
and with support from Jack Lewis and Peg O’Connell 

Brian Bigley, uilleann pipes, Irish flute, whistles, traditional Irish dance
Kristen Bigley, violin
Ian Crane, Scottish smallpipes, border pipes, vocals
Tiffany Schaefer, Celtic harp, vocals

About the artists
The Cleveland Celtic Ensemble offers a captivating fusion of Celtic tradition and chamber music sophistication, delivering performances that are both intimate and exhilarating. Their unique blend of Scottish and Irish bagpipes, fiddle, harp, flute, and vocals creates a rich tapestry of sound that resonates with audiences seeking both authenticity and innovation.

Each member brings a wealth of experience and accolades to the ensemble. Brian Bigley has toured extensively across North America and Europe, showcasing his mastery of the uilleann pipes and traditional Irish dance. Kristen Bigley, with her classical training, seamlessly bridges the gap between classical and folk genres. Ian Crane’s performances have graced prestigious venues such as the Smithsonian Folk Life Festival, the Kennedy Center, and the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Tiffany Schaefer, winner of the 2022 US National Scottish Harp Championship, enriches the ensemble’s sound with her harp and vocal prowess.

Their debut album, Cleveland Celtic Ensemble, features traditional and contemporary pieces from Ireland, Scotland, and America, reflecting their commitment to both preservation and innovation in Celtic music. The ensemble’s performances have been featured on platforms like the Irish and Celtic Music Podcast, further cementing their reputation in the Celtic music community.

 

Tickets $31, Members $28, Students $25

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Public Tour of Duke Chapel
description:
Learn about the history, architecture, and life of Duke Chapel on this tour, which is free and open to the public.

The tour begins at 12:15 p.m., or immediately following the conclusion of the Sunday morning service, and lasts approximately forty-five minutes. No reservation is required, but if you plan to bring a large group, please notify us in advance. Meet the docent on the front steps of the Chapel.

Paid parking is available on a first-come, first-served basis in the Bryan Center Parking Lot at 125 Science Drive. ADA parking is available in the Bryan Center Surface Lot at the same address.

Source: Duke University

title: Invasive Plant Removal (Marvin)
description:
Join NCWF Habitat Builders Chapter at Marvin Efird Park to remove some invasive species. We will show you how to identify various species and how to remove them from the landscape. 

Invasive plants are non-native introduced plants that do not support native wildlife. They are very aggressive, outcompete wildlife-friendly plants, and take over natural areas. Nandina, Privet, Monkey Grass, and Autumn/Russian olive are common invasive plants that have escaped residential landscapes and are taking over natural areas. To make matters worse, these plants are still available for sale in big box stores. 

We will have some tools available, but you are encouraged to bring a pair of loppers, pruners, pruning saw, or shovel. NO POWER TOOLS PLEASE. 
REGISTER HERE

Source: NC Wildlife Federation

title: Solar System Odyssey
description: Source: Morehead Planetarium & Science Center

title: The 23rd Annual Valentine's Jazz Festival
description:
Celebrate the joy, energy, and community spirit of big-band jazz at the 23rd Annual Valentine's Jazz Festival, a beloved tradition that unites three of the Triangle's most vibrant jazz programs. This year's festival brings together the powerhouse ensembles of Duke University, North Carolina Central University, and the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill for an afternoon filled with swing, soul, and electrifying ensemble playing.

Each band brings its own history, personality, and stylistic flair to the stage-from NCCU's nationally renowned jazz program, known for its rich legacy of professional-caliber musicianship, to UNC-Chapel Hill's dynamic student ensembles, and, of course, Duke's own Jazz Ensemble, celebrated for its versatility, rhythmic drive, and creative artistry.

The result is a thrilling musical exchange that highlights the incredible depth of jazz talent across our region. Expect everything from high-energy swing charts and soulful ballads to contemporary works that showcase the evolving language of jazz today. With more than 60 student musicians performing across the three groups, the festival offers a rare chance to experience big-band jazz on a grand scale.

More than just a concert, the Valentine's Jazz Festival is a celebration of collaboration and community-a place where students from across campuses come together to share their passion, creativity, and musical voice. Whether you're a longtime jazz lover or new to the genre, this annual tradition promises an afternoon of joyful energy and unforgettable performances.

Tickets on sale at tickets.duke.edu.

General Admission: $10
Seniors (65+): $5
Duke Students: Free (one per person)

Source: Duke University

title: Rewilding Oases Planting Workday (Chapel Hill)
description:
Join NCWF Tri-County Conservationists Chapter for a Rewilding Oases workday at Brumley! Native species and habitats in Brumley Nature Preserve have been pushed out by invasive species like privet and autumn olive. Walnut Grove Loop is a lovely, shaded area of Brumley South. Most of the big invasives have been removed, now we are establishing Rewilding Oases, where volunteers will focus their efforts on restoring native species. At this event, we will begin planting our oases with native tree and shrub saplings, including black cherry, beech, elderberry, and black walnut. Help us restore habitat for wildlife in Chapel Hill!  
REGISTER HERE

Source: NC Wildlife Federation

title: Craft Club & Supply Swap
location: Glass Jug Downtown, 545 Foster Street, Suite 10, Durham, 27701
description:
Get artsy crafty over a craft beer at our new Craft Club! Bring your own craft to do alongside others – whether it’s knitting, sewing, coloring, painting, whatever! Show off what you’re working on and learn from the skills of others as you sip cocktails, brews, wine, THC beverages, and more! 
And bonus – every week we’re also hosting a craft swap! Are you a serial hobbyist? Do you have a silly excess of scraps and leftover supplies from discarded crafty projects? How about that pile of things you actually did finish, but that you can’t possibly use all of? Bring the excess items you’ve made and your spare supplies to trade! Participants will be able to drop their contributions on a reserved table, and everyone can shop the stash. We will operate on an honor system where everyone is encouraged to take roughly the same value of things they brought. 
Even better, once a month our Craft Club will also host a workshop on various topics so you can learn and grow as an artist while you have fun. 
So grab a drink, get crafty, and plan to hang out for a while to see who all stops by and what type of goods come through the swap. 


Source: Downtown Durham Inc

title: The Longest Night: A Winter's Tale
description: Source: Morehead Planetarium & Science Center

title: Pre-Theatre Menu at Alley Twenty Six
location: Alley Twenty Six, 320 E Chapel Hill St, Durham, NC, 27701, United States
description:
Durham’s Alley Twenty Six offers a Pre-Theatre Menu from 4-5:30 p.m. Tuesdays-Sundays. The three-course menu includes appetizer, entree, and dessert. An example menu includes a mandatory green salad or chilled crab rangoon dip for the first course; ricotta gnocchi or shrimp roll for the second course; and for dessert, Mexican chocolate pot de crème or St. Angel Triple Crème Cheese. Price: $40. The menu and prices change based on season and ingredient availability. Alley Twenty Six is located at 320 E.Chapel Hill St., Durham. Info: https://www.alleytwentysix.com/

Source: Downtown Durham Inc

title: The Song of the Earth
location: Live at Bay 7, 324 Blackwell St #700, Durham, 27701
description:
Enter a realm where beauty and mortality intertwine in The Song of the Earth, a hauntingly intimate performance of Arnold Schoenberg and Rainer Riehn’s arrangement of Gustav Mahler’s Das Lied von der Erde. Scored for a reduced ensemble yet retaining every ounce of Mahler’s emotional depth, this rarely heard transcription brings clarity and immediacy to a masterpiece that meditates on life, loss, and the eternal. With its fusion of symphony and song, East and West, hope and despair, The Song of the Earth offers a deeply human experience that is at once fragile, powerful, and timeless.

Source: Downtown Durham Inc

description:
Durham’s Alley Twenty Six is offering menu specials with cocktail pairings for Galentine’s and Valentine’s celebrations from Feb. 12-14. The menu includes:

title: Carolina Skies
description: Source: Morehead Planetarium & Science Center

title: Bach Cantata Series: Bach & Dumont
description:
Johann Sebastian Bach's cantatas are often considered the pinnacle of German sacred music, works whose theological depth and emotional resonance touch deep places in the human soul. This year's cantata series, Bach &, features cantatas, concerti, and organ works by Bach and his contemporaries, illuminating the connections and differences between these Baroque masters. This concert pairs the music of Bach with the French composer Henri Dumont. 

Pieces by Dumont include: 
* "Super flumina Babylonis"
* "Litanies de la Vierge." 

Compositions by Bach include:
* "Nun komm, der Heiden Heiland," BWV 61,
* Orchestral Suite No. 2 in B minor
* Pièce d'Orgue, BWV 572

Performers:
* Dr. Philip Cave, Duke Chapel conductor-in-residence, director
* Dr. Roseen Giles, Mrs. Alexander Hehmeyer Associate Professor of Music at Duke, baroque flute
* Dr. David Lim, Duke Chapel organ scholar, organist
* Mallarmé Music, ensemble
* Vocalists

Free admission. Paid parking is available on a first-come, first-served basis in the Bryan Center Parking Lot at 125 Science Drive. ADA parking is available at the surface lot at the same address.

Learn more about the music in a pre-concert talk at 4:00 p.m. in the Divinity School's Goodson Chapel.

Families with young children, or those unable to attend the performance, are welcome to visit the dress rehearsal on Saturday, February 14, between 1:30 and 4:00 p.m. in Duke Chapel.

Source: Duke University

title: Somatic Flow at Recess Yoga
location: Recess Yoga Durham, 345 W. Main st, 2nd floor, Durham, NC, Durham, 27701
description:
This exploratory, heart-centered practice supports us in attuning to the deeper, more subtle layers of the body. You’ll be guided through embodied movement, breath work (pranayama), and nervous system regulation to cultivate a deeper mind-body connection and to release deep-seated tension. Somatic Flow is an expansive, grounding, and deeply nourishing practice that is sure to transform your yoga practice! Perfect for anyone looking to unwind, restore inner harmony, and rediscover ease in movement. FREE CLASS. Find and follow Recess Yoga Durham on Instagram @recess_yoga_durham for more updates and studio information!

Source: Downtown Durham Inc

title: Valentine’s/Galentine’s Modern Calligraphy for Beginners at Weldon Mills Distillery
location: Weldon Mills Distillery, 300 E Main St Suite 001, Durham, 27701
description:
Join Sip & Script for a Night of Learning Calligraphy! 
Join us at Weldon Mills Distillery in Durham, NC for a festive workshop of Galentine’s fun and pretty lettering for beginners! Whether you’re a stationery nerd, DIY Bride-to-be, or just a crafty individual, in this workshop you’ll be learning an introduction to modern calligraphy with a pointed dip pen and ink. We will cover all the basics and get you ready to add those special lettered details to your Galentine’s cards. The perfect crafty night out! 
Class includes 1.5 hours of instruction and demonstration, our beginner’s calligraphy kit (two nibs, black ink pot, 2 letter guides, tracing paper and straight pen holder), and all materials to write on. Everything is yours to keep at the end of the workshop! 
To learn more about Weldon Mills Distillery, check out their website and say hey on Instagram. 
Get your tickets below! 
Feel free to come early, grab your seat, and purchase any food (food and drinks available to purchase throughout class too!). Class will start promptly at 5:30 p.m.! 
Class Expectations: Yes, lefties are welcome too! This class is encouraged for someone who has never taken a calligraphy class before. We teach the basics and our expectation for you is to have ink flowing through your nib with enough confidence to be able to practice way beyond class. We love using tracing paper with our guides to help you build muscle memory and develop your own style! If you have tried calligraphy out before, this class will be a great refresher and hopefully a chance to try some new supplies from our beginner kit that will re-introduce you to this lovely form of art! 
A note on bringing guests 16 and under: We love to share this passion with kids. You are welcome to get a ticket for your child as long as you are comfortable with people around them having a drink or two. We do ask that anyone under the age of 16 is to be accompanied by a ticketed adult at all times.

Source: Downtown Durham Inc

location: Motorco, 723 Rigsbee, Durham, NC, 27701, United States
description:
Join the Common Woman Chorus for a night of singing, seduction, and delightful depravity at our Villains Cabaret Fundraiser on Sunday, February 15th at 6pm. Revel in a collection of “after-dark” performances inspired by mischief-makers, rogues, anti-heroes, and villains of all kinds, brought to life by our talented singers at Motorco Music Hall! We are thrilled to welcome back Stormie Daie, the Thunderous Black Enby Queen of Durham, NC, as our host for the evening. Grab your tickets below and side with the villains at the Common Woman Cabaret! 
VIP Ticket is First Row of Seating – CWC Swag is included with every VIP ticket!
Standard Ticket is General Admission

Source: Downtown Durham Inc

title: Silent Book Club Sundays @ DSSOLVR (FREE)
description:
Silent Book Club – Durham 
Join us for an evening of literary camaraderie at DSSOLVR’s Durham taproom! Weekly on Sundays, starting @ 6:30 pm, the @SilentBookClub convenes to celebrate the joy of reading with fellow book lovers. 
Come read and mingle with new, bookish friends! Bring whatever book you happen to be reading, read in companionable silence (for about an hour), then share about it with your table mates. 
Schedule: 
– Meet and chat until 6:30 – 7:00 
– Silent reading 7:00 – 8:00 
– Chat about reading 8:00 – ??? 
Wi-Fi – Free guest Wi-Fi available.
Dogs – Dog Friendly inside & outside.
Family – Family friendly w/ high chair, changing table, and sensory toys for kids. Free to play video Games & board games available.
Food – Snacks available on site. Several food delivery & carry out options available within a 2 block radius.
Parking – Street parking available all around as well as free parking lot a block away next to Welcome Tattoo and two blocks away behind Cocoa Cinnamon.
Menu – Menu has rotating options of beer, cider, Gluten free beers, liquor/cocktails, Jell-O shots, and extensive non-alcoholic offerings!

Source: Downtown Durham Inc

title: Trey Kennedy – The Relatable Tour
location: DPAC Presented by First Horizon, 123 Vivian St / William V. "Bill" Bell Way, Durham, 27701
description:
Hi – this is Trey! I’m supposed to tell you all my accomplishments in this bio but there’s NO way anyone would read that. I just hope you come to my show and bring your friends and family; this is my favorite show I’ve written yet. You can check out my most recent special “GROW UP” on Hulu or my Youtube channel. I promise to give you a good time and in return I just ask for your thoughts and prayers – I’m bringing my wife and 2 kids under 2 on the tour bus. See y’all there!

Source: Downtown Durham Inc

title: Celebrating Black History Month: Quilts and Baskets
location: Falls Lake State Recreation Area - Visitor Center
description:
Create colorful paper quilts and mini baskets with yarn. Art supplies will be provided along with informative details about the history of the creative art form of quilt and basket making. This will be an interactive drop-in arts and crafts event. Feel free to take a craft sheet home with you while supplies last. Join us in celebrating part of American history!

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Great Backyard Bird Count
description:
Fly on over to Hanging Rock State Park for a unique adventure! We’ll start and end at the Lake Parking Area for a 2.6-mile leisurely hike, exploring portions of the Wolf Rock Trail, Chestnut Oak Nature Trail, and Lake Trail. Along the way, we’ll take part in a fun citizen-science project that helps collect data for the Great Backyard Bird Count.

This experience is open to all ages and birding skill levels—whether you’re a seasoned birder or just curious! Hanging Rock is home to a variety of species, from woodland birds to those that swim in the lake. Bring your binoculars and dress for the weather. A limited supply of binoculars and field guides will be available, but feel free to bring your own.

Join us for a relaxing hike, beautiful views, and a chance to contribute to a nationwide birding effort! Registration is required, please email Ranger Jonathan at jonathan.buie@ncparks.gov.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Dune Hike
location: Meet at the pavilion beside park visitor center.
description:
Ascend the ridge with a ranger! Learn more about dune life and just how unique the park really is. Take in the view. It will be a lasting memory.

title: Introduction to Focus Groups
description:
This course will be offered over two mornings (2/16/2026 and 2/18/2026 from 10am – 2pm) via Zoom only.

Focus groups are commonly used to capture rich information about attitudes and beliefs. This class will prepare prospective students to organize and moderate focus groups. Students will learn the most appropriate uses of focus groups, how to segment and recruit audiences, how to develop a moderator’s guide, and how to moderate focus groups. The class will be supplemented with real-life examples and hands-on exercises.

Registration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

title: Jointly Modeling the Effects of Evolutionary Processes on Genomic Variation
description:
The Johri lab is interested in better characterizing the shape of the distribution of fitness effects of new mutations in organisms and on understanding how selection on functionally important regions affects genome-wide patterns of variation. Population genomic inference currently does not account for the effects of selection across the genome, which is especially problematic in species with compact genomes (i.e., those with a high density of protein-coding and regulatory regions) where natural selection is pervasive. We develop statistical and computational methods that simultaneously account for the effects of selection jointly with other evolutionary processes to make accurate evolutionary inferences (such as historical changes in population size) using sequence variation from natural populations. As most pathogenic species tend to have highly compact genomes and experience strong bouts of selection and drastic repeated bottlenecks, our methodological advances and recent theoretical efforts will be important to uncovering their population and selective history.

title: Understanding and Improving Garden Soils: A Deeper Look
description:
Healthy plants start with healthy soil, but what is healthy soil, and how can you build it in your own garden? This course will take you below the surface to explore the science and structure that make soils thrive. By delving into the chemistry, the biology and the physics that drive soil health and fertility, you’ll gain the tools you need to cultivate a richer, more resilient garden from the ground up.

In this expanded five-week course, we’ll take a closer look at the essential principles of soil science and how to apply them in practical, gardener-friendly ways. You’ll explore how soils behave — how texture, structure and compaction influence water movement, aeration and root growth — and gain practical tips on sampling and assessing your soil so you know what you’re working with. Along the way, we’ll connect these principles to soil fertility and plant nutrition, exploring how nutrients move through the soil, how fertilizers work and how to feed your plants effectively without overdoing it.

Whether you’re troubleshooting problem areas, establishing new garden beds or simply eager to understand what’s happening beneath your feet, this course will equip you with the knowledge and confidence to build better soils and grow stronger, more resilient plants.

Source: NC State University

title: National Civics Bee - Essay Contest Deadline
description:
NC State is proud to host the Civics Bee in North Carolina. We have regional partners with the Chambers of Commerce in Clayton, Fayetteville, and Roanoke Valley, and the YMCA of the Triangle.  https://spia.chass.ncsu.edu/graduate/mpa/civics-bee/ What is the National Civics Bee?  It's like the Spelling Bee but about civics education. All NC Middle Schoolers are eligible to participate, and students progress from an essay contest to a regional, state and national contests. Student winners are awarded $$ and the winner of the National Bee wins $100,000 for their 529 Education Fund. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oykg52IHtys How to Apply: All Middle School youth in North Carolina are eligible for the Civics Bee Essay Contest. This Essay Application Guide is a step-by-step guide to support the essay writing process. The Essay Portal is open until February 4thhttps://civics.uschamberfoundation.org/student-essay-guide/   EDIT AND UPDATES: Due to weather & school closures, the Essay Contest for the National Civics Bee has been extended until February 17th - Access the Essay Portal & more information about the extension can be found here

 

❓The National Civics Bee is hosted by the US Chamber of Commerce, and NC State is proud to host the state Civics Bee in North Carolina. We have regional partners with the Chambers of Commerce in Clayton, Fayetteville, and Roanoke Valley, and the YMCA of the Triangle. Here's NC State's announcement | Learn more here 

 

Who: All Middle School youth in North Carolina are eligible for the Civics Bee Essay Contest. 

 

What: The National Civics Bee is like the Spelling Bee but about civics education. All NC Middle Schoolers are eligible to participate, and students progress from an essay contest to a regional, state and national contests.

 

How: Middle Schoolers must submit an Essay to enter the Civics Bee. This Essay Application Guide is a step-by-step guide to support the essay writing process. 

 

Where: Essays should be submitted through this Portal.

 

When: Middle Schoolers should submit their essay by February 17, 2026. The Essay Portal will close by February 17th 11:59pm Hawaii Standard Time / 3:59 am on February 18th in NC!

 

🏆The Prizes: Student winners are awarded $$ and the winner of the National Bee wins $100,000 for their 529 Education Fund. Our North Carolina state winner will win $1000, and 2nd and 3rd place win prizes too!  

 

➡️ Resources for you: Educator Toolkit

➡️ More about the Civics Bee in North Carolina

 

--

NCCivicsBee@ncsu.edu

More about the Civics Bee at NC State

title: Africa to Carolina Exhibit at Somerset Place
description:
February 1st marks the start of #BlackHistoryMonth! To commemorate the African diaspora and the impact Black culture has made on United States history, we will re-open our Africa to Carolina exhibit to the public. The Africa to Carolina initiative serves to identify, acknowledge, and mark each site in the state where enslaved Africans disembarked directly from the African Continent. In our self-guided exhibit, visitors can learn about the experiences of enslaved Africans who survived the Atlantic slave trade to North Carolina. Stop by the visitor center for free admission into the exhibit.

title: Making an Impact with Data Viz
description:
Collecting data is now easier than it has ever been. But, as data becomes more prolific, datasets become larger and more complex. How do we find meaningful patterns in our data? How can we communicate those patterns to others? Data visualization allows us to make sense of today’s ever evolving information landscape.

 

This workshop will introduce the history and basic principles of data visualization. Learn about best practices and resources for making an impact with your data through compelling charts, graphs, and maps. At the end of the short course, participants will be able to:

Understand the preattentive process and how it affects visual perceptionCritically evaluate the accuracy and quality of visualizations they encounter in their daily livesImplement best practices when creating their own visualizations 

This workshop is offered by University Libraries and will be led by librarian Lorin Bruckner.

 

This workshop is being offered remotely via Zoom only. Registrants will receive a Zoom link; those on the waitlist will not receive a Zoom link unless they are bumped up to a registered spot. In particular, this presentation will focus on the Biosketch and Current and Pending (Other) Support forms, which will need to be completed using the SciENcv tool. It will include demonstrations of SciENcv as well as ORCID iD creation and linking steps. The presentation aims to prepare researchers for the new NIH requirements by providing detailed instructions and resources to ensure compliance.

title: Create A Culture of Resilience Webinar
description:
Across the country, colleges and universities are grappling with a difficult reality: Students are arriving on campus with fewer coping skills, less resilience and greater struggles with emotional regulation. Many have not yet learned how to manage disappointment or move through temporary setbacks. This leaves staff and faculty on the front lines, shouldering the emotional weight — often without the tools they need to protect their own well-being.

Join the Office of Equal Opportunity on Tuesday, Feb. 17, to learn how Pepperdine University's innovative Resilience-Informed Skills Education (RISE) program was developed and implemented. You'll hear from expert presenters about RISE, a proactive, research-informed, skill-building program that is transforming student well-being and empowering staff. You'll leave this webinar with the knowledge and skills necessary to create meaningful, sustainable change at NC State.

The expert presenters are listed below.

Connie Horton is the vice chancellor and executive director of the RISE Institute at Pepperdine, where she leads initiatives to expand resilience education and well-being efforts across the university and beyond.Stacey Lee Gobir is the director of the RISE program.

title: CEE Seminar - From Cavity Expansion to Clinical Diagnosis
description:
The mechanical properties of biological tissues change over time and with disease progression. Quantifying these mechanical properties can thus be instrumental for medical diagnosis and for evaluation of tissue viability for transplant. However, it is exceptionally challenging to mechanically characterize soft and biological materials using conventional testing methods, especially in-vivo. In recent years, volume controlled cavity expansion (VCCE) has emerged as a powerful needle-based method for quantifying the nonlinear properties of soft materials in-situ. In this talk, after briefly revisiting the fundamentals of VCCE, I will describe the translation of VCCE into Digital Palpation (DP); a minimally invasive diagnostic tool offering a quantitative alternative to a clinician's sense of touch. I will describe the application of DP for testing in human tissue and will focus on an ex-vivo study of 35 tests in freshly resected human thyroid nodules. I will show how data from this rapid and minimally invasive mechanical test enables separation between benign and malignant nodules of this highly prevalent cancer and can even hint at resolving oncocytic and follicular sub-types that routinely confound existing diagnosis methods. At present, up to one third of thyroid nodules cannot be decisively classified, leading to avoidable surgical removal of the thyroid gland. We hope that these results can, in the future, help to reduce the large fraction of thyroidectomies (40-70%) that ultimately prove benign and thus avoidable; potentially relieving patients from the potential life-long implications of surgical complications and hormone replacement, and paving the way for the diagnosis of additional diseases.

description: REGISTRATION: Click Here Registration closes 24 hours before event start. If your availability changes please email asist@duke.edu to update your registration. The Duke Office of Scientific Integrity is partnering with Trinity College to expand our offerings of interactive Responsible Conduct of Research (RCR) trainings tailored for Duke researchers in the humanities, arts, and interpretative social sciences! We've heard the feedback that the RCR training programs - which are required for all research-active Duke faculty and staff - have not been well-matched to research in the humanities. So, we're working with Trinity leadership to help make those programs more useful for our faculty, and we want to engage the humanities research community in that process. As a first pilot step, we will host RCR training events that will both fulfill the 200-level RCR requirement for attendees and help shape the future of RCR training in the humanities and related disciplines. The initial events will be limited to senior (e.g., associate, full, emeritus) faculty who work in any area of the humanities, arts, and/or interpretive social sciences. We believe that your perspective can help us shape the development of more relevant and effective research training programs. Contact: ASIST asist@duke.edu Source: Duke University

title: Triangle Nuclear Theory Colloquium - Pion Mass Dependence in Chiral EFT and the QCD Axion
description:
QCD and effective field theory together put low energy nuclear physics on solid theoretical footing to calculate observables with some confidence, but open questions remain.  Two related questions are why QCD seems not to violate CP and how the properties of nuclear matter depend on the light quark masses (or equivalently the pion mass).  The classic solution to the former problem is to invoke a new light field, the QCD axion, a well-motivated dark matter candidate which a diverse experimental campaign is currently searching for.  Neutron stars can also probe the QCD axion parameter space if nuclear matter becomes more attractive at reduced pion mass via the formation of an axion condensate.  Answering the question of whether an axion with a mass at the QCD prediction could condense in neutron stars hinges on a number of fundamental questions in nuclear physics, including the properties of three nucleon forces, the importance of light resonances neglected in chiral EFT, fine tuning in s-wave scattering, and at what density chiral symmetry restoration occurs in cold nuclear matter.  In this talk, I will present our current research on pion mass dependence in chiral EFT, possible observable signatures in neutron stars, and what the study of pion mass dependence can teach us about extant theoretical problems in low energy nuclear physics.

title: Free Talk: Embodying Social Justice Values in Documentary Filmmaking through Reflection
description:
Join us for a free talk and reception with Natalie Bullock Brown, director of the Documentary Accountability Working Group (DAWG) and a leading advocate for ethics‑driven, justice‑centered nonfiction storytelling.

Brown will share how her path was shaped by the liberatory visions of Marlon Riggs, bell hooks, and Angela Y. Davis, and how those influences led to the creation of DAWG's collaborative, care-centered approach to documentary ethics. Drawing from DAWG's framework From Reflection to Release, she will discuss why accountable filmmaking must center participants, reject auteur myths, and embrace justice, dignity, and collective practice, principles that guided the development of the DAWG Syllabus and continue to anchor her work.

All are welcome - students, scholars, community members and anyone interested in how documentary storytelling supports movements for justice. Refreshments will be served following the talk.

About the Speaker:

Natalie Bullock Brown is the director and co‑founder of the Documentary Accountability Working Group (DAWG), established in 2020 to transform nonfiction filmmaking through values‑based and community‑centered methodologies. DAWG's ethical framework and companion syllabus have become widely used tools across the documentary field. Natalie is also a documentary producer and emerging director, a 2023 Harvard Kennedy School Shorenstein Center Documentary Film Fellow, and a 2023 DOC NYC New Leaders cohort member, with decades of experience in media, education, and justice‑oriented storytelling.

Continuing Education Course Opportunity:

This free talk is offered through the Duke Center for Documentary Studies Continuing Education Program. Brown will teach a Learn more here: https://rsvp.duke.edu/event/89e057b7-ee73-4b90-b3a1-b15d949ac137/summary

description:

The are Cary Jaycees, your local crew of young professionals who know how to blend community service with a whole lot of fun. If you’ve ever wanted to meet awesome people, make a real impact, or build your leadership skills while doing some seriously cool projects, this is your group.

The Jaycees are always looking for new members, so if you’ve been thinking about getting more involved in Cary and beyond, consider this your sign. We meet on the third Tuesday of every month at Gamers Geekery and Tavern at 6:30 PM and would love for you to stop by, say hello, and see what they’re all about. We cover the game fee for anyone playing with us and will also have appetizers to share.

title: TriDIYBio meeting
description:

title: Celebrating Black History Month: Quilts and Baskets
location: Falls Lake State Recreation Area - Visitor Center

This will be an interactive drop-in arts and crafts event. Feel free to take a craft sheet home with you while supplies last. Join us in celebrating part of American history!

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: CaSA Conversations: Sustainable Innovation
description:
Join NC State's Climate and Sustainability Academy (CaSA) for the first event in our CaSA Conversations series. We will hear from some of NC State’s student and professional leaders in sustainable innovation. The panelists are:

Lisa Chang, director of Technology Entrepreneurship and Commercialization Reid Barnett, founder of Ceretune and a Ph.D. candidate in the Wilson College of TextilesEllie Player, an NC State undergrad and winner of the 2026 NC State Sustainability Make-A-ThonEnjoy coffee, breakfast and networking from 8:45 to 9 a.m., followed by the panel discussion.  This event is free to attend, but registration is required.

Source: NC State University

title: Africa to Carolina Exhibit at Somerset Place
description:
February 1st marks the start of #BlackHistoryMonth! To commemorate the African diaspora and the impact Black culture has made on United States history, we will re-open our Africa to Carolina exhibit to the public. The Africa to Carolina initiative serves to identify, acknowledge, and mark each site in the state where enslaved Africans disembarked directly from the African Continent. In our self-guided exhibit, visitors can learn about the experiences of enslaved Africans who survived the Atlantic slave trade to North Carolina. Stop by the visitor center for free admission into the exhibit.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Your Future as an International Graduate Student
description:
The Graduate School will host an information session to help international graduate students get acclimated to NC State. Join our international admissions manager and an international graduate student for a live conversation about the NC State experience. The session will include a Q&A period and discussions about the following:

The move to Raleigh: Housing, transportation and settling into the Research TriangleNext steps: A clear timeline for your enrollment and arrivalThe student perspective: What it’s really like to be a graduate student at NC State

title: Introduction to Focus Groups (offered by NC TraCS)
description:
This interactive online workshop will provide an introduction to focus groups, a data collection method used in qualitative research. Topics covered will include focus group methodology, considerations for planning a focus group, development of focus group discussion guides, focus group facilitation skills, and tips for conducting virtual focus groups. Attendees will also observe or participate in a mini "mock" virtual focus group session.

 

This event may be recorded. Materials such as slides or handouts will be shared with documented attendees only.

 

Presenters:
MaryBeth Grewe, MPH
Program Manager, Qualitative Research Service
Research Specialist, Patient and Community Engagement in Research (PaCER) Program

 

Simone Frank, MPH
Senior Project Manager, Patient and Community Engagement in Research (PaCER) Program
Research Specialist, Qualitative Research Service

 Register

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt
description:
The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt showcases how the biblical story of heroic Queen Esther, depicted by Rembrandt and his contemporaries in art and popular culture, expressed ideas of political and religious freedom during the Dutch Golden Age. Charting this history through objects and artworks, The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt provides an original perspective on one of the most studied periods of Dutch prosperity.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Wilderness Workout
description:
Sticking with that resolution to shrink the waistline? This full body workout mimicking animal movements can help. The first 5-10 minutes will focus on stretching and warming up our muscle groups. This will be followed by 10 minutes of body movement practice leading into a 20-minute circuit of those learned movements, known as an AMRAP (as many rounds/reps as possible). We’ll end with a 10-minute cool down. This will be physically challenging, but movements can be modified. Meet in the open lawn near the Visitor’s Center. Program is weather dependent.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Introduction to Focus Groups
description:
This course will be offered over two mornings (2/16/2026 and 2/18/2026 from 10am – 2pm) via Zoom only.

Focus groups are commonly used to capture rich information about attitudes and beliefs. This class will prepare prospective students to organize and moderate focus groups. Students will learn the most appropriate uses of focus groups, how to segment and recruit audiences, how to develop a moderator’s guide, and how to moderate focus groups. The class will be supplemented with real-life examples and hands-on exercises.

Registration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: ReAdOn: Research Administrator Onboarding
description:
ReAdOn provides an introductory overview of the full research administration lifecycle, from proposal development to award closeout, and incorporates topics in ethics, compliance and research security. The series consists of 4 weekly virtual sessions: 

Wed, Feb 4, 11:30am-2:00pm, Session 1: Program Overview and Proposals (note: this session is 30 minutes longer) Wed, Feb 11, 11:30am-1:30pm, Session 2: Ethics, Compliance, and Security in Proposals and Awards Wed, Feb 18, 11:30am-1:30pm, Session 3: Award Execution and Post-Award Actions Wed, Feb 25, 11:30am-1:30pm, Session 4: Award and Project Management through Closeout  

While the series is especially beneficial for new research administrators, anyone interested in gaining a deeper understanding of the research administration landscape at UNC-CH is encouraged to attend. The agenda is available at https://go.unc.edu/ReAdOn-2026-Agenda

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Building Brilliance
description:
Join Prevention Services and the College of Sciences for a strengths-based, supportive lunch-and-learn designed to empower neurodivergent students in personal development and college success. The group’s focus is on three core areas: building strong social and interpersonal skills, such as handling conflict, setting boundaries and self-advocacy. The group meets over three sessions, twice each semester. Lunch will be provided. The sessions are below.

Session OneFeb. 18, noon to 1 p.m., Bureau of Mines, Room 201April 1, noon to 1 p.m., Campus Health, Room 2301Session TwoFeb. 25, noon to 1 p.m., Campus Health, Room 2301April 8, noon to 1 p.m., Cox Hall, Room  306Session ThreeMarch 4, noon to 1 p.m., Bureau of Mines, Room 201April 15, noon to 1 p.m., Bureau of Mines, Room 201

title: Master of Management, Risk and Analytics Information Session
description:
Please attend an information session to learn about the Master of Management, Risk and Analytics program. During the virtual session, program staff will discuss the growing need for risk management professionals in all industries, career prospects in those industries and the program’s admissions process and curriculum. An MRA student will discuss their experience in the program. We’ll have plenty of time for you to ask questions. We look forward to chatting with you.

title: Coping With Compassion Stress
description:
There is a certain type of person who not only accepts the challenges of working in a high stress emotional environment but also excels despite the demands. Whether they are working with individuals who are experiencing trauma, grief, loss, illness or other stressful concerns the people whose role it is to help others in distress are often perceived as dedicated, hardworking, selfless and compassionate. Nevertheless, it is often those whose mission it is to help others who may be at increased risk of neglecting their own self-care. This training will raise awareness of the need to maintain appropriate self-care despite the demands of work and/or the pressures of home life. The course will offer specific tips to encourage self-care in order to maintain high level of functioning both personally and professionally.

 

Workshop Objectives:

At the end of this workshop, you will be able to:
• Describe how helping others in need can lead to potential self-neglect
• Understand the importance of self-care in working with an emotionally stressed population
• Understand how to perform a self-care assessment
• Describe to best strategies for implementing self-care strategies
• Identify resources available for continued self-care success

 

Click on Carolina Talent registration link and select the “Request” button to automatically enroll.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Free Yoga
location: Partners I – NC State University, Suite 2580
description:
Take a break from your day and enjoy a free yoga class on Centennial Campus. Classes are held every weekday, except when the university is closed, from 12:15 to 1:05 p.m. The classes are open to everyone, and registration is not required. Please bring your own mat.

title: Python Crash Courses: Intro to Data
description:

This workshop is offered by University Libraries and will be led by librarians Philip McDaniel, Lorin Bruckner, Michele Hayslett, Matt Jansen, and Rolando Rodriguez along with Mark Reed from ITS Research Computing. Contact Matt Jansen with any questions.

 

This workshop is being offered remotely via Zoom only. Registrants will receive a Zoom link; those on the waitlist will not receive a Zoom link unless they are bumped up to a registered spot. After the workshop, registrants and those on the waitlist will receive a link to the workshop recording. You can register on the University Libraries calendar: https://calendar.lib.unc.edu/event/16022052

title: Science Detectives: Nature is Beautiful

description:

location: Nature Research Center, 121 West Jones Street, Raleigh, NC, 27601, United States
description:

title: Ranger Workshop - Grandfather Mountain History & Ecology
description:
What makes Grandfather Mountain State Park so special? Join us for a PowerPoint presentation explaining how Grandfather Mountain State Park was created, and why we are so fortunate to be an International Biosphere Reserve. Take a journey through each of our 16 distinct natural communities, and some of the 73 rare and endangered species that call this mountain home. This program will be held at the Seven Devils Community Center as part of their Ranger Workshop Series.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Lunch And Learn - AI Assistants, Agents, Orchestration
description:
Research Triangle DevOps
This session kicks off a three-part lunch-and-learn webinar series on DevOps, AI, and agents, focused on practical use and guardrails.

Everyone’s talking about AI “agents”, but most people mean very different things. In this first session, we slow the hype down to unpack what assistants, agents, and orchestration actually are, why DevOps teams are suddenly prime territory for experimentation, and where things go sideways when speed outruns review, security, and operational reality.

We will explore agentic AI as a common vocabulary, a few durable mental models, and a grounded look at where real leverage exists today, especially if you already live in CI/CD and automation. You will leave with a clearer way to distinguish assistants, agents, and orchestration, and an understanding of where AI fits into organizations.

Source: Meetup: Triangle DevOps

title: Lunchtime Discovery: Opening Doors to Research: Engaging and Empowering Undergraduates
location: Nature Research Center, 121 West Jones Street, Raleigh, NC, 27601, United States
description:

Dr. Angela Allen’s work emphasizes applying foundational scientific principles to address real-world environmental challenges that directly affect communities. Through the Environmental Resources Water Training Program, she mentors and guides students in collaborations with colleagues and community partners in research centered on community engagement. Join us to learn how these experiential learning opportunities extend beyond the classroom and encourage students to engage with complex environmental issues, preparing them to be the next generation of environmental stewards. 
Dr. Angela Allen, Assistant Teaching Professor, Director of Environmental Technology and Management and Co-Director of Environmental Sciences, North Carolina State University, Department of Forestry and Environmental Resources 

Live Presentation hosted by NC Museum of Natural Sciences’ SECU Daily Planet Curator Chris Smith and the NC Department of Environmental Quality Office of Environmental Education and Public Affairs staff. ﻿﻿

February 18

title: AI Series: Automating Daily Tasks & Workflows
description:
If you're doing the same task over and over... it's time to automate it. Join Bill Bowser of StoredTech for a hands-on session built for real businesses with real workloads. This isn't theory. It's practical automation you can put in place immediately. Stop manualy sending follow-ups, chasing emails, or re-entering hte same information in three different places. Bill will walk you thorugh how simple automation tools and AI assistants can: -Handle routine admin tasks -Reduce human error -Creat seamless workflows -Free up hours every single week No advanced tech background required. Just a willingness to stop wasting time.

Source: Wake Forest Chamber of Commerce

title: Feb 18 - Feedback-Driven Annotation Pipelines for End-to-End ML Workflows
description:
Raleigh AI, Machine Learning and Computer Vision Meetup
In this technical workshop, we’ll show how to build a feedback-driven annotation pipeline for perception models using **[FiftyOne](https://docs.voxel51.com/index.html)**. We’ll explore real model failures and data gaps, and turn them into focused annotation tasks that then route through a repeatable workflow for labeling and QA. The result is an end-to-end pipeline keeping annotators, tools, and models aligned and closing the loop from annotation, curation, back to model training and evaluation.

**Time and Location**

Feb 18, 2026
10 - 11 AM PST
Online. **[Register for the Zoom!](https://link.voxel51.com/26-0218-annotation-meetup)**

**What you'll learn**

* **Techniques for labeling the data that matters the most** for annotation time and cost savings
* **Structure human-in-the-loop workflows** for finding and fixing model errors, data gaps, and targeted relabeling instead of bulk labeling
* **Combine auto-labeling and human review** in a single, feedback-driven pipeline for perception models
* **Use label schemas and metadata as “data contracts”** to enforce consistency between annotators, models, and tools, especially for multimodal data
* **Detect and manage schema drift** and tie schema versions to dataset and model versions for reproducibility
* **QA and review steps** that surface label issues early and tie changes back to model behavior
* **An annotation architecture** that can accommodate new perception tasks and feedback signals without rebuilding your entire data stack

Source: Meetup: Raleigh AI, ML & Computer Vision
source: Meetup: Raleigh AI, ML & Computer Vision

title: Four Signs Your Data Is (Actually) Ready for AI
description:
Data Science Raleigh
Many enterprises believe they’re ready for AI once models are selected, platforms are deployed, and pilots are underway. But in practice, AI initiatives often stall before reaching production—or they underperform once they do. The root cause? The data isn’t actually ready.

In this thought-leadership session, Naveen Punjabi from Google Cloud and Jake Bengtson from Striim unpack four critical signs that your data foundation can actually support AI at scale. Drawing from real-world customer patterns, we’ll explore why centralized data isn’t enough, how invisible data errors derail AI outcomes, and why stale data threatens use cases like RAG and AI agents.

What we'll cover:

* What Google Cloud is seeing across enterprise AI adoption—and where data readiness tends to break down
* Four practical indicators your data is ready for trustworthy, production-grade AI
* Why validation and accuracy matter before any models get involved
* How real-time pipelines give AI access to operational truth
* How Google Cloud and Striim help enterprises move from AI experimentation to enterprise impact

This session is built for data, analytics, and AI leaders ready to move beyond AI experimentation—and build foundations that truly support scale.

**What You'll Learn:**

1️⃣ **Spot the Warning Signs:** Know when your data might silently sabotage your AI initiatives.

2️⃣ **Go Beyond Centralization:** Why a data lake isn’t the same as a data strategy.

3️⃣ **Enable Live AI:** How real-time pipelines can unlock true operational intelligence.

4️⃣ **Validate Early, Scale Confidently:** Why data quality must be addressed before model deployment.

5️⃣**Learn from the Field:** What Google Cloud and Striim have seen across real enterprise AI journeys.

**[Register here](https://hubs.ly/Q0417jxY0)**

Source: Meetup: Data Science Raleigh

title: AI for Smarter Reading
description:
This presentation will explore how AI can help you quickly make sense of complex information by simplifying emails, PDFs, reports, and articles into what truly matters. Participants will learn how to extract key insights, identify risks and next steps, recognize potential bias, and practice these skills through a guided exercise that turns a real document into a clear, actionable summary.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Designing AI-Assisted Qualitative Research Worklows with MAXQDA
description:
This interactive, hands-on workshop will introduce participants to a research design framework for considering the use of generative AI in qualitative research designs and workflows (Paulus & Lester, 2024).
We will start by acknowledging inherent risks and ethical dilemmas posed by the development of large language models and how generative AI is challenging the essence of what it means to do qualitative work (Paulus & Marone, 2025; Paulus, Lester & Davis, 2025). We will learn how to distinguish between methodological strategies and technological tactics, i.e. why researchers must first know how they want to work with their data before choosing the best tools to do so. We will then discuss the current ‘state of play’ regarding the various genres of AI-assist technologies available to qualitative researchers and how to select the most appropriate platform. We will then design and implement an “AI-assisted workflow” for managing and analyzing data using MAXQDA. Finally, we will discuss best practices for how to report the use of AI in research studies (Lester & Paulus, forthcoming) and how to reflexively consider the consequences of doing so.
Sample interview data will be used for the practice exercises with discussion around the use of other types of qualitative data. Workshop time will alternate between short lectures and demonstrations, small group discussions, practical hands-on activities, and application of principles learned to the participants’ own research studies and data.

Registration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: PSSA 2:  Supporting Student Survivors of IPV
description:
Supporting Student Survivors of Interpersonal Violence is the second workshop in the Pack Survivor Support Alliance, or PSSA, series offered by the Women's Center. Faculty and staff on a college campus play an integral role in the healing and recovery of college-age student survivors of IPV. This workshop will provide an overview of some of the warning signs and trauma symptoms of IPV and the range of ways IPV can impact the student experience. Participants will practice how to best respond to student disclosures of IPV, successfully connect students to campus resources and provide student survivors with ongoing support.

Source: NC State University

title: ERSP: Birds of Eno River State Park
location: Fews Ford Access Visitor Center, 6101 Cole Mill Road, Durham NC 27705
description:
Eno River State Park & Occoneechee Mountain State Natural Area programs are free but have limited space.  
Call or email to sign up!  
(984) 250-1370 | eno.river@ncparks.gov 

Join a Park Technician to learn more about the birds of Eno River State Park. We will begin with a short lesson at the Visitor Center, followed by a 2-mile hike around Fews Ford. We will identify species based on their calls, appearance, behavior, and habitat. All skill levels are welcome to join! Source: Eno River Association

title: Volunteer Stewardship Workday: Trail Work at the Confluence Natural Area
location: Confluence Natural Area, 4214 Highland Farm Rd, Hillsborough, NC 27278, USA
description:
Join us to work on trail repairs and improvements at the Confluence!

RSVP here. Source: Eno River Association

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Soundside Loop Nature Trail Hike
location: Meet at the pavilion beside park visitor center.
description:
Get out and explore with Ranger Austin a one mile loop hike along the Soundside Nature Trail.  Learn more about the environment found at the base of the dunes, including the Roanoke Sound.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt
description:
The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt showcases how the biblical story of heroic Queen Esther, depicted by Rembrandt and his contemporaries in art and popular culture, expressed ideas of political and religious freedom during the Dutch Golden Age. Charting this history through objects and artworks, The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt provides an original perspective on one of the most studied periods of Dutch prosperity.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: College of Design Career Expo
description:
For Employers:

Looking to connect with soon-to-be design graduates? Register now for the College of Design Career Expo to showcase your company and engage with a diverse pool of emerging talent. With about 300 students in attendance, this event offers a dynamic platform for employers to promote their brand and connect with students pursuing degrees in Architecture, Art + Design, Graphic & Experience Design, Industrial Design, and Landscape Architecture & Environmental Planning. Learn more and register here. 

For Students: 

Stop by to meet employers, introduce yourself, and learn about their opportunities. Ask questions, express your interest, and request a business card to follow up afterward. Be sure to bring copies of your resume! Typically, over 250 students and alumni attend. Participation is free for all students and alumni.

Source: NC State University

title: Science for All Summit
location: Friday Conference Center, 100 Friday Center Dr, Chapel Hill, NC, 27517, United States
description:
Turn Motivation into Action



Are you a student, educator, or other change agent? The fourth annual Science for All Summit returns this year on February 19 and 20! Produced by Morehead Planetarium and Science Center, this two-day Summit offers engaging conversations, workshops, and sessions focused on access and opportunity in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). 





At the Summit, we will provide opportunities to share new research findings, exchange resources, discuss strategies, and demonstrate effective practices and interventions. The 2026 program will include keynote addresses by Dr. Connie Locklear, Dr. Jessica Hernandez, and Dr. Sarina Saturn.  




Learn more about the Summit

Source: Morehead Planetarium & Science Center

title: Using AI to Create and Edit Images
description:
How can I get an ex-boyfriend out of a picture? How do you create images from text? This session looks at the various tools available, especially those that are part of the Adobe Creative Cloud, to help you create sensational images. NOTE: Participants are encouraged to have the latest version of the Adobe Creative Cloud. It is free for students. Visit https://adobe.unc.edu for more information. We will cover other text to image apps in this session.

 

This workshop is offered by the University Libraries and will be led by librarian Lynn Eades

 

This workshop is being offered remotely via Zoom only. You can register at the library calendar. Registrants will receive a Zoom link; those on the waitlist will not receive a Zoom link unless they are bumped up to a registered spot.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Marching toward Revolution: the Year-Long Buildup to the Battle of Moores Creek Bridge
description:
The Battle of Moores Creek Bridge was the first Revolutionary skirmish in North Carolina, February 27, 1776. Though a minor conflict, the Patriot victory bolstered local support for American independence and curtailed Loyalist recruitment efforts across the South. Join Archivists Alison Thurman, Josh Hager, and Katie Crickmore as they discuss North Carolina's advance toward the Revolution, including details about the Committees of Safety, Josiah Martin’s flight, and the Battle of Moores Creek Bridge itself.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

NC State University librarians will serve as hosts of the competition, and trivia master extraordinaire Dave Provost is our question maker.

The winning teams will take home a seasonal 3D printed trophy and a free coffee drink, but the real prize might be the friends we make along the way.

title: beginR
description:
This workshop is being offered remotely via Zoom only. Registrants will receive a Zoom link; those on the waitlist will not receive a Zoom link unless they are bumped up to a registered spot. After the workshop, registrants and those on the waitlist will receive a link to the workshop recording.


Learning R on your own? Want some help along the way? beginR is a series of virtual meetings organized by the University Libraries and the Odum Institute that provides support to students, faculty and staff who are learning the R programming language. The first week, the instructors will introduce attendees to R, help them install the software, and share the materials that will be covered in subsequent meetings. In the following weeks, beginR attendees will learn R by following the lessons on the R Open Labs website at their own pace. Each week, staff will be available via Zoom to answer questions, solve problems and provide the solutions to exercises.

 

Please register through our University Libraries calendar to receve the Zoom link: https://calendar.lib.unc.edu/event/15988425. If registration becomes full, recordings will be shared with those on the waitlist as well.

 

beginR is a collaboration between the University Libraries and the Odum Institute. The workshops will be led by librarians Lorin Bruckner and Matt Jansen, and Nuvan Rathnayaka from the Odum Institute.

location: Downtown Raleigh, 11 West Jones Street, Raleigh, NC, 27601, United States
description:
Secrets of the Sea 3D

title: Nature Stories
location: Prairie Ridge, 1671 Gold Star Drive, Raleigh, NC, 27607, United States
description:
Join us as we open your eyes to the wonderful world of nature through a family-friendly, nature-filled storytime. We’ll begin by sharing a story in the Nature PlaySpace Amphitheater at 10:30am, and will then head to other areas of Prairie Ridge as we explore natural themes from each day’s stories in a hands-on, interactive manner. 
This is a free program beginning at 10:30am. Come dressed for the weather and prepared to take a walk! Most walks will be stroller friendly. Everyone is welcome at the Nature PlaySpace, but it has been designed especially for kids 7 and younger.  Nature Stories books and activities were chosen with this age group in mind. 
Please note that this program occurs at the Museum’s Prairie Ridge Ecostation location in west Raleigh. For more information, contact prairieridge@naturalsciences.org

Join other nature-loving women for a 1.5-hour hike in Johnston Mill Preserve at a moderate pace -- not speedy, not slow, just moderate.  On this hike, you will experience a range of forest types while walking along New Hope Creek, which meanders through the northeast portion of the preserve. 
 Trail Guide Nancy will provide hot drinks at the end of the hike. This is a free event, but preregistration is required. 
 
If registration for this event is full, please fill out the waitlist form here.

title: 3D Movie: T. Rex
location: Downtown Raleigh, 11 West Jones Street, Raleigh, NC, 27601, United States
description:
T. REX 3D
For more than 100 years dinosaurs have inspired and thrilled audiences, commanding blockbuster status in museums and at the box office. But among them towers a king. With leaps in CGI and revolutions in tyrannosaur paleontology over the past 25 years, the time has come to revisit T. rex. 
Explore the interplay between speculation and evidence through famous specimens, landmark discoveries and wild cinematic depictions over the last century. Discover how the process of science refreshes and re-imagines our understanding of this legendary dinosaur. 
Filmmakers worked with top tyrannosaur scientists, a coalition of natural history institutions and pioneering paleo and visual effects artists to create one of the most dazzling and accurate T. rex documentaries ever made. 
BUY TICKETS

title: Polanyi Lecture with Anya Plutynski
description:
Anya Plutynski, historian and philosopher of biology and medicine at Washington University in St. Louis, will discuss "Expertise from the Inside Out: How psychotherapy challenges standard models of expertise" for the Polanyi Lecture.

 

A central concern of much of psychotherapy research, clinical practice and training programs in psychotherapy over the course of the late 20th and early 21st century has been what it means to have "expertise" in the field. When can we say that a psychotherapist is an "expert?"

 

Plutynski will discuss the topic from the vantage point of her research interests in philosophy of biology, history and philosophy of medicine, philosophy of science and biomedical ethics. Her most recent book is Explaining Cancer: Finding Order in Disorder.

 

The Polanyi Lecture series honors the late chemist and philosopher Michael Polanyi by bringing to campus scholars who bridge science and the humanities.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Centennial Campus Running Club: Wolves on the Run
description:
Wolves on the Run is a running and walking club open to all. Join your colleagues and friends for a social run or walk on Centennial Campus. We meet at the dock at Lake Raleigh.

title: K-12 Teachers: Join Us for Teaching the Legacy of Sarah Keys Evans
description:
**Attending teachers will receive a FREE copy of Sarah Keys Evans: The Power of Quiet Courage , written by Amy Nathan with illustrations by Jermaine Powell**

K-12 teachers are invited to join the NC Department of Natural & Cultural Resources (DNCR) for a virtual conversation about a less-known North Carolina trailblazer, Sarah Keys Evans. In 1952, as a young Black Army private returning home to Washington, NC, she refused to give up her seat on an interstate bus stopped in Roanoke Rapids, NC, leading to a landmark case that helped end segregation in interstate travel. Her courageous stand (three years before Rosa Parks) helped pave the way for civil rights.

During the virtual event, will be have a conversation by Amy Nathan, author of DNCR’s new children’s book Sarah Keys Evans: The Power of Quiet Courage, as we explore why Mrs. Evan’s story matters. We’ll also be joined by Christie Norris, Director of Education for DNCR, and Alex Brown, Director of Programs and Audience Engagement for DNCR’s NC Museum of Art - Winston Salem, to explore ways to bring this powerful history, story, and its accompanying art into your classroom.

Teachers who attend for the full-hour event on Feb. 19 will be mailed a FREE copy of the book after the event. An accompanying lesson plan will also be shared. CEUs (.1) are also available upon request for attendees.

Who Should Attend?
Any K-12 teacher (public, private or charter) in North Carolina! While Sarah Keys Evans: The Power of Quiet Courage is written for grades 4 – 5, the book can be utilized in most any grade – and every North Carolina student should know the story of Sarah Keys Evans. The stunning illustrations by Jermaine Powell also provide ample classroom connections for any grade. 

How to Register
Sign-up for free using this short form.

Event Logistics
You will receive a Zoom link in February at the e-mail you provide in your registration. Please do not share the Zoom link and instead share the registration link with others interested in participating. 

Post-event, teachers in attendance (public, private and charter) will be mailed a FREE copy of the book at the mailing address you provide. A school e-mail address must be provided for confirmation of your status as a teacher.

You will be able to ask questions via chat during the event.

Sponsors & Additional Resources
This event is provided by the North Carolina Department of Natural and Cultural Resources' Office of K-12 Education. Through our Learning Happens Here initiative, DNCR provides high-quality K–12 programming that supports educators and expands access to meaningful learning experiences for students across the state. Learn more at Learning Happens Here | NC DNCR.

Source: NC Cultural Resources
