title: An Evening with NC Poet Laureate Jaki Shelton Green
description:
The Crafts Center and the Gregg Museum of Art & Design are honored to host Jaki Shelton Green for a panel discussion followed by a Q&A in conjunction with the exhibition WORDS = POWER. Green will have a book signing that will include various publications and CDs for sale.

Green is the first African American and third woman to serve as the North Carolina poet laureate. When former Gov. Roy Cooper appointed her in 2018, he stated that “Jaki Shelton Green brings a deep appreciation of our state’s diverse communities to her role as an ambassador of North Carolina literature. Jaki’s appointment is a wonderful new chapter in North Carolina’s rich literary history.”

ASL interpreters and CART captions will be available. For additional accommodation requests, please contact Tamara Velasco at tgvelasc@ncsu.edu by February 5. We will do our best to honor requests made after this deadline. 

This event is free, but registration is required.

Source: NC State University

title: GradGather
description:
Join the LGBTQ Pride Center for the center's graduate student social. Come meet fellow grad students and enjoy free food, board games, coloring and good vibes. Whether you’re looking to relax, make new friends or just take a break from the grind, this is the perfect space to unwind and connect.

Source: NC State University

title: GradGather PowerPoint Social
description:
Join the LGBTQ Pride Center for our graduate student PowerPoint Night social. Come meet fellow grad students and enjoy free dinner, niche knowledge and good vibes. Whether you’re looking to relax, make new friends or just take a break from the grind, this is the perfect event to unwind and connect. We encourage you to bring a roughly five-minute slide presentation on any work-appropriate, nonpolitical topic or to just join the conversation that ensues. All students are welcome to attend.

Source: NC State University

title: Mentorship Meetup
description:
Are you an NC State student with a business idea, curious about exploring mentorship at NC State or looking to build a support network? The Entrepreneurship Mentorship Program is for you.

NC State Entrepreneurship and the eClinic host mentorship meetups to help student entrepreneurs connect with mentors from a wide range of industries. During the meetups, you can discuss your ideas, ask for help, meet fellow students and potential co-founders and pick our mentors' brains. In addition, the mentorship program has a request portal that students can use to ask for introductions to industry and entrepreneurial experts.

The meetups are open to all students. Students who have requested mentorship in the last two semesters will receive invitations to the meetups.

Raleigh Founded — North Street, 509 West North St., Suite 224, in Raleigh, will host the Feb. 19 meetup. To attend, please register.

Source: NC State University

title: Political Science Club: Conspiracy Theories
description:
Join the Political Science Club to discuss conspiracy theories. We'll talk about theories people believe to be plausible, ridiculous and interesting. All students are welcome to attend. Bring your friends.

title: Transfer Student Support: Let's Hear About Your First Month
description:
The College of Humanities and Social Sciences' Advocates Program invites new transfer students to attend a webinar to discuss the highs and lows of their first month at NC State. Whether you are a new transfer student looking to connect or a transfer student who has navigated the challenges of adjusting to life at NC State, you are welcome to come and share.

Source: NC State University

title: Global Film Series: Boxcutter
location: James B. Hunt Jr. Library, Auditorium
description:
The NC State University Libraries and the Office of Global Engagement invite the NC State community to come see a screening of Boxcutter. The film is about Rome, an aspiring Toronto rapper with talent but is crippled by insecurity. After his album's only copy is stolen just hours before he can meet megastar producer Richie Hill, Rome and his friend Jenaya race across the city to reconstruct the record and seize his one shot. Set against Toronto's vibrant music scene, the film "finds its strength in those within the community who believe in you when you might not always believe in yourself," according to Cinema Axis. 

NC State librarians Greg Tourino, Alex Valencia and Gabriel Graña will introduce the film. 

The film screening is part of the Global Film Series, a collaboration between the Libraries and the Office of Global Engagement. 

The film's runtime is one hour and 34 minutes.

Source: NC State University

title: American Revolution Lecture Series: Rick Atkinson
location: Department of Natural and Cultural Resources
description:
Celebrate the 250th anniversary of the beginning of the American Revolution.

Join us as we welcome Rick Atkinson, author of The Fate of the Day: The War for America, Fort Ticonderoga to Charleston, 1777–1780, to speak about the middle years of the Revolution.

Drawing from his latest book, Atkinson explores various historical figures, his research process, and the significance of the American Revolution as we approach the 250th anniversary of American independence.

Speaker bio:

Rick Atkinson is the New York Times bestselling author of seven previous works of history, including The Long Gray Line, the Liberation Trilogy, and The British Are Coming, the first volume of the Revolution Trilogy. He has won numerous awards, including Pulitzer Prizes for history and journalism. His latest book is The Fate of the Day.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

For more than 100 years dinosaurs have inspired and thrilled audiences, commanding blockbuster status in museums and at the box office. But among them towers a king. With leaps in CGI and revolutions in tyrannosaur paleontology over the past 25 years, the time has come to revisit T. rex. 
Explore the interplay between speculation and evidence through famous specimens, landmark discoveries and wild cinematic depictions over the last century. Discover how the process of science refreshes and re-imagines our understanding of this legendary dinosaur. 
Filmmakers worked with top tyrannosaur scientists, a coalition of natural history institutions and pioneering paleo and visual effects artists to create one of the most dazzling and accurate T. rex documentaries ever made. 
BUY TICKETS

title: Sinking Ship Productions’ The 7th Voyage of Egon Tichy
description:
Trapped in a time loop, space traveler Egon Tichy faces his own worst enemy: himself. And he’s multiplying. In this inventive fusion of live performance and digital video sleight-of-hand, a single actor builds a cinematic sci-fi comedy in real time, transforming an 8x4 white box into a cosmic wonderland.

The acclaimed physical theater company Sinking Ship Productions and the Obie Award-winning Theater in Quarantine have reimagined their streaming hit, The 7th Voyage of Egon Tichy, as a mind-bending in-person experience — a slapstick adventure and poignant meditation on the tug-of-war between the versions of ourselves we can never escape.

The 7th Voyage of Egon Tichy contains mild adult language and situations but is appropriate for audiences of all ages.

Source: NC State University

February 13th- The Land Remembers 
February 20th- Community Institutions 
February 27th- Navigating Freedom 
What is Telling the Full Story: The Alliance for Historic Hillsborough’s Telling the Full Story program seeks to uncover and share the diverse, often untold histories of Hillsborough. Through community conversations, interactive maps, and oral histories, this program invites everyone to explore the people, events, and places that have shaped our community, fostering a richer understanding of our shared heritage.

title: Thursday Community Board Game night at Moondog Meadery
description:
Durham Geeks
In conjunction with Moon Dog Meadery, we continue to have our Thursday Night Gaming Night from 7 until they kick us out. It's a bit smaller group than the large Monday night extravaganza, and there are a lot of drop in and independent groups here as well. Restaurants are open on Thursdays, so you can Dash you food right inside, or bring it with you!

Moondog has an extensive and ever-changing collection of games that are usually loaned out for a fee, but on Thursdays (just like on Mondays), they are all free to play. Usually we can find folks to fill in your table or teach you the basics of the games. I've been hosting it for a few months now, and we have had a great time with students returning and bringing in new colleagues, as well as the faithful ones who attended over the summer.

Dogs and outside food both allowed and encouraged. Always free! There is award-winning mead on tap and bottled, as well as an ever-changing collection of beer, cider, THC-infused water, colas and, yes, just plain old water to keep you hydrated on your adventure.

Any questions? Contact us here at Durham Geeks!

title: Science Café: Rhinos, Red Pandas, and Hell Pigs, Oh My!
location: Nature Research Center, 121 West Jones Street, Raleigh, NC, 27601, United States
description:
a glimpse into North Carolina’s terrestrial ecosystems 20 million years ago
Museum paleontologist Sean Moran holds the cast of a single hell pig molar. 
Join us in person or watch the livestream on YouTube. 
Much of North Carolina’s fossil record over the last 100 million years is derived from marine environments, often excluding fossils from terrestrial ecosystems. This talk will explore new fossils collected from Jones County and deposited in the early Miocene, about 20 million years ago, that are beginning to shed light on an unusual land mammal fauna from our state. 
Sean Moran is the Collections Manager of Paleontology at the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences. Though responsible for managing and growing the Museum’s Paleontology Research Collections, from fossil crabs to dinosaurs, ferns to sharks, his research interests mostly relate to the evolution and ecology of terrestrial mammals over the last 34 million years. 
Grab a bite from the Daily Planet Café and join host Chris Smith for our monthly Science Café. Gather with other curious minds at this after-hours event for an informal presentation and conversation about current science topics with guest experts. The Daily Planet Café is open 5–8pm with a full menu during the Science Café.

Source: NC Museum of Natural Sciences

title: Africa to Carolina Exhibit at Somerset Place
description:
February 1st marks the start of #BlackHistoryMonth! To commemorate the African diaspora and the impact Black culture has made on United States history, we will re-open our Africa to Carolina exhibit to the public. The Africa to Carolina initiative serves to identify, acknowledge, and mark each site in the state where enslaved Africans disembarked directly from the African Continent. In our self-guided exhibit, visitors can learn about the experiences of enslaved Africans who survived the Atlantic slave trade to North Carolina. Stop by the visitor center for free admission into the exhibit.

description:

Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

title: The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt
description:
The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt showcases how the biblical story of heroic Queen Esther, depicted by Rembrandt and his contemporaries in art and popular culture, expressed ideas of political and religious freedom during the Dutch Golden Age. Charting this history through objects and artworks, The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt provides an original perspective on one of the most studied periods of Dutch prosperity.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Analyzing Qualitative Data for Applied Contexts
description:
It’s Monday morning and you open your qualitative research project folder. Thousands of pages of text, distributed across 90 in-depth interviews, await. What’s next? This workshop provides a roadmap for conducting an applied thematic analysis, through all major steps in the analytic process. Participants will learn the benefits of writing a qualitative data analysis plan, to ensure that the data collected are analyzed in a way that best informs the research question(s) and fulfills the study’s objectives.

The instructor will demonstrate how to inductively identify themes, transform those themes into codes, and aggregate codes into an evidence-based codebook that is easy to use and that will inform the study’s research question(s). Some time will be spent on the topic of integrating codes and interpreting thematic structure. Basic data reduction techniques will also be presented Hands-on exercises are included for those who wish to practice the concepts learned.

Registration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Writing Up and Publishing Qualitative Research
description:
This workshop covers the various stages involved with writing up and publishing findings from a qualitative research study. Course content is designed for researchers who intend to publish their findings in a peer-reviewed journal, and well as those who are responsible for reviewing qualitative research papers. Topics covered include:
• Developing a publication plan, to ensure smooth workflow
• Choosing the best journal(s) for your research
• Drafting concise, yet informative Abstracts
• Writing the Methods and Results sections for applied qualitative research papers
• Post-submission: dealing with reviews and editors
Ultimately, the workshop is designed increase participants’ chances of manuscript acceptance. Some time will, therefore, be spent on discussing principles of effective scientific writing. Course structure includes lecture, interactive discussion, and hands-on exercises. Registration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: 2026 Buchdahl Lecture
location: Talley Student Union, Piedmont/Mountains Ball Room
description:
The 2026 Buchdahl Lecture will focus on over 300,000 years of human history, using the stories of our ancestors and Indigenous cultures to show how we have survived climate change, war, diseases and countless other challenges. We will explore the story of Egypt's so-called Old Kingdom collapse in 2200 BCE, learning how that time period is a mirror for life today and how societies respond to concurrent crises.  The archaeological site of el Lisht, Egypt's capital from the Middle Kingdom (1800 BCE), will provide a case study for what might be possible following a period of multiple crises. What we will learn is that the imminent societal collapse promoted by countless tech bros and podcasters is simply a lie. Our ancestors nearly became extinct almost a million years ago, and yet, they persisted, evolving into homo sapiens. Our human story is one of survival and hope. A better world is possible, with the road well-lit via evidence from the archaeological evidence and Indigenous wisdom.

Source: NC State University

title: Dungeons & Dragons
description:
Join the Women's Center for Dungeons & Dragons. Whether you're a seasoned pro or new to the game, join us to explore magical realms, craft powerful characters and tell epic stories. Together, we'll roll the dice and create unforgettable adventures in a supportive and empowering environment. Let's dive in and shape our destinies.

title: How To Get Started in Research Workshop
description:
Are you interested in research opportunities as an undergraduate student? This is a free, walk-in event – no RSVP required.

title: 3D Movie: T. Rex
location: Downtown Raleigh, 11 West Jones Street, Raleigh, NC, 27601, United States
description:
T. REX 3D
For more than 100 years dinosaurs have inspired and thrilled audiences, commanding blockbuster status in museums and at the box office. But among them towers a king. With leaps in CGI and revolutions in tyrannosaur paleontology over the past 25 years, the time has come to revisit T. rex. 
Explore the interplay between speculation and evidence through famous specimens, landmark discoveries and wild cinematic depictions over the last century. Discover how the process of science refreshes and re-imagines our understanding of this legendary dinosaur. 
Filmmakers worked with top tyrannosaur scientists, a coalition of natural history institutions and pioneering paleo and visual effects artists to create one of the most dazzling and accurate T. rex documentaries ever made. 
BUY TICKETS
T. REX 3D movie website

location: Downtown Raleigh, 11 West Jones Street, Raleigh, NC, 27601, United States
description:

Day-to-day topics vary but often include physics and chemistry demonstrations on inertia, buoyancy and electromagnetism. Enjoy natural science topics such as the incredible composition of beaver teeth or the amazing design and strength of birds’ eggs. 
This walk-up program is offered: 

Wednesdays — 1:30pm
Thursdays — 1:30pm

Location: Windows on the World on the 3rd floor of the Nature Exploration Center.

location: Downtown Raleigh, 11 West Jones Street, Raleigh, NC, 27601, United States
description:

Meet some of the ocean’s strangest and most spectacular creatures in “Secrets of the Sea 3D.” From adorable pygmy seahorses and opalescent squid, to manta rays, tiger sharks, a coconut octopus and more, “Secrets of the Sea 3D” takes you face-to-face with more than 70 different marine species, showing the fascinating ways they interact with each other and their environment. Explore the wonders of the ocean world and discover the critical importance of marine biodiversity to keeping our oceans healthy.

title: An Evening with Mr. Jefferson with Tom Pitz
description:
Long an aficionado of Revolutionary Era history, Tom Pitz has been performing as Thomas Jefferson since 1987. He considers it an honor and a privilege to bring one of America’s greatest historical figures back to life for audiences. His performance sites include Michie Tavern, the Denver Museum of Natural Science, the College of William and Mary, Keswick Hall, the United States Treasury, the University of Virginia, the Virginia Genealogical Society, Hampden-Sydney College, Carthage College, and the National Geographic Society. As a graduate of Mr. Jefferson’s University, he is well aware that John Adams’ dying statement, “Jefferson survives,” is as true today as it was on July 4th, 1826.

This program will take place on Friday, Feb. 20th, at 6 p.m. During this event Mr. Pitz will appear as President Jefferson and will go into detail (in the first person) about his life.

This event will take place in the 1904 courtroom at the Museum of Ashe County History, located at 301 E. Main Street in Jefferson, and is FREE and open to all to attend.

This event is part of Ashe County's 250th lecture series and is sponsored by America 250 NC. For more information call (336) 846-1904.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Astronomy Event
description:
Medoc Mountain State Park will be holding its monthly astronomy event on 2/20/2026. Our telescope will be set up in the field below the picnic shelter. 

Please dress appropriately for the weather and only use red light flashlights. 

The event is weather-dependent and subject to cancellation.

title: Wintering Waterfowl Tour (Pantego)
description:
Join Pocosin Lakes National Wildlife Refuge for a guided tour of the Pungo Unit to observe migratory waterfowl and other wildlife. The tour will provide details about the role Pungo plays in providing a waterfowl sanctuary and include information on Tundra Swan and other migrating waterfowl! This is a caravan tour with participants driving their own vehicle following behind the tour leader. 
Vehicles are subject to road conditions on the Pungo Unit. It is recommended to arrive with a full tank of gas and to be driving in a 4WD capable vehicle to avoid getting stuck on the refuge. Roads on the refuge have a weight limit of 8,000lbs. The tour will begin at the Pungo Unit Kiosk located near 600 Refuge Rd Pantego, NC at the corner of Pat’s Rd and Refuge Rd. There is a sign at the kiosk stating “Refuge Tour Meets Here.” Tours last approximately 1.5 hours. 
To reserve your spot, click here.

Source: NC Wildlife Federation

title: Adult Nights: Anime
location: North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences
description:
Calling all anime fans! Step into a world where science meets fandom at this adults 21+ after-hours celebration of the art, stories, and pop culture of Japanese animation.

We’ll explore the real-life inspiration behind our favorite series and characters, so come dressed in your best cosplay and make this event a part of your arc! We’ll be playing iconic soundtracks and serving up drinks with our own anime twist to ensure this is no filler episode.

Whether you’re a hardcore otaku or just a casual viewer, this is your chance to geek out, dress up, and be a part of Adult Nights canon.

Tickets: $25; $15 Members. You must be 21 years or older to attend. A photo ID is required for entry.

title: Sinking Ship Productions’ The 7th Voyage of Egon Tichy
description:
Trapped in a time loop, space traveler Egon Tichy faces his own worst enemy: himself. And he’s multiplying. In this inventive fusion of live performance and digital video sleight-of-hand, a single actor builds a cinematic sci-fi comedy in real time, transforming an 8x4 white box into a cosmic wonderland.

The acclaimed physical theater company Sinking Ship Productions and the Obie Award-winning Theater in Quarantine have reimagined their streaming hit, The 7th Voyage of Egon Tichy, as a mind-bending in-person experience — a slapstick adventure and poignant meditation on the tug-of-war between the versions of ourselves we can never escape.

The 7th Voyage of Egon Tichy contains mild adult language and situations but is appropriate for audiences of all ages.

Source: NC State University

description:
Chapel Hill And Durham Fun with Friends (CHAD) 30s 40s 50s+

This is a free event but a $5 minimum purchase is asked to purchase an an appetizer or drink, and also the event is free if you buy a full entrée at 25% off for the night.

I recommend the Himalayan style chicken, crispy, but not greasy, with spiced potatoes, but the menu includes South Asian, Vegetarian, Nepalese, Bhutanese, cuisine, wings, tacos, fried rice, and more with a full bar and cocktails.

title: Teen Science Cafe: AI Applications
location: Morehead Planetarium and Science Center, 250 E Franklin St, Chapel Hill, North Carolina, 27516, United States
description:
Please join us at Morehead Planetarium and Science Center for February’s Teen Science Cafe! In this session, we’ll be discussing AI applications. Stay tuned for more information on this month’s speaker!Open to teens ages 13-18, our monthly cafes include exciting activities, engaging talks from expert speakers, and even free food! Plus, we cover a variety of different topics, ranging from cell biology to deep space galaxies, making it a one-of-a-kind spot for high school students to explore new ideas, interact with each other, and have fun!Doors will open at 6:00 pm for pizza and conversation. The cafe will start at 6:30 pm and wrap up around 7:30 pm. 




Learn more about Teen Science Cafe








Program Schedule 



6:00 pm: Arrive and check in. We will gather inside the west, main entrance of Morehead. 



6:00 – 6:30 pm: Pizza social. The pizza social will take place in our classrooms, located on the 2nd floor. 



6:30 pm – 7:30 pm: Discussion & activities. Trivia will take place in the Science Stage. 



Please Note: Depending on scheduled activities, the program may end between 7:30 p.m. and 7:45 p.m.

title: Chapel Hill Bird Club Outing
description:
For questions, contact Bo Howes at bohowes@gmail.com.  The location will be Johnston Mill Nature Preserve, Mt. Sinai Road entrance: 2713 Mt Sinai Rd, Chapel Hill, NC 27514.

This outing is sponsored by Chapel Hill Bird Club. More info about this outing is available at:  https://chbc.carolinanature.com/birdwalks/.

Outings usually last 2-3 hours. No reservations or sign-up needed. If there is a large turnout for any particular outing, we may split into two groups. We do recommend carpooling for families or friend pods; while we love pets, there is a ‘no-pet’ policy for bird outings. New birders and birders of all skill levels are welcome. 

Please wear long pants, socks, and sturdy shoes (ticks and chiggers may be present). Sun and bug protection are also recommended. Bring snacks and water if you like. Heavy rain will result in cancellation. Source: New Hope Bird Alliance

title: Red, White, & Blueberry Pancake Breakfast
description:
Burgaw, NC 

A Delicious Way to Celebrate Community, Heritage, and America 250

Start your day with a plate full of patriotism and blueberry flavor! Join us for the Red, White, & Blueberry Pancake Breakfast — a sweet annual tradition but this year we are celebrating community, heritage, and America 250.

From 8 to 11 a.m., guests are invited to enjoy a hearty hometown breakfast featuring fluffy blueberry pancakes, sausage, and a beverage of choice. Tickets are $10 per person, with children under five eating free. Tickets may be purchased in advance or at the door, and for those on the go, drive-thru take-out service will also be available.

The Blueberry Pancake Breakfast serves as a key fundraiser for the North Carolina Blueberry Festival, held annually in the historic town of Burgaw. The 2026 North Carolina Blueberry Festival will take place on Saturday, June 20, with the Kickoff Concert on Friday, June 19.

Proceeds from the pancake breakfast and festival events directly support the NC Blueberry Festival Association Academic Scholarship Program, which provides financial awards to graduating high school seniors in the blueberry producing counties of southeastern North Carolina to assist with their college education.

This beloved breakfast tradition officially kicks off the 2026 festival season, bringing the community together over good food for a great cause.
For advance ticket purchases or additional information, please contact the NC Blueberry Festival office at info@ncblueberryfestival.com.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

8:30 a.m.

title: Africa to Carolina Exhibit at Somerset Place
description:
February 1st marks the start of #BlackHistoryMonth! To commemorate the African diaspora and the impact Black culture has made on United States history, we will re-open our Africa to Carolina exhibit to the public. The Africa to Carolina initiative serves to identify, acknowledge, and mark each site in the state where enslaved Africans disembarked directly from the African Continent. In our self-guided exhibit, visitors can learn about the experiences of enslaved Africans who survived the Atlantic slave trade to North Carolina. Stop by the visitor center for free admission into the exhibit.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: State Line and Waterfall Hike
location: Deshazo Mill Access Mayo River State Park
description:
On this peaceful trail, you’ll pass a scenic waterfall, follow a babbling creek, and hike past the confluence of a river as you journey from North Carolina into Virginia. At the end, you can snap a photo with one foot in each state.

The trail is approximately 1.3 miles long and ranges from easy to moderate in difficulty. Please remember to wear appropriate footwear and bring water.

We will meet at the Deshazo Mill Access at 9:00 a.m. on February 21. The address is 113 Deshazo Road, Stoneville, NC 27048.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Agroecology Farm Volunteer Workday
description:
Come volunteer at the Agroecology Education Farm. This is a great opportunity to work on the farm, learn about sustainable farming, spend time outside and tour the farm. You are welcome to come alone, bring a friend or a group of friends. If you have questions about the volunteer workday, please contact Sara Snyder, farm manager, at sasnyde4@ncsu.edu.

title: Winter Symposium and Rare and Unusual Plant Auction
description:
Gardening With Gusto, a JC Raulston Arboretum winter symposium, is designed to stoke the fires of curiosity, creativity and love for plants during the cold months, so you can head into spring inspired and energized.

This morning symposium is for anyone who loves plants and gardening — whether you’re just starting out or have spent years nurturing your landscape. Through a series of engaging presentations from passionate horticulturists, you’ll be reminded why gardening captures our hearts and how it continues to connect us to nature, our communities and each other.

Gardening With Gusto will be available in person and online, so you can join us no matter where you are. Recordings of all presentations will also be available for attendees, making it easy to revisit the ideas and inspiration that resonate most.

Registration is required to attend the symposium. Please visit the arboretum's website to register for the symposium and to learn about its registration fees.

Source: NC State University

title: Changemakers’ Summit: Looking to Collective Resilience for Sustainable Impact
description:
Spend a Saturday at the Campus Y with fellow Changemakers and get to know our team!

In this half-day, summit-style retreat, we will pause, connect, and explore the weaving of personal and communal resilience—and how this connection can shift the ground in how we approach change. By finding power in the collective, cultivating compassion for ourselves and others and leaning into community, we hope students will leave the Summit feeling connected, grounded, and inspired to be part of positive, lasting change together.

During the Summit, students will:

Join others in a community weaving project,Explore protecting your peace through group dialogue,Discover practices that support collective mindfulness,Identify specific ways to move forward together.This CLE credit event includes free snacks, lunch, a T-shirt and UNC Y swag. 

All undergraduate and graduate students are welcome.
RSVP through heel life to reserve your spot!

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

Eno River State Park & Occoneechee Mountain State Natural Area programs are free but have limited space.  
Call or email to sign up!

Walk with a volunteer along Buckquarter Creek Trail to see some early signs of Spring! Learn to identify early spring ephemeral flowers and other plant species we come across along the trail. Bring binoculars to do some bird watching along the way! Source: Eno River Association

title: Black History Month Guided Tours
location: Pauli Murray Center for History and Social Justice
description:
This guided tour of the Pauli Murray Center for History and Social Justice will be hosted by our Executive Director, Angela Thorpe Mason, and will focus on key pieces of Pauli Murray's life and legacy as an African American, in honor of Black History Month. Visitors will be guided through the interior exhibit and historic space of Pauli Murray's childhood home, and time for questions and interactive reflection will be included in the time spent together.

Advanced registration is required and tickets sell out quickly! Visit tinyurl.com/pmc tours to reserve your spot.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Crafting the American Story
description:
In honor of the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence the City of Southport, the Fort Johnston-Southport Museum & Visitors’ Center, and the Brunswick Arts Council invite the community to explore how art, identity, and history intertwine throughout our collective American experience.

Crafting the American Story: Art, Identity, & History celebrates the boundless creativity of Americans—past and present—while recognizing the power of artistic expression to shape, reflect, and challenge our collective narrative.

This exhibition will showcase the creativity of Brunswick County artists while exploring how art reflects and interprets our nation’s history. Through the graphic arts, sculpture and handcrafts, visitors will encounter works that engage with themes of resilience, cultural identity, and the diverse perspectives that enrich our shared story.

What You’ll Discover

The exhibition highlights how creativity has shaped and been shaped by American history over the past 250 years. From responses to adversity and change, to celebrations of cultural heritage, the works on display will show how art captures, or was influenced by, the complexity of the American experience.

The show invites both artists and audiences to reflect on:

How historical events inspire creative expressionThe power of art and handicraft as a storytelling mediumThe inclusion of perspectives often missing from familiar narrativesThe ways resilience, identity, and innovation converge to shape our futureAs part of the program, America 250 NC will present a One Day Wonder traveling exhibit “To Preserve the Blessings of Liberty: State Constitutions of North Carolina.” Featuring copies of the 1776 State Constitution and Declaration of Rights, the 1868 State Constitution, and a letter from John Adams known as “Thoughts on Government,” the exhibit explores North Carolina’s three state constitutions and key amendments, examining how they reshaped ideas of citizenship and expanded, or restricted, participation in the state’s political life. This exhibit will be available for a limited time on opening day only.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: First in Freedom Festival: Visit the Battleship NORTH CAROLINA: A Legendary Ship with a Remarkable Story
description:
Visit the Battleship NORTH CAROLINA: Where History Comes Alive

Rising proudly along the Cape Fear River, the Battleship NORTH CAROLINA is more than a landmark—it’s a powerful journey into America’s past. Just minutes from historic downtown Wilmington, this iconic World War II battleship invites visitors of all ages to step aboard and experience history where it happened.

The battleship is an ideal stop for families, school groups, and visitors exploring the Wilmington area. Self-guided tours allow you to explore at your own pace, while guided tours and group programs provide deeper insight into the ship’s history and significance.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Founding Fathers at Latimer House
description:
Historic Latimer House will proudly participate in the America 250 First in Freedom Festival as an official Passport Stamp Cancellation Site, offering visitors a unique opportunity to engage with the nation’s founding history during the festival week, February 21–28.

For one week only, Latimer House will present an extraordinary public viewing of original documents from three Founding Fathers—George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, and James Madison. These rare and significant items are part of the archive of the Lower Cape Fear Historical Society, which is celebrating 70 years of historic preservation work in the region.

In recognition of service, active-duty and veteran military members will receive free admission with valid ID throughout the festival week. Limited tickets are available online at the Latimer House website.

The America 250 First in Freedom Festival commemorates the events and ideals that led to American independence, and Latimer House’s participation highlights the enduring relevance of original historical documents and preservation efforts.

For history enthusiasts, families, students, and visitors alike, Latimer House’s festival programming offers a rare chance to connect directly with the words and legacy of the nation’s founders—available for one week only.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Guided History Tour—Airlie Gardens
description:
Dive into the rich history, horticulture, and ecology of Airlie Gardens on a walking tour of the grounds. This program is included in Garden Membership, advance registration is required.

Tours are offered the first and third Saturday of every month. More details can be found here:

https://airliegardens.org/events/guided-history-tour-17/

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Living History: The Stamp Act Resistance
description:
Join us at Brunswick Town/Fort Anderson State Historic site as we travel back in time to February 1766 as tensions are growing in the lower Cape Fear regarding the dreaded stamp act. Visitors can expect to see and interact with interpreters portraying key players of the stamp at resistance in Brunswick Town. Two lectures will be taking place throughout the day. John Moseley from the North Carolina Maritime Museum at Southport will be discussing the events leading up to the resistance in Brunswick at 10am and Hunter Ingram from the Burgwin-Wright will be discussing the course of the events in February 1766 in Brunswick at 1pm. Activities for kids will include making tricorn hats and painting toy soldiers.
This is a free event for all ages.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: NC Aquariums Chapter of FrogWatch USA volunteer training
description:
Become a FrogWatch USA volunteer with the NC Aquariums Chapter. The 2-day volunteer training, hosted by Lake Waccamaw State Park is being offered on January 21 (10:00 a.m. - 4:00 p.m.) and on January 28 (10:00 a.m. - 1:00 p.m.). Become a FrogWatch USA community scientist by attending both dates. 

FrogWatch USA volunteers learn to identify frogs and toads by their breeding calls. Each 2-day training introduces FrogWatch protocols and procedures, introduces the breeding calls of local species, and provides a mock listening sessions for practice. Volunteers who complete the training are invited to engage in social listening sessions throughout southeast NC and receive a quarterly newsletter regarding FrogWatch activity.

To register or to see other training dates/locations, please visit the NC Aquarium at Fort Fisher website at the link provided. For more information about FrogWatch USA and becoming a volunteer, please email Kristin.Holloman-Noe@ncaquariums.com.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: NC First in Freedom Festival
description:
In 2026 the inaugural North Carolina First in Freedom Festival, taking place throughout Southeastern NC during the week of February 21-28, 2026 (10:00 AM - 4:00 PM), will celebrate more than 250 years of our Nation’s story and culture viewed through the lens of historical North Carolina events and the arts. Please visit the NC FIFF website to see the planned activities: 

https://www.ncfirstinfreedomfestival.com/

Funded in part by an America 250 NC grant, a program of the NC Department of Natural and Cultural Resources.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Stories of the Revolution: People and Places of Pender County
description:
American Revolution stories of people and places of Pender County (then northern New Hanover County) will be featured in an exhibit. While the Battle of Moores Creek is famous, this exhibit features many other lesser-known stories. The fertile lands of Rocky Point was the residence of many prominent Revolutionary leaders. Stories will be told about members of the Moore, Ashe, Lillington, Swann, Bloodworth, and other families. Free Blacks were also Patriot soldiers, while enslaved Daniel Moore found his liberty with the British. Places of Revolutionary events include the Patriot fort near Rutherford's Mill and Herron's Bridge on the Northeast Cape Fear River. The lovely Sloop Point House, a home of Samuel Ashe, built in 1726 by his father John Baptiste Ashe, still stands on the coast. It’s the 2nd oldest building in the state as it turns 300 years old. Come discover these rich stories of patriotic heritage and more.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt
description:
The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt showcases how the biblical story of heroic Queen Esther, depicted by Rembrandt and his contemporaries in art and popular culture, expressed ideas of political and religious freedom during the Dutch Golden Age. Charting this history through objects and artworks, The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt provides an original perspective on one of the most studied periods of Dutch prosperity.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Thomas Day Narrative: Expanded
description:
In celebration of Black History Month, Thomas Day State Historic Site will be offering a unique guided tour series where visitors can discover lesser-known details about the Day family's involvement in African American achievements throughout the 19th century.

Tours will take place each Saturday in February and involve a short lecture showcasing documents, followed by a guided tour of the site.

Tour dates and times are as follows:
- February 7 at 10am, 1pm, & 3pm
- February 14 at 10am, 1pm, & 3pm
- February 21 at 10am, 1pm, & 3pm
- February 28th at 10am, 1pm, & 3pm

Walk-ins are welcome, but please register in advance using the link so that we can accommodate all: https://forms.gle/8tGXS38yQVWBdGuMA
** Tour fees must be paid on the date of your visit.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Travel back in time to February 1766
description:
Travel back in time to February 1766 as tensions are growing in the Lower Cape Fear regarding the dreaded Stamp Act. Visitors can expect to see interpreters portraying key figures in the Stamp Act resistance in Brunswick Town and interact with them. Activities for kids will include making tricorn hats and painting toy soldiers.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Wildlife Detective
location: Carvers Creek State Park – Long Valley Farm Access
description:
Have you seen animal tracks and wondered what the critter was thinking and doing? Sometimes, their tracks can give you a pretty good idea! We will be doing a short guided hike (just under half a mile) to interpret the tracks we come across. Afterwards, we will play a game! This program is suitable for all ages, adults and kids are all encouraged to participate! We'll be meeting next to the visitor center at 10am.

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

title: Bald Eagle Watch (Moncure)
description:
Join NCWF South Wake Conservationists Chapter for a bald eagle watch at the Jordan Lake Dam Tailrace Fishing Area. Jordan Lake is home to a large number of permanent resident eagle pairs, and in the winter the population grows to one of the largest on the East Coast with the arrival of migratory eagles. Although we cannot 100% guarantee a sighting, we are crossing our fingers! The wintering eagles are usually solo and immature eagles that are not yet sporting their white feathers. We hope to see you there! 
REGISTER HERE

Source: NC Wildlife Federation

title: Black His/Her-Story Month Carnival
description:
WilmingtoNColor Presents: Black His/Her-tory Carnival

On Saturday Feb. 21st WilmingtoNColor will be celebrating the rich black heritage of Wilmington NC and beyond  from 11am - 4pm at Chow Town Food Truck Park across the street from the  1898 Memorial Park on the Historic Northside of downtown Wilmington Brooklyn Arts District  for the Black His/Her-Story Month Carnival 

 

Attendees will be able to experience the following: 

Mini Black History Bus Tours provided by WilmingtoNColor Heritage Tour HBCU informational boothsBounce Houses Video Gaming (Xbox, PlayStation, old arcade games and more) CornholeFace painting Balloons Spades Dominoes Vendors Speeches Performances Music And more  

With this event WilmingtoNColor will look to entertain and educate guests on Wilmington’s Rich Heritage around food, music, culture and fun

This Family Friendly Event is “Pay what you can” but if you would like to be a sponsor please contact us at Info@WilmingtoNColor.com

Who:WilmingtoNColor 

What:Black History Carnival  

When:Saturday February 21st, 2026

Time: 11-4pm 

Where:Chow Town across the street from the 1898 Memorial Park - (1125 n 4th st Wilmington NC 28401)

Why:Black History Month Celebration, Community, Culture, Music, Family, Legacy 

About WilmingtoNColor:  

wilmingtoNColor is the only shuttle tour in The World that tells the story of the only successful coup d'etat (Government Overthrow) on US Soil.  

 

On November 10, 1898, an angry mob of white supremacists led the only successful coup in America, where a massacre took place that wiped out the educated, rich and influential African American population. This coup took away the roots of the academic and economic foundation of the Black community, and its effects still haunt the community today. wilmingtoNColor, or Wilmington in Color, is here to connect the past with the present, in hopes of rebuilding a future that can reflect what Wilmington, NC looked like before the events of 1898 took place. 

Guest will see and learn about Green Book Locations, Religious, Educational and Medical Institutions, Fraternity and Sorority Houses, Current Black Owned Businesses and more. This hour long tour packs centuries of rich heritage into 90mins.

Interested in booking a tour click hereor email info@WilmingtoNColor.com

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Echoes of Change: Resilience Against Oppression Walking Tour
description:
Echoes of Change: Resilience Against Oppression Walking Tour explores the NC State Capitol and NC Freedom Park as sites of resistance in North Carolina by examining how physical spaces and the people connected to them have shaped struggles for justice in the 20th century.

At the NC State Capitol, we will consider the building in two ways: first, as a physical space where acts of resistance and demonstrations unfolded, and second, as a workplace for individuals whose policies and decisions sparked opposition and activism.

The program will also explore NC Freedom Park as a space born directly out of the need for progress. Through the stories of individuals such as Julius Chambers, Ella Baker, and Golden Frinks, we will highlight how people—not just places—drove transformative change. By centering individual acts of resistance, this event underscores how collective action and courageous leadership have shaped North Carolina’s history and continue to influence its present.

This tour is partially outdoors and requires walking about a block to the NC State Capitol. Please dress comfortably for the weather.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

The New Bern Chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution, the Richard Dobbs Spaight Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution, and the St John's Masonic Lodge # 3, cordially invite you to join us for our “Annual George Washington Birthday Celebration/Luncheon” on February 21st. title: GGC Adventure Series: Bike Navigation and Scavenger Hunt
description:
Back for another year of inspiring adventures in nature, this season of the Greenway Gear Collective Adventure Series will feature Adventure Race themed outings.
Each event will focus on one of the disciplines of adventure racing: traditionally mountain biking, orienteering (map and compass navigation), and paddling (canoe or kayak) and will take place at or around Lake Raleigh. Beginners or veterans alike will be in excellent hands with each adventure led by Debra and Jeff Rezeli, experts with over 11 years of adventure racing experience.
Register for each event here.

For those who love a goal to build towards...
The series will build skills in advance of a local practice 3-hour adventure race in May and the option to register and participate in a 5-hour adventure race hosted by Broad Run Offroad on June 13 & 14 at Lake Anna State Park in Spotsylvania, VA.
For more information on adventure racing, check out the US Adventure Racing Association website.

Source: NC State University

title: "Field & Factory: A Look at Tobacco’s Laborers" at Duke Homestead
description:
To learn a fuller story of the people who worked in tobacco, join Duke Homestead staff on site for a special program, “Field & Factory: A Look at Tobacco’s Laborers.” These walks will highlight the contributions that each group of people working in tobacco made to North Carolina’s culture and powerful economy in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, while addressing the inequalities in tobacco’s labor forces.

We will depart from the visitor’s center lobby at 11:15am and 2:15pm on Saturday, February 7th, 14th, 21st, and 28th. Admission is free.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Sightseeing Tours
description:
Cape Fear Riverboats is excited to announce February Sightseeing Tours for 2026 in support of the North Carolina First in Freedom Festival. For over 35 years, Cape Fear Riverboats has operated captain-narrated Sightseeing & Sunset Tours from downtown Wilmington which is TripAdvisors' Top Destination on the Rise for 2024. Daily tours onboard our current vessels, Henrietta and Osprey, highlight the area's history, legends, and charm, weaving over 400 years of history from the area's founding by English settlers all the way to modern times. For Group or Charter inquiries, please contact sales@capefearriverboats.com. For Public Tour or Sunset tickets, please visit https://capefearriverboats.com/ or call 910-613-9822.

title: Durham Farmers' Market
location: Durham Central Park, 501 Foster Street, Durham, NC, 27701, United States
description:
The Durham Farmers’ Market is a community of farmers, growers and crafters. We are strongly committed to local products: every item you see at the market was produced by the people selling it, and it all comes from no more than 70 miles away. 
The Durham Farmers’ Market open Saturdays mornings for local produce, flowers, crafts and more! The Wednesday Market is open from 3-6pm Wednesdays, Mid-April through Mid-October 
If you’d like more information about this week’s vendor list, SNAP benefits and map, visit durhamfarmersmarket.com 

We are happy to offer Double Bucks to our SNAP clients. This means is a SNAP client has $10, they receive $20 in tokens to spend at the winter market.

Estamos muy contentos de ofrecer Double Bucks a nuestros clientes de SNAP. Esto significa que si un cliente de SNAP gasta $ 10, recibirá $ 20 en tokens para gastar en productos frescos.


Additionally, we offer a cash match program for other qualifying folks. To receive this benefit, simply bring cash to the info table. Then, we’ll double the amount with tokens. For example, $10 in cash equals $20 in tokens.

También ofrecemos un programa de contrapartida en efectivo para nuestros beneficiarios de SNAP que no tienen beneficios durante el mes, clientes de WIC y miembros de la comunidad que viven en viviendas públicas. Para recibir este beneficio, simplemente traiga efectivo a la tabla de información y duplicaremos la cantidad con tokens. Por ejemplo, $ 10 en efectivo equivalen a $ 20 en fichas.

Source: Durham Central Park

title: Invasive Plant Removal (Monroe)
description:
Join NCWF Union County Wildlife Chapter and community volunteers to remove invasive species along the Carolina Thread Trail at the Union County Agricultural Center. Invasive plants are non-native introduced plants that do not support native wildlife. They are very aggressive, outcompete wildlife-friendly plants, and take over natural areas. Removing invasive species is often the first step to enhancing and restoring habitat for wildlife. 
Volunteers will discover how to identify invasive plants and practice removing them by hand and with tools. Please bring your favorite pair of loppers, pruning saw, and a pair of gloves. We will have some tools available. Ages 13+ please. 
REGISTER HERE

Source: NC Wildlife Federation

title: Salamander Studies in Duke Forest
description:
While gardens sleep, winter is the busiest time for North Carolina’s salamanders. Join Dr. Ron Grunwald, Duke Department of Biology, to look for these “cool” amphibians in Duke Forest, where you might see woodland red-back salamanders in the woods and two-lined and dusky salamanders in the stream. Learn about ongoing salamander studies and the habitats different salamander species rely on for their life cycles. Be prepared for a walk on the forest floor and to dip your toes in a rocky creek. 
Fee: $22; 20% discount for Duke Gardens members with discount code. 
Location: Duke Forest; driving directions will be included in a program reminder email sent the week before the program. Parking is free and carpooling is encouraged.
 
Accessibility: This will be a small group program that takes place outdoors and traveling on unpaved trails with some uneven surfaces.

Source: Sarah P. Duke Gardens

title: Rescues and Records
description: Source: Hope Animal Rescue

title: Educational Bird Walk (Gatesville)
description:
Join NCWF Wildlife Habitat Stewards of Northeastern NC Chapter for an educational Bird Walk! Come explore the beautiful Coleman Trail at Merchants Millpond State Park on Saturday, February 21, from 10 am – 12 pm. 
We’re excited to have Skadi Kylander leading the walk. Skadi is a passionate birder with a biology degree from Chowan University and ongoing PhD research at East Carolina University, where she studies Prothonotary Warblers and their nesting habits. She is knowledgeable about the birds of Merchants Millpond and loves sharing that knowledge with others. 
As we walk along the trail, we’ll look and listen for local bird species. We’ll have field guides and other resources on hand, and you’re encouraged to bring our phone. Skadi will show you how to use the Merlin and iNaturalist apps to help identify and document what you discover. Feel free to bring binoculars or a camera, and we’ll also have a spotting scope available for those moments when a bird or waterfowl decides to pose. 
The Coleman Trail is an easy, family-friendly 2-mile loop starting right from the Boat Access Parking area. Participants under 18 must be accompanied by an adult.  
REGISTER HERE

description:
More than 20,000 African Americans trained in segregated facilities between 1942 and 1949 at Montford Point, NC, and became the first African Americans to serve in the United States Marine Corps. title: Sinking Ship Productions’ The 7th Voyage of Egon Tichy - NC State LIVE Performance
description:
“Virtuosic! Some of the new medium’s most imaginative work.” – New York Times [Critics Pick]

Trapped in a time loop, space traveler Egon Tichy faces his own worst enemy: himself. And he’s multiplying! In this inventive fusion of live performance and digital video sleight-of-hand, a single actor builds a cinematic sci-fi comedy in real time, transforming an 8’x4′ white box into a cosmic wonderland.

The acclaimed physical theater company Sinking Ship Productions and the Obie Award-winning Theater in Quarantine have reimagined their streaming hit The 7th Voyage of Egon Tichy as a mind-bending in-person experience—a slapstick adventure and poignant meditation on the tug-of-war between the versions of ourselves we can never escape.

Considerations: The 7th Voyage of Egon Tichy contains mild adult language and situations but is appropriate for audiences of all ages.

Source: NC State University

title: Photography Workshop: Winter Light in the Garden
location: North Carolina Botanical Garden, 100 Old Mason Farm Road, Chapel Hill, NC, 27517, United States
description:
Register Here

with Barbara Tyroler, Photographer 
Date: Saturday, February 21, 2026
Time: 12:30 – 4:30 p.m.
Location: North Carolina Botanical Garden
Fee: $52 ($47 Members) 
  
Winter offers a quieter, more contemplative beauty—and this workshop invites you to discover it through your lens. In the winter garden, structure replaces color, shadows grow longer, and the smallest details become the most expressive. Together, we’ll explore how to photograph bare branches, seed heads, textures, frost patterns, muted palettes, and the striking geometry that emerges when the garden rests. Through guided exercises and intentional seeing practices, you’ll learn to work with low winter light, embrace simplicity, and create images that reflect the stillness and poetry of the season. Perfect for photographers who want to expand their visual awareness and find beauty in the subtle, overlooked moments of winter. All cameras and lenses appropriate from smart phones to digital single lens reflex and mirrorless. 
  
Register Here

Source: NC Botanical Garden

title: Discover Tryon Palace: Outlander
location: Tryon Palace Historic Sites and Gardens
description:
Step into Tryon Palace and explore Diana Gabaldon’s award-winning Outlander series. Learn about the lives of the fictional Jamie and Claire Fraser, their family and friends, and interactions with historical figures and events in the tumultuous period of the American Revolution.

Tour covers storylines from Outlander books 4 – 8 and the Starz Outlander seasons 4 – 8. (For those not current on the books or show, there will be spoilers for these books and seasons.)

Tour begins at 301 George Street, across from the Tryon Palace Main Gates. Ticket holders should check in at the Waystation ticketing desk no later than 3:30 p.m.

title: TOUR: A Closer Look at the Collection

title: Foundational Documents Talks - The Constitution
description:
Join the Orange County Historical Museum to celebrate the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence with a year-long series of talks discussing the founding of our country.

Why was the Constitution written? What are the basic powers provided and forbidden the government? How was the Constitution ratified? Why did North Carolina resist? What was Hillsborough's role in the process?Find the answer to these questions and more in this presentation by OCHM Exhibits Coordinator Courtney Smith.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

Crafts & Drafts has a huge variety of craft kits for purchase, or you can bring something you’re working on and enjoy one of their many draft beers on tap. They’ll donate a portion of their sales to APS, too! Come meet some adoptable dogs and some fellow crafty folks! We’ll see you there!

title: Melanated Creatives Market
location: The Pavilion, 501 Foster Street, Durham, NC, 27701, United States
description:
Join us for the Melanated Creatives Market on February 21 at Durham Central Park Pavilion, a vibrant community gathering in celebration of Black History Month 
This market is a joyful space rooted in culture, creativity, and connection. Come experience a thoughtfully curated lineup of Black-owned businesses, artists, makers, and healers offering handmade goods, art, holistic products, fashion, home items, and more. 
Whether you’re coming to shop, connect, or simply soak in the energy, this market is about honoring Black creativity past, present, and future while supporting local entrepreneurs and building community together. Families are welcome, conversations are encouraged, and every purchase helps circulate love and resources back into our community. 
Come as you are, bring a friend, and celebrate Black excellence with us in a space that feels warm, welcoming, and alive with intention.

Source: Durham Central Park

title: Dancing in Defiance: A Night of Merriment and Rebellion
description:
Step Back into 1766 - The Friends of BTFA Present- Dancing in Defiance: A Night of Merriment and Rebellion

The Friends of Brunswick Town/Fort Anderson cordially invite you to Dancing in Defiance: A Night of Merriment and Rebellion. Join us on February 21, from 5:00 PM to 8:00 PM, for an unforgettable evening where history comes to life.

This is an immersive experience. You will march to the ruins of Royal Governor Tryon’s house, retracing the steps of the historic Stamp Act resistance. Enjoy live Colonial Music & Dancing in a stunning historical setting.

This is a ticketed event with limited capacity, and all registrations must be completed by February 6. Adults: $30, Youth (Ages 12–18): $15. Please note: This event is curated for an adult and teenage audience and is not suitable for children under 12.

title: Wintering Waterfowl Tour (Pantego)
description:
Join Pocosin Lakes National Wildlife Refuge for a guided tour of the Pungo Unit to observe migratory waterfowl and other wildlife. The tour will provide details about the role Pungo plays in providing a waterfowl sanctuary and include information on Tundra Swan and other migrating waterfowl! This is a caravan tour with participants driving their own vehicle following behind the tour leader. 
Vehicles are subject to road conditions on the Pungo Unit. It is recommended to arrive with a full tank of gas and to be driving in a 4WD capable vehicle to avoid getting stuck on the refuge. Roads on the refuge have a weight limit of 8,000lbs. The tour will begin at the Pungo Unit Kiosk located near 600 Refuge Rd Pantego, NC at the corner of Pat’s Rd and Refuge Rd. There is a sign at the kiosk stating “Refuge Tour Meets Here.” Tours last approximately 1.5 hours. 
To reserve your spot, click here.

location: Tanger Center for the Performing Arts
description:

The program opens with Toast of the Town, a lively overture by young black composer, Quinn Mason. Other pieces on the program include Debussy’s dreamy Prelude to the Afternoon of a Faun, Peck’s dynamic Glory and Grandeur, and the majestic Dvorak Symphony No. 7.

title: Sinking Ship Productions’ The 7th Voyage of Egon Tichy
description:
Trapped in a time loop, space traveler Egon Tichy faces his own worst enemy: himself. And he’s multiplying. In this inventive fusion of live performance and digital video sleight-of-hand, a single actor builds a cinematic sci-fi comedy in real time, transforming an 8x4 white box into a cosmic wonderland.

The acclaimed physical theater company Sinking Ship Productions and the Obie Award-winning Theater in Quarantine have reimagined their streaming hit, The 7th Voyage of Egon Tichy, as a mind-bending in-person experience — a slapstick adventure and poignant meditation on the tug-of-war between the versions of ourselves we can never escape.

The 7th Voyage of Egon Tichy contains mild adult language and situations but is appropriate for audiences of all ages.

Source: NC State University

title: Apply for Teacher Workshop: Rivers and Resistance - Freedom Seeking in Eastern NC
description:
Join us for Rivers and Resistance: Freedom Seeking in Eastern NC, a transformative, place-based workshop designed for middle and high school teachers.

·       Virtual Event Kick Off (via Zoom) on Thursday, March 26 (5 PM - 7:30 PM)
·       Immersive Learning in Eastern NC Friday, April 10 - Sunday, April 12, 2026  
 
APPLICATION DEADLINE is February 22
 
Event Overview
Throughout North Carolina's early history, many enslaved people carved out freedom for themselves, some using the waterways, swamps, and diverse landscapes of eastern North Carolina as pathways to liberation. This immersive weekend experience will highlight the courageous acts of resistance and resilience by those who escaped or aided others in their journey to freedom.
 
Participants will explore the historical significance of key sites, including DNCR's Somerset Place and Historic Edenton, delving into the stories of enslaved people like Harriet Jacobs and many others. Through interaction with top scholars, tours, discussions, and hands-on activities, the workshop will weave together history and science, connecting the natural ecology of the region—its rivers, swamps, and forests—with the survival strategies of freedom seekers.
 
Attendees will also have the unique opportunity to canoe the very waterways enslaved people navigated, offering an immersive experience in the natural environment that shaped their journeys. Guided by DNCR's NC Museum of Natural Sciences, teachers will gain insights into the region’s ecosystems and learn how waterways and landscapes influenced the history, culture and experiences of freedom seekers. 

In addition to examining the physical landscapes of resistance, we will explore cultural strategies of survival and freedom, such as the role of foodways in sustaining communities. We will be joined by Adé Carrena, an award-winning chef, culinary artist, storyteller, and filmmaker, who will guide us through the rich tapestry of Southern culinary traditions and their deep roots in African diasporic culture. As she leads our group in preparing a shared meal, participants will experience firsthand how recipes became vessels of memory and resilience.

Equally powerful is the role of music and spirituals, songs that served as both comfort and covert communication, embedding directions and encouragement within their melodies. Acclaimed scholar and singer Mary D. Williams will join us for a private performance sharing some of the spirituals that were a source of strength through generations. These cultural practices were not mere expressions of creativity; they were acts of quiet defiance, sustaining hope and forging pathways to liberation.
 
Teachers will leave with new perspectives on integrating history, culture, science, and nature into comprehensive lessons, as well as strategies for teaching the history of slavery and freedom seeking in effective and responsible ways.
 
Attending educators will receive:

2.0 CEUs (with the completion of pre-readings) Overnight accommodations (Friday and Saturday evening) at the Eastern 4-H Center and meals Private access to key historic sites such as Historic Edenton and Somerset Place.A guided paddle (via canoe) along the Cashie River, with a focus on nature and the environmental factors that shaped the experiences of enslaved people. Discussions on the intersections of history, nature, and science in the regionA virtual keynote by Dr. Antwain Hunter, UNC-Chapel HillA hands-on foodways workshop and lunch with Adé Carrena, an award-winning chef, culinary artist, storyteller, and filmmakerA private performance by Mary D. Williams that focuses on the role of music in the resistance and resilience of enslaved peopleResources and strategies for teaching about slavery, resistance, freedom, and resilience. 
Application and Requirements
Applications are open to teachers of all disciplines in grades 6-12 who evidence in their application how this experience directly connects with their work in the classroom.
 
Space is limited to 16 teachers; filling out this application does not guarantee your registration. Selections will be made based on the responses provided, as well as ensuring representation from multiple grades, subject areas, and geographies. 
 
Priority will be given to applications from cross-disciplinary teams of two or more teachers from the same school who apply (e.g., a social studies teacher and a science teacher from the same school interested in teaching this content across curriculums) Registrants who have not previously participated in a workshop provided by the hosting organizations will also receive preference. 
 
Applicants must be currently employed full-time in a North Carolina public school (including public charters), teaching at least 50% in person, and must make clear in their responses how they will utilize this experience back in the classroom. 
Before submitting an application, please ensure you can participate in the virtual kick-off on Thurs. March 26 at 5:30 PM, arrive at Somerset Place by 4 PM on Friday, April 10, and that you can attend all portions of the agenda until 11 AM on Sunday, April 12. (If you will need to leave school early to arrive by 4 pm on April 10, please get approval from your principal before applying.) Late arrivals and early departures cannot be accommodated. 
 
You will know that your application was submitted when you receive an auto-message noting such. (We recommend keeping a local copy of your responses before submitting.) If you are unsure your application was submitted, you can e-mail educationoutreach@dncr.nc.gov for a confirmation.
 
You should receive a response to your application no later than March 9. (Please hold the dates until that point.) If after March 9 you have not received a response and a message is not in your junk/spam folder, please contact us at educationoutreach@dncr.nc.gov. 
 
Acceptances & Cancellations 
If a spot is offered to you, you must confirm your participation by responding to your acceptance e-mail within three business days. If you are accepted and at any point find that you are no longer able to participate, it is critical that you provide ample notice of cancellation. Failure to do so prevents other teachers on the wait list from participating and results in waste of food, accommodations, and other resources. Teachers who do not cancel and do not show up may have their school billed for a "no show" fee of $100.
 
Questions?
Contact christie.norris@dncr.nc.gov. 

APPLY HERE: Rivers and Resistance APPLICATION
 
This workshop is a collaboration between the North Carolina Department of Natural and Cultural Resources (DNCR) divisions/programs (including the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences, the America 250 NC initiative, Division of Historic Sites) and Carolina K-12. It is funded by DNCR’s America 250 NC initiative.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

location: 900 Bass Lake Rd, Holly Springs, NC 27540, USA
description:

The park opens at 8 am. The address is 900 Bass Lake Road, Holly Springs, NC (note that this is the main parking lot, not the smaller lot on another road). Meet at the end of the parking lot near the building. This  2+ mile walk on unpaved trails begins at 8:15 and ends shortly after 10:30.

title: (Regional) Stone Mountain State Park, NC
description:
Triangle Hiking and Outdoors Group
Join THOG for a hike at Stone Mountain State Park which offers cascading waterfalls, forests, scenic hiking trails, and a historic homestead. Stone Mountain itself is a 600-foot granite dome.

Itinerary:

We will hike a total of around 9 miles which includes the Stone Mountain Trail Loop that will take us to the top of Stone Mountain. We'll stop by a couple of waterfalls along our route on the trail, as well as the homestead at the bottom. We will hike at around a 2mph pace. Trail difficulties range from Moderate to Strenuous. Be mindful of your hiking abilities. This hike includes a lot of stairs. Travel time to the park is about 2 hours.

Bring water (1-2 Liters), snacks and Lunch. We will have lunch at the top of Stone Mountain.

For your safety, hiking boots or shoes with soles that grip well are highly suggested, especially when hiking near the slope or near the waterfalls.

Expect to meet in Chapel Hill on Sunday morning to setup carpools. Plan to leave the parking lot as close to 7:30 as possible. Please be sure to share the cost of gas with your driver.
We should be back in town by 5PM.

TRIP PARTICIPANT WAIVER OF LIABILITY I fully realize that this activity involves a risk of personal injury, property damage, or loss of my person or property. I hereby for myself, my heirs, executors and administrators, and same for persons with whom are in my party, waive and release any claims or rights against Triangle Hiking & Outdoors Group (THOG), all of its owners and coordinators for any and all injury, damages or loss to my person or property incurred during this activity. I also understand that THOG organizers are not required, nor should it be assumed that they are CPR/First Aid/Wilderness Survival Certified and I am responsible for my own personal safety.

Questions? Send me a message or comment below.

See you all on Sunday!
Larredo

Source: Meetup: Triangle Hiking & Outdoors

title: Crafting the American Story
description:
In honor of the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence the City of Southport, the Fort Johnston-Southport Museum & Visitors’ Center, and the Brunswick Arts Council invite the community to explore how art, identity, and history intertwine throughout our collective American experience.

Crafting the American Story: Art, Identity, & History celebrates the boundless creativity of Americans—past and present—while recognizing the power of artistic expression to shape, reflect, and challenge our collective narrative.

This exhibition will showcase the creativity of Brunswick County artists while exploring how art reflects and interprets our nation’s history. Through the graphic arts, sculpture and handcrafts, visitors will encounter works that engage with themes of resilience, cultural identity, and the diverse perspectives that enrich our shared story.

What You’ll Discover

The exhibition highlights how creativity has shaped and been shaped by American history over the past 250 years. From responses to adversity and change, to celebrations of cultural heritage, the works on display will show how art captures, or was influenced by, the complexity of the American experience.

The show invites both artists and audiences to reflect on:

How historical events inspire creative expressionThe power of art and handicraft as a storytelling mediumThe inclusion of perspectives often missing from familiar narrativesThe ways resilience, identity, and innovation converge to shape our futureAs part of the program, America 250 NC will present a One Day Wonder traveling exhibit “To Preserve the Blessings of Liberty: State Constitutions of North Carolina.” Featuring copies of the 1776 State Constitution and Declaration of Rights, the 1868 State Constitution, and a letter from John Adams known as “Thoughts on Government,” the exhibit explores North Carolina’s three state constitutions and key amendments, examining how they reshaped ideas of citizenship and expanded, or restricted, participation in the state’s political life. This exhibit will be available for a limited time on opening day only.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

description:

Please visit the NC FIFF website to see the planned activities: 

https://www.ncfirstinfreedomfestival.com/

Funded in part by an America 250 NC grant, a program of the NC Department of Natural and Cultural Resources.

title: The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt
description:
The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt showcases how the biblical story of heroic Queen Esther, depicted by Rembrandt and his contemporaries in art and popular culture, expressed ideas of political and religious freedom during the Dutch Golden Age. Charting this history through objects and artworks, The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt provides an original perspective on one of the most studied periods of Dutch prosperity.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Sightseeing Tours
description:
Cape Fear Riverboats is excited to announce February Sightseeing Tours for 2026 in support of the North Carolina First in Freedom Festival. For over 35 years, Cape Fear Riverboats has operated captain-narrated Sightseeing & Sunset Tours from downtown Wilmington which is TripAdvisors' Top Destination on the Rise for 2024. Daily tours onboard our current vessels, Henrietta and Osprey, highlight the area's history, legends, and charm, weaving over 400 years of history from the area's founding by English settlers all the way to modern times. For Group or Charter inquiries, please contact sales@capefearriverboats.com. For Public Tour or Sunset tickets, please visit https://capefearriverboats.com/ or call 910-613-9822.

title: A Colonial Faire at Harmony Hall
description:
Immerse yourself in Colonial history and culture to celebrate America’s 250th anniversary!   

Activities Include:

Welcome Ceremony and Presentation: Learn about “The Race to Wilmington—Bladen County and the Pathway to Moore’s Creek” presented by the Le Marquis de Lafayette Chapter from the North Carolina Society Sons of the American Revolution.  Music and Dance: Enjoy lively performances featuring the Huckleberry Brothers Band, along with a caller to guide participants through traditional country dances.Children’s Crafts and Games: Engage in traditional activities such as quill writing,  bowling, and playing with hoops and sticks.Traditional Crafts and Vendors: Explore a variety of local crafts and vendors showcasing handmade goods.Food for Sale: Savor delicious food offerings available for purchase.Musket Firing: Experience the excitement of musket firing demonstrations.Craft Demonstrations: Witness traditional crafts in action, including felting, quilting, blacksmithing, and hearth cooking.Colonial Reenactors: Meet reenactors who bring history to life.For more information, visit our Facebook Page – Harmony Hall Village – White Oak or email us at harmonyhallwhiteoak@gmail.com.

Source: NC Cultural Resources
