title: Public Art Plaza at the Erwin Center Shining a Spotlight on Highland's People, Places, and Events Ribbon Cutting Ceremony
description:
Highland Neighborhood Association is pleased to announce a public art dedication, taking place on Sunday, February 22, 2026 at 3pm, located at the Erwin Center, 913 N. Pryor Street, Gastonia NC. This artwork shines a spotlight on the remarkable people, places and stories of the Highland Community.

Members of the Highland Community worked with nationally celebrated public artist David Wilson, and local artists Pamela Underwood and Tykevious McDowell, to gather oral histories and images that tell the story of Highland through the eyes of those who live and work here. In addition to the notable people and places highlighted by the artwork (including artists John Biggers and Jim Biggers, athletes Sleepy Floyd and James Worthy, Highland High School, Big Daddy's, and the Elks Lodge), are everyday folks, charitable organizations, and businesses, who together make up the fabric of this vibrant community.

This artwork will also have a digital component managed by Gaston County Museum of Art, with ongoing contributions from volunteers, community members, and Highland School of Technology students, to assure the piece continues to educate into the future.

Special thanks to members of Highland Neighborhood Association, The City of Gastonia, Erwin Center Park Staff, Project Manager Carl Harris, Gaston County Museum of Art and History, Highland School of Technology, and Kintegra Health for their partnership and support in managing and completing this project — the largest and most significant piece of public art in Gaston County. Funding for this project was provided by the Z. Smith Reynolds Foundation through its Inclusive Public Art initiative.

The dedication event is open to the public and all are welcome.

For more information, contact Donyel Barber at dbarber@kintegra.org.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Indivisible – A One-Man Performance by Dr. Sonny Kelly
location: The William and Ida Friday Center at UNC-Chapel Hill
description:
“… one nation, under God, indivisible, with liberty and justice for all.”

 

In this compelling and interactive presentation, scholar and playwright Dr. Sonny Kelly weaves together storytelling, lecture, poetry, and dramatic interpretation to confront the painful and persistent legacies that continue to shape American life.This free public event takes place on Sunday, February 22, 2026 from 3:00 p.m. to 5:00 p.m. at The Friday Center, 100 Friday Center Dr. in Chapel Hill; registration is required.

 

Tracing a powerful thread from the colonial era to the present day, Dr. Kelly brings to life pivotal figures such as Crispus Attucks, Frederick Douglass, and Fred Hampton, illuminating how their struggles and leadership speak directly to the divisions we face today. With insight and urgency, he asks the central questions: How did we get where we are, and what can history teach us about where we go next?

 

Indivisible reveals a too-often overlooked American story – one marked not only by oppression, but by enduring hope, resilience, and the pursuit of unity. This is a story that challenges us to listen deeply, reflect honestly, and take up the baton from past leaders to help build a more just and indivisible nation.

 

More than a performance, Indivisible is an experience. Dr. Sonny Kelly embodies 20 distinct characters, guiding audiences through unforgettable stories that span generations. With an exceptional ability to connect, educate, and inspire, Dr. Kelly invites audiences into a safe and courageous space – one that encourages honest engagement with difficult truths, exploration of shared humanity, and the pursuit of healing and unity.




Indivisible offers audiences an experience that:

Brings American history vividly to life through interactive theater, storytelling, and dramatic interpretation.Illuminates overlooked voices and pivotal figures whose legacies shaped…and continue to shape our nation’s story.Encourages reflection and dialogue about unity, division, and the meaning of justice in America today.Engages both heart and mind, blending scholarship with powerful live performance.Inspires hope, resilience, and connection across generations and communities.Creates a welcoming space for thoughtful community conversation.Join us for an insightful, moving, and inspiring Black History Month experience.
Registration is required to attend. Event is free and open to the public, and recommended for school grades 3 and up/ages 10 and up.

 

Campus Life Experience (CLE) credits are available to UNC students via https://heellife.unc.edu/

title: Crafting the American Story
description:
In honor of the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence the City of Southport, the Fort Johnston-Southport Museum & Visitors’ Center, and the Brunswick Arts Council invite the community to explore how art, identity, and history intertwine throughout our collective American experience.

Crafting the American Story: Art, Identity, & History celebrates the boundless creativity of Americans—past and present—while recognizing the power of artistic expression to shape, reflect, and challenge our collective narrative.

This exhibition will showcase the creativity of Brunswick County artists while exploring how art reflects and interprets our nation’s history. Through the graphic arts, sculpture and handcrafts, visitors will encounter works that engage with themes of resilience, cultural identity, and the diverse perspectives that enrich our shared story.

What You’ll Discover

The exhibition highlights how creativity has shaped and been shaped by American history over the past 250 years. From responses to adversity and change, to celebrations of cultural heritage, the works on display will show how art captures, or was influenced by, the complexity of the American experience.

The show invites both artists and audiences to reflect on:

How historical events inspire creative expressionThe power of art and handicraft as a storytelling mediumThe inclusion of perspectives often missing from familiar narrativesThe ways resilience, identity, and innovation converge to shape our futureAs part of the program, America 250 NC will present a One Day Wonder traveling exhibit “To Preserve the Blessings of Liberty: State Constitutions of North Carolina.” Featuring copies of the 1776 State Constitution and Declaration of Rights, the 1868 State Constitution, and a letter from John Adams known as “Thoughts on Government,” the exhibit explores North Carolina’s three state constitutions and key amendments, examining how they reshaped ideas of citizenship and expanded, or restricted, participation in the state’s political life. This exhibit will be available for a limited time on opening day only.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: QGIS and GRASS Open-Source GIS
description:
This is a three-part, hands-on GIS course. No previous GIS experience is required. The first session on Monday will be a general overview and introduction to the benefits of Open Source GIS in general, to QGIS in specific, and will include our first hands-on session with QGIS. Topics to be covered include: the QGIS user interface, loading vector and raster files, QGIS plug-ins, web mapping functions, QGIS data manipulation, icons and pull-down tools, basic data manipulation, working with attribute tables, and general familiarity with QGIS. 

Part 2 on Wednesday will continue our work with QGIS, including using the vector, raster, and web analysis functions, using the print composer.  We will also cover the QGIS website, tutorials, listserv, discussion groups, sources of help, etc. 

Part 3 on Friday will focus on the GRASS GIS and other advanced tools available through the QGIS Processing Toolbox within the QGIS interface. Topics covered will include the GRASS vector and raster data formats, GRASS vector, raster, and imagery analysis, GRASS 3-D data (voxels), the raster map calculator, the print composer, and other GRASS capabilities. You can attend just the first, first two, or all dates.

 

Laptops are required for this course, no computers are in the room. Students should download QGIS (www.qgis.org) before the class, and will download the sample data and tutorials (QGIS includes a current version of GRASS) at the start of the class. QGIS runs on Windows, Mac, and Linux systems. At the end of the course, students will have a general ability to use QGIS and GRASS, and can continue learning on their own using the data and tutorials provided.

 

It is highly recommended to bring your power cords, extension cord, and/or powerstrips for your laptops. Come early if you need assistance loading QGIS. Feel free to contact the instructor at: madrys@email.unc.edu

 

This workshop is offered by the University Libraries and will be led by Dr. Scott Madry, with support from library staff, Gracie Riehm and Philip McDaniel. 

 

NOTE: This workshop will be held in-person ONLY in Davis Library, room 246. Space is limited. Please register in advance on the University Libraries calendar: https://calendar.lib.unc.edu/event/16023034

title: Version Control with Git and GitHub
description:
In this course, participants will learn how to keep track of the code they use in their research using the version control system Git and the collaboration platform GitHub. Git allows you to keep track of changes to your code, easily revert to previous versions, and “tag” versions of code used in publications so that the exact code used can be retrieved at a later date. GitHub allows Git users to collaborate with each other on projects by managing simultaneous changes to the same files and allowing users to review and discuss each others’ code. Git and Github are applicable to any text-based programming or analysis language, including R, Python, Stata, Julia, and others.

This course is a prerequisite for the “Modular Design and Automated Testing with R” course in April.

title: Understanding and Improving Garden Soils: A Deeper Look
description:
Healthy plants start with healthy soil, but what is healthy soil, and how can you build it in your own garden? This course will take you below the surface to explore the science and structure that make soils thrive. By delving into the chemistry, the biology and the physics that drive soil health and fertility, you’ll gain the tools you need to cultivate a richer, more resilient garden from the ground up.

In this expanded five-week course, we’ll take a closer look at the essential principles of soil science and how to apply them in practical, gardener-friendly ways. You’ll explore how soils behave — how texture, structure and compaction influence water movement, aeration and root growth — and gain practical tips on sampling and assessing your soil so you know what you’re working with. Along the way, we’ll connect these principles to soil fertility and plant nutrition, exploring how nutrients move through the soil, how fertilizers work and how to feed your plants effectively without overdoing it.

Whether you’re troubleshooting problem areas, establishing new garden beds or simply eager to understand what’s happening beneath your feet, this course will equip you with the knowledge and confidence to build better soils and grow stronger, more resilient plants.

Source: NC State University

title: Ackland Film Forum: “Aftersun” (Charlotte Wells, 2022)
description:
Set during a modest holiday at a Turkish resort in the early 2000s, Aftersun approaches coming of age obliquely, through memory and retrospection. Stunningly shot on 35mm film, which is contrasted with mini DV home movie video footage, the plot follows young Sophie (Frankie Corio) and her father Calum (Paul Mescal). But it is the adult Sophie’s somber attempt to reconstruct this formative trip that gives the story its emotional charge. Coming of age here is not marked by clear lessons or dramatic turning points, but by the gradual, dawning recognition of a parent’s fragility—and of the limits of childhood understanding. 
  
The film will be introduced by Rick Warner, Bowman and Gordon Gray Distinguished Term Professor and Director of Film Studies. 
  
This film will be screened at 7:30 p.m. at the Chelsea Theater, 1129 Weaver Dairy Road, Suite AB, Chapel Hill, NC 27514. Click here for more information on theater pricing; tickets are free for UNC-Chapel Hill students. UNC-Chapel Hill students can receive CLE credit for attending by scanning the QR code at the event. 
  
About the Series:
Join the Ackland Film Forum this spring for Growing Up, Looking Back, a series that accompanies the Ackland exhibition Bill Bamberger: Boys Will Be Men. This semester’s series highlights the filmgoing experience by using three local movie theaters as its venues. 
The Ackland Film Forum is co-organized by the Ackland Art Museum and UNC Film Studies, housed in the UNC-Chapel Hill Department of English and Comparative Literature.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: High Country Wild Chartering Ceremony (Blowing Rock)
description:
High Country Wild is one of NCWF’s newest Community Wildlife Chapters. The chapter protects, conserves, and restores wildlife and habitat in Ashe and Watauga County. The chapter brings the local community together with opportunities to restore habitat, connect with nature, and learn about important wildlife and habitat topics in the region. 
Join us as we get together for a fun evening to celebrate and officially launch the new Chapter. This is an opportunity to learn more about High Country Wild, meet NCWF staff and local chapter leaders, and get involved with conservation at the grassroots level. Drinks will be available alongside plenty of snacks. Bring your ideas, curiosity, and maybe a few random wildlife facts. All are welcome! Space is limited so please sign up now. 
Big thanks to Blue Ridge Conservancy for letting us use their amazing conservation campus as our venue. 
REGISTER HERE

Source: NC Wildlife Federation

title: Civic Hacking for Affordable Housing
description:
Code with the Carolinas - Triangle
Join volunteers at Code with the Carolinas as we help the [National Zoning Atlas](https://www.zoningatlas.org/) (NZA) team include North Carolina and South Carolina in their nationwide zoning atlas. "The National Zoning Atlas aims to depict key aspects of zoning codes in an online, user-friendly map." The Atlas aims to provide data for better solutions in transportation, environmental, and especially affordable housing policy.

Affordable housing proponents have long recognized zoning policies as barriers to affordable housing. To improve zoning policies, we first need to better understand the current state of zoning across the United States. Code with the Carolinas is helping this cause by joining the National Zoning Atlas to gather zoning data for North and South Carolina.

This is a multi-dimensional project grounded in data science with an end-goal of contributing to a nationally influential dataset. Our current work session activities focus on internet search and integrating data from multiple sources. The project as a whole has occasional opportunities for U/X and outreach and opportunities to learn about machine learning and natural language processing through the work of the NZA team. Volunteering on this project will provide excellent exposure to the foundations of civic data science, with a focus on GIS data.

Even if you're new to this project and/or civic tech volunteering, you're welcome to join the meeting. Visitors are always welcome and no technical skills are needed. You can learn more about the project on our [Slack Workspace](https://join.slack.com/t/codeforthecarolinas/shared_invite/zt-1kxuwu05x-3KxOpkOYjAuN5yuOAH8ROg) in the #project-zoning-atlas channel.

Meetings start with brief introductions. New volunteers are offered a personal orientation, often in a breakout room, while experienced volunteers get right to work. By the end of the session, both groups of volunteers are working together. We also contribute to the project through asynchronous work and informal work sessions.

Meetings are on the Jitsi platform and the link is provided before each meeting. If you will be joining on mobile, install the Jitsi app in advance [https://jitsi.org/downloads/](https://jitsi.org/downloads/) .

Learn more at [codewiththecarolinas.org](codeforthecarolinas.org) or reach out to info@codewiththecarolinas.org

All activities of Code with the Carolinas, a project of [Social Good Fund](https://www.socialgoodfund.org/), follow our [Code of Conduct](https://share.mailbox.org/ajax/share/0d32d5f905f8fd49d5e80395f8fd47f2b59ce3ef8b335f72/1/8/Nzg/NzgvMTkx) and are subject to this [Volunteer Waiver of Liability](https://share.mailbox.org/ajax/share/06dd62200e6b28426b137e0e6b2848fb901487014f72cd16/1/8/Nzg/NzgvMTE2).

Source: Meetup: Code with the Carolinas

title: Weekly Game Night!
description:
Durham Geeks
We meet at Moon Dog Meadery under Joe Van Gogh on Broad Street every Monday night. We have loads of games (some belong to MoonDog, some are brought by attendees), a fun and welcoming group of folks (always eager to have more, however!), and there are always folks eager to teach games to those who haven't played certain titles.

Moondog has a growing collection of canned and bottled brews, ciders, and colas in addition to their in-house-brewed meads. There are also some snacks like chips and popcorn. Sometimes, folks bring in other treats to share. If you do, please mark them as containing any common allergens.

Outside food (delivered, brought in, or homemade) is welcomed and encouraged. Outside drinks are not. Since the venue does not prepare food, **dogs are allowed and welcomed.** (Dogs are very friendly and welcoming, too, but they mostly roam around to collect ear scritches and love. If you're not comfortable with dogs around, let us know, and we'll try to accommodate.)

Bring games, friends, and a welcoming spirit. We're excited to have you with us!

Source: Meetup: Durham Geeks

title: Education in Motion: Amplify, Accelerate, Catalyze
description:
Join a dynamic gathering of education leaders, innovators and change makers to shape the future of research, policy and practice. The William and Ida Friday Institute for Educational Innovation is hosting the first annual Education in Motion Summit: Amplify, Accelerate, Catalyze of education partners working in similar spaces: centers, institutes, nonprofit organizations and more.

Source: NC State University

title: Africa to Carolina Exhibit at Somerset Place
description:
February 1st marks the start of #BlackHistoryMonth! To commemorate the African diaspora and the impact Black culture has made on United States history, we will re-open our Africa to Carolina exhibit to the public. The Africa to Carolina initiative serves to identify, acknowledge, and mark each site in the state where enslaved Africans disembarked directly from the African Continent. In our self-guided exhibit, visitors can learn about the experiences of enslaved Africans who survived the Atlantic slave trade to North Carolina. Stop by the visitor center for free admission into the exhibit.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Invasive Species Awareness Week
description:
Interested in knowing about what kinds of invasive species we have at Hanging Rock State Park? Well, swing by our Visitor Center and browse through information our park staff have put together on species like the woolly adelgid or the infamous kudzu that we try to actively treat here at the park. Understand the importance of reducing the spread of invasive species and how you may be able to play a role. For questions, reach out to Ranger Fields at Jacob.fields@ncparks.gov

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Community Living in North Carolina: Strengthening support systems for older adults and adults with disabilities
description:
Thanks to funding by NC Money Follows the Person, four organizations within North Carolina have developed programs aimed at supporting older adults and adults with disabilities in the state. These programs address four main barriers impacting North Carolina’s older adults and adults with disabilities: limited availability of housing, transportation, and Direct Support Workers, and the need for Natural Supports. We look forward to discussing the progress and impact these programs have made in their communities.

Presenters:

Linda Kendall Fields, M.Ed, Director and Principal Investigator, Cares
Tracy Pakornsawat, Professional Development Consultant with DHHS, NC Money Follows the Person

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: UNC School of Nursing Mobile Health Clinic: Celebrating 10 Years of Community Engagement
description:
Established in 2016, the UNC School of Nursing (SON) Mobile Health Clinic (MHC) is a nurse-led, free clinic providing health screenings, patient education, and referrals to community resources. The clinic is operated by SON faculty, inter-professional students, and community volunteers, addressing gaps in healthcare for vulnerable populations. The MHC has been awarded the Gold Seal for quality care by the National Association of Free and Charitable Clinics. The upcoming showcase will feature a panel presentation on the clinic’s history, strategic partnerships, outreach initiatives, and its measurable impact on community health and students’ learning. The panel discussion will be followed by an optional virtual tour of the clinic and adjacent community resources.

Presenters:

Marianne Cockroft, PhD, RN, Associate Professor Emerita, UNC SON, Founding Director of UNC SON Mobile Health ClinicJean Davison, DNP, FNP-BC, FAAN, Professor, UNC SON, Medical Director of UNC SON Mobile Health ClinicAndre Anthony, CEO, NeighborUp (Community Partner)Johanne Laboy, PhD, Adjunct Assistant Professor, UNC SONRebecca Hankins, Director of Development and Communication, CORA Food PantryCatherine Parrish, BSN, Graduate Student

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: PSSA 3: Building a Trauma-Informed Practice for Faculty and Staff
description:
Building a Trauma-Informed Practice for Faculty and Staff is the third workshop in the Pack Survivor Support Alliance, or PSSA, series offered by the Women's Center. The workshop provides a deep dive into understanding the impacts trauma can have on students’ physical, emotional and psychological well-being. This workshop will cover concepts including the neurobiology of trauma, trauma responses and stages of recovery for survivors of interpersonal violence. Using these concepts, faculty and staff will explore what it means to create a trauma-informed practice and how to implement it in their relationships with students and co-workers and in their departments.

Source: NC State University

title: Crafting the American Story
description:
In honor of the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence the City of Southport, the Fort Johnston-Southport Museum & Visitors’ Center, and the Brunswick Arts Council invite the community to explore how art, identity, and history intertwine throughout our collective American experience.

Crafting the American Story: Art, Identity, & History celebrates the boundless creativity of Americans—past and present—while recognizing the power of artistic expression to shape, reflect, and challenge our collective narrative.

This exhibition will showcase the creativity of Brunswick County artists while exploring how art reflects and interprets our nation’s history. Through the graphic arts, sculpture and handcrafts, visitors will encounter works that engage with themes of resilience, cultural identity, and the diverse perspectives that enrich our shared story.

What You’ll Discover

The exhibition highlights how creativity has shaped and been shaped by American history over the past 250 years. From responses to adversity and change, to celebrations of cultural heritage, the works on display will show how art captures, or was influenced by, the complexity of the American experience.

The show invites both artists and audiences to reflect on:

How historical events inspire creative expressionThe power of art and handicraft as a storytelling mediumThe inclusion of perspectives often missing from familiar narrativesThe ways resilience, identity, and innovation converge to shape our futureAs part of the program, America 250 NC will present a One Day Wonder traveling exhibit “To Preserve the Blessings of Liberty: State Constitutions of North Carolina.” Featuring copies of the 1776 State Constitution and Declaration of Rights, the 1868 State Constitution, and a letter from John Adams known as “Thoughts on Government,” the exhibit explores North Carolina’s three state constitutions and key amendments, examining how they reshaped ideas of citizenship and expanded, or restricted, participation in the state’s political life. This exhibit will be available for a limited time on opening day only.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Founding Fathers at Latimer House
description:
Historic Latimer House will proudly participate in the America 250 First in Freedom Festival as an official Passport Stamp Cancellation Site, offering visitors a unique opportunity to engage with the nation’s founding history during the festival week, February 21–28.

For one week only, Latimer House will present an extraordinary public viewing of original documents from three Founding Fathers—George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, and James Madison. These rare and significant items are part of the archive of the Lower Cape Fear Historical Society, which is celebrating 70 years of historic preservation work in the region.

In recognition of service, active-duty and veteran military members will receive free admission with valid ID throughout the festival week. Limited tickets are available online at the Latimer House website.

The America 250 First in Freedom Festival commemorates the events and ideals that led to American independence, and Latimer House’s participation highlights the enduring relevance of original historical documents and preservation efforts.

For history enthusiasts, families, students, and visitors alike, Latimer House’s festival programming offers a rare chance to connect directly with the words and legacy of the nation’s founders—available for one week only.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: NC First in Freedom Festival
description:
In 2026 the inaugural North Carolina First in Freedom Festival, taking place throughout Southeastern NC during the week of February 21-28, 2026 (10:00 AM - 4:00 PM), will celebrate more than 250 years of our Nation’s story and culture viewed through the lens of historical North Carolina events and the arts. Please visit the NC FIFF website to see the planned activities: 

https://www.ncfirstinfreedomfestival.com/

Funded in part by an America 250 NC grant, a program of the NC Department of Natural and Cultural Resources.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: New Faculty Research Orientation
description:
The Office of Research and Innovation (ORI) invites new NC State faculty engaged in research and scholarship to register for the New Faculty Research Orientation. Come build connections, forge new partnerships and gain direct access to research-focused resources available across ORI and our key partners. 

Registration is required to attend.

Source: NC State University

title: Government Affairs Committee - Apex Chief of Police, Ryan Johansen
description:
Our special guest speaker is Apex Police Chief Ryan Johansen, who will discuss his first year on the job and the department's plans for 2026. Be a part of the conversation!

Source: Apex Chamber of Commerce

title: Celebrate Every BODY
description:
This interactive event will empower participants to celebrate and embrace self-love and self-compassion, educate them about eating disorders and include awesome giveaways.

To learn more about eating disorders, check out the National Eating Disorders Association website.

Source: NC State University

title: LEAD Event: Overcoming Your Distorted Negative Thinking
description:
Have you had an argument with your spouse or significant other that impacted your whole day? Maybe you had thoughts like, “I’m such a jerk,” or, “All we do is fight.” Have you ever been stuck in traffic thanks to an accident? Maybe you said to yourself, “I knew I shouldn’t have gone this way,” or “This always happens to me.” Statements like these are common reactions to scenarios in our lives, but they are inaccurate and distort how we see ourselves and the world around us. This session will examine the 10 cognitive distortions and how they impact our mood and create faulty beliefs about ourselves and the world around us. Join Learning and Organizational Development for a session where we will examine these distortions and identify ways to challenge negative thoughts and limit their impact on our lives.

This workshop is part of L&OD's LEAD Events, an initiative that provides employees with opportunities to learn or refresh skills that can help them grow their careers. LEAD Events are a component of L&OD's Leadership Education and Development, or LEAD, program.

Source: NC State University

title: Sightseeing Tours
description:
Cape Fear Riverboats is excited to announce February Sightseeing Tours for 2026 in support of the North Carolina First in Freedom Festival. For over 35 years, Cape Fear Riverboats has operated captain-narrated Sightseeing & Sunset Tours from downtown Wilmington which is TripAdvisors' Top Destination on the Rise for 2024. Daily tours onboard our current vessels, Henrietta and Osprey, highlight the area's history, legends, and charm, weaving over 400 years of history from the area's founding by English settlers all the way to modern times. For Group or Charter inquiries, please contact sales@capefearriverboats.com. For Public Tour or Sunset tickets, please visit https://capefearriverboats.com/ or call 910-613-9822.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Faculty and Staff Walking Club
description:
Join your colleagues for a lovely walk down to the NC State greenway. We'll meet outside the Starbucks at Talley Student Union and walk down the greenway to Pullen Park and back. The route is approximately 1.4 miles. All are welcome to participate.

Source: NC State University

title: Rainbow Reading Group: Song in A Weary Throat by Pauli Murray
description:
The African American Cultural Center, LGBTQ Pride Center, Women's Center, Multicultural Student Affairs and the NC State Libraries have joined together to host a semester-long book club. The club will read and discuss the award-winning book, Song In a Weary Throat by Pauli Murray, throughout the spring semester. A different student success center will host each month's book club session. The book club will visit the Pauli Murray Center.

The first 20 people to sign up for the book club will receive a free book and reading kit curated by the African American Cultural Center Library, Multicultural Students Affairs, the Women’s Center, the LGBTQ Pride Center and the NC State Libraries.

The book club sessions will take place:

Jan. 22 from noon to 2 p.m. in the LGBTQ Pride Center at Talley Student UnionJoin us for a meet and greet and introduction to Song in a Weary Throat.Feb. 5 from noon to 2 p.m. in the African Cultural Center Library at the Witherspoon Student CenterWe will discuss chapters 1-3 and 7 and 8.Feb. 24 from noon to 2 p.m. in Multicultural Student Affairs at Talley Student UnionWe will discuss chapters 9, 11, 15, 16 and 19.March 24 from noon to 2 p.m. in the Women’s Center at Talley Student UnionWe will discuss chapters 20-22, 24-25 and 26. April 7 from noon to 2 p.m. in the Fishbowl at D.H. Hill LibraryWe will discuss chapters 27, 29-30 and 34.

Source: NC State University

title: Moving Forward Together: Building Resilience of Small Businesses and Communities
description:
This drop-in style event explores how NCGrowth is building an economy with opportunities for all to prosper by building resilience of small businesses and communities. The event will feature a panel discussion and informal networking tables highlighting the community-based work of NCGrowth and the Kenan Institute for Private Enterprise.

12-1pm Panel Discussion with representatives of Winston-Salem State University, Manolo’s Bakery, Freedom Org, and other NCGrowth clients1-2pm Lunch and NetworkingContact: Carolyn Fryberger, Associate Director of Economic Development, Carolyn_fryberger@unc.edu

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Free Yoga
location: Partners I – NC State University, Suite 2580
description:
Take a break from your day and enjoy a free yoga class on Centennial Campus. Classes are held every weekday, except when the university is closed, from 12:15 to 1:05 p.m. The classes are open to everyone, and registration is not required. Please bring your own mat.

Source: NC State University

title: Grief Walk
location: North Carolina Museum of Art, 2110 Blue Ridge Rd, Raleigh, 27607, United States
description:
Join us as we seek comfort in nature and connection with others as we walk the paths at the Museum Park at the North Carolina Museum of Art. 
Note: The Park paths are paved with slight inclines. Please leave pets at home. You are welcome to attend some or all of the walking sessions.

February 10 and 24
March 10 and 24

title: ERSP: Untitled Hike
location: Eno River State Park, 6101 Cole Mill Rd, Durham, NC 27705, USA
description:
Eno River State Park & Occoneechee Mountain State Natural Area programs are free but have limited space.  
Call or email to sign up!  
(984) 250-1370 | eno.river@ncparks.gov

Join a Ranger to hike 3 miles round trip to the site of a cemetery of enslaved people. We will discuss laws and statistics related to the practice of slavery in NC. This hike features discussions about racial violence and content that is more suited to a mature audience. Please attend with a respectful attitude and be prepared for a significant creek crossing and some short sections of off-trail hiking. Source: Eno River Association

title: Fort Macon Daily Tours – 1:00 p.m.
description:
Guided tours of Fort Macon are available daily at 1:00 p.m. during the Park's slower season between mid Oct. and Mid April.

The tours will last about 45 minutes.

Meet at the fort entrance. Pets are not allowed inside the fort.

 

Photo by C. Peek: The fort at Fort Macon State Park

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Tableau I
description:
Tableau is a user-friendly software application used to create static or interactive visualizations and dashboards. Examples can be found on Tableau Public. 

 

Tableau’s drag-and-drop interface provides tools to build a variety of visualizations with no coding required, and visualizations can be embedded in websites by copying and pasting embed code. Attendees will get started with Tableau in this hands on workshop by learning how to import data, create basic charts and maps, make and publish dashboards, and more!

 

This session requires you to have access to Tableau. Please follow the instructions here to download and install Tableau. If you are unable to install the software, please contact Lorin Bruckner for assistance.

 

This workshop is offered by University Libraries and will be led by librarian Lorin Bruckner.

 

This workshop is being offered remotely via Zoom only. Registrants will receive a Zoom link; those on the waitlist will not receive a Zoom link unless they are bumped up to a registered spot. After the workshop, registrants and those on the waitlist will receive a link to the workshop recording. You can register on the University Libraries calendar: https://calendar.lib.unc.edu/event/16021557

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: The New NIH Public Access Policy: What You Need to Know
description:
The 2024 NIH Public Access Policy includes several significant changes from the previous policy, and applies to all NIH-funded manuscripts accepted for publication on or after July 1, 2025. Learn more about what has changed, how to comply, and what to expect going forward.

 

This workshop is offered by the UNC Health Sciences Library and the Scholarly Communications Office, and led by Collin Drummond and Katherine Howell.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Junior Ranger Hike
description:
Hike with Ranger Marissa on the Maple Run Trail to participate in Junior Ranger activities and earn a Junior Ranger patch! The hike will be about 0.5 miles long on easy terrain. This program is great for younger children and home-school groups looking to get outside. All materials will be provided. Meet at the Park Office to begin.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Lunch and Learn: The Missing Link: Adding Your Data to Your App
description:
All Things AI (Live)
So you vibe-coded a front-end app—now what? Building a sleek interface is only half the battle. The real magic happens when your data starts moving.

In this session, we'll turn static interfaces into powerful automated tools by connecting front-end platforms like Softr and Zoho Forms to [Make.com](http://Make.com). You'll learn how to capture data instantly with webhooks, map information so it lands exactly where it needs to be, and build multi-step workflows that trigger emails, update CRMs, or generate documents the moment a form is submitted.

You'll learn how to power our app with these no-code tactics.

* **Webhooks & Triggers:** How to capture data instantly as users interact with your apps.
* **Data Mapping:** Ensuring information from your forms lands exactly where it needs to be.
* **Beyond the Entry:** Strategies for building multi-step workflows that trigger emails, update CRMs, or generate documents immediately after a form submission.

Whether you're building a client portal or a lead generation engine, you'll leave with a blueprint for seamless flow between your users and your tech stack.

Source: Meetup: All Things AI

title: Concise Communication
description:
Do people say that your communication style is too wordy? If so, join the Graduate School for Concise Communication, formerly Concise Writing. This interactive workshop will address the challenge of building clear, concise sentences that represent your science to diverse stakeholders. Using Richard Lanham’s famous “Paramedic Method” and other approaches, participants will leave the session with strategies for user-friendly sentences in reports and other areas of workplace communication.

Source: NC State University

title: Collaborative Approaches to Improving the Legal Landscape for Survivors of Gender-Based Violence in NC
location: The Frank Porter Graham Student Union, 3411
description:
Join the Carolina Women’s Center for a panel discussion highlighting the work of campus and community members in navigating and shaping North Carolina’s legal landscape. This event will showcase collaborations among UNC faculty, law students, government agencies, nonprofits, and legal service providers who provide support and resources to those impacted by gender-based violence.

Presenters:

Shelley Kennedy, Assistant Director, Carolina Women’s CenterKathleen Lockwood, Victim Services Manager, NC Department of JusticeBeth Posner, Clinical Professor of Law and Director of the Family Defense Clinic, UNC School of LawRegister HERE to attend. https://uncch.givepulse.com/event/820765

 

To view other Carolina Engagement Week events, visit our website.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Goldston America 250 Film Series
description:
Join the Chatham Community Library for this Goldston America 250 Film Series, hosted every fourth Tuesday, January-December 2026, 4pm-6pm. America 250’s mission is to honor and commemorate the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence, marking America’s Semiquincentennial. The Goldston Library will screen the following documentaries and films:

Tue, Jan 27, 4pm-6pm The Congress, Ken Burns.
Tue, Feb 24, 4pm-6pm Becoming Frederick Douglass, Stanley Nelson and Nicole London.
Tue, Mar 24, 4pm-6pm Rachel Carson: The Woman Who Launched the Modern Environmental Movement, Michelle Ferrari.
Tue, Apr 28, 4pm-6pm Thomas Jefferson: A View from the Mountain, Martin Doblmeier.
Tue, May 26, 4pm-6pm The Address, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jun 23, 4pm-6pm The Brooklyn Bridge, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jul 28, 4pm-6pm The Statue of Liberty, Ken Burns.
Tue, Aug 25, 4pm-6pm American Coup: Wilmington 1898, Yoruba Richen and Brad Lichtenstein.
Tue, Sep 22, 4pm-6pm How it Feels to be Free, Yoruba Richen.
Tue, Oct 27, 4pm-6pm 80 Years Later, Celine Parreñas Shimizu.
Tue, Nov 24, 4pm-6pm Gather, Sanjay Rawal.
Tue, Dec 22, 4pm-6pm Women of World War II: The Untold Stories, Eli Brown.

This FREE, family-friendly event is open to the public. No registration is required. The event will take place indoors in the Goldston Library. The Goldston Library is ADA-compliant, including wheelchair-accessible parking, entrances, seating, common spaces, walkways, and restrooms. Free parking is available outside the library. Pets are not allowed - please leave your furry friends at home.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: HOPE Seekers: A Peer-Led Approach to Youth Mental Wellness
location: The Frank Porter Graham Student Union, 3411
description:
Mental health challenges among underrepresented youth are increasingly prevalent, often exacerbated by systemic inequities and a lack of culturally responsive support. The Honoring Our Power and Emotions (HOPE Seekers) Program, developed in collaboration by The Resiliency Collaborative (TRC) and UNC Gillings School of Public Health, is a peer-led initiative designed to empower youth with mental health strategies while fostering leadership and a deep commitment to belonging, equity, and inclusion. This session will explore the ways in which trauma-sensitive practices, social-emotional learning, and peer-to-peer facilitation models can create safe, supportive environments for students.

Presenters: 

Kelsey Lam, Director of Youth Programs, The Resiliency CollaborativeDr. Caroline Chandler, Assistant Professor, UNC Gillings School of Public Health: Department of Maternal and Child HealthKirsten Novilla, Graduate Research Assistant, UNC Gillings School of Public HealthNicolette Rojas, Graduate Research Assistant, UNC Gillings School of Public HealthRegister HERE to attend. https://uncch.givepulse.com/event/821931

 

To view other Carolina Engagement Week events, visit our website.

Carolina Engagement Week is co-hosted by Carolina Across 100, the Carolina Center for Public Service, the Carolina Engagement Council, the Center for Thriving Communities, NCGrowth, ncIMPACT and UNC Rural.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: CHASS Global Coffee
description:
The College of Humanities and Social Sciences invites international and domestic students to come enjoy coffee and cookies and to learn about the college and high-impact experiences. You'll also learn about the college's commitment to global impact.

Participants will also be guided through icebreaker questions during 15-minute conversation rounds. After each round, groups will rotate, giving everyone a chance to meet and connect with new people throughout the event.

Source: NC State University

title: The Social Wellness Pop-Up: Matcha Mixer
description:
Join Wellness and Recreation for the February Social Wellness Pop-Up and to celebrate National Heart Month. Come mix and customize your own delicious, heart-healthy matcha drink while socializing with fellow students. It’s the perfect way to unwind, learn something new and nourish your body and mind.

Source: NC State University

title: Forgotten Heroes: Remembering North Carolina’s Black Patriots of the Revolutionary War (An A250 Event)
description:
Uncover the stories of Black North Carolinians who fought for American independence, including those with ties to the Wilmington area. During the American War for Independence, more than 400 Black and multiracial soldiers from North Carolina fought for their young country and state in military roles. As we celebrate the 250th anniversary of the country they helped to establish, we invite you to join us onboard the Battleship North Carolina to learn more about their often-forgotten stories. Presented as part of America 250 by Trevor Freeman, Museum Educator, Battleship North Carolina Memorial.

Tuesday, February 24, 2026, from 5:30 - 6:30 pm
Battleship North Carolina Memorial, 1 Battleship Road, Wilmington, NC
$5 for in-person attendance with advance online registration
$5 for livestream attendance
$8 at the door, as space allows

Space is limited! To reserve your spot, visit http://bit.ly/forgottenheroesNC

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Night Sky with the Naked Eye
description:
Join a ranger after dark to explore the night skies with only using your eyes! Many of our planets are visible this month. You will get a chance to learn about some of the planets and constellations that will be lighting up our night sky. Program is weather dependent. Contact park office for program update: 910-326-4881. Meet at the Visitor Center.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Solving Sustainability Live Podcast: Solving Solar
location: Partners I – NC State University, Raleigh Founded (Suite 1650)
description:
Solving Sustainability is a live interdisciplinary podcast that seeks to raise awareness about macro-level sustainability challenges and innovations while fostering meaningful discussion between students, researchers, entrepreneurs and policymakers.

During the episode, the podcast will seek to engage NC State community members — students alongside interested faculty and staff — who have experience within sustainability but may not have a deep understanding of environmental justice. The podcast is not just an entertaining way to seek solutions but also a call to action and a way to connect with others.

This event will take place in the Raleigh Founded cafe on Centennial Campus. Hors d'oeuvres will be available for all attendees.

Source: NC State University

title: Marian Cheek Jackson Center: Abundance-based Community Development Workshop
location: The Frank Porter Graham Student Union, 3411
description:
When working in a historically underserved community, it can be easy to focus on what collective needs go unmet, what resources are unavailable, and the hardships people experience on a daily basis. But how does this focus affect your attitude, your approach to dialogue and collaboration, and your strategy development? Explore this question with the Marian Cheek Jackson Center, a hub of creative action for Chapel Hill and Carrboro’s historically Black neighborhoods.

The Abundance-based Community Development workshop invites you to think about rhetorical and strategic frameworks in the context of community empowerment. Read varying narratives of the Northside neighborhood, considering what kind of rhetoric moves you to work creatively. Listen to local, Black oral histories and notice the ways they affect you. Imagine the impact of building relationships and uplifting your community’s existing power.

Presenter(s): 

Renna Voss, Student Engagement and Food Justice Fellow, The Marian Cheek Jackson Center for Saving and Making HistoryRegister HERE to attend. https://uncch.givepulse.com/event/822674

 

To view other Carolina Engagement Week events, visit our website. Carolina Engagement Week is co-hosted by Carolina Across 100, the Carolina Center for Public Service, the Carolina Engagement Council, the Center for Thriving Communities, NCGrowth, ncIMPACT and UNC Rural.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: New book event: History professor W. Fitzhugh Brundage
description:
W. Fitzhugh Brundage, William B. Umstead Distinguished Professor of History, will discuss his new book, "A Fate Worse than Hell: American Prisoners of the Civil War," on Tuesday, Feb. 24 at 6 p.m. at Flyleaf Books in Chapel Hill. A book-signing at 5:30 p.m. will precede the event.

 

It is newly estimated that 750,000 soldiers died in the American Civil War. But less well-known than the war’s death toll are the roughly 400,000 Union and Confederate troops who were captured and imprisoned. Many POWs died from starvation, dysentery, and exposure, and at the worst of the prison pens, more than 30,000 soldiers were caged in the equivalent of ten city block. "Fate Worse than Hell" contemplates the roots and consequences of this mass incarceration from America’s bloodiest conflict.

 

Brundage will discuss the book with David Blight, Sterling Professor of History at Yale University.

 

Register at the Flyleaf Books link.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: UNC Postdoctoral Association's Research Cafe
description:
Human bodies are composed of complex physiological architecture to support survival, including a beating heart and a dynamic immune system. This same architecture also undergirds our everyday emotional lives, affecting how we infer each other’s emotional states and sense that our feelings are “shared” in a given moment. In this talk, Dr. Mallory Feldman will share the science of the body’s role in emotional experience, and Dr. Catherine Berman will discuss when and how co-experienced emotions (particularly positive emotions) may shape well-being, including in fleeting social interactions. Join us on Tuesday, February 24, from 6:00 to 7:00 PM at the Chapel Hill Public Library. We will serve light refreshments during the talk. This event is made possible with the support of UNC Carolina Seminars.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater
description:
Under the visionary leadership of new artistic director Alicia Graf Mack, the beloved Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater brings its signature blend of spiritual depth and technical brilliance. Expect a powerful mix of new and classic works, including the celebrated masterpiece Revelations. 

 

Tickets are available starting at $39. Enjoy a variety of season-long discounts, available exclusively for Carolina Performing Arts’ series performances.

title: Wildlife Trivia and Chapter Interest Meeting (Whiteville)
description:
Join the NCWF Southeastern Swamp Stewards Chapter for Wildlife Trivia at Penn’s Grill in Whiteville! Come out for this free event and test your knowledge against other Nature Nerds, win prizes and, more importantly, BRAGGING RIGHTS! Learn about the wildlife all around us while having fun and be sure to stay for a short meeting about how you can join Swamp Stewards and help protect wildlife in Southeastern NC.

title: *IN-PERSON* SF/F Group
description:
Durham Writers Group
We will be at the People's Solidarity Hub at 1809 Chapel Hill Rd, Durham. This venue does not serve food or drink, but feel free to bring your own. There is a kitchenette for our use, but be sure to clean up afterwards. The space might be a little cozy; please consider masking or staying home if you have a respiratory ailment.

This sub-group focuses on Speculative Fiction, including Science Fiction, Fantasy and Horror. If you have anything that falls under that category — be it short story, poem, novel-in-progress or screenplay — then come! We'd love to hear from you.

Our format allows each reader 15 minutes to present their work aloud, followed by approximately 20 minutes of feedback from the other attendees. To ensure fairness, each attendee is limited to 1 minute of Initial Feedback time. During that period, the author remains silent. Next, we have a 5 minute Free-For-All discussion about the work -- then the author may speak. (We usually get through three readers.)

Though not required, in order to receive more in-depth feed-back, readers may post their work in advance on our Google Group:
https://groups.google.com/d/forum/durham-sff-writers-group

We ask that participants keep their comments constructive and respectful, focusing on what works or doesn't work in the piece.

We also ask that readers provide a warning, both on the Google Group and during the meeting, if their story features content that some readers might find upsetting. This includes descriptions of violence or sexual content.

Readers are:
•
•
•

Backup Readers are:
•
•
•

Deep Backup:
•

***

***We meet every Tuesday at the same time, but alternate between In-Person*** ***and on Zoom. Members may attend both formats, if desired, but readers will be listed separately under the In-Person or Zoom weeks.***

title: Travel CHINA like a local! Virtual QnA [x-posted]
description:
Raleigh & Triangle Activities Meetup Group
Putting out feelers for curious, cooperative 'comrades' to explore quiet corners of Old Cathay! Trip date TBD - waiting for airfares to come down.

This will happen on Google Meet.

**CHECK THE COMMENTS FOR MEETING LINK!**

[Comment if you are able to log onto the link but don't see me - in the past Google has let two meetings with the same link open, each person thinking the other didn't show up. So comment here and we'll see if we can fix it. :-) ]

I've been traveling to China for 27 years. Join me for a unique, off the beaten track culture immersion adventure!

Comfort NOT guaranteed! LOTS of walking! This trip is NOT for everyone but everyone who has come with me so far has LOVED it!

Itinerary NOT guaranteed so as to maximize experience! Spontaneous private zheng concert in a riverside pavilion? Let's stop and enjoy! Weather is forecast to be rain in the mountains? Let's go to the ancient village instead.

Costs currently unknown but should be under $100/day for ALL in-country necessities: food, lodging, entrance fees, ground transport. Whatever price I end up quoting will NOT include transport to/from China, alcohol, upgrades to lodging\*, upgrades to in-country transport\*.

You can do it cheaper with a big box tour. If strict time schedules, overpriced shopping, industrial restaurant food, and being kept away from locals is good enough for you than that's your best bet. If unique, real China, great food, insider knowledge with eye for western comforts\*\*, and turn on a dime\*\*\* [a mao?] escapades are for you than come with me!

Only seven people! Small and 'nimble'\*\*\*!

Have you already been to China? Already have seen the Forbidden City and Great Wall? No worries! Big box tours do NOT go where I go!

Have you never been to China and NEED to see the big sights? No problem! I can create an optional 3 day add-on for the Great Wall, Forbidden City, Temple of Heaven, and other Beijing highlights. AND I can take you to hidden gems few big tours touch.

Let's dialog! Looking for like minded people so everyone's on the same page. Don't want to put hard-core shoppers with shop-hating history buffs, or long distance hikers with casual strollers. Just a more practical way to go. If enough interest I can lead TWO trips, each with its own emphasis. I reserve the right to group/accept/deny as I see fit. [I only want happiness! Sometimes that means saying 'maybe next time'.]

Go to Jan Tu Tours on FB and browse the photo albums to get a hint of what one might see. No guarantees of ANYTHING! China changes very quickly.

\*Where available - LOTS of things NOT available off the beaten track. I said 'adventure'!

\*\*Sometimes western comforts are just not there. Deep in the countryside villages rarely have western toilets.

\*\*\*Quick change of plans is relative in China; western expectations are best set aside and an embrace the new/unknown/surprise attitude is highly recommended. But that's what a cultural adventure is all about!

Source: Meetup: Raleigh & Triangle Activities

title: Pilot Mountain Rock Climbing
description:
Embark on an exhilarating climbing adventure at Pilot Mountain State Park. Whether you're stepping into outdoor climbing for the first time or seeking new challenges as an experienced climber, Pilot Mountain offers a range of routes to suit every level. Discover the thrill of scaling one of North Carolina’s most popular climbing destinations.  With transportation, lunch, gear, and instruction provided, this trip promises an unforgettable day of achievement and camaraderie in the great outdoors.

Source: NC State University

title: NHBA Bird Outing
description: Contact Tom Driscoll at spttdrdshnk@yahoo.com  with questions. The location will be Flat River Waterfowl Impoundment, about 0.4 miles north of Jock Road. The coordinates are 36.127667, -78.832790. This outing is sponsored by the New Hope Bird Alliance (formerly New Hope Audubon). Outings usually last 2-3 hours. No reservations or sign-up needed. If there is a large turnout for any particular outing, we may split into two groups. We do recommend carpooling for families or friend pods; while we love pets, there is a ‘no-pet’ policy for bird outings. New birders and birders of all skill levels are welcome.  Please wear long pants, socks, and sturdy shoes (ticks and chiggers may be present). Sun and bug protection are also recommended. Bring snacks and water if you like. Heavy rain will result in cancellation. Source: New Hope Bird Alliance

title: Africa to Carolina Exhibit at Somerset Place
description:
February 1st marks the start of #BlackHistoryMonth! To commemorate the African diaspora and the impact Black culture has made on United States history, we will re-open our Africa to Carolina exhibit to the public. The Africa to Carolina initiative serves to identify, acknowledge, and mark each site in the state where enslaved Africans disembarked directly from the African Continent. In our self-guided exhibit, visitors can learn about the experiences of enslaved Africans who survived the Atlantic slave trade to North Carolina. Stop by the visitor center for free admission into the exhibit.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Invasive Species Awareness Week
description:
Interested in knowing about what kinds of invasive species we have at Hanging Rock State Park? Well, swing by our Visitor Center and browse through information our park staff have put together on species like the woolly adelgid or the infamous kudzu that we try to actively treat here at the park. Understand the importance of reducing the spread of invasive species and how you may be able to play a role. For questions, reach out to Ranger Fields at Jacob.fields@ncparks.gov

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: 2026 Emerging Issues Forum: Future Forward Water
description:
Join the Institute for Emerging Issues for the 2026 Emerging Issues Forum: Future Forward Water. North Carolina’s economic vitality depends on how we manage our water systems today. From aging infrastructure and emerging contaminants to workforce shortages and storm resilience, this multi-city event offers attendees a unique opportunity to connect locally and tackle our state’s most pressing water challenges. This event also marks the 40th anniversary of the Emerging Issues Forum and is the second installment of the 2025-2027 Future Forward Infrastructure series.  Founded by former North Carolina Governor and NC State alumnus Jim Hunt, the Emerging Issues Forum brings thought leaders together to address critical challenges in North Carolina and implement solutions that drive the state forward.

Get your tickets, view the agenda and learn more about the forum locations on the forum website.

Source: NC State University

title: Crafting the American Story
description:
In honor of the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence the City of Southport, the Fort Johnston-Southport Museum & Visitors’ Center, and the Brunswick Arts Council invite the community to explore how art, identity, and history intertwine throughout our collective American experience.

Crafting the American Story: Art, Identity, & History celebrates the boundless creativity of Americans—past and present—while recognizing the power of artistic expression to shape, reflect, and challenge our collective narrative.

This exhibition will showcase the creativity of Brunswick County artists while exploring how art reflects and interprets our nation’s history. Through the graphic arts, sculpture and handcrafts, visitors will encounter works that engage with themes of resilience, cultural identity, and the diverse perspectives that enrich our shared story.

What You’ll Discover

The exhibition highlights how creativity has shaped and been shaped by American history over the past 250 years. From responses to adversity and change, to celebrations of cultural heritage, the works on display will show how art captures, or was influenced by, the complexity of the American experience.

The show invites both artists and audiences to reflect on:

How historical events inspire creative expressionThe power of art and handicraft as a storytelling mediumThe inclusion of perspectives often missing from familiar narrativesThe ways resilience, identity, and innovation converge to shape our futureAs part of the program, America 250 NC will present a One Day Wonder traveling exhibit “To Preserve the Blessings of Liberty: State Constitutions of North Carolina.” Featuring copies of the 1776 State Constitution and Declaration of Rights, the 1868 State Constitution, and a letter from John Adams known as “Thoughts on Government,” the exhibit explores North Carolina’s three state constitutions and key amendments, examining how they reshaped ideas of citizenship and expanded, or restricted, participation in the state’s political life. This exhibit will be available for a limited time on opening day only.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Founding Fathers at Latimer House
description:
Historic Latimer House will proudly participate in the America 250 First in Freedom Festival as an official Passport Stamp Cancellation Site, offering visitors a unique opportunity to engage with the nation’s founding history during the festival week, February 21–28.

For one week only, Latimer House will present an extraordinary public viewing of original documents from three Founding Fathers—George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, and James Madison. These rare and significant items are part of the archive of the Lower Cape Fear Historical Society, which is celebrating 70 years of historic preservation work in the region.

In recognition of service, active-duty and veteran military members will receive free admission with valid ID throughout the festival week. Limited tickets are available online at the Latimer House website.

The America 250 First in Freedom Festival commemorates the events and ideals that led to American independence, and Latimer House’s participation highlights the enduring relevance of original historical documents and preservation efforts.

For history enthusiasts, families, students, and visitors alike, Latimer House’s festival programming offers a rare chance to connect directly with the words and legacy of the nation’s founders—available for one week only.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

description:
The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt showcases how the biblical story of heroic Queen Esther, depicted by Rembrandt and his contemporaries in art and popular culture, expressed ideas of political and religious freedom during the Dutch Golden Age. Charting this history through objects and artworks, The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt provides an original perspective on one of the most studied periods of Dutch prosperity.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

title: QGIS and GRASS Open-Source GIS
description:
This is a three-part, hands-on GIS course. No previous GIS experience is required. The first session on Monday will be a general overview and introduction to the benefits of Open Source GIS in general, to QGIS in specific, and will include our first hands-on session with QGIS. Topics to be covered include: the QGIS user interface, loading vector and raster files, QGIS plug-ins, web mapping functions, QGIS data manipulation, icons and pull-down tools, basic data manipulation, working with attribute tables, and general familiarity with QGIS. 

Part 2 on Wednesday will continue our work with QGIS, including using the vector, raster, and web analysis functions, using the print composer.  We will also cover the QGIS website, tutorials, listserv, discussion groups, sources of help, etc. 

Part 3 on Friday will focus on the GRASS GIS and other advanced tools available through the QGIS Processing Toolbox within the QGIS interface. Topics covered will include the GRASS vector and raster data formats, GRASS vector, raster, and imagery analysis, GRASS 3-D data (voxels), the raster map calculator, the print composer, and other GRASS capabilities. You can attend just the first, first two, or all dates.

 

Laptops are required for this course, no computers are in the room. Students should download QGIS (www.qgis.org) before the class, and will download the sample data and tutorials (QGIS includes a current version of GRASS) at the start of the class. QGIS runs on Windows, Mac, and Linux systems. At the end of the course, students will have a general ability to use QGIS and GRASS, and can continue learning on their own using the data and tutorials provided.

 

It is highly recommended to bring your power cords, extension cord, and/or powerstrips for your laptops. Come early if you need assistance loading QGIS. Feel free to contact the instructor at: madrys@email.unc.edu

 

This workshop is offered by the University Libraries and will be led by Dr. Scott Madry, with support from library staff, Gracie Riehm and Philip McDaniel. 

 

NOTE: This workshop will be held in-person ONLY in Davis Library, room 246. Space is limited. Please register in advance on the University Libraries calendar: https://calendar.lib.unc.edu/event/16023034

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Introduction to Individual and Aggregate Data Network Models for Understanding Human Processes
description:
Using network models to understand human processes

With increased interest in person-centered interventions and treatments has come increased interest in understanding human processes as they unfold within individuals. Additionally, technological advances have made the collection of person-specific data easier and more cost-effective for researchers interested in studying human behavior within everyday contexts. This two-day course focuses on using two popular network models to explore research questions concerning within-person processes.

This course is intended for individuals with research questions that can be answered using multivariate time series data/intensive longitudinal data. Examples of such data include daily diary data; data collected via self-report through ecological momentary sampling (ESM); passive data from cell phones; and other psychophysiological data such as MRI data or heart rate data.

The two network modeling frameworks presented in this course are graphicalVAR (GVAR) and Group Iterative Multiple Model Estimation (GIMME). Both models can be used to explore processes as they unfold within individuals to obtain individual person-specific network models (idiographic analysis) or group/population level network models (nomothetic analysis).  Differences between the modeling frameworks will be presented. Challenges and considerations for choosing between methods will be discussed.

Statistical models and topics presented during this course include the following:

Vector autoregression (VAR) time series analysis in both non-SEM and SEM frameworksMultilevel Modeling (MLM)Issues with aggregating data when trying to understand within-person processesFitting of network models using graphicalVAR and GIMME approachesApproaches for summarizing idiographic results using meta-analytic techniquesThis course is applied in nature and offers a conceptual overview of the modeling frameworks as well as the technical details needed to fit the models. Examples with hands on learning will be provided throughout the two-day course to give learners the opportunity to practice fitting and interpreting models.

Registration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: ReAdOn: Research Administrator Onboarding
description:
ReAdOn provides an introductory overview of the full research administration lifecycle, from proposal development to award closeout, and incorporates topics in ethics, compliance and research security. The series consists of 4 weekly virtual sessions: 

Wed, Feb 4, 11:30am-2:00pm, Session 1: Program Overview and Proposals (note: this session is 30 minutes longer) Wed, Feb 11, 11:30am-1:30pm, Session 2: Ethics, Compliance, and Security in Proposals and Awards Wed, Feb 18, 11:30am-1:30pm, Session 3: Award Execution and Post-Award Actions Wed, Feb 25, 11:30am-1:30pm, Session 4: Award and Project Management through Closeout  

While the series is especially beneficial for new research administrators, anyone interested in gaining a deeper understanding of the research administration landscape at UNC-CH is encouraged to attend. The agenda is available at https://go.unc.edu/ReAdOn-2026-Agenda

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Building Brilliance
description:
Join Prevention Services and the College of Sciences for a strengths-based, supportive lunch-and-learn designed to empower neurodivergent students in personal development and college success. The group’s focus is on three core areas: building strong social and interpersonal skills, such as handling conflict, setting boundaries and self-advocacy. The group meets over three sessions, twice each semester. Lunch will be provided. The sessions are below.

Session OneFeb. 18, noon to 1 p.m., Bureau of Mines, Room 201April 1, noon to 1 p.m., Campus Health, Room 2301Session TwoFeb. 25, noon to 1 p.m., Campus Health, Room 2301April 8, noon to 1 p.m., Cox Hall, Room  306Session ThreeMarch 4, noon to 1 p.m., Bureau of Mines, Room 201April 15, noon to 1 p.m., Bureau of Mines, Room 201

title: Centennial Visioneers Toastmasters
description:
Toastmasters is a diverse and fun club focused on helping our members grow by improving their public speaking and leadership skills in a supportive, encouraging environment. Meetings are at 321 Coffee on Centennial campus in their Confernece Room 2 and guests are always welcome to visit. Come see what all the hype is about!

For more information about our club and how being a member can benefit you, please contact our VP of Public Relations, Keisha Demps. Be sure to check out the Toastmasters International website, too.

Source: NC State University

title: Staff Senate Wilson College of Textiles Tour
description:
Join Staff Senate for a tour of the NC State Wilson College of Textiles building. As the only college in North America dedicated to textiles, it is the destination of choice for anyone who needs textiles expertise — including some of the biggest brands on the planet.

Source: NC State University

title: Helping Children Develop Strong Ethics and Values
description:
Music, TV programs, electronic games, other children and adults all influence children. But not many of these influences teach them ethics and values. Teaching youngsters’ ethics and values begins at home and is a parental responsibility. This workshop will help you explain basic ethics and morals so your children can understand how to determine right from wrong.

 

Workshop Objectives:

At the end of this workshop, you will be able to:
Define values, ethics, morals and character
• Identify the values you wish to impart to your children
• Describe how culture can instill values
Identify how you teach values to your children
• Describe how parental modeling affects value development
• Describe how to use family meetings and occasions to teach values
• Describe how discussing choices and decisions teaches values
Describe the role of relationships in value formation
• Identify the importance of working together with your spouse to determine which values will be taught
• Identify the importance of cultivating close relationships with your children as a basis for value development
• Recognize the need for patience as children will test limits and explore boundaries while formulating their own values
• Identify the importance of consistency in value clarification and role modeling values.

 

Click on Carolina Talent registration link and select the “Request” button to automatically enroll.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Portraits of Climate Change from Across North Carolina
description:

This pop-up will feature images from the original photography exhibit alongside photographs from contests held in Manteo, Greenville, and Goldsboro.

Come at 4 for a discussion with project team members and contributors to the original Snapshot: Climate issue that sparked this project, or swing through anytime from 12:00 – 5:00 to mingle, enjoy the gallery, and reflect on key opportunities and challenges this project raises.

the American SouthAyşe Erginer, Executive Editor, Southern Cultures, UNC Center for the Study of the American

location: Partners I – NC State University, Suite 2580
description:

Source: NC State University

title: Version Control with Git and GitHub
description:
In this course, participants will learn how to keep track of the code they use in their research using the version control system Git and the collaboration platform GitHub. Git allows you to keep track of changes to your code, easily revert to previous versions, and “tag” versions of code used in publications so that the exact code used can be retrieved at a later date. GitHub allows Git users to collaborate with each other on projects by managing simultaneous changes to the same files and allowing users to review and discuss each others’ code. Git and Github are applicable to any text-based programming or analysis language, including R, Python, Stata, Julia, and others.

This course is a prerequisite for the “Modular Design and Automated Testing with R” course in April.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Python Crash Courses: Intro to Data
description:
The Python Crash Course: Intro to Data introduces fundamental tools for working with tabular data in Python such as Pandas, Jupyter Notebooks, and data visualization packages. We'll work through some applied examples and survey more specialized packages for data science in Python and talk about next steps on your learning journey.

 

This workshop assumes some basic familiarity with Python syntax (for example see “A Whirlwind Tour of Python”). This workshop will use conda via miniforge, and Visual Studio Code. Setup help will be available before the first session.

 

This workshop is offered by University Libraries and will be led by librarians Philip McDaniel, Lorin Bruckner, Michele Hayslett, Matt Jansen, and Rolando Rodriguez along with Mark Reed from ITS Research Computing. Contact Matt Jansen with any questions.

 

This workshop is being offered remotely via Zoom only. Registrants will receive a Zoom link; those on the waitlist will not receive a Zoom link unless they are bumped up to a registered spot. Participants will experience using several virtual collaboration tools, hear tips for building trust and rapport in online spaces, and learn key digital accessibility considerations. Attendees will receive a handout with suggested tools and their uses and accessibility tips to adapt for their own community-engaged work.

title: Handsewn Doll Workshop with Margarette Joyner--A Black History Month Event
description:
Join African-American Legacy Project Coordinator and award-winning textile artist Margarette Joyner as she leads workshop participants in the art of crafting handmade dolls that replicate the ones enslaved women would have created for their own children. As Ms. Joyner states, " “Hand sewing is becoming a dying art, but there are many benefits to the art form.  You’re using your hands and eyes in coordination, which is great practice for other activities. You’re also working on fine motor skills, which can be helpful for tasks like handwriting and using a computer mouse.  But the best thing about hand sewing is that it’s a relaxing activity. When you’re focusing on the task at hand, you can forget about all of your troubles and just enjoy the moment. Sometimes it’s nice to take a break from thinking about things and just work on something creative.  So let’s learn how to create a handmade doll similar to the primitive dolls made by the enslaved women of Colonial Williamsburg.” 

The activity will take place in Rosedale's kitchen cellar, and seating is limited to 15. Materials will be provided.

Originally from New York, they have called North Carolina home for over a decade and built their business with a strong focus on community involvement and connection. After years of helping clients through nonprofit housing programs, Yandry decided to become a licensed real estate agent during COVID. Since then, she has grown into one of the top-producing agents in the county. With a background in psychology, Yandry is known for her strategic, calm, and highly effective negotiation style. description:
Want to know how generative AI (GenAI) can be used to support your research? This workshop covers various GenAI tools that have applications for research tasks including tools that support writing manuscripts, exploring and summarizing literature (e.g., Research Rabbit, Consensus, and Elicit), performing evidence synthesis (including systematic and scoping reviews), and data analysis.
