Every community holds a secret map of untapped strengths, including local heroes, quiet spaces, and hidden resources that, when connected, may be leveraged for significant changes, even saving lives. Unfortunately, many people don’t know how to identify and mobilize these assets.

In an immersive, high-energy session, learn from participants in CARE4Youth, a collaboration between Carolina Across 100, the Child and Adolescent Anxiety and Mood Disorders Program (CHAAMP), and ten cross-sector collaborative teams from across North Carolina. During this session, we will help you create your own asset map for issues important to you and your community, and share how our focus on existing community strengths through asset mapping is revolutionizing local mental health outcomes.

Michael Welker, Director of Policy and Research Partnerships, ncIMPACT Initiative at the UNC School of GovernmentAbigail Holdsclaw, Lead Community-Based Researcher, ncIMPACT Initiative at the UNC School of GovernmentLocation: School of Government, Room 2403

description:
Engaging students and the community in authentic participatory science research, the Monkey Health Explorer project integrates biological data with blood chemistry, immune health, and behavior. The presenters collaborated with educators to build upon existing curriculum, incorporating data science methods to analyze the biological data. This session includes an overview of the project and curricular development, with lessons learned from the 20,000+ international contributors and participating teachers. We illustrate the value of authentic research to enlighten students in real-world projects relevant to their future careers. This session is presented by the Renaissance Computing Institute (RENCI) in partnership with the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences, with insight from educators across North Carolina and Puerto Rico.

title: The Agentic Shift: Designing AI That Can Reason, Plan, and Act
description:
Data Science Raleigh
As AI evolves from passive tools to active collaborators, enterprises face a pivotal shift: embracing systems that can not only respond but also take initiative. This webinar unpacks what it means to build and deploy agentic AI—models that possess goal-directed reasoning, dynamic planning capabilities, and the ability to autonomously execute tasks across complex workflows.

We’ll explore architectural and governance considerations for enterprise adoption, including how to integrate agentic systems into existing data ecosystems, ensure transparency and control, and maintain human-in-the-loop oversight. Join us for a practical, forward-looking discussion on how to prepare your organization for AI that doesn’t just assist—but acts.

**What You'll Learn:**

1️⃣ **What Agentic AI Really Means:** Understand the core components—reasoning, planning, and autonomous action—and how they differ from traditional AI assistants.

2️⃣ **Enterprise Readiness:** Learn what technical and organizational infrastructure you need to safely and effectively deploy agentic systems.

3️⃣ **Designing for Oversight and Control:** Explore observability, guardrails, and human-in-the-loop strategies for managing proactive AI in production environments.

Panelists to be announced soon.

**[Register here](https://hubs.ly/Q03VW1dg0)**

Source: Meetup: Data Science Raleigh

title: Creative Art History: Roland Betancourt, UC Irvine
description:
Department of Art and Art History

 

“Like the Dawn of Creation: Byzantine Fragments in the Modern Imagination”

 

This talk explores how Byzantium operates as a queer cipher in modern culture, appearing as an adjectival modifier, “the Byzantine,” rather than as a distinct historical referent. Analyzing Gore Vidal’s 1959 adaptation of Tennessee Williams’s Suddenly, Last Summer, Betancourt demonstrates how Byzantine references encode queer identity through the film’s absent protagonist, whose unspeakable sexuality mirrors Byzantium’s own unintelligibility. Drawing on extensive archival research, he shows how “the Byzantine” articulated coded queerness for these writers and artists. This talk proposes reimagining Byzantine art history through modes of “queer fragmentation,” recognizing Byzantine elements across temporal boundaries.

 

Roland Betancourt is a scholar of Byzantium and modern popular culture with research that lies firmly at the intersection of the history of science and technology, intellectual history, and the history of art. Dr. Betancourt is the Andrew W. Mellon Professor at the Center for Advanced Study in the Visual Arts at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, DC from 2024-2026. He also holds the honor of Chancellor’s Professor, Department of Art History, at the University of California, Irvine. He is also the author of four monographs, including The Secrets We Keep: Hidden Histories of the Byzantine Empire (The Getty, 2024), Performing the Gospels in Byzantium: Sight, Sound, and Space in the Divine Liturgy (Cambridge University Press, 2021), Byzantine Intersectionality: Sexuality, Gender, and Race in the Middle Ages (Princeton University Press, 2020), and Sight, Touch, and Imagination in Byzantium (Cambridge University Press, 2018). Betancourt’s forthcoming book, Disneyland and the Rise of Automation: How Technology Created the Happiest Place on Earth (Princeton University Press, 2026), traces the origins and evolution of the theme park’s technical innovations during Disneyland’s first three decades in operation, exploring how engineers reimagined the systems and machines of industrial manufacturing and the military.

 

A weeknight or daytime permit is now required after 5:00 pm on weekdays. No permit is required from 5:00 pm Friday through 7:30 am Monday. A $1.00 one-night pass is available in selected lots. More information can be found HERE.

title: Voices Rising: Save Our Sounds (Greensboro)
description:
Join NCWF Triad Wild! Chapter for a conversation about one of North Carolina’s most treasured natural resources: our estuarine sounds. Our sounds, most notably the Albemarle-Pamlico Sound, are known for their stunning coastal landscapes, immense biodiversity, historical significance, economic importance, and are the largest estuarine system in the nation managed by one state. Estuaries, sometimes described as “rainforests of the sea”, are crucial because they filter pollutants, provide critical nurseries for fish and shellfish (supporting fisheries), as well as economic benefits through recreation, tourism, and jobs, all while supporting immense biodiversity. Our shallow sounds are in deep trouble for several reasons, not the least of which is our fisheries management. It’s not too late to recognize and to cherish North Carolina’s natural treasures for the gift they are and undertake-with dogged determination-the effort to restore their abundance, for humans and the environment. Restoration is not a pipe dream; it is just waiting for us to get on board.  
REGISTER HERE

title: Becoming American Scripture: The Declaration of Independence after 1776
description:
The history of how the Declaration of Independence came to be is familiar to many Americans.
Less familiar and equally important is the subsequent history of the document. How did the Declaration go from being a congressional PR document of moderate significance to becoming the defining document of American history and one of the most influential documents in the history of the world.

Though it served an important purpose in 1776, the Declaration was not particularly noted or celebrated in the decades after the Revolution.

In this talk, historian Michael D. Hattem will discuss how groups from across the political spectrum have redefined the Declaration and its ideals in an effort to make them more relevant and meaningful to their own times. In the process, he will show how the Declaration became "American Scripture," as well as a model for independence-seeking people around the world.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: 250th Anniversary of the Battle of Moores Creek Bridge
description:
Moores Creek National Battlefield will be commemorating the 250th Anniversary of the Battle of Moores Creek February 26-28, 2026. This battle was the first decisive patriot victory in the American Revolution and led to North Carolina to be the first colony to authorize its delegates to the 2nd Continental Congress to vote for independence. North Carolina was the "first in freedom."

The basic schedule follows:

Day 1: Thursday, Feb 26--Day of Education (Focus will be on hosting multiple school groups along with traditional living history demonstrations)

Day 2: Friday, Feb 27--Day of Commemoration (The focal point will be a traditional wreath laying ceremony along with living history demonstrations and special guests)

Day 3: Saturday, Feb 28--Day of Community Celebration (This day is set aside as a day of fun with music, games, “Freedom” Art Show, and food trucks along with traditional living history displays)

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Crafting the American Story
description:
In honor of the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence the City of Southport, the Fort Johnston-Southport Museum & Visitors’ Center, and the Brunswick Arts Council invite the community to explore how art, identity, and history intertwine throughout our collective American experience.

Crafting the American Story: Art, Identity, & History celebrates the boundless creativity of Americans—past and present—while recognizing the power of artistic expression to shape, reflect, and challenge our collective narrative.

This exhibition will showcase the creativity of Brunswick County artists while exploring how art reflects and interprets our nation’s history. Through the graphic arts, sculpture and handcrafts, visitors will encounter works that engage with themes of resilience, cultural identity, and the diverse perspectives that enrich our shared story.

What You’ll Discover

The exhibition highlights how creativity has shaped and been shaped by American history over the past 250 years. From responses to adversity and change, to celebrations of cultural heritage, the works on display will show how art captures, or was influenced by, the complexity of the American experience.

The show invites both artists and audiences to reflect on:

How historical events inspire creative expressionThe power of art and handicraft as a storytelling mediumThe inclusion of perspectives often missing from familiar narrativesThe ways resilience, identity, and innovation converge to shape our futureAs part of the program, America 250 NC will present a One Day Wonder traveling exhibit “To Preserve the Blessings of Liberty: State Constitutions of North Carolina.” Featuring copies of the 1776 State Constitution and Declaration of Rights, the 1868 State Constitution, and a letter from John Adams known as “Thoughts on Government,” the exhibit explores North Carolina’s three state constitutions and key amendments, examining how they reshaped ideas of citizenship and expanded, or restricted, participation in the state’s political life. This exhibit will be available for a limited time on opening day only.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Founding Fathers at Latimer House
description:
Historic Latimer House will proudly participate in the America 250 First in Freedom Festival as an official Passport Stamp Cancellation Site, offering visitors a unique opportunity to engage with the nation’s founding history during the festival week, February 21–28.

For one week only, Latimer House will present an extraordinary public viewing of original documents from three Founding Fathers—George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, and James Madison. These rare and significant items are part of the archive of the Lower Cape Fear Historical Society, which is celebrating 70 years of historic preservation work in the region.

In recognition of service, active-duty and veteran military members will receive free admission with valid ID throughout the festival week. Limited tickets are available online at the Latimer House website.

The America 250 First in Freedom Festival commemorates the events and ideals that led to American independence, and Latimer House’s participation highlights the enduring relevance of original historical documents and preservation efforts.

For history enthusiasts, families, students, and visitors alike, Latimer House’s festival programming offers a rare chance to connect directly with the words and legacy of the nation’s founders—available for one week only.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: NC First in Freedom Festival
description:
In 2026 the inaugural North Carolina First in Freedom Festival, taking place throughout Southeastern NC during the week of February 21-28, 2026 (10:00 AM - 4:00 PM), will celebrate more than 250 years of our Nation’s story and culture viewed through the lens of historical North Carolina events and the arts. Please visit the NC FIFF website to see the planned activities: 

https://www.ncfirstinfreedomfestival.com/

Funded in part by an America 250 NC grant, a program of the NC Department of Natural and Cultural Resources.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt
description:
The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt showcases how the biblical story of heroic Queen Esther, depicted by Rembrandt and his contemporaries in art and popular culture, expressed ideas of political and religious freedom during the Dutch Golden Age. Charting this history through objects and artworks, The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt provides an original perspective on one of the most studied periods of Dutch prosperity.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Methods for Conducting Qualitative Research in Diverse Settings
description:
Knowing how to develop various types of qualitative research studies to respond to complex research and community priorities is rewarding, but can also be daunting. This short course provides practical skills for conducting various types of qualitative research in U.S. and international settings. First, students will learn about the epistemological and theoretical foundations of qualitative research and the range of methodologies currently used such as programmatic qualitative research, ethnography, grounded theory, phenomenology, and case studies. Next, the short course provides step-by-step instructions on how to develop and implement various qualitative methods and designs, such as interviews, focus groups, and observations – and how to handle single- versus multi-method qualitative studies or cross-sectional versus longitudinal qualitative studies. Students will learn basic principles for data generation, ethics, and data quality in qualitative studies. We will also focus on practical steps for data analysis, including data management, transcription, and coding. Traditionally, qualitative research is conducted in-person, and students will be trained for in-person interactions. However, the short course’s concluding module teaches students about techniques required for contemporary qualitative research online and by phone, including consideration of recent advances in conducting qualitative research using social media. This course is designed to provide new knowledge for both introductory and intermediate students. Registration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Backyard Birds
location: Cliffs of the Neuse State Park
description:
Join us at 11am at the picnic shelter to learn about making backyards a safe and healthy place for birds. We will go over many different ways to bring birds to your backyards, and we will be using peanut butter to make homemade bird feeders for the kids!

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Nature Notes
description:
This monthly journaling series allows attendees a “slowdown” from the complexities of life to observe the small details nature has to offer (light on leaves, birdsong, shifting weather), and capturing those moments on paper through words or images. Sometimes the focus is on scientific observation, others are drawing on past experiences or emotions. This month’s journal entry will focus on the interconnectedness of living things within the park as well as the relationship between Dr. William Sharpe and John Hurst. Not sure who they are or how these two topics relate? Come find out. Bring your journal and something to write with. We'll meet at the Live Oak loop. Program is weather dependent.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Sightseeing Tours
description:
Cape Fear Riverboats is excited to announce February Sightseeing Tours for 2026 in support of the North Carolina First in Freedom Festival. For over 35 years, Cape Fear Riverboats has operated captain-narrated Sightseeing & Sunset Tours from downtown Wilmington which is TripAdvisors' Top Destination on the Rise for 2024. Daily tours onboard our current vessels, Henrietta and Osprey, highlight the area's history, legends, and charm, weaving over 400 years of history from the area's founding by English settlers all the way to modern times. For Group or Charter inquiries, please contact sales@capefearriverboats.com. For Public Tour or Sunset tickets, please visit https://capefearriverboats.com/ or call 910-613-9822.

title: Mental Health Seminar: From Grief to Growth - Navigating Loss with Compassion and Strength
description:
Grief is often linked to death, but many of life’s losses are quieter and less visible—changes in identity, shifting roles, unmet expectations, and transitions that leave lasting marks. Led jointly by a faculty researcher and a campus chaplain, this seminar explores grief as a shared human experience, drawing on research-based insights alongside reflective and compassionate practices. Participants will examine how grief shapes identity, relationships, and sense of purpose, while learning practical ways to navigate loss in their own lives. The session will also consider how individuals and communities can create space for grief in supportive, meaningful ways. Participants will leave with concrete tools for honoring loss, fostering resilience, and sustaining compassion and continuity through periods of change.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Mental Health Seminar: From Grief to Growth – Navigating Loss with Compassion and Strength
description:
Grief is often associated with death, but loss takes many forms—shifts in identity, changing roles, unmet expectations, and the quiet disappointments that shape our lives. Led jointly by a faculty member and a campus chaplain, this session integrates research-based insights with reflective and compassionate practices.   

Designed to support both personal reflection and broader community impact, the seminar will offer practical tools for navigating grief individually and strategies for integrating these concepts into community spaces. Participants will examine how grief influences identity, relationships, and sense of purpose, while considering how individuals can honor what has been lost while remaining open to growth and change. You will leave with a deeper understanding of grief as a shared human experience—and with approaches for fostering compassion, resilience, and continuity in times of change.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Celebration of 250 Years of Freedom
description:
Honoring PVT John Grady of Duplin County. The only Patriot Soldier Killed in the Battle of Moores Creek.

Located in the heart of Kenansville, the Duplin County Veterans Memorial Museum stands as a powerful tribute to the men and women of Duplin County who have served our nation. More than a museum, this meaningful space preserves personal stories, military history, and the enduring legacy of sacrifice, courage, and patriotism.

The Duplin County Veterans Memorial Museum was created to ensure that local veterans are never forgotten. Its exhibits honor those who served in conflicts from World War I to the present day, highlighting not only major moments in U.S. military history but also the individual experiences of Duplin County residents who answered the call to serve.

Photographs, uniforms, medals, letters, and personal artifacts help tell deeply human stories—bringing history to life in a way that feels personal, local, and heartfelt.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

The tours will last about 45 minutes.

Meet at the fort entrance. Pets are not allowed inside the fort.

 

Photo by C. Peek: The fort at Fort Macon State Park

title: Stories of the Revolution: People and Places of Pender County
description:
American Revolution stories of people and places of Pender County (then northern New Hanover County) will be featured in an exhibit. While the Battle of Moores Creek is famous, this exhibit features many other lesser-known stories. The fertile lands of Rocky Point was the residence of many prominent Revolutionary leaders. Stories will be told about members of the Moore, Ashe, Lillington, Swann, Bloodworth, and other families. Free Blacks were also Patriot soldiers, while enslaved Daniel Moore found his liberty with the British. Places of Revolutionary events include the Patriot fort near Rutherford's Mill and Herron's Bridge on the Northeast Cape Fear River. The lovely Sloop Point House, a home of Samuel Ashe, built in 1726 by his father John Baptiste Ashe, still stands on the coast. It’s the 2nd oldest building in the state as it turns 300 years old. Come discover these rich stories of patriotic heritage and more.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

description:
This workshop continues to explore methods used in creating interactive visualizations and dashboards as introduced in Tableau I. Topics covered in the hands-on course will include: merging data sources, groups and sets, advanced maps and interactive menus, dashboard actions, and more!

 

This session also requires you to have access to Tableau. Please follow the instructions here to download and install Tableau. If you are unable to install the software, please contact Lorin Bruckner for assistance.

description:

This workshop will provide an overview of the ETD website, formatting specifications, graduation requirements and resources that can help guide students through the ETD process. Participants will also have the opportunity to develop a thesis/dissertation writing timeline that aligns with their intended graduation date and ask the ETD reviewer questions about the overall process.

title: Feb 26 - Exploring Video Datasets with FiftyOne and Vision-Language Models
description:
Raleigh AI, Machine Learning and Computer Vision Meetup
Join [Harpreet Sahota](https://www.linkedin.com/in/harpreetsahota204/) for a virtual workshop to learn how to use Facebook's Action100M dataset and FiftyOne to build an end-to-end workflow.

**Date, Time and Location**

Feb 26, 2026
9am - 10am Pacific
Online. **[Register for the Zoom!](https://voxel51.com/events/exploring-video-datasets-with-fiftyone-and-vision-language-models-february-26-2026)**

Video is the hardest modality to work with. You're dealing with more data, temporal complexity, and annotation workflows that don't scale. This hands-on workshop tackles a practical question: given a large video dataset, how do you understand what's in it without manually watching thousands of clips?

In this workshop you'll learn how to:

* **Navigate and explore** video data in the FiftyOne App, filter samples, and understand dataset structure
* **Compute embeddings** with Qwen3-VL to enable semantic search, zero-shot classification, and clustering
* **Generate descriptions and localize events** using vision-language models like Qwen3-VL and Molmo2
* **Visualize patterns** in your data through embedding projections and the FiftyOne App
* **Evaluate model outputs** against Action100M's hierarchical annotations to validate what the models actually capture

By the end of the session, you'll have a reusable toolkit for understanding any video dataset at scale, whether you're curating training data, debugging model performance, or exploring a new domain.

Source: Meetup: Raleigh AI, ML & Computer Vision
source: Meetup: Raleigh AI, ML & Computer Vision

title: Heels Master Class with Anabelle Scarborough
location: Wellness and Recreation Center and Carmichael Gym, 2307
description:
This Heels masterclass begins with a grounding, yoga-inspired, and somatic warm-up to help you drop into your body, breathe deeply, and cultivate presence and find strength. From there, we’ll move into playful, beginner-friendly choreography and across the floor exercises in heels, exploring movement practices designed to awaken your sensuality and confidence. We will dive into a group choreography session toward the end of class. This is a space to move with intention, embody authenticity, and connect with your body in a way that feels bold, beautiful, and free. It is recommended to bring the following: a journal for reflections, dancing heels you feel confident and comfortable in, and a water bottle. 

 

Artist Bio: Anabelle Scarborough is a dancer, choreographer, educator, and visual artist based on the East Coast, currently based in the Raleigh–Durham region of North Carolina. Raised in the Appalachian Mountains, her work is deeply informed by themes of beauty, femininity, spontaneity, improvisation, and community. She trained at the Martha Graham School in New York City and at UNC Chapel Hill, studying modern, contemporary, improvisation, composition, ballet, and heels. She is a 200-hour certified yoga instructor through the Asheville Yoga Center and is currently pursuing a Master’s degree in Clinical Mental Health Counseling at Wake Forest University. Together, these experiences inform a holistic, trauma-informed approach to movement that honors both emotional and physical wellbeing. Anabelle is currently a Guest Teaching Artist at North Carolina State University's Department of Performing Arts and Technology. Working at the intersection of art, healing, and community, Anabelle’s interdisciplinary practice spans dance, yoga, photography, film, and arts-based education. 

Her projects reimagine how performance can activate and transform shared spaces, inviting audiences into intimate, participatory experiences that emphasize presence, connection, and collective storytelling. More can be found here: Anabellescarborough.com

Source: NC State University

title: Abbey Speaker Series: Race and the American Founding
location: Frank Porter Graham Student Union Auditorium
description:
The Abbey Speaker Series marks the 250th anniversary of American independence with a discussion of Race and the American Founding at 5:30pm on Thursday, February 26 in the Frank Porter Graham Student Union Auditorium.

The Declaration of Independence proclaimed equality —”all men are created equal”—but the Constitution tolerated slavery. Abolitionists, Abraham Lincoln, and civil rights leaders later wielded the Declaration’s words, but its principal author, Thomas Jefferson, owned slaves, and the Declaration refers to Native Americans as “merciless savages.” How should we think about this founding paradox that has haunted the nation for 250 years? Historian Annette Gordon-Reed and political theorist Lucas Morel will explore these and related issues in a discussion moderated by Carolina Public Humanities Executive Director Max Owre.

Students who attend in person can earn CLE credit. No tickets necessary; seating is first-come, first-served. Reserved tickets are available for guests coming from outside Chapel Hill; email publicdiscourse@unc.edu to reserve seats.

Join us for pizza in the lobby afterward!

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Planting Seeds of Support: Neighborhood-Based Solutions to Strengthen Local Food Security Through PORCH
description:
How can one neighborhood help strengthen an entire community’s food security? This session invites participants into “planting seeds of support,” showing how simple, neighbor-led action can address hunger in North Carolina and beyond. Through storytelling, local data, and examples from current PORCH chapters, attendees will explore how small, consistent efforts grow into sustained support for local food pantries. The session concludes with an interactive call to action where attendees receive a digital toolkit and learn how to share resources in their own hometowns or networks to inspire new neighborhood-led solutions. Leave equipped to spark community engagement and help plant the next “seed” where it’s needed most.

 

Presenters:

Jordan Cole, Business Development Coordinator, PORCH CommunitiesChristine Cotton, Founder & CEO, PORCH

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Andrews Launch Accelerator: Launch Sessions
description:
The Andrews Launch Accelerator's Launch Sessions are designed to help ventures articulate, validate and communicate their value to key programs and stakeholders. The schedule for the Launch Sessions is below. All sessions will be held virtually.

Session 1 (Feb. 26): Join us for an introduction to the Andrews Launch Accelerator, the Launch Sessions and the first core principle: customer discovery.

Session 2 ( March 5): This session will explore the often-overlooked fundamentals of customer discovery.  It will focus heavily on understanding your customers' frustrations, dissatisfactions and unfulfilled desires. The session will also delve into collecting evidence of these things through unbiased discovery work.

Session 3 (March 12): You'll learn about the methods entrepreneurs use to rapidly validate demand for what they are working on without spending a lot of money and time.

Session 4 (March 26): With just a few days left before the Andrews Launch Accelerator applications are due on March 31, this session will be an open-floor Q&A on anything related to the Andrews Launch Accelerator, including applications.

Source: NC State University

The event will take place on February 26th at 6:30pm at Southside Church of Christ located at 800 Elmira Avenue in Durham.
“Young, Gifted and Black” will bring together students, families, educators, and community members for an uplifting and educational celebration of Black history, culture, and accomplishment. The event will feature student performances, cultural presentations, interactive activities, and opportunities for community engagement that reflect QEI’s mission to inspire confidence, growth, and a strong sense of identity in every child.

This FREE community event aligns with QEI’s longstanding commitment to academic excellence, character development, and community building. As a trusted institution in Durham for over two decades, QEI continues to serve as an educational resource and source of pride for the families it supports.

Event Details:
What: “Young, Gifted and Black” — Black History Month Celebration
When: February 26th, 2026 6:30PM
Where: Southside Church of Christ — 800 Elmira Avenue, Durham, NC 27707
Who: Students, families, and the community welcome -- FREE OPEN TO THE PUBLIC

title: Stories that Connect Us: A Community Conversation on Telling the Full Story
location: Passmore Center, 103 Meadowlands Dr, Hillsborough, NC, 27278, United States
description:
Discover the stories that shape our community in a special four-part conversation series! Hosted by the Alliance for Historic Hillsborough and the Telling the Full Story committee, each session dives into the history of local sites from our interactive map, with engaging video presentations and oral histories that bring these places to life. Join us for lively discussions and reflections on the impact of these spaces in Hillsborough. 
Mark your calendar for Thursday evenings in February 2025, 5:30–7:00 PM at the Passmore Center in Hillsborough, NC. Come to learn, connect, and be inspired—see you there! 
February 6th- Entrepreneurship in the 20th Century 
February 13th- The Land Remembers 
February 20th- Community Institutions 
February 27th- Navigating Freedom 
What is Telling the Full Story: The Alliance for Historic Hillsborough’s Telling the Full Story program seeks to uncover and share the diverse, often untold histories of Hillsborough. Through community conversations, interactive maps, and oral histories, this program invites everyone to explore the people, events, and places that have shaped our community, fostering a richer understanding of our shared heritage. 
Funding for this program series is generously provided by North Carolina Humanities.

Source: NC Humanities Council

title: Ask Us Anything About AI with Google, Make.com and more...
description:
All Things AI (Live)
You don't get access like this very often. Also, we are in the process of coordinating schedules, so right now the experts are clearing their schedules.

We're bringing together some of the most experienced AI practitioners in the Triangle—people who build, deploy, and advise on AI systems every day—for a wide-open **Ask Us Anything session about AI**.

No slides. No vendor pitches. No rehearsed talking points.

Just direct access to experts who've been in the room where real AI decisions get made.

This is your chance to ask the questions you can't get answered on LinkedIn or in webinars:

* What's actually working with AI right now—and what's quietly failing
* How serious teams move from pilots to production
* Where generative AI, agents, and automation deliver real ROI
* What executives get wrong about AI strategy
* How to think about data, security, governance, and risk *before* problems show up
* Build vs. buy decisions that won't age badly
* The skills your team needs this year, not in theory

If you're responsible for AI decisions, budgets, platforms, or people—or if you're trying to separate signal from noise—this session is designed for you.
You bring the questions.
We bring the experience.

**Who should attend**

* Technology and business leaders
* Builders, architects, and operators
* Product, data, and platform teams
* Anyone serious about using AI responsibly and effectively

**Location**
Raleigh, NC
Come curious.
Leave smarter.

Source: Meetup: All Things AI

title: Play Board Games at the Geekery
description:
Triangle Board Games and Bars
Come play games at Gamers Geekery and Tavern every thursday night!

Starting time is 6:30, but feel free to come in anytime and just hang out for the night. Group is very casual and friendly.

How it works:
Come on in, grab a name tag and pay the $2.50 meetup participant fee at the bar area, find the tables that are reserved for the Meetup group, play games with others who show up. Food and drinks are available at the bar.

Please RSVP by noon day of. If less than four people are able to attend a given Wednesday the event will be canceled.

Source: Meetup: Triangle Board Games & Bars

title: Thursday Community Board Game night at Moondog Meadery
description:
Durham Geeks
In conjunction with Moon Dog Meadery, we continue to have our Thursday Night Gaming Night from 7 until they kick us out. It's a bit smaller group than the large Monday night extravaganza, and there are a lot of drop in and independent groups here as well. Restaurants are open on Thursdays, so you can Dash you food right inside, or bring it with you!

Moondog has an extensive and ever-changing collection of games that are usually loaned out for a fee, but on Thursdays (just like on Mondays), they are all free to play. Usually we can find folks to fill in your table or teach you the basics of the games. I've been hosting it for a few months now, and we have had a great time with students returning and bringing in new colleagues, as well as the faithful ones who attended over the summer.

Dogs and outside food both allowed and encouraged. Always free! There is award-winning mead on tap and bottled, as well as an ever-changing collection of beer, cider, THC-infused water, colas and, yes, just plain old water to keep you hydrated on your adventure.

Any questions? Contact us here at Durham Geeks!

Source: Meetup: Durham Geeks

title: Pups & Pucks Night with the Carolina Hurricanes
location: Lenovo Center, 1400 Edwards Mill Road, Raleigh, NC
description:
This special ticket package includes your game ticket and a limited edition collapsible Canes-branded water bowl—perfect for showing your love for your furry friends at home while cheering on the Carolina Hurricanes. 
For every ticket purchased a portion will be donated back to Second Chance Pet Adoptions and SPCA of Wake County! 
Tickets and bowls can sell out fast, so be sure to buy your tickets as soon as possible!

Source: Second Chance Pet Adoptions

title: 47th Annual Minority Health Conference
location: Friday Conference Center in Chapel Hill, NC
description:
Join the Gillings School of Global Public Health and the Minority Student Caucus for the 47th Annual Minority Health Conference.

 

This year’s theme, “Uniting Words and Worlds: Innovation in Health Communication,” will explore how creative, inclusive, and evidence-based communication strategies advance health equity and foster understanding across communities.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Africa to Carolina Exhibit at Somerset Place
description:
February 1st marks the start of #BlackHistoryMonth! To commemorate the African diaspora and the impact Black culture has made on United States history, we will re-open our Africa to Carolina exhibit to the public. The Africa to Carolina initiative serves to identify, acknowledge, and mark each site in the state where enslaved Africans disembarked directly from the African Continent. In our self-guided exhibit, visitors can learn about the experiences of enslaved Africans who survived the Atlantic slave trade to North Carolina. Stop by the visitor center for free admission into the exhibit.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Invasive Species Awareness Week
description:
Interested in knowing about what kinds of invasive species we have at Hanging Rock State Park? Well, swing by our Visitor Center and browse through information our park staff have put together on species like the woolly adelgid or the infamous kudzu that we try to actively treat here at the park. Understand the importance of reducing the spread of invasive species and how you may be able to play a role. For questions, reach out to Ranger Fields at Jacob.fields@ncparks.gov

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: AI Literacy Workshop I
description:
Are you ready to level up your artificial intelligence skills ethically, creatively and practically?

The College of Humanities and Social Sciences invites students from all majors and backgrounds who want to better understand generative AI and how it's used in communication, strategy and real-world contexts to attend its AI Literacy Workshop. If you complete the workshop, you'll receive a certificate of completion.

Registration is required. The first 30 registrants will receive a free $50 learning kit and a complimentary lunch. Register today.

Source: NC State University

title: 250th Anniversary of the Battle of Moores Creek Bridge
description:
Moores Creek National Battlefield will be commemorating the 250th Anniversary of the Battle of Moores Creek February 26-28, 2026. This battle was the first decisive patriot victory in the American Revolution and led to North Carolina to be the first colony to authorize its delegates to the 2nd Continental Congress to vote for independence. North Carolina was the "first in freedom."

The basic schedule follows:

Day 1: Thursday, Feb 26--Day of Education (Focus will be on hosting multiple school groups along with traditional living history demonstrations)

Day 2: Friday, Feb 27--Day of Commemoration (The focal point will be a traditional wreath laying ceremony along with living history demonstrations and special guests)

Day 3: Saturday, Feb 28--Day of Community Celebration (This day is set aside as a day of fun with music, games, “Freedom” Art Show, and food trucks along with traditional living history displays)

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Crafting the American Story
description:
In honor of the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence the City of Southport, the Fort Johnston-Southport Museum & Visitors’ Center, and the Brunswick Arts Council invite the community to explore how art, identity, and history intertwine throughout our collective American experience.

Crafting the American Story: Art, Identity, & History celebrates the boundless creativity of Americans—past and present—while recognizing the power of artistic expression to shape, reflect, and challenge our collective narrative.

This exhibition will showcase the creativity of Brunswick County artists while exploring how art reflects and interprets our nation’s history. Through the graphic arts, sculpture and handcrafts, visitors will encounter works that engage with themes of resilience, cultural identity, and the diverse perspectives that enrich our shared story.

What You’ll Discover

The exhibition highlights how creativity has shaped and been shaped by American history over the past 250 years. From responses to adversity and change, to celebrations of cultural heritage, the works on display will show how art captures, or was influenced by, the complexity of the American experience.

The show invites both artists and audiences to reflect on:

How historical events inspire creative expressionThe power of art and handicraft as a storytelling mediumThe inclusion of perspectives often missing from familiar narrativesThe ways resilience, identity, and innovation converge to shape our futureAs part of the program, America 250 NC will present a One Day Wonder traveling exhibit “To Preserve the Blessings of Liberty: State Constitutions of North Carolina.” Featuring copies of the 1776 State Constitution and Declaration of Rights, the 1868 State Constitution, and a letter from John Adams known as “Thoughts on Government,” the exhibit explores North Carolina’s three state constitutions and key amendments, examining how they reshaped ideas of citizenship and expanded, or restricted, participation in the state’s political life. This exhibit will be available for a limited time on opening day only.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Founding Fathers at Latimer House
description:
Historic Latimer House will proudly participate in the America 250 First in Freedom Festival as an official Passport Stamp Cancellation Site, offering visitors a unique opportunity to engage with the nation’s founding history during the festival week, February 21–28.

For one week only, Latimer House will present an extraordinary public viewing of original documents from three Founding Fathers—George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, and James Madison. These rare and significant items are part of the archive of the Lower Cape Fear Historical Society, which is celebrating 70 years of historic preservation work in the region.

In recognition of service, active-duty and veteran military members will receive free admission with valid ID throughout the festival week. Limited tickets are available online at the Latimer House website.

The America 250 First in Freedom Festival commemorates the events and ideals that led to American independence, and Latimer House’s participation highlights the enduring relevance of original historical documents and preservation efforts.

For history enthusiasts, families, students, and visitors alike, Latimer House’s festival programming offers a rare chance to connect directly with the words and legacy of the nation’s founders—available for one week only.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: NC First in Freedom Festival
description:
In 2026 the inaugural North Carolina First in Freedom Festival, taking place throughout Southeastern NC during the week of February 21-28, 2026 (10:00 AM - 4:00 PM), will celebrate more than 250 years of our Nation’s story and culture viewed through the lens of historical North Carolina events and the arts. Please visit the NC FIFF website to see the planned activities: 

https://www.ncfirstinfreedomfestival.com/

Funded in part by an America 250 NC grant, a program of the NC Department of Natural and Cultural Resources.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Soundside Loop Nature Trail Hike
location: Meet at the pavilion beside park visitor center.
description:
Get out and explore with Ranger Austin a one mile loop hike along the Soundside Nature Trail.  Learn more about the environment found at the base of the dunes, including the Roanoke Sound.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Spot It & Stop It: Invasives at Lake James
description:
In recognition of Invasive Species Awareness Week, join Lake James State Park staff for a guided walk and hands-on demonstration focused on identifying and preventing invasive species. Learn how invasive plants impact native ecosystems and what you can do to help stop their spread both in the park and at home. All ages welcome. No experience necessary.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt
description:
The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt showcases how the biblical story of heroic Queen Esther, depicted by Rembrandt and his contemporaries in art and popular culture, expressed ideas of political and religious freedom during the Dutch Golden Age. Charting this history through objects and artworks, The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt provides an original perspective on one of the most studied periods of Dutch prosperity.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: How To Get Started in Research Workshop
description:
Are you interested in research opportunities as an undergraduate student? If so, join the Office of Undergraduate Research during its weekly Zoom workshops that cover a range of commonly asked questions regarding how to find undergraduate research opportunities and how to get started. A Q&A session will be held at the end of the workshop.

Source: NC State University

title: QGIS and GRASS Open-Source GIS
description:
This is a three-part, hands-on GIS course. No previous GIS experience is required. The first session on Monday will be a general overview and introduction to the benefits of Open Source GIS in general, to QGIS in specific, and will include our first hands-on session with QGIS. Topics to be covered include: the QGIS user interface, loading vector and raster files, QGIS plug-ins, web mapping functions, QGIS data manipulation, icons and pull-down tools, basic data manipulation, working with attribute tables, and general familiarity with QGIS. 

Part 2 on Wednesday will continue our work with QGIS, including using the vector, raster, and web analysis functions, using the print composer.  We will also cover the QGIS website, tutorials, listserv, discussion groups, sources of help, etc. 

Part 3 on Friday will focus on the GRASS GIS and other advanced tools available through the QGIS Processing Toolbox within the QGIS interface. Topics covered will include the GRASS vector and raster data formats, GRASS vector, raster, and imagery analysis, GRASS 3-D data (voxels), the raster map calculator, the print composer, and other GRASS capabilities. You can attend just the first, first two, or all dates.

 

Laptops are required for this course, no computers are in the room. Students should download QGIS (www.qgis.org) before the class, and will download the sample data and tutorials (QGIS includes a current version of GRASS) at the start of the class. QGIS runs on Windows, Mac, and Linux systems. At the end of the course, students will have a general ability to use QGIS and GRASS, and can continue learning on their own using the data and tutorials provided.

 

It is highly recommended to bring your power cords, extension cord, and/or powerstrips for your laptops. Come early if you need assistance loading QGIS. Feel free to contact the instructor at: madrys@email.unc.edu

 

This workshop is offered by the University Libraries and will be led by Dr. Scott Madry, with support from library staff, Gracie Riehm and Philip McDaniel. 

 

NOTE: This workshop will be held in-person ONLY in Davis Library, room 246. Space is limited. Please register in advance on the University Libraries calendar: https://calendar.lib.unc.edu/event/16023034

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Teaching in an AI Environment Webinar
description:
How do you deal with artificial intelligence as a graduate teaching assistant? What classroom policies should you have regarding questions of academic integrity? In what ways can generative AI be used to support the processes of teaching and learning? Come explore these questions and related issues in an interactive, discussion-focused workshop.

Source: NC State University

title: Energy Data Made Simple
description:
Ever looked at your utility bill and thought… what does any of this even mean?

Join us for an interactive session designed to help residents better understand the energy information on their utility bills. In this workshop, we move beyond traditional presentations and engage participants in creative, hands-on activities.

Through guided prompts and small-group sketching, you will explore new ways to visualize and communicate energy data in ways that are simple and relatable. Our goal is to make utility bills less confusing and empower residents with knowledge they can use in everyday life. No design or technical experience required, just curiosity and an interest in understanding your energy use.

Presenters:

Rachel Oatis, FT MBA Student, Kenan-Flagler Business SchoolJoseph James, Assistant Professor of Sustainable Technology & the Built Environment, Appalachian State UniversityLocation: Bell Hall 1010

 

Register HERE to attend. https://uncch.givepulse.com/event/825794

 

To view other Carolina Engagement Week events, visit our website. Carolina Engagement Week is co-hosted by Carolina Across 100, the Carolina Center for Public Service, the Carolina Engagement Council, the Center for Thriving Communities, NCGrowth, ncIMPACT and UNC Rural.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Occupational Therapy Rural Health Committee: Reflections from the pilot year
description:
UNC’s Division of OS/OT partnered with Novant Health & UNC Health’s Ingram Institute’s Novant SERVE initiative to form our program’s first-ever Occupational Therapy Rural Health Committee (OTRHC). There are unique strengths and opportunities, as well as barriers and challenges that are imperative to consider when supporting rural healthcare providers and communities. At the conclusion of this session, participants will be able to learn about a concentrated effort to broaden OT services and increase workforce development via the OTRHC program in a 5-county Southeast North Carolina region. Participants will be able to reflect on rural community outreach efforts, and the assets and challenges associated.

Presenters:

Sara Kelleher Peña, Lead, Occupational Therapy Rural Health CommitteeDarius Ingram, Director of Strategic Initiatives, Novant/UNC partnershipEdye Barbour, Novant Health SERVE Program Coordinator, UNC Health Ingram InstituteDr. Jennifer Renshaw, Director of the Occupational Therapy Assistant program at Cape Fear Community CollegeMiranda Bravo, Occupational Therapy student class of 2026

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Sightseeing Tours
description:
Cape Fear Riverboats is excited to announce February Sightseeing Tours for 2026 in support of the North Carolina First in Freedom Festival. For over 35 years, Cape Fear Riverboats has operated captain-narrated Sightseeing & Sunset Tours from downtown Wilmington which is TripAdvisors' Top Destination on the Rise for 2024. Daily tours onboard our current vessels, Henrietta and Osprey, highlight the area's history, legends, and charm, weaving over 400 years of history from the area's founding by English settlers all the way to modern times. For Group or Charter inquiries, please contact sales@capefearriverboats.com. For Public Tour or Sunset tickets, please visit https://capefearriverboats.com/ or call 910-613-9822.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Meet Phi Beta Kappa Visiting Scholar Margo Schlanger
description:
Please join the Taylor Sociology Club and Phi Beta Kappa Visiting Scholar Margo Schlanger for lunch and a chance to talk with her about her work on gender consciousness and the law. Schlanger, who clerked for former Supreme Court Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg, is a professor of law and director of the Civil Rights Litigation Clearinghouse at the University of Michigan Law School. She will discuss "A Reasonable Woman Standard."

All are welcome to attend, but registration is required. Lunch will be provided.

Source: NC State University

title: Introduction to Individual and Aggregate Data Network Models for Understanding Human Processes
description:
Using network models to understand human processes

With increased interest in person-centered interventions and treatments has come increased interest in understanding human processes as they unfold within individuals. Additionally, technological advances have made the collection of person-specific data easier and more cost-effective for researchers interested in studying human behavior within everyday contexts. This two-day course focuses on using two popular network models to explore research questions concerning within-person processes.

This course is intended for individuals with research questions that can be answered using multivariate time series data/intensive longitudinal data. Examples of such data include daily diary data; data collected via self-report through ecological momentary sampling (ESM); passive data from cell phones; and other psychophysiological data such as MRI data or heart rate data.

The two network modeling frameworks presented in this course are graphicalVAR (GVAR) and Group Iterative Multiple Model Estimation (GIMME). Both models can be used to explore processes as they unfold within individuals to obtain individual person-specific network models (idiographic analysis) or group/population level network models (nomothetic analysis).  Differences between the modeling frameworks will be presented. Challenges and considerations for choosing between methods will be discussed.

Statistical models and topics presented during this course include the following:

Vector autoregression (VAR) time series analysis in both non-SEM and SEM frameworksMultilevel Modeling (MLM)Issues with aggregating data when trying to understand within-person processesFitting of network models using graphicalVAR and GIMME approachesApproaches for summarizing idiographic results using meta-analytic techniquesThis course is applied in nature and offers a conceptual overview of the modeling frameworks as well as the technical details needed to fit the models. Examples with hands on learning will be provided throughout the two-day course to give learners the opportunity to practice fitting and interpreting models.

Registration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: In-Person Workshop: How To Write an Abstract
description:
The Office of Undergraduate Research can help students prepare their abstracts for oral research and poster presentations at its in-person abstract workshops. Please attend one of our workshops so we can help you get ready to showcase your hard work on and off campus. We’re also happy to help you one-on-one and point you towards additional opportunities to present your work.

Source: NC State University

title: Free Yoga
location: Partners I – NC State University, Suite 2580
description:
Take a break from your day and enjoy a free yoga class on Centennial Campus. Classes are held every weekday, except when the university is closed, from 12:15 to 1:05 p.m. The classes are open to everyone, and registration is not required. Please bring your own mat.

Source: NC State University

title: Celebration of 250 Years of Freedom
description:
Honoring PVT John Grady of Duplin County. The only Patriot Soldier Killed in the Battle of Moores Creek.

Located in the heart of Kenansville, the Duplin County Veterans Memorial Museum stands as a powerful tribute to the men and women of Duplin County who have served our nation. More than a museum, this meaningful space preserves personal stories, military history, and the enduring legacy of sacrifice, courage, and patriotism.

The Duplin County Veterans Memorial Museum was created to ensure that local veterans are never forgotten. Its exhibits honor those who served in conflicts from World War I to the present day, highlighting not only major moments in U.S. military history but also the individual experiences of Duplin County residents who answered the call to serve.

Photographs, uniforms, medals, letters, and personal artifacts help tell deeply human stories—bringing history to life in a way that feels personal, local, and heartfelt.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Fort Macon Daily Tours – 1:00 p.m.
description:
Guided tours of Fort Macon are available daily at 1:00 p.m. during the Park's slower season between mid Oct. and Mid April.

The tours will last about 45 minutes.

Meet at the fort entrance. Pets are not allowed inside the fort.

 

Photo by C. Peek: The fort at Fort Macon State Park

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Stories of the Revolution: People and Places of Pender County
description:
American Revolution stories of people and places of Pender County (then northern New Hanover County) will be featured in an exhibit. While the Battle of Moores Creek is famous, this exhibit features many other lesser-known stories. The fertile lands of Rocky Point was the residence of many prominent Revolutionary leaders. Stories will be told about members of the Moore, Ashe, Lillington, Swann, Bloodworth, and other families. Free Blacks were also Patriot soldiers, while enslaved Daniel Moore found his liberty with the British. Places of Revolutionary events include the Patriot fort near Rutherford's Mill and Herron's Bridge on the Northeast Cape Fear River. The lovely Sloop Point House, a home of Samuel Ashe, built in 1726 by his father John Baptiste Ashe, still stands on the coast. It’s the 2nd oldest building in the state as it turns 300 years old. Come discover these rich stories of patriotic heritage and more.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Agroecology Farm Volunteer Workday
description:
Come volunteer at the Agroecology Education Farm. This is a great opportunity to work on the farm, learn about sustainable farming, spend time outside and tour the farm. You are welcome to come alone, bring a friend or a group of friends. If you have questions about the volunteer workday, please contact Sara Snyder, farm manager, at sasnyde4@ncsu.edu.

Source: NC State University

title: Fab Friday
description:
Do you love hearing about current events and a variety of topics? Are you looking for a way to build your leadership skills and show off your creativity? If so, the Fabulous Fridays series hosted by the Women's Center is for you. Join your peers and build community through storytelling, discussion, interactive activities and more.

Source: NC State University

title: Beyond the Bubble: Why Should Communities (and Donors) Outside of Chapel Hill Care About Your Work?
description:
As UNC-Chapel Hill faculty, staff, and students, we know the incredible work happening here. But most North Carolinians don’t – and they’re rarely thinking about us. How do we bridge that gap to engage communities effectively?

This interactive session helps participants step outside the Chapel Hill bubble to craft messaging that resonates statewide. Using the Zietlow Fellowship as an example, we’ll explore UNC’s role as one partner among many while workshopping clear, compelling pitches for both community audiences and potential funders. You’ll leave with practical tools to tell your story authentically, build trust beyond campus, and demonstrate impact that matters across North Carolina.

Presenters:

Meridith Whitaker, Foundation Relations Development Officer, University DevelopmentKylie Seltzer, Zietlow Postdoctoral Fellow, Carolina Public Humanities

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Tour: A Closer Look at "Color Concentrated"
description:
Join Ackland educators for a lively half-hour look at a small handful of artworks. These engaging conversational tours offer a closer look at and new perspectives on works on view at the Museum. Today’s tour looks at Color Concentrated: A Salon-Style Show from the Robertson Collection. 
This is a free, walk-in event – no RSVP required. 
This event is part of UNC–Chapel Hill’s Campus Life Experience (CLE) program. Students who attend can scan the QR code provided at the event to receive CLE credit.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Hike with a Ranger
location: Cliffs of the Neuse State Park
description:
Come out and take a hike with a ranger!  Meet at the Overlook Parking lot at 2 pm.  We will hike down past the overlook, down the 350-yard trail, and meander back to the park lot checking out the sights along the way.  Please wear sturdy shoes for hiking and dress appropriately for the weather.  It is recommended that you bring your own water and snacks.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Writer's Toolkit Virtual Workshop
description:
In a virtual two-part workshop, the Graduate School will provide strategies for planning and managing a writing project and fundamental tips for structuring writing for a variety of contexts. Participants will clarify their writing goals for the semester and learn strategies to implement on current and future writing projects. We will use different genres of writing as case studies, so participants can learn tips for summarizing, paraphrasing and synthesizing their writing projects.

Source: NC State University

title: Junior Ranger Hike
description:
Hike with Ranger Marissa on the Maple Run Trail to participate in Junior Ranger activities and earn a Junior Ranger patch! The hike will be about 0.5 miles long on easy terrain. This program is great for younger children and home-school groups looking to get outside. All materials will be provided. Meet at the Park Office to begin.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Japanese Tea Gathering: First Breath of Spring
location: Onsite at Duke Gardens – directions to follow
description:
With tea master Chizuko Sueyoshi and members of the Japanese Tea Practitioners of Durham 
Join us for a moment of respite in the Duke Gardens teahouse, where you will experience the centering calm of a Japanese tea gathering in the Urasenke tradition. Enjoy the aesthetics, poetry and serenity of this rich tradition over an enticing bowl of whisked green tea and a Japanese confection.  Guests will be escorted on a 15-minute walk to the teahouse, where seating is on the floor unless a chair is requested upon registration by emailing GardensEducation@duke.edu. For ages 12 and up. 
Fee: $68; 20% discount for Duke Gardens members with discount code. 
Parking: Parking included. Directions will be included in a program reminder email sent the week before the program. 
Location: Onsite at Duke Gardens. 
Accessibility: This is a small group program that takes place partially seated indoors and partially outdoors, traveling on a combination of paved and unpaved paths with some uneven surfaces and moderate inclines. 
Please note: Construction for the transformative Garden Gateway Project is in progress. The Doris Duke Center and main visitor parking lots are closed for the duration of construction.

Source: Sarah P. Duke Gardens

title: Dungeons & Dragons
description:
Join the Women's Center for Dungeons & Dragons. Whether you're a seasoned pro or new to the game, join us to explore magical realms, craft powerful characters and tell epic stories. Together, we'll roll the dice and create unforgettable adventures in a supportive and empowering environment. Let's dive in and shape our destinies.

Source: NC State University

title: Faculty Council
description:
Location: 1001 Kerr Hall

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Winter Tree ID Hike
location: Lake James State Park- Catawba River Access Picnic Shelter
description:
Join Ranger Greene on a winter tree ID hike at Lake James State Park. Be sure to be prepared for the weather and bring water. Children must be accompanied by an adult. 

Hike- We will meet at the Picnic Shelter at the Catawba River Access. The hike is a moderate 1 mile hike along the Sandy Cliff Overlook, we will go slowly looking at how we can ID different tree species in the winter, stopping halfway to enjoy the views at the Overlook!

Source: NC Cultural Resources

If you lost timber during Hurricane Helene, you may qualify for relief! This FREE workshop will cover who qualifies for the program, how to apply, and what resources are available to mitigate wildfire risk and non-native invasive species.  
REGISTER HERE

Artist's Reception for Legends & Landmarks Exhibition by James C. Horton.

description:
Explore the park after dark with Ranger Austin!  Take advantage of this unique experience, while hearing why Jockey's Ridge is one of North Carolina's most treasured natural areas.  Registration is required in advance.  Meet at the pavilion beside the park's visitor center.  Please email austin.paul@ncparks.gov to signup.  Program time will be 6:30-7:30pm.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: An Evening with Diana Gabaldon
description:
An Evening with Diana Gabaldon at the historic Penderlea Auditorium. This intimate program will feature engaging conversation, storytelling, and insights from the bestselling author whose work has brought colonial America to life for millions of readers. The evening includes an opportunity for a backstage meet-and-greet, giving fans the chance to meet Ms. Gabaldon in person and take photos.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: One Sky, Many Eyes
description: Source: Morehead Planetarium & Science Center

title: Motown Music Bingo for Adults and Seniors
description:
Adults are invited to join us for Motown Music Bingo. We'll play a few rounds and listen to some of the greatest hits. There will be prizes!

You will get a bingo card with different songs and artists, and you'll be able to test your Motown memory while song snippets are played.

Registration required.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Revolutionary Wilmington Walking Tour
description:
Enjoy an exciting walking tour of historic downtown Wilmington during the American Revolutionary War. Local historians will discuss the importance of the Lower Cape Fear in the 18th century. View Wilmington's oldest standing building, circa 1740; the DuBois-Boatwright House from 1768; the Burgwin-Wright House built in 1771; and the earliest public burial ground where rests Cornelius Harnett, the "Samuel Adams of North Carolina." Learn about Great Britain’s grand plan to launch a military campaign against the Southern colonies by way of the Cape Fear River in 1776; the resulting and significant Battle of Moore’s Creek Bridge; the colony's firm commitment to independence; the British occupation and reign of terror in southeastern North Carolina in 1781; and the war’s aftermath in the region. Have you ever heard of the “Midnight Ride of Polly Slocumb”?

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: 25th Annual African American Cultural Celebration
description:
The North Carolina Museum of History proudly presents the annual African American Culture Celebration (AACC)! With support from its community partner, the North Carolina African American Heritage Commission, this signature event kicks off Black History Month by showcasing the rich history, achievements, and cultural contributions of African Americans in North Carolina. For 25 years, the celebration has been hosted by the museum, bringing together community members, organizations, authors, artists, musicians, filmmakers, scholars, and more to highlight the powerful influence of African American heritage on our state’s past and present.

The AACC consists of a virtual education day on Friday and an in-person festival on Saturday. Multiple demonstrations, presentations, and performances reach thousands of people each year, encouraging strong community ties and the celebration of African American culture.

NOTE: While the North Carolina Museum of History building is closed for renovation, this year's festival is being held at the North Carolina Museum of Art. Activities will take place in the East Building and on the Gipson Plaza. Parking is available in the three main museum parking lots.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Stars, Stripes & Shared Traditions: A Pinehurst Recipe Collection Celebrating America’s 250 Years
description:
To celebrate the people, families, and traditions that make Pinehurst special, the Village is creating a community cookbook featuring recipes and stories from residents.

From holiday favorites to handed-down classics, this collection will reflect how traditions — like democracy — are shared, passed on, and shaped by generations.

The recipe submission date has been extended to February 28, 2026.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The 25th Annual African American Cultural Celebration
description:
RESCHEDULED! 
The 25th annual African American Cultural Celebration has been rescheduled for February 28 due to weather-related concerns, at the North Carolina Museum of Art. 
This year marks 25 years that this celebration has brought together African American community members, organizations, authors, artists, musicians, filmmakers, scholars, and more, around a central theme to highlight the contributions that African Americans, past and present, have made to North Carolina’s history and culture. Multiple demonstrations, presentations, and performances reach thousands of people. 
A virtual Education Day for the Cultural Celebration on the preceding Friday was added in 2022.

Source: NC Humanities Council

title: Guided Battlefield Tour with Diana Gabaldon & Park Ranger
description:
On Saturday morning, attendees will be invited to walk in the footsteps of history during a conducted and guided tour of Moores Creek National Battlefield in Currie. Led by a National Park Service ranger and joined by Diana Gabaldon, this immersive tour explores the terrain, turning points, and enduring significance of the 1776 battle that helped secure North Carolina’s legacy as “First in Freedom.”

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Hilltop-Needmore Park (North) Bird Outing
location: Hilltop Needmore Town Park & Preserve, 4621 Shady Greens Dr, Fuquay-Varina, NC 27526, USA
description:
Free Birding trip with Wake Audubon at Hilltop-Needmore Park NORTH

4621 Shady Greens Drive, Fuquay-Varina, NC 27526

Leaders: Larry Zoller and Kyra Thurow Bartow 

Location: Lower Clubhouse Parking Lot

Date: Saturday,  FEBRUARY 28, 2026,  8:30 to 10:30 AM

Come join Wake Audubon for a winter morning bird walk on the North Trail.  The walk is leisurely with frequent stops for birds. There are elevation changes but we often stop to enjoy birds. Please wear shoes good for walking on the dew-covered grassy fairway. Anyone 6 years and up are welcome to join us!

The path we take includes steep inclines, but no stairs.

This walk is usually on the fourth Saturday of most months. 

Ebird hotspot site: https://ebird.org/hotspot/L16295752

Let's Go Birding!


Source: Wake Audubon

title: Africa to Carolina Exhibit at Somerset Place
description:
February 1st marks the start of #BlackHistoryMonth! To commemorate the African diaspora and the impact Black culture has made on United States history, we will re-open our Africa to Carolina exhibit to the public. The Africa to Carolina initiative serves to identify, acknowledge, and mark each site in the state where enslaved Africans disembarked directly from the African Continent. In our self-guided exhibit, visitors can learn about the experiences of enslaved Africans who survived the Atlantic slave trade to North Carolina. Stop by the visitor center for free admission into the exhibit.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The 11th Annual Symposium of the Art Student Graduate Organization - “Anachronic Enchantment: Temporalities in Visual and Material Culture"
description:
The symposium will be held in-person at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill on
Saturday, February 28 from 9:00 AM- 2:30 PM. Presentations will be followed by a Q&A session and are open to a general audience. 
When something is described as anachronistic, it is often to say that it is contradictory, inconsistent, illogical, or misplaced. Essentially, to be anachronistic is to exist outside of historical time. However, has science not demonstrated that time is relative? Is temporality, meaning our relationship with time, not subject to change? Instead of anachronistic, Alexander Nagel and Christopher Wood have coined the term anachronic to refer to art that has “witnessed time.” Art historian, Keith Moxey, adds that anachronicity is the ability of objects “to exceed the parameters of their chronological circumstances.” 
With this in mind, this symposium considers temporality as its central framework and invites interdisciplinary reflection on how time is constructed, experienced, and represented across humanistic study. By foregrounding temporal frameworks, we seek to interrogate whose times are privileged, silenced, or contested, and how alternative conceptions of time challenge dominant narratives. Central to this inquiry are questions that examine how artists have engaged with temporality to construct new and alternative histories; how meaning and interpretation inevitably shift across time, requiring us to reconsider our own scholarly and curatorial practices; and how ephemeral forms of art disrupt and complicate traditional art historical methods.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill
