title: ERSP: Early Spring in Eno
location: Fews Ford Access, Piper-Cox House Parking Lot, 6101 Cole Mill Road, Durham NC 27705
description:
Eno River State Park & Occoneechee Mountain State Natural Area programs are free but have limited space.  
Call or email to sign up!  
(984) 250-1370 | eno.river@ncparks.gov 

Walk with a volunteer along Buckquarter Creek Trail to see some early signs of Spring! Learn to identify early spring ephemeral flowers and other plant species we come across along the trail. Bring binoculars to do some bird watching along the way! Source: Eno River Association

title: 250th Anniversary of the Battle of Moores Creek Bridge
description:
Moores Creek National Battlefield will be commemorating the 250th Anniversary of the Battle of Moores Creek February 26-28, 2026. This battle was the first decisive patriot victory in the American Revolution and led to North Carolina to be the first colony to authorize its delegates to the 2nd Continental Congress to vote for independence. North Carolina was the "first in freedom."

The basic schedule follows:

Day 1: Thursday, Feb 26--Day of Education (Focus will be on hosting multiple school groups along with traditional living history demonstrations)

Day 2: Friday, Feb 27--Day of Commemoration (The focal point will be a traditional wreath laying ceremony along with living history demonstrations and special guests)

Day 3: Saturday, Feb 28--Day of Community Celebration (This day is set aside as a day of fun with music, games, “Freedom” Art Show, and food trucks along with traditional living history displays)

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: CENTURY OF COURAGE: WWI & II LIVING HISTORY EVENT
description:
Museum of the Waxhaws Presents

A Century of Courage: WWI & WWII Living History Event

Saturday, February 28 • 10 AM–4 PM

Step into the stories of two world-changing conflicts as reenactors, historians, and immersive displays bring the World Wars to life. From trenches to home front, from uniforms to equipment, experience a full day of hands-on learning and powerful tribute to the courage that defined a century. Military/Veterans & Kids 5 and under enjoy free admission. 

History comes alive—don’t miss it.

 

General Admission Tickets: https://square.link/u/s1Xdrv2A?src=sheet

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Crafting the American Story
description:
In honor of the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence the City of Southport, the Fort Johnston-Southport Museum & Visitors’ Center, and the Brunswick Arts Council invite the community to explore how art, identity, and history intertwine throughout our collective American experience.

Crafting the American Story: Art, Identity, & History celebrates the boundless creativity of Americans—past and present—while recognizing the power of artistic expression to shape, reflect, and challenge our collective narrative.

This exhibition will showcase the creativity of Brunswick County artists while exploring how art reflects and interprets our nation’s history. Through the graphic arts, sculpture and handcrafts, visitors will encounter works that engage with themes of resilience, cultural identity, and the diverse perspectives that enrich our shared story.

What You’ll Discover

The exhibition highlights how creativity has shaped and been shaped by American history over the past 250 years. From responses to adversity and change, to celebrations of cultural heritage, the works on display will show how art captures, or was influenced by, the complexity of the American experience.

The show invites both artists and audiences to reflect on:

How historical events inspire creative expressionThe power of art and handicraft as a storytelling mediumThe inclusion of perspectives often missing from familiar narrativesThe ways resilience, identity, and innovation converge to shape our futureAs part of the program, America 250 NC will present a One Day Wonder traveling exhibit “To Preserve the Blessings of Liberty: State Constitutions of North Carolina.” Featuring copies of the 1776 State Constitution and Declaration of Rights, the 1868 State Constitution, and a letter from John Adams known as “Thoughts on Government,” the exhibit explores North Carolina’s three state constitutions and key amendments, examining how they reshaped ideas of citizenship and expanded, or restricted, participation in the state’s political life. This exhibit will be available for a limited time on opening day only.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Founding Fathers at Latimer House
description:
Historic Latimer House will proudly participate in the America 250 First in Freedom Festival as an official Passport Stamp Cancellation Site, offering visitors a unique opportunity to engage with the nation’s founding history during the festival week, February 21–28.

For one week only, Latimer House will present an extraordinary public viewing of original documents from three Founding Fathers—George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, and James Madison. These rare and significant items are part of the archive of the Lower Cape Fear Historical Society, which is celebrating 70 years of historic preservation work in the region.

In recognition of service, active-duty and veteran military members will receive free admission with valid ID throughout the festival week. Limited tickets are available online at the Latimer House website.

The America 250 First in Freedom Festival commemorates the events and ideals that led to American independence, and Latimer House’s participation highlights the enduring relevance of original historical documents and preservation efforts.

For history enthusiasts, families, students, and visitors alike, Latimer House’s festival programming offers a rare chance to connect directly with the words and legacy of the nation’s founders—available for one week only.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Let’s Craft! Tricorn Hats in Little Red Schoolhouse
description:
Want to wear a piece of 18th century clothing? Join us in Little Red Schoolhouse as we make and decorate our own tricorn hats, just like the ones worn during the American Revolution! Our Sensory Friendly environment (dim lights, calm room, limited people) will be from 10:00am to 12:00pm. Free. Drop in. All ages welcome.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: NC First in Freedom Festival
description:
In 2026 the inaugural North Carolina First in Freedom Festival, taking place throughout Southeastern NC during the week of February 21-28, 2026 (10:00 AM - 4:00 PM), will celebrate more than 250 years of our Nation’s story and culture viewed through the lens of historical North Carolina events and the arts. Please visit the NC FIFF website to see the planned activities: 

https://www.ncfirstinfreedomfestival.com/

Funded in part by an America 250 NC grant, a program of the NC Department of Natural and Cultural Resources.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Semper Fidelis: A Community Wide Celebration of America 250 in Onslow County
description:
Exhibition Grand Opening Reception at the Onslow County Museum capturing the stories of Onslow County and the American Revolution. A series of vignettes including "The Ordinary," "The Courthouse," "Widows and Orphans," "Black Patriots," "The Longleaf Pine Forest," "The Waterfront and Port," "Loyalists," and more will depict the local Onslow County experience during the era of the American Revolution.

Location: Onslow County Museum; 301 S. Wilmington Street, Richlands, NC 28574

Contact: Lisa_Whitman-Grice@onslowcountync.gov, 910-324-5008

onslowcountync.gov/museum

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt
description:
The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt showcases how the biblical story of heroic Queen Esther, depicted by Rembrandt and his contemporaries in art and popular culture, expressed ideas of political and religious freedom during the Dutch Golden Age. Charting this history through objects and artworks, The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt provides an original perspective on one of the most studied periods of Dutch prosperity.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Thomas Day Narrative: Expanded
description:
In celebration of Black History Month, Thomas Day State Historic Site will be offering a unique guided tour series where visitors can discover lesser-known details about the Day family's involvement in African American achievements throughout the 19th century.

Tours will take place each Saturday in February and involve a short lecture showcasing documents, followed by a guided tour of the site.

Tour dates and times are as follows:
- February 7 at 10am, 1pm, & 3pm
- February 14 at 10am, 1pm, & 3pm
- February 21 at 10am, 1pm, & 3pm
- February 28th at 10am, 1pm, & 3pm

Walk-ins are welcome, but please register in advance using the link so that we can accommodate all: https://forms.gle/8tGXS38yQVWBdGuMA
** Tour fees must be paid on the date of your visit.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Winter Plant ID Hike
description:
Join a Park Ranger at the Lower Trailhead Parking Area for a guided hike with the purpose of identifying dormant native and non-native, invasive plant species. All experience levels are welcome.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: 25th Annual African American Cultural Celebration (rescheduled to Feb. 28)
description:
The 25th Annual African American Cultural Celebration has been rescheduled for Saturday, Febraury 28 due to weather-related concerns to ensure a safe and welcoming experience for all participants and guest. 

The Virtual Education Day will still be held on Friday, January 30. 

The North Carolina Museum of History proudly presents the annual African American Culture Celebration (AACC)! With support from its community partner, the North Carolina African American Heritage Commission, this signature event kicks off Black History Month by showcasing the rich history, achievements, and cultural contributions of African Americans in North Carolina. For 25 years, the celebration has been hosted by the museum, bringing together community members, organizations, authors, artists, musicians, filmmakers, scholars, and more to highlight the powerful influence of African American heritage on our state’s past and present.

The AACC consists of a virtual education day on Friday and an in-person festival on Saturday. Multiple demonstrations, presentations, and performances reach thousands of people each year, encouraging strong community ties and the celebration of African American culture.

NOTE: While the North Carolina Museum of History building is closed for renovation, this year's festival is being held at the North Carolina Museum of Art. Activities will take place in the East Building and on the Gipson Plaza. Parking is available in the three main museum parking lots.

title: Birding for Beginners
location: Duke Gardens Lewis St. Entrance, 2000 Lewis Street, Durham, NC, 27705, United States
description:
Bundle up and build your bird observation skills on a slow stroll through Duke Gardens with Bella Insignares, education staff at Duke Gardens, as you gather a list of different birds that use the Gardens. If you have ever found yourself wondering about the birds that are flying or singing around you, join us to learn more together as a group. Bring your own binoculars if you have them (not required) and a sense of curiosity. 
Fee: $10 per person; free for Duke Gardens members with discount code. 
Parking: Parking fees apply. Suggested parking location is in the H lot near the 2000 Lewis St. entrance. 
Location:  Meet at 2000 Lewis St. entrance; program will take place throughout Duke Gardens. 
Accessibility: This program is designed for small groups outdoors using fully accessible paths of travel. 
Please note: Construction for the transformative Garden Gateway Project is in progress. The Doris Duke Center and main visitor parking lots are closed for the duration of construction. 


Source: Sarah P. Duke Gardens

title: Black Genius Fest
description:
Black Genius Fest 2026 is a free, interactive celebration honoring the 100th anniversary of Black History Month. This year's theme, "Architects of the Dream: Past, Present, Future," honors those who built the foundation, celebrates the parents and educators shaping learning today, and inspires the children who will design tomorrow.

Held on Durham's historic Parrish Street—the heart of the original Black Wall Street—Black Genius Fest brings together over 18 interactive exhibitions for participants of all ages. From hands-on art and science activities to storytelling and performances, every experience is designed to affirm the brilliance within children and the wisdom within Durham families and communities.

Black Genius Fest is rooted in Village of Wisdom's mission to protect and nurture Black Genius through culturally affirming learning environments created by and for the community.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Hidden Battleship Tour
description:
Hidden Battleship is for the explorer at heart! Join us for an afternoon on a unique, behind-the-scenes tour of unrestored areas on the Battleship. Organized into small groups, the participants are led to areas in the bow, third deck, and below, and the superstructure, including all the way to the very top! This program requires climbing ladders, crossing high hatches, and going through tight/confined spaces. The tour is limited to ages 16 and older.

2026 Dates

► January 24
► February 28
► March 28
► April 18
► November 14

11 am – 5 pm; $75 (plus tax) per participant. This program always sells out, so get your Hidden Battleship ticket now! This program is for ages 16 and older.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: NC AFLCIO’s LABOR IN LOVE
description:
Free Family Fun Day

Labor Unions, Community Organizations and Blood donations, Games, Freebies and Community Resources

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: "Field & Factory: A Look at Tobacco’s Laborers" at Duke Homestead
description:
To learn a fuller story of the people who worked in tobacco, join Duke Homestead staff on site for a special program, “Field & Factory: A Look at Tobacco’s Laborers.” These walks will highlight the contributions that each group of people working in tobacco made to North Carolina’s culture and powerful economy in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, while addressing the inequalities in tobacco’s labor forces.

We will depart from the visitor’s center lobby at 11:15am and 2:15pm on Saturday, February 7th, 14th, 21st, and 28th. Admission is free.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Sightseeing Tours
description:
Cape Fear Riverboats is excited to announce February Sightseeing Tours for 2026 in support of the North Carolina First in Freedom Festival. For over 35 years, Cape Fear Riverboats has operated captain-narrated Sightseeing & Sunset Tours from downtown Wilmington which is TripAdvisors' Top Destination on the Rise for 2024. Daily tours onboard our current vessels, Henrietta and Osprey, highlight the area's history, legends, and charm, weaving over 400 years of history from the area's founding by English settlers all the way to modern times. For Group or Charter inquiries, please contact sales@capefearriverboats.com. For Public Tour or Sunset tickets, please visit https://capefearriverboats.com/ or call 910-613-9822.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

location: Ackland Art Museum, 101 S. Columbia Street, Chapel Hill, NC, 27514, United States
description:

title: Durham Farmers' Market
location: Durham Central Park, 501 Foster Street, Durham, NC, 27701, United States
description:
The Durham Farmers’ Market is a community of farmers, growers and crafters. We are strongly committed to local products: every item you see at the market was produced by the people selling it, and it all comes from no more than 70 miles away. 
The Durham Farmers’ Market open Saturdays mornings for local produce, flowers, crafts and more! The Wednesday Market is open from 3-6pm Wednesdays, Mid-April through Mid-October 
If you’d like more information about this week’s vendor list, SNAP benefits and map, visit durhamfarmersmarket.com 

We are happy to offer Double Bucks to our SNAP clients. This means is a SNAP client has $10, they receive $20 in tokens to spend at the winter market.

Estamos muy contentos de ofrecer Double Bucks a nuestros clientes de SNAP. Esto significa que si un cliente de SNAP gasta $ 10, recibirá $ 20 en tokens para gastar en productos frescos.


Additionally, we offer a cash match program for other qualifying folks. To receive this benefit, simply bring cash to the info table. Then, we’ll double the amount with tokens. For example, $10 in cash equals $20 in tokens.

También ofrecemos un programa de contrapartida en efectivo para nuestros beneficiarios de SNAP que no tienen beneficios durante el mes, clientes de WIC y miembros de la comunidad que viven en viviendas públicas. Para recibir este beneficio, simplemente traiga efectivo a la tabla de información y duplicaremos la cantidad con tokens. Por ejemplo, $ 10 en efectivo equivalen a $ 20 en fichas.

Source: Durham Central Park

title: Morrow Mountain Winter Hikes (Albemarle)
description:
Join our newly forming NCWF Uwharrie Wildlife Stewards Chapter at Morrow Mountain State Park for a real adventure! Morrow Mountain is a special sanctuary for people and wildlife alike. We will attend a guided hike of the historical Quarry Trail which is less than one mile in length. Park staff will discuss a number of subjects including: the unique geology of the Uwharries, CCC construction at the park, and we will visit a known vernal pool wetland. 
For those craving more of a challenge, stick around for the optional hike on Hattaway Mountain Trail. This three and one half mile round trip trail features moderate to strenuous terrain and extensive views of Stanly and Montgomery Counties. 
Quarry Trail is a FAMILY-FRIENDLY hike and ideal for young children. Hattaway Mountain is a longer hike and more strenuous difficulty. Recommended for ages 13 and up. Folks under 18 must always be accompanied by an adult. Total trail distance combined is approximately 4 miles. 
REGISTER HERE

Source: NC Wildlife Federation

title: Speed Hike at Johnston Mill
location: Johnston Mill Main Entrance, 2713 Mt. Sinai Rd, Chapel Hill, NC, 27514, United States
description:
Come join TLC for an invigorating speed hike to wake up your Saturday morning!
This hike is led by one of our wonderful Trail Guides and will have a goal pace of 20 minutes per mile for about 3 miles. Explore Johnston Mill and see what all you can find while keeping your heart healthy, and socializing on trail. This is a free event but preregistration is required.


 

If registration is full, please fill out the waitlist form here by February 26th.

Current Mask Policy: TLC seeks to build a supportive, mask-friendly environment in all collaborations with staff and the public. Please wear a mask if you are not vaccinated, or if that makes you feel most comfortable. We will have masks available if you would like to wear one during an event. We also encourage those eligible to be vaccinated to get their Covid-19 vaccine and booster shot. If you are experiencing any Covid-related symptoms, please stay home and attend a program another day. Our top priority is to create a safe environment for our community. Thank you for your understanding.

Source: Triangle Land Conservancy

title: Kayak/Paddle Through History on Moore's Creek
description:
Kayak/Paddle round trip from the Moores Creek Battleground. Paddle starts in the park, proceeds under the historic bridge and down the black waters of Moores Creek. Experience the river as it was in 1776. History and Nature in the black river waters of Moores Creek.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: NCMA Student Short-Film Festival
description:
The NCMA is hosting its first-ever student short-film festival. Short films are an exciting form that allows aspiring filmmakers and artists to experiment and grow, which the NCMA is eager to help foster. 

Tickets $5, Members $3

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Cooking Outdoors
location: Carvers Creek State Park – Long Valley Farm Access
description:
Join Ranger Baker for a fun and flavorful outdoor cooking program at Carvers Creek State Park! Learn different ways to cook outside— With a grill or using simple outdoor cooking techniques—while discovering tips for safe and tasty meals in the great outdoors. Perfect for beginners and curious cooks of all ages. Meet at picnic area in front of office.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Keep Charlotte Beautiful (Charlotte)
description:
Go clean and green by joining NCWF Charlotte Wildlife Stewards Chapter in a trash cleanup along a stretch of Tyvola Road. Trash is harmful to wildlife and pollutes our streams, rivers, and oceans. Did you know that every 25 pounds of trash collected turns into a native tree planted by the North Carolina Wildlife Federation? That’s the green part! All tools and equipment will be provided. 
REGISTER HERE

Source: NC Wildlife Federation

title: Invasive Plant Species Removal (Roper)
description:
Join NCWF Wildlife Habitat Stewards of Northeastern NC Chapter and Spruill Conservation Farm for a hands-on habitat restoration project on Saturday, February 28, from 10 am to 12 pm. Together, volunteers will focus on removing invasive heavenly bamboo (Nandina domestica) along the farm’s wooded nature trail. 
Heavenly bamboo poses a threat to local ecosystems as it spreads quickly when birds eat its berries and disperse the seeds, allowing dense thickets to form that crowd out native plants and reduce habitat quality for wildlife. Its berries are also highly toxic, releasing cyanide when eaten, and birds such as cedar waxwings have been known to die after consuming large quantities. 
This volunteer effort will involve digging, prying, cutting, and lifting plant roots, so participants should be prepared for physical activity. It’s a great opportunity to make a meaningful impact on the trail and the wildlife that depends on it.
 
REGISTER HERE

Source: NC Wildlife Federation

title: Fort Macon Daily Tours – 1:00 p.m.
description:
Guided tours of Fort Macon are available daily at 1:00 p.m. during the Park's slower season between mid Oct. and Mid April.

The tours will last about 45 minutes.

Meet at the fort entrance. Pets are not allowed inside the fort.

 

Photo by C. Peek: The fort at Fort Macon State Park

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Saturday Social at the Park Info Table

title: Winter Tree and Plant Identification
description:
Join Ken Crouse on February 28 at 1:00pm to walk the Talking Tree Trail and learn how to identify different tree and plant species in the winter.  Be sure to dress for the weather and bring water! See you there!

This event is part of UNC–Chapel Hill’s Campus Life Experience (CLE) program. Students who attend can scan the QR code provided at the event to receive CLE credit.

title: Magic Tree House Space Mission

title: Black History Tours at Old Salem
description:
Explore engaging demonstrations and stories in our historic buildings, then meet our guides for a walking tour that highlights the town’s history and the evolving story of Black history over time. Visitors are encouraged to ask questions and engage one-on-one with our interpretive staff as they discover the stories of Old Salem’s most impactful community members and witness their living legacies this month.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Yoga In Nature™, YOGA + HIKE + HOT TEA
description:
Yoga In Nature™, NC
**FINDING PEACE. Winter months bring Yoga + Hiking + Hot Tea, as we explore our yoga (+ hike) and connect with nature through all of our senses.** Let us feel grounded and connected to the earth as we move through our practice. ***This is a "pay when you sign up" to hold your spot, as spaces are limited. $25/person***
Venmo @Darlene-Genander (0862 if asked)
OR PayPal dgenander@yogainnature.com
Also accepting Zelle

Get a healthy dose of Yoga In Nature™ as we move through a 45 minute vinyasa flow yoga practice (ALL LEVELS INCLUDING FIRST TIMERS) then we walk in the woods, as we explore nature with all of our senses! Winter is a wonderful time to move through nature and experience the stillness, yet observe all that is alive. Allow 2.5 hours for the full event (although it could be closer to 2 hours if you choose to hike quickly and skip the tea/gathering at the end).

Yoga, hike, hot tea and community gathering:)

We will meet at Shinleaf, Falls Lake location and will explore our edges and breath, as we connect to our natural surroundings. NO MAT NEEDED. We will work through a standing slow flow, growing roots and connecting to the earth. Then we will take a 2-3 mile out and back hike to Shinleaf Point, on trails (alternate route from this parking as an option if needed) Feel free to bring an insulated mug to carry on our journey (or I will have cups for tea).

Wear layers and good shoes for hiking.

If it rains, is freezing, or generally inclement weather, I will cancel at least 24 hours in advance and reschedule for the following weekend.

Source: Meetup: Yoga In Nature NC

title: Diana Gabaldon Book Signing Event at Lucas Farm
description:
A special book signing event at Lucas Farm, offering fans another opportunity to meet Diana Gabaldon in a scenic and historic rural setting. One person and one book per ticket.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Snakes of NC
description:
Learn all about the variety of snakes native to North Carolina and which ones call Eastern NC home! Uncover their unique adaptations, life cycles, and the critical roles they play in local ecosystems.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Japanese Tea Gathering: First Breath of Spring
location: Onsite at Duke Gardens – directions to follow
description:
With tea master Chizuko Sueyoshi and members of the Japanese Tea Practitioners of Durham 
Join us for a moment of respite in the Duke Gardens teahouse, where you will experience the centering calm of a Japanese tea gathering in the Urasenke tradition. Enjoy the aesthetics, poetry and serenity of this rich tradition over an enticing bowl of whisked green tea and a Japanese confection.  Guests will be escorted on a 15-minute walk to the teahouse, where seating is on the floor unless a chair is requested upon registration by emailing GardensEducation@duke.edu. For ages 12 and up. 
Fee: $68; 20% discount for Duke Gardens members with discount code. 
Parking: Parking included. Directions will be included in a program reminder email sent the week before the program. 
Location: Onsite at Duke Gardens. 
Accessibility: This is a small group program that takes place partially seated indoors and partially outdoors, traveling on a combination of paved and unpaved paths with some uneven surfaces and moderate inclines. 
Please note: Construction for the transformative Garden Gateway Project is in progress. The Doris Duke Center and main visitor parking lots are closed for the duration of construction.

Source: Sarah P. Duke Gardens

title: Supermassive Black Holes
description: Source: Morehead Planetarium & Science Center

title: Bull City Brews: A Taste of Durham's Past (Hosted by West Point on the Eno)
description:
Let's get together to discover Durham's history one pint at a time! Durham has been a city of constant creativity and innovation since 1869. From it's origins as a tobacco boom town and home to the most successful Black Wall Street in the country, to its modernization as a place for ingenuity, recreation, and entertainment, Durham has the stories you won't want to miss! Put on your walking shoes as our historic guides take you on a tour through the Bullpen Social District to learn about Durham's past while enjoying beverages from several local spots.

 

Hosted by historians from West Point on the Eno

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Open House
description:
Splat Space - Durham's Hackerspace
Every Saturday between 1pm to 4pm we open our doors to the public to give anyone who wants to stop by a chance to see our space. It's a chance for prospective new members to take a tour of our space and ask any questions they have about what we offer.

Feel free to come by or contact us if you want to schedule a tour.

Source: Meetup: Splat Space (Durham Hackerspace)

title: Fox Creek Livestaking Workshop (Swannanoa)
description:
Swannanoa Valley WILD, Friends of Fox Creek Park, Swannanoa Community Council, and WNC Grows are excited to announce a livestaking workshop at Fox Creek Park in Swannanoa. We’ve removed a significant portion of invasive kudzu along Fox Creek and now it’s time to replant with native species like silky dogwood, ninebark, and elderberry in an effort to control erosion and provide habitat for wildlife. Participants will learn how to use the livestaking technique on their own properties while helping us restore Fox Creek along the way. Participants will also receive a bundle of livestakes to take home with them free of charge! Special thanks to the Pigeon River Fund of the Community Foundation of WNC and National Wildlife Federation’s Trees For Wildlife Program for making this workday possible. 
REGISTER HERE

Source: NC Wildlife Federation

title: Bamboo Redux (Cary)
description:
Please join NCWF South Wake Conservationists Chapter in removing invasive plants from the banks of Swift Creek at Hemlock Bluffs Nature Preserve in Cary. Volunteers will work on removing privet, bamboo, and wisteria. All of these plants are extremely aggressive and are threatening native plants in the preserve. Come help us in our relentless pursuit of invasive removal!  
REGISTER HERE

Source: NC Wildlife Federation

title: Nature Connection Walk
location: Williamson Farm and Nature Preserve, 4429 Old Country Mial Rd, Raleigh, 27610, United States
description:
Join us for a mindful stroll around Williamson Nature Preserve!
Deepen your connection with nature on a slow-and-easy ramble around the Two Pond Loop Trail with certified interpretive naturalist and environmental educator Margot Lester. This session includes sense-sharpening, mindfulness and nature journaling activities to help us slow down and reconnect with the natural world. Come dressed for the weather and uneven terrain. Bring a water bottle, your curiosity and — if you want to journal — your favorite writing materials. This excursion counts towards the NC-EE Criteria II, III or continuing ed hours.  This event is free, but preregistration is required.

 

 

 



 

 

If registration is full, please fill out the waitlist form here by February 26th.

Inclement Weather Policy: In the event of inclement weather, you will be contacted by email for a call on cancellation or postponement. At our Williamson and Brumley South Nature Preserves, due to the multi-use trail systems, we close the trails to the public if there has been rain to try and prevent erosion and detrimental impact. Please note that this event falls under this category and will be cancelled if the trails are closed.

title: Get Wild: Let's Explore Lichens!
location: Swift Creek Bluffs Nature Preserve, 7800 Holly Springs Rd, Raleigh, NC, 27606, United States
description:
Join us for a family friend Lichen Exploration hike!
Let's get to likin' lichen on this ramble through the swift creek bottomlands. Come explore the special symbiosis that lichens use to live, and learn about the different kinds of lichens in the piedmont woods around us.

Play some nature games, build your skills of observation by entering their teeny tiny world, and start to notice the lichen all around you!

Get Wild! Hikes and activities are most appropriate for 5 years and up. Wear layers and bring a water bottle. Please register all members of the family attending, including children and adults.

This is a free event, but pre-registration is required.



If registration is full for this hike, please email Meera Butalia at mbutalia@triangleland.org to be added to the waitlist.

Please remember to wear good walking shoes and bring a full water bottle. The parking area is very limited so please carpool with your guests if you can. Please make sure to let us know if your plans have changed so that we can admit anyone on the waitlist! Below are current event policies:

Current Mask Policy: TLC seeks to build a supportive, mask-friendly environment in all collaborations with staff and the public. Please wear a mask if you are not vaccinated, or if that makes you feel most comfortable. We will have masks available if you would like to wear one during an event. We also encourage those eligible to be vaccinated to get their Covid-19 vaccine and booster shot. If you are experiencing any Covid-related symptoms, please stay home and attend a program another day. Our top priority is to create a safe environment for our community. Thank you for your understanding.

Inclement Weather Policy: In the event of inclement weather, you will be contacted by email for a call on cancellation or postponement. At our Williamson and Brumley South Nature Preserves, due to the multi-use trail systems, we close the trails to the public if there has been rain to try and prevent erosion and detrimental impact. You will also be contacted by email if the event is capable of being held, but the trails are closed.

title: Moonlight Hike with a Ranger
location: Cliffs of the Neuse State Park
description:
Come out and take a hike in the moonlight with a ranger!  Meet at the Visitor Center at 7 pm.  We will hike down to the swim lake, walk the beach, and meander back to the Visitor Center, exploring the park in the moonlight.  Please bring a working flashlight, wear sturdy shoes, and dress appropriately for the weather.  It is recommended that you bring your own water and snacks.

title: United Strings of Color: Partnership in Black Music
description:
Become inspired by three musical partnerships that encouraged and championed Black classical music. As cultural pioneers from various backgrounds, these performing partners found connection in the shared experience of navigating multiple worlds, and actively helped to bring new music to the public. United Strings of Color invites you to learn about this blossoming of appreciation for Black classical music through our performance of chamber works and telling the story of their unique history!

title: NHBA Bird Outing
description:
Contact Claire Cote at clairemccote@gmail.com with questions.  The location will be Bluestem Conservation Cemetery, 1900 Hurdle Mills Road, Cedar Grove, NC 27231. Take 86 north out of Hillsborough. Drive 8.1 miles from US 70, then turn right on Caviness Jordan Road. That road will tee into Hurdle Mills Road in roughly two miles. Go right and Bluestem will be on the left. Meet in the parking lot. It's a 'green cemetery' with walking trails and a pond.

This outing is sponsored by the New Hope Bird Alliance (formerly New Hope Audubon).

Outings usually last 2-3 hours. No reservations or sign-up needed. If there is a large turnout for any particular outing, we may split into two groups. We do recommend carpooling for families or friend pods; while we love pets, there is a ‘no-pet’ policy for bird outings. New birders and birders of all skill levels are welcome.

Please wear long pants, socks, and sturdy shoes (ticks and chiggers may be present). Sun and bug protection are also recommended. Bring snacks and water if you like. Heavy rain will result in cancellation. Source: New Hope Bird Alliance

title: Rescheduled - ERA Guided History Hike - Pump Station
description:
Registration is full for this hike, as it is a rescheduled event.

Stroll through history on this hike featuring Durham’s first public drinking water source. Building foundations and dams still surface in the woods, river, and creek. We may see signs of spring, including foliage of early wildflowers. Portions of the hike will be off-trail, some sections may be steep, muddy, or on rough terrain. A walking stick is highly recommended, and sturdy shoes are a must. Time permitting, we will hike the remainder of the 1.5 mile loop. Source: Eno River Association

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt
description:
The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt showcases how the biblical story of heroic Queen Esther, depicted by Rembrandt and his contemporaries in art and popular culture, expressed ideas of political and religious freedom during the Dutch Golden Age. Charting this history through objects and artworks, The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt provides an original perspective on one of the most studied periods of Dutch prosperity.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Bagels, Bikes, Breaking Down Transportation
description:
Do you want to learn the easiest way to bike from main campus to downtown Raleigh? If so, join the Sustainability Stewards for a chill, beginner-friendly group ride from the back of Carmichael Gym along the Reedy Creek Greenway to the new Benchwarmers Bagels location in downtown. The ride is about 15 minutes each way. We'll spend 45 minutes eating food, hanging out and chatting before we cruise back to campus through Dorothea Dix Park. This is a relaxed, no-pressure ride — perfect for if you’ve never biked to downtown before and want to learn a route in a fun, social setting. Meet us at the Fix-It Station behind Carmichael Gym at 10 a.m.

Source: NC State University

The tours will last about 45 minutes.

Bring plenty of drinking water, wear appropriate clothing for the weather and closed-toed shoes.

title: ERA - Guided History Hike - Holden Mill
location: Eno River State Park - Fews Ford Access, Piper-Cox House Parking Lot, 6101 Cole Mill Rd, Durham, NC 27705, USA
description:
Registration is required - Tickets drop on February 1st at 8:00am!
Price: $4
*Ticket prices directly support the work of the Eno River Association. Thank you for your support!

Hike the most scenic stretch of the Eno River past many rock outcrops and rapids to the stone ruins of the old Holden Mill. This 4 mile hike includes a walk along the river as well as up some long hill climbs through beautiful old hardwood forest. A hiking staff is recommended. Source: Eno River Association

title: Early Spring Meander at Swift Creek Bluffs
location: Swift Creek Bluffs Nature Preserve, 7800 Holly Springs Rd, Raleigh, NC, 27606, United States
description:
Take a stroll through the calming scenery of Swift Creek Bluffs!
With a focus on looking for signs of spring, we will saunter rather than power-walk through the woods. Join TLC Trail Guide and naturalist, Julie Hall, to walk slowly for 1.5 miles and stop for moments of silence to appreciate the nourishing wonder and beauty of nature!  You will have an opportunity to hike up the "Stairway to Heaven" and take in the lush hardwood canopy and meandering Swift Creek below, while sitting on a bench at the top of the 100-ft bluffs. 

This is a free event, but preregistration is required. Due to the size of the parking lot, we will keep the hiking group small and ask that you register by vehicle rather than individual. Feel free to bring guests but please carpool to ensure we have enough space in the parking lot.

 



 

If registration is full, please fill out this waitlist form by February 26th.

Current Mask Policy: TLC seeks to build a supportive, mask-friendly environment in all collaborations with staff and the public. We also encourage those eligible to be vaccinated to get their Covid-19 vaccine and booster shot. If you are experiencing any Covid-related symptoms, please stay home and attend a program another day. Our top priority is to create a safe environment for our community. Thank you for your understanding.

title: AI Assisted Surveys
description:
This course will be held online only over 3 days. Attendance is required as it will not be recorded.

This 6-hour course provides training on how AI can assist a survey project from beginning to the end.

We will focus on each step of the research process (Callegaro and Yang, 2025)

PlanningExecutionActivationIn the planning phase there are two sub phases
1) Ideate and define

AI can be an idea helper and assist on generating research ideas starting from previously knowledgeA literature review can definitely be assisted by AI and there are specific tools available for that2) Design and plan

The design stage is where AI can assist in producing design brief, analysis plan and map the concepts that are going to be measured using the questionnaireThe execution phase consists of
3) Data wizard

Here AI has been used to help drafting and pretesting the questionnaire, help writing survey material such as survey invitation and confidentiality assurances.4) Analysis copilot

Once the data collection is under way, AI can assist in automating, and writing statistical code to analyze the dataset (stat code assistant). It can also be used as  theme discovery, for coding of open ended answers and data visualization.The activation phase consists of:
5) Insight partner

Help summarize findings, generate reports, help review the final deliverables such as a research report or a complete academic paper6) Storytelling aid

Develop presentation materials, create multi-media artifacts, generated blog post for different platforms, generate images based on content from the researchOrganizational Structure of the Course 
The course will be taught in a workshop style where the lectures will be using presentation slides as a roadmap. After each concept has been introduced and discussed, the participants will be invited to work on brief hands on exercises with different LLMs such as Gemini, Claude, Copilot, and ChatGPT

Participants will be strongly encouraged to ask questions during lectures, especially on how the content relates to their own research.

Learning objectives
By the end of the course, you will:

Learn how to prompt LLMs for survey research help and assistanceLearn how to evaluate the quality of LLMs outputsStrengths and challenges of different LLMs toolsWhere LLMs are not necessaryEthical usage of LLMs/AI ToolsRecent debate of using LLMs to produce research and write academic papersRegistration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: The Tactile Page: Poetry, Process, and Letterpress: Panel with 2026 Frank B. Hanes Writer-in-Residence, Ross Gay
description:
Panel: The Tactile Page: Poetry, Process, and Letterpress

Davis Library Room 295

Moderator: Pr Carlina Duan

Panelists:

Ross Gay, 2026 Frank B. Hanes Writer-in-ResidenceNadia Clifton, Special Collections Instruction Librarian, Wilson Special Collections LibraryJosh Hockensmith, Book and print artistAaron Smithers, Special Collections Research & Instructional Services LibrarianHow do poets pay attention to language as a material form? What might the letterpress teach us about rejuvenating our relationships to making and reading poetic text? How do poets and printers engage with the physical life and process of inking words on a page? Please join Hanes Writer-in-Residence Ross Gay and the Creative Writing Program for a special panel discussion on poetic attention and the letterpress, where we explore these questions, and more! This conversation will feature award-winning poet and essayist Ross Gay, author of Book of Delights and Be Holding—alongside UNC librarians, poets, and printmakers. Together, we will explore poetry of the handmade, followed by a live demo of the University Libraries' letterpress.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Free Yoga
location: Partners I – NC State University, Suite 2580
description:
Take a break from your day and enjoy a free yoga class on Centennial Campus. Classes are held every weekday, except when the university is closed, from 12:15 to 1:05 p.m. The classes are open to everyone, and registration is not required. Please bring your own mat.

Source: NC State University

description:
Join campus dietitian Soo Uhm for an interactive session about nutrition misinformation and how to avoid harmful mindsets about food as part of Eating Disorders Awareness Week. All students are welcome to attend.

title: How To Get Started in Research Workshop
description:
Are you interested in research opportunities as an undergraduate student? If so, join the Office of Undergraduate Research during its weekly Zoom workshops that cover a range of commonly asked questions regarding how to find undergraduate research opportunities and how to get started. A Q&A session will be held at the end of the workshop.

Source: NC State University

title: Pathways After a Degree in Film, Games and Media Studies
description:
Ever wonder where a degree in film, games or media studies can take you? Join the Film Studies Program and the Department of English for a candid panel discussion with three professionals. You'll hear how they’ve navigated paths from conducting research into roles such as curating a game museum, developing artificial intelligence for storytelling and teaching media culture. The panelist will be:

Mirek Stolee, curator for tabletop games and puzzles at The Strong National Museum of PlayDevi Acharya, a senior data scientist at Take-Two AILaijana Braun, a research associate and lecturer in media aesthetics and culture at the Braunschweig University of Art in Germany

Source: NC State University

title: Provost Search Candidate Selection Meeting
description:
The search committee for the executive vice chancellor and provost position will hold a candidate selection meeting. Agenda items include reviewing and selecting candidates for first-round interviews. Public participation is welcome during the open session.

Source: NC State University

title: SPEL Talk: Education and Polarization in American Politics
description:
The Society for Politics, Economics and the Law will present a lecture by Matt Grossmann, a professor of political science at Michigan State University. Grossman will discuss education and polarization in American politics.

Source: NC State University

title: Data In Society, Not Data As Society
description:
Join the Department of Communication as we welcome author and UCLA professor Dr. Safiya Noble to campus for a research talk and Q/A session. Her academic research focuses on the internet and its impact on society.

 

Professor Noble is the author of the best-selling book on algorithmic harm in commercial search engines, entitled Algorithms of Oppression: How Search Engines Reinforce Racism (NYU Press), which has been widely-reviewed in scholarly and popular publications.

 

Free and open to the public. CLE credit available.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: 2026 Frank B. Hanes Writer-in-Residence Reading with Ross Gay
description:
Reading by Ross Gay, 2026 Frank B. Hanes Writer-in-Residence. Ross Gay is the author of four books of poetry: Against Which; Bringing the Shovel Down; Be Holding, winner of the PEN American Literary Jean Stein Award; and Catalog of Unabashed Gratitude, winner of the 2015 National Book Critics Circle Award and the 2016 Kingsley Tufts Poetry Award. In addition to his poetry, Ross has released three collections of essays—The Book of Delights was released in 2019 and was a New York Times bestseller; Inciting Joy was released in 2022, and his newest collection, The Book of (More) Delights was released in September of 2023.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Plant-Lover's Tour: Ladies' Choice
description:
March is Women's History Month, and the JC Raulston Arboretum (JCRA) will celebrate with a special Plant-Lover's Tour: Ladies' Choice. Join JCRA Nursery Technician Sophia McCusker and master's student and former JCRA intern Eileen Gahan as they lead you through the garden, highlighting the plants they love most. From early spring showstoppers already bursting into bloom to dependable favorites that deserve a little more appreciation, this tour is all about personal picks with professional insight.

And because it's Ladies' Choice, you can expect a few wild cards on the tour, such as plants that do great in containers and are impossible to kill in the nursery and plants that definitely do not grow in Ireland but seem to do amazing here. 

Come see what makes the cut when McCusker and Gahan get to choose their favorites and discover a few new must-have plants for your own garden.

Source: NC State University

title: AI in Research Series – AI and Simple Statistics
description:
AI in Research: Driving Innovation Forward

Discover how artificial intelligence can streamline workflows, uncover hidden patterns, and empower breakthroughs in your field. Learn practical applications of AI through Odum Institute AIR series that can revolutionize your research process.

AI, for example ChatGPT, may be used to carry out some tasks commonly used by social scientists. Examples include Pearson’s chi-square test, Fisher’s exact test, Student’s t-test, power calculations and non-centrality parameters. The quality of responses has varied to this point and may continue to at the time of the class. Examples will be given.

You must have a UNC Chapel Hill Onyen to register and attend this course. No registration fees required but you must register to secure your spot and receive the Zoom link.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Lunch and Learn: How Small Orgs and Non-Profits are Getting Value out of AI
description:
All Things AI (Live)
Small organizations and nonprofits face mounting pressure to adopt AI while operating on tight budgets without dedicated tech teams. Their bilingual, client-facing staff already juggle direct service, paperwork, and community outreach—they're not writing code, and they shouldn't have to.
This session explores what AI adoption actually looks like in that reality. Drawing on hands-on projects with nonprofits and minority-owned small businesses, Will demonstrates how to identify high-value use cases, design AI workflows *with* staff rather than *for* them, and introduce new tools without creating overwhelm.
Examples include Spanish-English workflows for grant writing, documentation and reporting, and day-to-day communication with clients and partners.

**Participants will leave with:**

* Patterns that reliably work in low-tech environments
* Practical guardrails for privacy and quality
* Ready-to-adapt prompts and process maps to bring back to their teams

Source: Meetup: All Things AI

title: The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt
description:
The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt showcases how the biblical story of heroic Queen Esther, depicted by Rembrandt and his contemporaries in art and popular culture, expressed ideas of political and religious freedom during the Dutch Golden Age. Charting this history through objects and artworks, The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt provides an original perspective on one of the most studied periods of Dutch prosperity.

title: AI Assisted Surveys
description:
This course will be held online only over 3 days. Attendance is required as it will not be recorded.

This 6-hour course provides training on how AI can assist a survey project from beginning to the end.

We will focus on each step of the research process (Callegaro and Yang, 2025)

PlanningExecutionActivationIn the planning phase there are two sub phases
1) Ideate and define

AI can be an idea helper and assist on generating research ideas starting from previously knowledgeA literature review can definitely be assisted by AI and there are specific tools available for that2) Design and plan

The design stage is where AI can assist in producing design brief, analysis plan and map the concepts that are going to be measured using the questionnaireThe execution phase consists of
3) Data wizard

Here AI has been used to help drafting and pretesting the questionnaire, help writing survey material such as survey invitation and confidentiality assurances.4) Analysis copilot

Once the data collection is under way, AI can assist in automating, and writing statistical code to analyze the dataset (stat code assistant). It can also be used as  theme discovery, for coding of open ended answers and data visualization.The activation phase consists of:
5) Insight partner

Help summarize findings, generate reports, help review the final deliverables such as a research report or a complete academic paper6) Storytelling aid

Develop presentation materials, create multi-media artifacts, generated blog post for different platforms, generate images based on content from the researchOrganizational Structure of the Course 
The course will be taught in a workshop style where the lectures will be using presentation slides as a roadmap. After each concept has been introduced and discussed, the participants will be invited to work on brief hands on exercises with different LLMs such as Gemini, Claude, Copilot, and ChatGPT

Participants will be strongly encouraged to ask questions during lectures, especially on how the content relates to their own research.

Learning objectives
By the end of the course, you will:

Learn how to prompt LLMs for survey research help and assistanceLearn how to evaluate the quality of LLMs outputsStrengths and challenges of different LLMs toolsWhere LLMs are not necessaryEthical usage of LLMs/AI ToolsRecent debate of using LLMs to produce research and write academic papersRegistration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

description:

We'll work through some applied examples and survey more specialized packages for data science in Python and talk about next steps on your learning journey.

 

This workshop assumes some basic familiarity with Python syntax (for example see “A Whirlwind Tour of Python”). This workshop will use conda via miniforge, and Visual Studio Code. Setup help will be available before the first session.

 

This workshop is offered by University Libraries and will be led by librarians Philip McDaniel, Lorin Bruckner, Michele Hayslett, Matt Jansen, and Rolando Rodriguez along with Mark Reed from ITS Research Computing. Contact Matt Jansen with any questions.

 

This workshop is being offered remotely via Zoom only. Registrants will receive a Zoom link; those on the waitlist will not receive a Zoom link unless they are bumped up to a registered spot. title: GenAI Life Hacks
description:

We will also crowd-source tips from attendees on how Gen AI tools have helped them organize tasks for work, school, and home life. 

Attendees will: 

Practice crafting clear prompts to create plans for time management, prioritizing work or study tasks, travel, cleaning, meal planning, and more.Understand how to use AI tools effectively. Share ideas for using Gen AI tools to create routines, manage tasks, develop study guides, and save time at work and home.This workshop is offered by the University Libraries and will be led by librarian Dayna Durbin and Michelle Hayslett.

title: Agentic AI in Action: 10-Minute Demo Spotlights from the Frontier
description:
Data Science Raleigh
Explore the real-world impact of Agentic AI in our fast-paced, insight-packed virtual showcase. Each 10-minute session features a live demo from a leading innovator in the Agentic AI space—highlighting practical applications, dynamic workflows, and tangible business outcomes.

This isn't just another pitch session. It’s a curated look at how agent-based systems are driving intelligent automation, adaptive planning, and cross-functional orchestration across industries. You’ll meet the minds behind these technologies and see firsthand how they’re redefining what's possible in enterprise AI.

**What You'll Learn:**

1️⃣ Autonomous Workflows: See how agentic systems plan, coordinate, and execute complex tasks across tools and teams.

2️⃣ Dynamic Decisioning: Explore examples of contextual reasoning, goal alignment, and memory-enhanced agents in action.

3️⃣Practical Integration: Understand what it takes to embed agentic AI into your stack—without overhauling everything.

Engage live with founders and builders shaping the future of autonomous enterprise solutions.

You’re short on time but deep on curiosity. This format respects both—cutting straight to the tech and the teams behind it. No filler, no fluff. Just signal.

**[Register Here](https://hubs.ly/Q03VVK8Y0)**

title: Sneak Peek Screening: A Life Reimagined: The George Masa Story
description:
As we celebrate the Department of Communication's 50th anniversary at NC State, join the department for a special prerelease screening of A Life Reimagined: The George Masa Story. For almost 100 years, the story of Masa, a Japanese immigrant, has been a mystery. Emmy-winning director Paul Bonesteel (’87) takes viewers on an inspiring journey through the life of Masa, who was a mysterious photographer and pioneering figure in conservation who helped shape the legacy of America’s national parks. Set against the stunning backdrop of the Great Smoky Mountains, the filmmaker’s study becomes an obsession as he delves into Masa's unique blend of artistry and activism, revealing a vision and passion for nature that still thrives today, reaching all the way back to his homeland of Japan.

title: 2026 Legacy Speakers Series “Retelling Our Story of Aging: Reimagining the Future through Community, Research, and Action”
description:
Join the UNC School of Social Work for our fifth annual Legacy Speakers Series. This year’s event, “Retelling Our Story of Aging: Reimagining the Future through Community, Research, and Action,” invites participants to explore a strengths-based, age-positive view of aging and what it will take to support thriving later in life. Spend the day with scholars, community leaders, and storytellers with lived experience as we examine the landscape of older adults in the United States and North Carolina and consider how communities and systems can respond more effectively. The day will be framed by keynote remarks from Kathy Greenlee, who will offer a national perspective on aging and highlight emerging opportunities to strengthen aging supports through collaboration across communities, research, and systems. Lived-experience storytelling and panel discussions will further explore research-informed practices, policy and system factors, and practical approaches for building more inclusive, age-friendly communities. Don’t miss this engaging event focused on shifting narratives about aging, strengthening community supports, and identifying actions we can take — individually and collectively — to shape a future where people can thrive as they age. You can register for the event here.

• visual design considerations of electronic and paper surveys

title: March 5 - AI, ML and Computer Vision Meetup
description:
Raleigh AI, Machine Learning and Computer Vision Meetup
Join our virtual meetup to hear talks from experts on cutting-edge topics across AI, ML, and computer vision.

**Date and Location**

Mar 5, 2026
9 - 11 AM Pacific
Online. **[Register for the Zoom!](https://voxel51.com/events/ai-ml-and-computer-vision-meetup-march-5-2026)**

**MOSPA: Human Motion Generation Driven by Spatial Audio**

Enabling virtual humans to dynamically and realistically respond to diverse auditory stimuli remains a key challenge in character animation, demanding the integration of perceptual modeling and motion synthesis. Despite its significance, this task remains largely unexplored. Most previous works have primarily focused on mapping modalities like speech, audio, and music to generate human motion. As of yet, these models typically overlook the impact of spatial features encoded in spatial audio signals on human motion.

To bridge this gap and enable high-quality modeling of human movements in response to spatial audio, we introduce the first comprehensive Spatial Audio-Driven Human Motion (SAM) dataset, which contains diverse and high-quality spatial audio and motion data. For benchmarking, we develop a simple yet effective diffusion-based generative framework for human MOtion generation driven by SPatial Audio, termed MOSPA, which faithfully captures the relationship between body motion and spatial audio through an effective fusion mechanism. Once trained, MOSPA can generate diverse, realistic human motions conditioned on varying spatial audio inputs. We perform a thorough investigation of the proposed dataset and conduct extensive experiments for benchmarking, where our method achieves state-of-the-art performance on this task.

*About the Speaker*

[Zhiyang (Frank) Dou](https://www.linkedin.com/in/zhiyang-frank-dou-0259111b3/) is a Ph.D. student at MIT CSAIL, advised by Prof. Wojciech Matusik. I work with the Computational Design and Fabrication Group and the Computer Graphics Group.

**Securing the Autonomous Future: Navigating the Intersection of Agentic AI, Connected Devices, and Cyber Resilience**

With billions of devices now in our infrastructure and emerging as autonomous agents (AI), we face a very real question: How can we create intelligent systems that are both secure and trusted? This talk will explore the intersection of agentic AI and IoT and demonstrate how the same AI systems can provide robust defense mechanisms. At its core, however, this is a challenge about trusting people with technology, ensuring their safety, and providing accountability. Therefore, creating a new way of thinking is required, one in which security is built in, and where autonomous action has oversight; and, ultimately, innovation leads to greater human well-being.

*About the Speaker*

[Samaresh Kumar Singh](https://www.linkedin.com/in/samaresh-singh-9772ba23/) is an engineering principal at HP Inc. with more than 21 years of experience in designing and implementing large-scale distributed systems, cloud native platform systems, and edge AI / ML systems. His expertise includes agentic AI systems, GenAI / LLMs, Edge AI, federated and privacy preserving learning, and secure hybrid cloud / edge computing.

**Plugins as Products: Bringing Visual AI Research into Real-World Workflows with FiftyOne**

Visual AI research often introduces new datasets, models, and analysis methods, but integrating these advances into everyday workflows can be challenging. FiftyOne is a data-centric platform designed to help teams explore, evaluate, and improve visual AI, and its plugin ecosystem is how the platform scales beyond the core. In this talk, we explore the FiftyOne plugin ecosystem from both perspectives: how users apply plugins to accelerate data-centric workflows, and how researchers and engineers can package their work as plugins to make it easier to share, reproduce, and build upon. Through practical examples, we show how plugins turn research artifacts into reusable components that integrate naturally into real-world visual AI workflows.

*About the Speaker*

[Adonai Vera](https://www.linkedin.com/in/adonai-vera/) \- Machine Learning Engineer & DevRel at Voxel51\. With over 7 years of experience building computer vision and machine learning models using TensorFlow\, Docker\, and OpenCV\.

**Transforming Business with Agentic AI**

Agentic AI is reshaping business operations by employing autonomous systems that learn, adapt, and optimize processes independently of human input. This session examines the essential differences between traditional AI agents and Agentic AI, emphasizing their significance for project professionals overseeing digital transformation initiatives. Real-world examples from eCommerce, insurance, and healthcare illustrate how autonomous AI achieves measurable outcomes across industries. The session addresses practical orchestration patterns in which specialized AI agents collaborate to resolve complex business challenges and enhance operational efficiency. Attendees will receive a practical framework for identifying high-impact use cases, developing infrastructure, establishing governance, and scaling Agentic AI within their organizations.

*About the Speaker*

[Joyjit Roy](https://www.linkedin.com/in/royjoyjit/) is a senior technology and program management leader with over 21 years of experience delivering enterprise digital transformation, cloud modernization, and applied AI programs across insurance, financial services, and global eCommerce.

Source: Meetup: Raleigh AI, ML & Computer Vision

description:

She will describe a handful of methods for quantifying urban heterogeneity; present an example of a multi-objective optimization framework for describing risk along hydrologic, economic and social dimensions; and then demonstrate an approach for quantifying trade-offs between different objectives when designing observation networks of the system.

title: From Data Governance to Semantic Intelligence
description:
Data Science Raleigh
As AI adoption accelerates, many enterprises are hitting the same wall: traditional approaches to data governance, metadata management, and cataloging were not designed to support AI and AI agents operating at scale. Fragmented tools, siloed semantics, and inconsistent definitions make it difficult for both people and AI systems to trust and act on data.

In this webinar, industry expert Mike Ferguson and Collate co-founder and CEO Suresh Srinivas explore how leading organizations are evolving from tool-centric data catalogs and governance toward semantic intelligence, a unified approach that brings governance, context, and meaning together to support analytics, automation, and AI at scale.

Collate co-founder and CTO Harsha Chintalapani will also provide a brief demonstration showing how semantic intelligence is applied in practice, including how data teams design and build AI agents on governed enterprise data.

**What You'll Learn:**

1️⃣ Why data discovery, governance, lineage, and data quality and observability must work together to support AI-driven use cases

2️⃣ How fragmented semantic layers and tool-specific context limit trust, scale, and reuse across analytics and AI

3️⃣What semantic intelligence means in practice and how it extends beyond traditional data catalogs

4️⃣How shared meaning enables secure, governed access to data for both people and AI agents

5️⃣How semantic intelligence supports the delivery of trusted, consumable data products with meaning, quality signals, and governance that are ready for analytics and AI agents

6️⃣What it takes to make data truly AI-ready without sacrificing control, compliance, or consistency

Designed for data leaders, enterprise architects, and governance teams, this session explains why existing catalogs and governance tools remain useful—but are no longer sufficient on their own—and how enterprises can operationalize shared meaning to support analytics, data engineering, and AI initiatives at scale.

**[Register here](https://hubs.ly/Q042D1NJ0)**

Source: Meetup: Data Science Raleigh

title: Ballet With Oliver Beres
location: Wellness and Recreation Center and Carmichael Gym, 2307
description:
Ballet teacher Oliver Beres will lead a class that will focus on the Vaganova technique with a blend of Balanchine style. The class will work on placement, technique and turnout, with a strong emphasis on musicality. The session will begin with intermediate barre work, starting at plies and finishing with grand battements. Center exercises and across-the-floor combinations that will incorporate a mix of adagio, turning combinations and jumping will also be part of the session.

Béres was born in Hungary and began his dance training in 1996 at age 11 when he was accepted into the Hungarian National Dance Academy. During his education, Béres was one of the four students chosen to perform with the Hungarian National Ballet. He was an apprentice in the company from age 14 until he graduated from the school in 2005. During his nine years of education, he had the privilege of training under many great teachers, including Zoltan Solymosi, who was a principal dancer with the Royal Ballet. Beres has performed in several countries in Europe, including Romania, Slovakia, Poland, Czech Republic, Austria and Italy. After graduation, he was offered a full scholarship with the North Carolina Dance Theatre in Charlotte, which brought him to the United States. He has danced with the Hungarian National Ballet, Slovak State Opera House, New Jersey Ballet and Carolina Ballet. He has performed several soloist and principal roles, including Firebird, Swan Lake, Don Quixote and many more. He retired as a soloist with Carolina Ballet in 2017 after dancing with the company for nine years. Béres is currently a full-time ballet teacher.

Session 2 ( March 5): This session will explore the often-overlooked fundamentals of customer discovery.  It will focus heavily on understanding your customers' frustrations, dissatisfactions and unfulfilled desires. The session will also delve into collecting evidence of these things through unbiased discovery work.

Restaurants are open on Thursdays, so you can Dash you food right inside, or bring it with you!

title: AI Assisted Surveys
description:
This course will be held online only over 3 days. Attendance is required as it will not be recorded.

This 6-hour course provides training on how AI can assist a survey project from beginning to the end.

We will focus on each step of the research process (Callegaro and Yang, 2025)

PlanningExecutionActivationIn the planning phase there are two sub phases
1) Ideate and define

AI can be an idea helper and assist on generating research ideas starting from previously knowledgeA literature review can definitely be assisted by AI and there are specific tools available for that2) Design and plan

The design stage is where AI can assist in producing design brief, analysis plan and map the concepts that are going to be measured using the questionnaireThe execution phase consists of
3) Data wizard

Here AI has been used to help drafting and pretesting the questionnaire, help writing survey material such as survey invitation and confidentiality assurances.4) Analysis copilot

Once the data collection is under way, AI can assist in automating, and writing statistical code to analyze the dataset (stat code assistant). It can also be used as  theme discovery, for coding of open ended answers and data visualization.The activation phase consists of:
5) Insight partner

Help summarize findings, generate reports, help review the final deliverables such as a research report or a complete academic paper6) Storytelling aid

Develop presentation materials, create multi-media artifacts, generated blog post for different platforms, generate images based on content from the researchOrganizational Structure of the Course 
The course will be taught in a workshop style where the lectures will be using presentation slides as a roadmap. After each concept has been introduced and discussed, the participants will be invited to work on brief hands on exercises with different LLMs such as Gemini, Claude, Copilot, and ChatGPT

Participants will be strongly encouraged to ask questions during lectures, especially on how the content relates to their own research.

Learning objectives
By the end of the course, you will:

Learn how to prompt LLMs for survey research help and assistanceLearn how to evaluate the quality of LLMs outputsStrengths and challenges of different LLMs toolsWhere LLMs are not necessaryEthical usage of LLMs/AI ToolsRecent debate of using LLMs to produce research and write academic papersRegistration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

title: Paying off Debt While Building Wealth
description:
In difficult economic times, many people are struggling to just keep up with monthly bills, let alone make progress on debt repayment. What suffers most is contributing to savings and investing goals. This session will focus on developing financial plans and strategies to address the dual goals of having a plan for paying off debt, while also contributing to building personal wealth.
This session covers the basics (or essentials) of each area and describes practical techniques that can help you to formulate your own plan to manage your personal finances to organize a sensible debt repayment plan without sacrificing other financial goals.

 

Workshop Objectives:

-Recognize the importance of a practical debt repayment strategy
-Understand the importance of setting and tracking short- and long-term financial goals
-Learn how to set milestones to address debt repayment and savings
-Be able to prioritize most effective use of disposable income
-Differentiate between saving and investing and when each makes sense

title: Spring Fling 2026: PacKIN Action Sibling Event
description:
Parents and Families Services invites students to bring siblings ages 7–17 to main campus for a special day designed just for them. PacKIN Action will give brothers, sisters, cousins and family friends a hands-on look at college life through campus traditions and interactive activities. The day’s events will include an interactive campus scavenger hunt, tie-dye shirt decorating, s’mores with the mascots, dinner at a dining hall and admission into the A cappella Showcase. Food and beverages are included with registration.

Each participant will receive a T-shirt, swag bag, Pack Passport, water bottle and lasting memories of the Wolfpack spirit. Whether it’s their first visit or a return trip, every sibling will leave feeling part of the Pack family.

title: Raleigh Smash 2026
location: Wellness and Recreation Center and Carmichael Gym
description:

Come enjoy competitive matches, a friendly atmosphere and a weekend full of badminton action. Registration is required to play. The registration deadline is February 22.

title: Fish Market Gallery: Works in Progress
description:
The College of Design Fish Market will host Works in Progress on March 6 from 6-11 p.m. at the Fish Market Gallery, 133 Fayetteville St. in Raleigh. Explore this year's exhibition lineup.

Works in Progress emphasises the beauty of the unfinished and the process of creating. We will accept half-finished pieces, sketches, sketchbooks, tools and materials from artists to show the diversity in artistic and design methods across NC State students. We will have interactive elements that will allow guests to participate in the art-making process.

Parking is available at the Municipal Parking Deck, 201 West Morgan St. in Raleigh.

Source: NC State University

title: Artemis II Launch Party
location: North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences
description:
Join us as we cheer on Artemis II, NASA’s first crewed Moon Mission in more than 50 years. NASA astronauts Reid Wiseman, Victor Glover and Christina Koch, as well as Jeremy Hansen from the Canadian Space Agency, will become the first people to return to the Moon since Apollo 17. Celebrate North Carolina’s own astronaut, Christina Koch, as she becomes the first woman to orbit the Moon.

Registration is required. Space is limited. Launch date and time are subject to change by NASA. Current launch windows are between 8PM–1AM on select dates through April. Register now to secure your spot and receive watch party details and go/no-gos via email.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

Tickets are limited, so don’t delay. This is an experience you won’t want to miss.
