title: Durant birding -  Registration required
location: Durant Nature Preserve, 8305 Camp Durant Rd, Raleigh, NC 27614, USA
description:
Early Bird at Durant Nature Preserve (registration required off Meetup)
Saturday, MARCH 7, 2026, 8 am - 9:30 am
Register Off-site only: Requires a login and password:
Login FIRST at https://ncraleighweb.myvscloud.com/webtrac/web/splash.html
THEN register for this free event at:
https://ncraleighweb.myvscloud.com/webtrac/web/iteminfo.html?Module=AR&FMID=441383870
Or click on Search -  Keyword Search and type in "EARLY BIRD"

Grab your binoculars and meet us at beautiful Durant Nature Preserve’s SOUTH entrance for a bird-watching hike led by Wake Audubon naturalist, Lynn Erla Beegle. Spend your morning watching and learning about birds that prefer forests and thickets edges on this approximately 1.5 mile hike. For beginning and advanced birders. Bring your binoculars, or borrow a pair of ours. Pre-registration is required. Limited to City of Raleigh residents.

Meet in the SOUTH parking lot at Durant Nature Preserve at 3237 Spottswood Street near Campbell Lodge. Note there is also a north parking lot on Camp Durant Road, but, you cannot drive from one lot to the other through the park . Source: Wake Audubon

title: Volunteer Stewardship Workday: Eno FMST
description: Join the Eno Friends of the Mountains-to-Sea Trail for a stewardship workday! RSVP to Fred Dietrich at dietrich@duke.edu. Source: Eno River Association

title: Career Crawl
description:
The annual Career Crawl hosted by the Graduate Association of Public Administrators will take place from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m. on Saturday, March 7, in the Caldwell Hall lounge. This interactive event will feature alumni networking opportunities, resume workshops and free professional headshots — all designed to help students prepare for internships, job searches and future career paths. Refreshments will be available.

Source: NC State University

title: Illuminate the Song
description:
In this hands-on University Theatre workshop, you'll learn how to use the fundamentals of lighting design to create and program a light show for a five- to 10-minute-long song. The music will be provided. Your task will be to make the light show come to life through movement, color and the texture of the lighting rig.

Source: NC State University

title: LGBTQ+ Beginner Bird
location: Annie Louise Wilkerson, MD Nature Preserve Park, 5229 Awls Haven Dr, Raleigh, NC 27614, USA
description:
*Complete this form to register. *This free workshop requires registration OFF Meetup.

LGBTQ+  Beginner Birders Program with Wake Audubon, Field Inclusive, Inc. and Raleigh Parks.

Date: Saturday, March 7, 2026

Time: 9:00* a.m. – 12:15 p.m. (*Please arrive 15 minutes early to reach the Education Center from parking and check-in; arrive 8:40 a.m. if also borrowing binoculars),

Location: Annie Louise Wilkerson, MD Nature Preserve Park, 5229 Awls Haven Dr., Raleigh, NC 27614

Hosting this event expressly for the LGBTQ+ community are workshop sponsors Wake Audubon and Field Inclusive, Inc. in partnership with City of Raleigh Parks and the LGBT Center of Raleigh. Collectively we’re striving for everyone to feel welcome, safe and included in the natural sciences and outdoors.

‘Birding’ – or the observation of birds in their natural habitats as a hobby – has become one of the most popular outdoor activities. If you are taking a new interest in birds and looking for help getting started, come develop your skills together with others at our Beginning Birding workshop.

This free public program teaches the basics of bird identification; how to use binoculars, guides and apps; types of bird safety and ways to bird safely; and the importance of inclusion and allyship in birding and the outdoors. We’ll spend time outside putting your learning to quick use.

Our route outside will consist of a mix of paved, gravel, and grassy surfaces with slight gradients. All-gendered restrooms will be available.

No binoculars? No problem! We have plenty of loaners to spare.

Note: Participation may be capped due to space restrictions, at which time notice of a wait list will be added to the top of the registration form. Please continue to register to join the waitlist. Should we receive cancellations, we’ll right away invite those on waitlist to confirm in the order registrations were received.

Reach Wake Audubon board director and Equity, Diversity, Inclusion and Belonging co-chair Rick LaRose at rlarose.was@gmail.com with any questions.

We look forward to building your beginner birding skills together with you on March 7!

Source: Wake Audubon

title: Bountiful Containers: The Art of Small Space Foodscaping
description:
Get ready to maximize every inch and savor the joys of cultivating your favorite plants in compact spaces. Dive into the secrets of designing and nurturing container foodscapes that deliver year-round beauty and abundant harvests. From sun-kissed herbs to luscious vegetables, author and horticulturist Brie Arthur has got you covered.

Discover the recipe for success as Arthur spills the beans on ideal soil blends, optimal fertilization and watering practices that will nurture your plants to perfection. Unleash your creativity with ingenious planting combinations that celebrate both form and function with a special container planting session after Arthur's talk. You'll design your own foodscaping container to take home to your special sweetheart or to feed your heart with some tasty winter vegetables.

You must register to attend the lecture. Registration includes Arthur's lecture and all supplies needed to plant a container of winter vegetables to take home.

Source: NC State University

title: Alamance County America 250 Celebration
description:
Alamance County America 250 Celebration       March 7 10-4

Save the Date! The Alamance County America 250 NC Celebration will take place at Alamance Battleground on Saturday, March 7th.
Join us for an inspiring day featuring engaging lectures and living history demonstrations, all in celebration of the upcoming 250th anniversary of America’s independence.
More details to come—stay tuned!

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: A Town is Born. When Are We US?
description:
A Town is Born. When Are We US? Story of why and where the town of Bath was founded, became the North Carolina's first colonial port of entry, held first library, and lay on the first Post Road. We will look at its role in the region, its local history that feeds into the story of independence seven decades later, and Founders of Bath relate how this area was selected, and their roles in its development.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Boomtown Bash
description:
Step back in time to the bustling 1850s with Reed Gold Mine’s new immersive living history event, "Boomtown Bash: Life at a Carolina Gold Mine." Focused on the heyday of North Carolina’s gold mining history, this event offers a captivating look into the lives of the miners, immigrants, and women who sought adventure and riches.

The outdoor Panning Area also be open for the event (weather permitting)! After learning about gold mining in the 19th century, try your hand at panning in our troughs and see if you have what it takes to strike it rich yourself. Panning tickets are $5.00 each, plus tax, for anyone ages 8 and older. Tickets are sold for set session times on a first come, first served basis in our Visitor Center.

Visitors of all ages will enjoy an unforgettable experience at “Boomtown Bash” by being transported back in time to the 1850s and reliving the spirit of adventure and pursuit of wealth that defined North Carolina’s Piedmont region until the dawn of the Civil War. Don’t miss your chance to learn more about America’s first Golden State and discover the forgotten history of North Carolina’s gold mining heritage.

“Boomtown Bash” will be held from 10:00 am to 4:00 pm on Saturday, March 7th.

Event admission is $5.00 for anyone aged 5 and up, payable on the event day. We accept cash and cards, excluding American Express. Children under 5 are free. Registration is not accepted.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Kinston's Civil War Experience: Homefront, Sailors, and Soldiers
description:
🤔🏛️ Curious about Kinston during the Civil War? 

Are you curious about the businesses that operated in downtown Kinston during the Civil War? Did you know Kinston was home to a Free Black community during this pivotal time? Ever wondered what daily life was like for women and children while men were away at war?

🪖💭 Were any battles fought in Kinston?
⚓ Do you know where the CSS Neuse ironclad was outfitted—and who served aboard her?
📜 What were the two largest Civil War battles fought in North Carolina?

If these questions spark your interest, join us for a day of exploration into Lenoir County’s history during the 1860s!

Throughout the museum, our knowledgeable staff and volunteers will bring history to life with living history demonstrations, interactive discussions, and helpful resources—all designed to answer your questions and deepen your understanding of life in North Carolina during the Civil War.

🎖️👩‍👩‍👦‍👦⚓
Perfect for families, history enthusiasts, and curious minds of all ages—this event offers a meaningful and memorable way to connect with the past.

Explore, learn, and experience history where it happened. We can’t wait to welcome you!

🎟️ Admission Rates:

$5 – Adults$4 – Senior Citizens, Active Duty Military, and Veterans$3 – StudentsFree – Children ages three and under📧 Questions?
Email Rachel at rachel.kennedy@dncr.nc.gov or call 252-526-9600, ext. 221 or 222.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: North Carolina Rice Festival at Brunswick Town/Fort Anderson State Historic Site
description:
Join us at Brunswick Town/Fort Anderson State Historic Site for the North Carolina Rice Festival! Activities will be located indoors and outdoors. Activities will include history/cultural presentations, tours, demonstrations, live entertainment, family fun, children’s stage, Gullah Geechee food vendors, and arts/crafts. Visit https://www.northcarolinaricefestival.org/ for more information.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt
description:
The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt showcases how the biblical story of heroic Queen Esther, depicted by Rembrandt and his contemporaries in art and popular culture, expressed ideas of political and religious freedom during the Dutch Golden Age. Charting this history through objects and artworks, The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt provides an original perspective on one of the most studied periods of Dutch prosperity.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: "Her Heart is Slowly Breaking:" a Women's History Tour of Stagville - 2026
description:
Explore the resistance, resilience, love, and labor of enslaved women on one of the largest plantations in North Carolina.

This March, visit Historic Stagville for a special guided tour of the Bennehan House and grounds featuring the stories of enslaved women from Stagville. This tour highlights the lives of Phoebe Bennehan, Anna Bell, Emma Turner Henderson, and more. Their personal stories, reconstructed with careful research, illuminate the experiences of countless women who endured bondage in North Carolina. 

This tour will be offered each Saturday in March, at 11 am, in recognition of Women's History Month.

This tour is intended for adult visitors. It includes content about violence, sexual violence, and family separation. Tours will last about 1 hour. The tour will include walking and standing, both indoors and outdoors, including walking over grass, gravel, and uneven surfaces.

Space is limited. Register now to reserve your space! Tickets are $10 per person plus tax, payable by card when you check-in for the tour on site.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: First Saturday Birding at Brumley
location: Brumley North Nature Preserve, 3620 Old State Highway 10, Chapel Hill, NC, 27514, United States
description:
Come join us for our First Saturday birding hike at our Brumley North Nature Preserve!
Did you know that Brumley North is the #2 Hotspot for birding in the state? Our Brumley Birding hike will be led by co-members of both TLC and the New Hope Bird Alliance. We will meander on an easy 1.5 mile hike over about 2 hours with many stops along the way. Please wear good walking shoes and layers, bring a water bottle, and binoculars if you have them. We suggest that you leave your furry friends at home for this hike as they may scare away wildlife viewing opportunities. This is a free event, but preregistration is required.



 
If registration is full, please fill out our waitlist form here by March 6th at noon.

title: Durham Farmers' Market
location: Durham Central Park, 501 Foster Street, Durham, NC, 27701, United States
description:
The Durham Farmers’ Market is a community of farmers, growers and crafters. We are strongly committed to local products: every item you see at the market was produced by the people selling it, and it all comes from no more than 70 miles away. 
The Durham Farmers’ Market open Saturdays mornings for local produce, flowers, crafts and more! The Wednesday Market is open from 3-6pm Wednesdays, Mid-April through Mid-October 
If you’d like more information about this week’s vendor list, SNAP benefits and map, visit durhamfarmersmarket.com 

We are happy to offer Double Bucks to our SNAP clients. This means is a SNAP client has $10, they receive $20 in tokens to spend at the winter market.

Estamos muy contentos de ofrecer Double Bucks a nuestros clientes de SNAP. Esto significa que si un cliente de SNAP gasta $ 10, recibirá $ 20 en tokens para gastar en productos frescos.


Additionally, we offer a cash match program for other qualifying folks. To receive this benefit, simply bring cash to the info table. Then, we’ll double the amount with tokens. For example, $10 in cash equals $20 in tokens.

También ofrecemos un programa de contrapartida en efectivo para nuestros beneficiarios de SNAP que no tienen beneficios durante el mes, clientes de WIC y miembros de la comunidad que viven en viviendas públicas. Para recibir este beneficio, simplemente traiga efectivo a la tabla de información y duplicaremos la cantidad con tokens. Por ejemplo, $ 10 en efectivo equivalen a $ 20 en fichas.

Source: Durham Central Park

title: Crafting Botanicals with Paper: Trilliums
location: North Carolina Botanical Garden, 100 Old Mason Farm Road, Chapel Hill, NC, 27517, United States
description:
Register Here

with Cynthia Woodsong, Artist 
Date: Saturday, March 7, 2026
Time: 10:00 a.m. – 2:30 p.m.
Location: North Carolina Botanical Garden
Fee: $57 ($52 Members) 
  
In celebration of spring ephemerals, this paper botanical workshop focuses on trilliums, which emerge in March and typically bloom through April. Trillium catesbaei (rosy wakerobin) and Trillium discolor (pale yellow trillium) will be featured.  Participants will use crepe paper to make a life-size replica of two trillium plants while learning about the botanical characteristics of this genus. Participants of previous workshops will learn a new technique for rendering leaves. 
No previous experience with making paper botanicals is needed, but the activity requires the use of scissors and good finger dexterity. 
Materials will be provided to complete the blooming stems, and tools will be available for use during the workshop. There will be a 30-minute break for lunch (bring your own). 
  
Register Here


Source: NC Botanical Garden

title: Poles and Plants
location: Johnston Mill Nature Preserve, 2713 Mt. Sinai Rd., Chapel Hill, North Carolina, 27514, United States
description:
Join us for an educational hike about plants and hiking poles!
During this hike you’ll join TLC Trail Guide, Nancy, to learn how and when to set the length of your poles, the most efficient way to grip your poles, and how to decide what features you want in your hiking poles.  Along the way, TLC Trail Guide, Dale, will point out local tree and plant species you will see throughout the preserve. This is a great hike to build on both your hiking pole and plant ID skills!

This will be a moderate 2-3 mile hike over variable terrain, stopping periodically for educational moments. Another big thank you to Great Outdoor Provision Company and LEKI for letting us borrow poles for you to try, but if you have a pair already, please bring them! This is a free event, but preregistration is required.

 



 
If registration for this event is full, please fill out our waitlist form here, but March 6th at noon. 
 

Current Mask Policy: TLC seeks to build a supportive, mask-friendly environment in all collaborations with staff and the public. Please wear a mask if you are not vaccinated, or if that makes you feel most comfortable. We also encourage those eligible to be vaccinated to get their Covid-19 vaccine and booster shot. If you are experiencing any Covid-related symptoms, please stay home and attend a program another day. Our top priority is to create a safe environment for our community. Thank you for your understanding.

Source: Triangle Land Conservancy

location: Ackland Art Museum, 101 S. Columbia Street, Chapel Hill, NC, 27514, United States
description:

This event is part of UNC–Chapel Hill’s Campus Life Experience (CLE) program. Students who attend can scan the QR code provided at the event to receive CLE credit.

title: Drafts of the Bull: Durham Craft Beer Tour
description:
Chapel Hill And Durham Fun with Friends (CHAD) 30s 40s 50s+
**NOTE:** You will need to register for the event on the Flavors of the Bull website. We are holding the date just for our group. Please go to [www.flavorsofthebull.com,](http://www.flavorsofthebull.com,/) click the "Book now" link in the upper right corner and then search for March 7th.

**Use promo code Meetup10 to save 10% off the cost of the tour**.

Join us for a craft beer tour in downtown Durham! Discover the heart of Durham’s craft beer culture with an immersive brewery tour that blends rich flavor and local history. Whether you’re a seasoned beer lover or simply curious, this tour offers an authentic taste of the city—full of character, craftsmanship, and that unmistakable Durham charm. Cheers to an unforgettable experience!

The tour begins at [Clouds Brewing](https://click.c.alumni.umich.edu/?qs=2496befc4dc0a0c62bf4352772a97ad930134646a5ed4de9c969af9933bf41ffa0e8316d877e42d862e08c96c84d3643908dfc34dcb896da), where they’ve been brewing since 2014 focusing on German-inspired, American-made bold brews and pub fare. From there, we’ll head to [Crank Arm Brewing](https://click.c.alumni.umich.edu/?qs=2496befc4dc0a0c64e906c9c0b5a717e2464ad075c6e17a0e62cccc6af0967f391c3e80975c513078d5bbfb417a040b26bac936a9c2d10a4), a place that’s been focused on bikes and beer since 2013. The next stop is [Flying Bull Beer Company](https://click.c.alumni.umich.edu/?qs=2496befc4dc0a0c6601bd6092f5dc59158eb234652fe945b3c6d0e86479881465ef975cb5351d44914f954fda6725c53f6d3961e2d475b13), which is focused on building community here in Durham through warm hospitality, great food, and even better beer. The last stop is [Atomic Clock Brewing Company](https://click.c.alumni.umich.edu/?qs=2496befc4dc0a0c64eaaf0b2b92897f2c1b273b3e03480ef9cde87d54ff71d2cd57a36580d5ebbc384249c14dcaaa927f37a1f27f5882ff0), known for innovative brews and a focus on perfection.

This tour is offered through Flavors of the Bull, a brand-new food and drink tour company in Durham (and started by a Michigan alum). Tours are $75/per person and include flights at each stop, food tastings throughout the tour, and local Durham history provided as we walk to each stop. Tours are limited to 15 people.

NOTE: You will need to register for the event on the Flavors of the Bull website. We are holding the date just for our group. Please go to [www.flavorsofthebull.com,](http://www.flavorsofthebull.com,/) click the "Book now" link in the upper right corner and then search for March 7th.

Use promo code Meetup10 to to save 10% off the cost of the tour.

Source: Meetup: CHAD (Chapel Hill & Durham Fun)

title: Spring Fling 2026: Pack the Pantry Fun Run
description:
Parents and Families Services is excited to partner with the Division of Academic and Student Affairs to host a race that will serve as a fundraiser in support of NC State’s Feed the Pack Food Pantry. A portion of all proceeds will go to Feed the Pack.

Just shy of a 5k, the 2.9-mile race will start and end around beautiful Lake Raleigh on NC State’s Centennial Campus. Timing and tracking will not be recorded formally. Participants interested in time-tracking will need to plan to do so independently. 

A $30 registration fee is required to participate in the race.  Here is what’s included in your registration:

T-shirtWater bottleRace bib Finisher’s medalAll items will be distributed at check-in on race day.

Race participants are encouraged to wear fruit and vegetable costumes. Please bring nonperishable food donations for Feed the Pack and to be entered win prizes.

Source: NC State University

location: Wellness and Recreation Center and Carmichael Gym
description:
Join the Badminton Club at NC State for an exciting badminton tournament open to all players in the local community. Whether you're a seasoned player or a rookie, this tournament is the perfect opportunity to showcase your skills and meet new opponents. Come enjoy competitive matches, a friendly atmosphere and a weekend full of badminton action. Registration is required to play. The registration deadline is February 22.

For more information, send an email to ncsushuttle@gmail.com.

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt
description:
The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt showcases how the biblical story of heroic Queen Esther, depicted by Rembrandt and his contemporaries in art and popular culture, expressed ideas of political and religious freedom during the Dutch Golden Age. Charting this history through objects and artworks, The Book of Esther in the Age of Rembrandt provides an original perspective on one of the most studied periods of Dutch prosperity.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Bike Maintenance Class and Group Ride
description:
Every second Sunday, get your biking fix with the Greenway Gear Collective's Bike Maintenance Class and Group Ride. Their 10 a.m. monthly basic maintenance class is a great way to learn the essentials of bike care and tune-ups. Each class is shaped by the needs of those who show up with no two being the same.

Then at noon, you can join a themed group ride starting and ending at The Bike Library container on the shores of Lake Raleigh. Bring your own bike or rent one of theirs. Feel free to show up for the class, the group ride or both.

While both of these events are drop-in accessible and encouraged, signing up in advance for the class or pre-filling out the waiver for the ride is always greatly appreciated.

Source: NC State University

description:

The tours will last about 45 minutes.

Meet at the fort entrance. Pets are not allowed inside the fort.

description:
1.5mile moderate hike along the Rumbling Bald Trail, a loop trail that meanders through a beautiful hardwood forest along the south face of Rumbling Bald Mountain, revealing huge boulder fields and the base of the cliff areas.

Bring plenty of drinking water, wear appropriate clothing for the weather and closed-toed shoes.
In case of inclement weather, the event will be cancelled.

title: Exhibit Reception: The Whimsical Naturalist
description:
Meet the artist and enjoy light refreshments at the exhibit reception for The Whimsical Naturalist at the North Carolina Botanical Garden on Sunday, March 8, from 1-3 p.m.!

 

In this exhibit of original watercolors, North Carolina artist Katie Crawford celebrates the rich biodiversity of the East Coast, telling the story of interconnectedness between species, ecosystems, and communities. Through portraits of native plants and animals, she uses anthropomorphism to shift perspectives and inspire visitors to consider how we are connected to our environment and each other.

 

The reception takes place in and around the DeBerry Gallery, in our main education center, and is open to all.

 

Reminder: Sunday, March 8 is the first day of Daylight Savings Time!

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

description:
Outdoor Flow Yogis
**S﻿unday Yoga** classes take place monthly at [Trophy Brewing](https://www.trophybrewing.com/brewery-taproom)'s Maywood location. Join us inside the brewery or out on the lawn for a 60-minute yoga flow for all experience levels. Beginners welcome! Bring your mat and any props you like to use.

Registration includes one drink ticket, so stick around after class to enjoy a Trophy pint or non-alcoholic beverage and relax with the crew—great way to start your Sunday FUNday.

Cost: $22 cash/venmo at the door or reserve online [here](https://trophysundayyoga2026.eventbrite.com/).

description:
The 12th annual UNC Cleantech Summit will take place at the UNC Friday Conference Center on March 9 – 10, 2026. The two-day event will bring together professionals in business, government, and academia from across the Southeast and around the world for discussion, workshops, mentoring, and networking to foster leadership and growth in the Southeast’s cleantech economy. The Summit convenes more than 1,000 attendees and is the largest event of its kind by a university in the United States. Co-hosted by the UNC Institue for the Environment and the Ackerman Center for Excellence in Sustainability at the Kenan-Flagler Business School. Registration opens Fall 2025.

title: Mental Health Seminar: The Healing Power of Presence - Mindfulness for Stress and Life Satisfaction
description:
What does it really mean to be present, and why does it matter for both our own well-being and the health of our communities? This seminar explores how mindfulness and presence can support mental and emotional health in everyday life. Through practical examples, guided reflection, and accessible mindfulness practices, participants will learn how cultivating awareness can reduce stress, improve emotional regulation, and increase overall life satisfaction. Beyond individual benefits, the session will examine how presence fosters empathy, stronger relationships, and more thoughtful engagement with others. Participants will leave with simple, usable tools for integrating mindfulness into daily routines and for building healthier, more connected communities through intentional awareness. This seminar is open to everyone, whether you are new to mindfulness or looking to deepen your existing practice.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Book Talk with Matt Kaplan
location: The Frank Porter Graham Student Union, Auditorium
description:
Broken Beakers and Brilliant Minds: Fixing The Machinery of Science 

  

From the energy crisis and feeding eight billion people to defeating cancer and coping with climate change, humanity faces some rather large challenges today. To tackle them, we need science running like a well-oiled machine. Unfortunately, it has more often resembled a clunky old engine: loud, temperamental and prone to breaking down at the worst possible moment. 

  

It is tempting to blame recent funding cuts for science’s current woes, but focusing only on money rather misses the point. Many of science’s biggest problems have been around for years, sometimes centuries. Scientists have long been criticized, sidelined or attacked for having ideas that were too new, too inconvenient or simply too correct for the people in power at the time. Even truly unscientific behaviors, like character assassination and fraud, are not modern inventions… though they do seem to have enjoyed a recent renaissance. 

  

The good news is that longstanding problems are not the same as unsolvable ones. Join Matt Kaplan, science correspondent at The Economist and author of I Told You So! Scientists Who Were Ridiculed, Exiled and Imprisoned… For Being Right, for a spirited and insightful talk on the history of these endemic issues and what we can do to finally consign them to the scientific scrap heap.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Solving Sustainability Live Podcast: Future of Protein
location: Partners I – NC State University, Raleigh Founded (Suite 1650)
description:
Solving Sustainability is a live interdisciplinary podcast that seeks to raise awareness about macro-level sustainability challenges and innovations while fostering meaningful discussion between students, researchers, entrepreneurs and policymakers.

During the episode, the podcast will seek to engage NC State community members — students alongside interested faculty and staff — who have experience within sustainability but may not have a deep understanding of environmental justice. The podcast is not just an entertaining way to seek solutions but also a call to action and a way to connect with others.

This event will take place in the Raleigh Founded Centennial Cafe and hors d'oeuvres will be available for all attendees.

Source: NC State University

title: Ackland Film Forum: "Boyhood" (Richard Linklater, 2014)
location: The Lumina Theater, 620 Market Street, Chapel Hill, 27516, United States
description:
Filmed over twelve years with the same cast members who conspicuously age from segment to segment, Boyhood offers one of cinema’s most literal and radical explorations of coming of age. Following Mason (Ellar Coltrane) from early childhood through his first days of college, the film refuses traditional narrative climaxes in favor of accumulation: small moments, shifting family dynamics, and incremental changes in perception as time itself figures as the “main character.” Linklater’s method allows us to experience maturation as something lived, uneven, and quietly profound. 
The film will be introduced by Rick Warner, Bowman and Gordon Gray Distinguished Term Professor and Director of Film Studies. 
  
This film will be screened at 7:30 p.m. at The Lumina Theater (620 Market St, Chapel Hill, NC 27516). 
Tickets are free for all audience members, and registration is required via The Lumina’s webpage. Please click here to reserve your free ticket. UNC-Chapel Hill students can receive CLE credit for attending by scanning the QR code at the event. 
  
About the Series: 
Join the Ackland Film Forum this spring for Growing Up, Looking Back, a series that accompanies the Ackland exhibition Bill Bamberger: Boys Will Be Men. This semester’s series highlights the filmgoing experience by using three local movie theaters as its venues. 
The Ackland Film Forum is co-organized by the Ackland Art Museum and UNC Film Studies, housed in the UNC-Chapel Hill Department of English and Comparative Literature.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Civic Hacking for Affordable Housing
description:
Code with the Carolinas - Triangle
Join volunteers at Code with the Carolinas as we help the [National Zoning Atlas](https://www.zoningatlas.org/) (NZA) team include North Carolina and South Carolina in their nationwide zoning atlas. "The National Zoning Atlas aims to depict key aspects of zoning codes in an online, user-friendly map." The Atlas aims to provide data for better solutions in transportation, environmental, and especially affordable housing policy.

Affordable housing proponents have long recognized zoning policies as barriers to affordable housing. To improve zoning policies, we first need to better understand the current state of zoning across the United States. Code with the Carolinas is helping this cause by joining the National Zoning Atlas to gather zoning data for North and South Carolina.

This is a multi-dimensional project grounded in data science with an end-goal of contributing to a nationally influential dataset. Our current work session activities focus on internet search and integrating data from multiple sources. The project as a whole has occasional opportunities for U/X and outreach and opportunities to learn about machine learning and natural language processing through the work of the NZA team. Volunteering on this project will provide excellent exposure to the foundations of civic data science, with a focus on GIS data.

Even if you're new to this project and/or civic tech volunteering, you're welcome to join the meeting. Visitors are always welcome and no technical skills are needed. You can learn more about the project on our [Slack Workspace](https://join.slack.com/t/codeforthecarolinas/shared_invite/zt-1kxuwu05x-3KxOpkOYjAuN5yuOAH8ROg) in the #project-zoning-atlas channel.

Meetings start with brief introductions. New volunteers are offered a personal orientation, often in a breakout room, while experienced volunteers get right to work. By the end of the session, both groups of volunteers are working together. We also contribute to the project through asynchronous work and informal work sessions.

Meetings are on the Jitsi platform and the link is provided before each meeting. If you will be joining on mobile, install the Jitsi app in advance [https://jitsi.org/downloads/](https://jitsi.org/downloads/) .

Learn more at [codewiththecarolinas.org](codeforthecarolinas.org) or reach out to info@codewiththecarolinas.org

All activities of Code with the Carolinas, a project of [Social Good Fund](https://www.socialgoodfund.org/), follow our [Code of Conduct](https://share.mailbox.org/ajax/share/0d32d5f905f8fd49d5e80395f8fd47f2b59ce3ef8b335f72/1/8/Nzg/NzgvMTkx) and are subject to this [Volunteer Waiver of Liability](https://share.mailbox.org/ajax/share/06dd62200e6b28426b137e0e6b2848fb901487014f72cd16/1/8/Nzg/NzgvMTE2).

Source: Meetup: Code with the Carolinas

title: Weekly Game Night!
description:
Durham Geeks
We meet at Moon Dog Meadery under Joe Van Gogh on Broad Street every Monday night. We have loads of games (some belong to MoonDog, some are brought by attendees), a fun and welcoming group of folks (always eager to have more, however!), and there are always folks eager to teach games to those who haven't played certain titles.

Moondog has a growing collection of canned and bottled brews, ciders, and colas in addition to their in-house-brewed meads. There are also some snacks like chips and popcorn. Sometimes, folks bring in other treats to share. If you do, please mark them as containing any common allergens.

Outside food (delivered, brought in, or homemade) is welcomed and encouraged. Outside drinks are not. Since the venue does not prepare food, **dogs are allowed and welcomed.** (Dogs are very friendly and welcoming, too, but they mostly roam around to collect ear scritches and love. If you're not comfortable with dogs around, let us know, and we'll try to accommodate.)

Bring games, friends, and a welcoming spirit. We're excited to have you with us!

Source: Meetup: Durham Geeks

description:

Make sure to park in the northwest corner of the Park Alumni Center parking lot a little before 9 a.m. for a brief safety conversation. Parking is free for everyone. Wear closed-toed shoes and bring a water bottle.Check the weather forecast and wear weather-appropriate clothing on the hike.Restrooms are available in the Alumni Center. There are no facilities on the trail.The hike will last approximately 90 minutes but could be a little shorter depending on the group's pace. Space is limited for each hike. Be sure to register.

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Election Polling: Design, Analysis, and Communication
description:
As the 2026 election cycle approaches, polls will once again dominate headlines and shape public discussion. This half-day course provides a practical foundation in the design, analysis, and communication of election polls. Topics include questionnaire design, the advantages and limitations of different survey modes, weighting techniques to improve representativeness, strategies for likely voter screens, and approaches to assess, interpret, and communicate poll results accurately. Registration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Social Media Made Simple: Tools, Timing, and Templates
description:
Social media doesn't have to feel like a second full-time job. Join us for Social Media Made Simple, led by the always dynamic Kim Kaid of Kaid Marketing. Kim brings the perfect mix of strategy, creativity, and real-world practicality. (and our attendees consistently rave about her sessions) In this interactive workshop, you'll learn: Which platforms actually make sense for your business (hint: not all of them) How to create eye-catching graphics using simple, customizable templates What to post, when to post, and how to stay consistent without burning out Kim will break it all down in a way that's current, clear, and immediatey actionable. You'll leave with practical tools, renewed confidence, and a realistic plan that makes social media work for your business... not the other way around. If you've ever thought "I know I should be doing more online, but I don't know where to start," this class is for you.

Source: Wake Forest Chamber of Commerce

title: Creating Your Own Digital Exhibit
description:
Want to tell a story using images, videos, documents, or other media from your research project? You can create and host a digital exhibit fore free using CollectionBuilder! This workshop will cover how to set up your own digital exhibit using CollectionBuilder and Google Sheets. Attendees will learn how to add images, PDFs, videos, and more to their website. CollectionBuilder makes it easy to set up your own digital exhibit with minimal technical expertise.

 

This workshop is offered by the University Libraries and will be led by librarian Rolando Rodriguez and CALA Shannon Henry. 

 

This workshop is being offered remotely via Zoom only. Registrants will receive a Zoom link; those on the waitlist will not receive a Zoom link unless they are bumped up to a registered spot. After the workshop, registrants and those on the waitlist will receive a link to the workshop recording. You can register on the University Libraries calendar: https://calendar.lib.unc.edu/event/16023378

description:

We’re also happy to help you one-on-one and point you towards additional opportunities to present your work.

description:

description:

title: State of AI : Context Engineering with Microsoft and Anthropic
description:
Modern Web (Triangle)
Context is becoming a defining layer of modern AI systems and is shaping how models reason, respond, and integrate into real products. This event explores how context engineering is influencing the current state of AI and the way teams are thinking about building more capable and reliable systems.

[Join us for a conversation](https://luma.com/79w48jgi) with experts from Microsoft and Anthropic as we examine emerging approaches to structuring context, lessons from real-world AI development, and the considerations guiding what comes next.

Featuring insights from
[Harald Kirschner](https://www.linkedin.com/in/digitarald/), Principal Product Manager for GitHub Copilot and VS Code at Microsoft
[Ado Kukic](https://www.linkedin.com/in/adocomplete/), Community Manager at Anthropic
[Brandon Mathis](https://www.linkedin.com/in/mathisbrandon/), Engineering Lead, This Dot Labs
[Tracy Lee](https://www.linkedin.com/in/tracyslee/), CEO, This Dot Labs

[If you are interested in attending, please RSVP using this link!](https://luma.com/iho7wvqp)

title: after work bike ride on the ATT
description:
Triangle Hiking and Outdoors Group
I know that it’s hard to imagine, given the weather we’ve had from. Mid January to almost mid February, but it’s time to prepare for the 2026 season of the Tuesday after work bike rides. This seasonal, weekly event has been going on since 2011! It will begin with just over 1 hour of riding, and as the days get longer we’ll increase the ride time and distance tracking sunset.
We'll be starting near Southpoint and final starting point will be sent out Monday evening. Make sure that your bike is in good working order - tires hold air and are up to pressure, brakes and shifters work and your chain has been oiled. We'll be riding just about 1 hours and about 12 miles. The ride is fairly flat and shaded and our pace will be moderate (about 13 mph average). I recommend a hard tail or hybrid bike, but if you really want to bring a road bike it's ok, though you'll likely be a bit bored. Unicycles....? I'll be eating after the ride at a restaurant. You're welcome to join me if you like. Helmets are required and by signing up you agree to THOG liability waiver statement. Please Note!! Any cancellation less than 30 hours before the beginning of the event will be considered a "no show"

Source: Meetup: Triangle Hiking & Outdoors

title: *IN-PERSON* SF/F Group
description:
Durham Writers Group
We will be at the People's Solidarity Hub at 1809 Chapel Hill Rd, Durham. This venue does not serve food or drink, but feel free to bring your own. There is a kitchenette for our use, but be sure to clean up afterwards. The space might be a little cozy; please consider masking or staying home if you have a respiratory ailment.

This sub-group focuses on Speculative Fiction, including Science Fiction, Fantasy and Horror. If you have anything that falls under that category — be it short story, poem, novel-in-progress or screenplay — then come! We'd love to hear from you.

Our format allows each reader 15 minutes to present their work aloud, followed by approximately 20 minutes of feedback from the other attendees. To ensure fairness, each attendee is limited to 1 minute of Initial Feedback time. During that period, the author remains silent. Next, we have a 5 minute Free-For-All discussion about the work -- then the author may speak. (We usually get through three readers.)

Though not required, in order to receive more in-depth feed-back, readers may post their work in advance on our Google Group:
https://groups.google.com/d/forum/durham-sff-writers-group

We ask that participants keep their comments constructive and respectful, focusing on what works or doesn't work in the piece.

We also ask that readers provide a warning, both on the Google Group and during the meeting, if their story features content that some readers might find upsetting. This includes descriptions of violence or sexual content.

Readers are:
•
•
•

Backup Readers are:
•
•
•

Deep Backup:
•

***

***We meet every Tuesday at the same time, but alternate between In-Person*** ***and on Zoom. Members may attend both formats, if desired, but readers will be listed separately under the In-Person or Zoom weeks.***

Source: Meetup: Durham Writers Group

title: Deskercise! Taking Care of Your Body During the Workday
description:
Have you ever felt tired and sluggish at work? Do you notice tension in your neck and back pain in the middle of your workday? Spending many of our waking hours sitting at a desk can lead to consequences for our health. However, it can be difficult to find time to exercise! This training will discuss the importance of not being completely sedentary all day, and review practical, easy ways to take care of your body while working a desk job.

 

Workshop Objectives:

This training will help you:
• Learn why sedentary lifestyles are hazardous for your health
• Identify exercises to incorporate into your workday
• Understand the relationship between physical and mental stress
• Practice mind-body connection through stress management exercises

 

Click on Carolina Talent registration link and select the “Request” button to automatically enroll.

title: Working with Text in Python
description:
Interested in working with newspapers, interviews, social media posts, or other text data? If you’re working with a large collection of text, computational text analysis can help you answer your research questions. In this workshop, we will explore how research questions translate to text analysis methods, such as word frequencies, topic modeling, and sentiment analysis. We will also go over how to use AI endpoints to programmatically make AI calls. This workshop assumes attendees have some familiarity with Python. Need a Python primer? check out our Python Crash Courses page. 

 

This workshop is offered by the University Libraries and will be led by librarians Lorin Bruckner and Rolando Rodriguez. 

 

This workshop is being offered remotely via Zoom only. Registrants will receive a Zoom link; those on the waitlist will not receive a Zoom link unless they are bumped up to a registered spot. After the workshop, registrants and those on the waitlist will receive a link to the workshop recording. You can register on the University Libraries calendar: https://calendar.lib.unc.edu/event/16022565

title: March 11 - Strategies for Validating World Models and Action-Conditioned Video
description:
Raleigh AI, Machine Learning and Computer Vision Meetup
Join us for a one hour hands-on workshop where we will explore emerging challenges in developing and validating world foundation models and video-generation AI systems for robotics and autonomous vehicles.

**Time and Location**

Mar 11, 2026
10-11am PST
Online, **[Register for the Zoom!](https://voxel51.com/events/debugging-the-future-strategies-for-validating-world-models-and-action-conditioned-video-march)**

Industries from robotics to autonomous vehicles are converging on world foundation models (WFMs) and action-conditioned video generation, where the challenge is predicting physics, causality, and intent. But this shift has created a massive new bottleneck: validation.

How do you debug a model that imagines the future? How do you curate petabyte-scale video datasets to capture the "long tail" of rare events without drowning in storage costs? And how do you ensure temporal consistency when your training data lives in scattered data lakes?

In this session, we explore technical workflows for the next generation of Visual AI. We will dissect the "Video Data Monster," demonstrating how to build feedback loops that bridge the gap between generative imagination and physical reality. Learn how leading teams are using federated data strategies and collaborative evaluation to turn video from a storage burden into a structured, queryable asset for embodied intelligence.

*About the Speaker*

[Nick Lotz](https://www.linkedin.com/in/nicholaslotz/) is chemical process engineer-turned-developer who is currently a Technical Marketing Engineer at Voxel51. He is particularly interested in bringing observability and security to all layers of the AI stack.

Source: Meetup: Raleigh AI, ML & Computer Vision

title: Fiddleheads: Preschool Nature Explorers - Spring
location: North Carolina Botanical Garden, 100 Old Mason Farm Road, Chapel Hill, NC, 27517, United States

Date: Wednesdays, March 11 – April 22 (6-week series; no class on April 1)
Time: 1:30 – 4:00 PM
Location: North Carolina Botanical Garden
Fee: $180 ($162 Household & above Members) 
  
Let curiosity lead the way! In this playful, nature-based drop-off program, preschoolers will discover the wonders of spring through hands-on activities, outdoor adventures, seasonal crafts, storytelling, and group play. Led by Garden environmental educators, each week explores a new theme—like frogs singing in the ponds, spring wildflowers, and busy pollinators —designed to foster joyful connection with the natural world. 
This is a 6-week program that meets once a week on Wednesdays (except 4/1). Each session starts in the children’s classroom before we head outdoors to explore nature’s classroom—our native plant gardens and forest trails! A healthy snack is included. Group limited to 10. 
  
Register Here

Introductions

title: Wednesday night meditation circle
description:

Join us for a meditation circle in the Plum Village tradition of Buddhist teacher Thich Nhat Hanh. We will practice a short seated meditation (10 minutes), walking meditation (10 minutes), dharma share on a topic of mindfulness by a fellow practitioner, group dharma sharing, and singing. We actively welcome and affirm BIPOC and queer people and seek to hold an inclusive space for all.

**Please note: Our location has changed to the Durham Friends Meetinghouse building in the Dogwood Room at 404 Alexander Ave, Durham, NC 27705**

The space has accessible parking, entrances, and gender neutral bathrooms. Chairs are available, and we encourage you to bring a cushion with you if you have one.

Our group is spirited, compassionate, and eager to learn mindfulness practices in community with one another. We have a suggested $0-5 donation to cover the cost of the space, with excess donations put toward group materials like spare cushions.

Please consider donating to our group on Venmo: [@DurhamPlumVillageMeditation](https://account.venmo.com/u/durhamplumvillagemeditation)

title: AI Hot Topics at NC State
location: Partners I – NC State University, Raleigh Founded (Suite 1650)
description:
The AI Hot Topics monthly networking series is a dynamic forum designed to foster dialogue and collaboration around the rapidly evolving artificial intelligence field. Whether you’re a seasoned AI practitioner, a curious scholar, or simply interested in the transformative potential of AI, this series offers a unique opportunity to connect with leading experts and contribute to meaningful discussions.

The topic for the March 12, 2026, forum will be Titled: Beyond Prediction: Synthetic Data, Agentic Intelligence, and Quantum Acceleration.

Description: 

This session highlights three emerging AI trends shaping safer and more capable systems. It covers how synthetic data and digital twins enable secure, controlled experimentation; how agentic AI allows systems to observe, reason, and act within set boundaries; and when quantum-supported optimization can offer real benefits. Participants will gain a clear view of how these developments work together to support responsible, scalable decision-making across research and industry.

Moderator: Carlos Pinheiro, SAS Data Analyst

Panelists: 

Udo Sglavo, Vice President Applied AI and Modeling R&D at SAS

title: CSS Neuse Museum Homeschool Day
description:
Join us for all of our homeschool day programs for the 2025-2026 school year! After everyone registers, our team will put each student in a group for the field trip. Make sure you include the Co-op or group you would like to be with on the registration form. You can register for all the homeschool day programs now, or you can register each month.

Dates and Themes:

October 8- Espionage
November 5- NC Ironclads and Civil War Weapons
December 17- Victorian Christmas
January 8- Environmental Education
February 12- NC History
March 12- Women's History
April 16- NC Government

For each of these programs, staff from other NC Historic Sites, other State of NC agencies, volunteers, and nonprofit organizations will assist in creating engaging experiences for your homeschool student(s). We aim to include as many hands-on activities as possible. Most of our stations will last around twelve minutes, and families will have a chance to rotate through several stations. Some months, we will also feature a guest speaker, with additional details sent out before the program.

The cost is $2.00 plus tax per student. Beginning in October, adult admission will be free, but everyone will still need to register. Ages 3 and under are free.

Registration link: https://tinyurl.com/y49amdu7

Registration will close on the Monday before the event date, so we can organize groups and send out the list. We will reopen registration after each homeschool day program is finished.

If you have any questions, please email Rachel at rachel.kennedy@dncr.nc.gov.

title: Siler City History Club
description:
Join the Chatham County Historical Association for the Siler City History Club on every second Thursday of the month, 10:30am-11:30am at First Baptist Church. The Chatham County Historical Association needs your help in learning about the rich and colorful history of Siler City! They have facts and figures, but they need to hear your own memories of Siler to really understand one of Chatham County’s most important cities. Come share your memories, stories, photos, mementos, and other Siler City treasures. Light refreshments will be served. This event is free, and everyone is welcome! No registration is required.

This event takes place indoors. First Baptist Church in Siler City is ADA-accessible. No pets allowed. Please leave your furry friends at home. Free parking is available next to the church.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events. See more events hosted by The Chatham Historical Association.

title: Drawing and Understanding Conifer Trees in Micron Pen
location: North Carolina Botanical Garden, 100 Old Mason Farm Road, Chapel Hill, NC, 27517, United States
description:
Register Here

with Stacy-Ann Searle, Landscape Artist 
Date: Thursday, March 12, 2026
Time: 9:30 a.m. – 3:30 p.m.
Location: North Carolina Botanical Garden
Fee: $78 ($70 Members) 
  
Conifers come in many varieties. In this three-session workshop, we will explore how to capture the different overarching structure of these trees, as well as a variety of leaf/needle forms and bark textures. For this class, we will be using micron pens to create a variety of small ink studies. Students will gain an understanding of the different mark making techniques, how to create textures in ink and gain confidence in using this very approachable ink medium.

title: Spring Wildflower Hike
location: Swift Creek Bluffs Nature Preserve, 7800 Holly Springs Rd, Raleigh, NC, 27606, United States
description:
Join TLC on an exploration of Swift Creek Bluffs to see what's in bloom!
Come and explore the ephemeral beauties and early bloomers that carpet the preserve this time of year with TLC Trail Guide Mary Abrams. You are encouraged to bring plant ID guides and have apps such as iNaturalist and Seek downloaded to your mobile device for extra help identifying your findings. We will walk less than 1 mile, but the climb up the stairway to heaven will provide a challenge—and reward us with great views. This is a free event, but preregistration is required.

Due to the size of the parking lot, we will keep the hiking group small and ask that you register by vehicle rather than individual. Feel free to bring guests but please carpool to ensure we have enough space in the parking lot.



If registration is full, please fill out this waitlist form by March 11th at 10am.

Current Mask Policy: TLC seeks to build a supportive, mask-friendly environment in all collaborations with staff and the public. Please wear a mask if you are not vaccinated, or if that makes you feel most comfortable. We will have masks available if you would like to wear one during an event. We also encourage those eligible to be vaccinated to get their Covid-19 vaccine and booster shot. If you are experiencing any Covid-related symptoms, please stay home and attend a program another day. Our top priority is to create a safe environment for our community. Thank you for your understanding.

title: It's Elementary: America 250 Fun and Games!
description:
Join the Chatham Community Library for It's Elementary: America 250 Fun and Games hosted on the second Thursday of every month, 4pm-5pm. Elementary-age kids are invited to explore America's past through a variety of crafts and games.

This FREE, family-friendly event is open to the public. No registration is required. The event will take place indoors in the Chatham Community Library's Holmes Family Meeting Room. The Chatham Community Library is ADA-compliant, including wheelchair-accessible parking, entrances, seating, common spaces, walkways, and restrooms. The Holmes Family Meeting Room has an automatic door opener. Free parking is available outside the library. Pets are not allowed - please leave your furry friends at home.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Circuit Breakers 2026 CRDM Symposium
description:
Circuit Breakers is the theme of the 2026 annual symposium for the Ph.D. in Communication, Rhetoric, and Digital Media program. Contemporary technologies — designed for efficiency, scalability and automated governance — obscure the frictions, breakdowns and refusals that shape everyday survival under neoliberal and colonial conditions. Rather than treating malfunction as failure, this symposium frames disruption as a productive site of critical inquiry, care and world-building. Bringing together media studies, rhetoric and critical making, Circuit Breakers foregrounds practices such as improvised infrastructures, technological disobedience, communal repair, Indigenous technological sovereignty, queer glitch and feminist refusal.

The event will take place at D.H. Hill Jr. Library on March 12 from 4 to 6 p.m. and on March 13 from 8:30 a.m. to 6 pm. To participate and submit your abstract, go to the Circuit Breakers website.

Source: NC State University

title: How To Get Started in Research Workshop
description:
Are you interested in research opportunities as an undergraduate student? If so, join the Office of Undergraduate Research during its weekly Zoom workshops that cover a range of commonly asked questions regarding how to find undergraduate research opportunities and how to get started. A Q&A session will be held at the end of the workshop.

title: March 12 - Agents, MCP and Skills Virtual Meetup
description:
Raleigh AI, Machine Learning and Computer Vision Meetup
Join us for a special edition of the AI, ML and Computer Vision Meetup where we will focus on Agents, MCP and Skills!

**Date, Time, Location**

Mar 12, 2026
9 - 11 AM PST
Online. **[Register for the Zoom!](https://voxel51.com/events/mcp-and-skills-meetup-march-12-2026)**

**Agents Building Agents on the Hugging Face Hub**

Discover how coding agents can run or support your fine-tuning experiments. From quick dataset validation and preprocessing, to optimal GPU hardware selection, to automated job submission based on metric tracking, to evaluation. Ben will demonstrate how Hugging Face skills can be used to define best practices for agents to support machine learning experiments. Bring Claude, Codex, or Mistral Vibes, and we’ll show you to get it training models with GRPO, SFT, and DPO.

*About the Speaker*

[Ben Burtenshaw](https://www.linkedin.com/in/ben-burtenshaw/) is a Machine Learning Engineer at Hugging Face, focusing on building agents with fine-tuning and reinforcement learning. He led educational projects like the Agents Course, the MCP Course, and the LLM course, which bridge the gap between complex Reinforcement Learning (RL) techniques and practical application. Ben focuses on democratizing access to efficient AI, empowering the community to align, evaluate, and deploy transparent agentic systems.

**Claude Code Templates**

This talk explores how to configure and align Claude Code agents using templates and custom components. I'll demonstrate practical configuration patterns that ensure your CLI agent executes exactly what you intend, covering Skills setup, hooks implementation, and template customization. Drawing from real-world examples building Claude Code Templates, attendees will learn how to structure their agent configurations for consistent, reliable behavior and create reusable components that maintain alignment across different use cases.

*About the Speaker*

[Daniel Avila](https://www.linkedin.com/in/daniel-avila-arias/) is an AI Engineer at Hedgineer building agentic systems and creator of Claude Code Templates.

**Move Faster in Computer Vision by Teaching Agents to See Your Data**

Computer vision teams spend too much time writing scripts just to find bad labels, blurry images, and edge cases. In this talk, I’ll show how to move that work to agents by using FiftyOne as a visual operating system. With Skills and MCP, agents can see inside your datasets, explore them visually, and handle common data cleanup tasks, so you can spend less time on data and more time shipping models.

*About the Speaker*

[Adonai Vera](https://www.linkedin.com/in/adonai-vera/) \- Machine Learning Engineer & DevRel at Voxel51\. With over 7 years of experience building computer vision and machine learning models using TensorFlow\, Docker\, and OpenCV\. I started as a software developer\, moved into AI\, led teams\, and served as CTO\. Today\, I connect code and community to build open\, production\-ready AI\, making technology simple\, accessible\, and reliable\.

**Skills As Documentation**

Skills are self-contained recipes - each one a piece of a larger puzzle. Instead of trying to modify human-centric documentation to better fit agents, skills let us build capabilities into our agents directly. This talk will showcase how to think about leveraging skills to enhance how users interact with your software!

*About the Speaker*

[Chris Alexiuk](https://www.linkedin.com/in/csalexiuk/) is a deep learning developer advocate at NVIDIA, working on creating technical assets that help developers use the incredible suite of AI tools available at NVIDIA. Chris comes from a machine learning and data science background, and he is obsessed with everything and anything about large language models.

Source: Meetup: Raleigh AI, ML & Computer Vision
source: Meetup: Raleigh AI, ML & Computer Vision

title: Andrews Launch Accelerator: Launch Sessions
description:
The Andrews Launch Accelerator's Launch Sessions are designed to help ventures articulate, validate and communicate their value to key programs and stakeholders. The schedule for the Launch Sessions is below. All sessions will be held virtually.

Session 1 (Feb. 26): Join us for an introduction to the Andrews Launch Accelerator, the Launch Sessions and the first core principle: customer discovery.

Session 2 ( March 5): This session will explore the often-overlooked fundamentals of customer discovery.  It will focus heavily on understanding your customers' frustrations, dissatisfactions and unfulfilled desires. The session will also delve into collecting evidence of these things through unbiased discovery work.

Session 3 (March 12): You'll learn about the methods entrepreneurs use to rapidly validate demand for what they are working on without spending a lot of money and time.

Session 4 (March 26): With just a few days left before the Andrews Launch Accelerator applications are due on March 31, this session will be an open-floor Q&A on anything related to the Andrews Launch Accelerator, including applications.

Source: NC State University

title: FemTech Panel and Showcase
description:
Join the NC State University Libraries to celebrate the work of NC State faculty and alumni whose design practices have led them into the femtech industry. This event will highlight how human-centered design and emerging technologies are being applied to menstrual care, pelvic health, post-mastectomy support and overall well-being. Speakers will offer short lightning talks on their projects, followed by a panel discussion moderated by Kelly Umstead, associate professor of industrial design. Attendees will have the opportunity to view prototypes and engage directly with the designers behind the work.

Source: NC State University

Triangle Board Games and Bars

How it works:
Come on in, grab a name tag and pay the $2.50 meetup participant fee at the bar area, find the tables that are reserved for the Meetup group, play games with others who show up. Food and drinks are available at the bar.

Please RSVP by noon day of. If less than four people are able to attend a given Wednesday the event will be canceled.

title: "Colonial Wilmington & The Revolution" Walking Tour
description:
Join the Burgwin-Wright House and Gardens for its thrilling "Colonial Wilmington & The Revolution" walking tour on March 13, June 12, September 11 and December 11!

The walking tour will invite guests to learn about how the American Revolution swept across Wilmington in the 1770s by visiting places important to the town's earliest days, including the former jail, courthouse and market sites. Get a unique perspective on what Wilmington would have looked on the eve of the Revolution, just in time for the 250th anniversary of America's independence!

The walking tour will depart from the Burgwin-Wright House (224 Market Street) at 9 a.m. and run 90 minutes. Please wear comfortable shoes and bring water to drink.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Birding with Wake Audubon
location: Williamson Farm and Nature Preserve, 4429 Old Country Mial Rd, Raleigh, 27610, United States
description:
Join TLC and Wake Audubon for this wonderful birding walk!
Our wonderful partners at Wake Audubon have joined TLC to lead a hike on the second Friday of each month at our Williamson Nature Preserve. Join this wonderful morning stroll and see what birds you can find. This hike will be just under 2 miles around the Two Pond Loop at the preserve. Please wear good walking shoes and layers, bring a water bottle, and binoculars if you have them. We suggest that you leave your furry friends at home for this hike as they may scare away wildlife viewing opportunities. This is a free event, but pre-registration is required.

 


If registration is full, please fill out the waitlist form here by March 12th at 10am.
Inclement Weather Policy: In the event of inclement weather, you will be contacted by email for a call on cancellation or postponement. At our Williamson and Brumley South Nature Preserves, due to the multi-use trail systems, we close the trails to the public if there has been rain to try and prevent erosion and detrimental impact. Please note that this event falls under this category and will be cancelled if the trails are closed.

Source: Triangle Land Conservancy

title: Coffee Club Sponsored by Renovation Sells
description:

Chamber Coffee Club meets the 2nd Friday of every month from 8:00 - 9:00 am at The Loading Dock in Wake Forest. What to Expect: Complimentary coffee and light breakfast snacks Opportunity to network with professionals from diverse industries Casual, friendly atmosphere to make new contacts & swap business cards A fun raffle opportunity! This is the perfect chance to start your day meeting new people, sharing ideas, and growing your professional circle. Not a Wake Forest Area Chamber member? This event requires a personal invitation from a current member or staff. Reach out to us to get on the list!

title: NC State Accessibility Collaborative Meeting
description:
The NC State Accessibility Collaborative (NCStAC) is for faculty, staff and students interested in learning about, sharing and promoting accessibility across our university. NCStAC provides a venue for networking and community building, knowledge and information sharing, cross-departmental coordination and peer-to-peer support and collaboration in all areas related to accessibility.

View the agendas for our meetings and browse the NCStAC shared folder. A recording and slides will be added to both folders after each meeting. Join NCStAC  to be added to our Google group and receive the Zoom link for our meetings.

title: Art and Literature: "Soft Night, Watching" and "The Colour out of Space"
description:
Join Lauren Turner (associate curator for contemporary art and special projects), artist Jen Clay, and Ben Boiling (teaching assistant professor of English and Comparative Literature) for a special viewing and discussion at the Ackland Art Museum. Explore the interactive, quilted installation Soft Night, Watching, currently on view, along with the H.P. Lovecraft story that helped inspire it. 
The Ackland is thrilled to partner with Carolina Public Humanities on a program with UNC-Chapel Hill scholars and the artist in conversation about the artwork, the broad themes it addresses, and the literary worlds it reflects upon. Participants will receive a copy of the story in advance and enjoy light refreshments during the program. 
Space is limited; tickets are required. The $40 ticket includes a copy of the book and refreshments at the event. Click here to purchase your ticket today!

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

location: Lake James State Park-Paddy's Creek Visitor Center
description:

title: St. Patrick’s Day Train Ride
description:
Climb aboard our St. Patrick’s Train on the evenings of March 13 & 14 and enjoy an Irish-inspired meal while riding the rails at the N.C. Transportation Museum. Wear your green and bring your Irish cheer! This dinner train will offer guests a happy hour of live music, appetizers, wine, and beer before boarding the train. Dinner will be served as you roll down the tracks, enjoying a full Irish-inspired meal!

Advance ticket purchase is strongly recommended. For members of the museum, it is strongly encouraged to reserve tickets in advance using your membership number.

Each individual passenger will receive two drink tickets to be redeemed from our selection of wine and beer in either the cocktail area or on the train. Additional drinks can also be purchased for an additional cost.

This event is for ages 21 and up only. There is no admittance for anyone under age 21. Valid ID must be shown.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: 1776 the Musical
location: Thalian Hall Center for the Performing Arts
description:
Experience the birth of a nation like never before in 1776 the Musical, a bold and witty retelling of America’s fight for independence. As tensions rise in the Second Continental Congress, John Adams, Thomas Jefferson, and Benjamin Franklin struggle to persuade a divided nation to declare freedom from British rule. With a Tony Award-winning score and a fresh, thought-provoking perspective, this powerful production brings history to life with humor, heart, and relevance for today. Thalian Hall is proud to co-produce this with Thalian Association for our 25-26 season.

Don’t miss this rousing journey to the signing of the Declaration of Independence!

title: Beginner Bird for All
location: Annie Louise Wilkerson, MD Nature Preserve Park, 5229 Awls Haven Dr, Raleigh, NC 27614, USA
description:
*Complete this form to register. *This free workshop requires registration OFF Meetup.

Beginner Birders Program with Wake Audubon and Raleigh Parks.

Date: Saturday, March 14, 2026

Time: 9:00* a.m. – 12:15 p.m. (*Please arrive 10 minutes early to check in; arrive 8:40 a.m. if borrowing binoculars),

Location: Walnut Creek Wetland Center, 950 Peterson St. Raleigh, NC 27610

Calling everyone curious about birding, but not sure where to begin!

‘Birding’ – or the observation of birds in their natural habitats as a hobby – has become one of the most popular outdoor activities. If you are taking a new interest in birds and looking for help getting started, come develop your skills together with others at our Beginning Birding workshop.

This free public program teaches the basics of bird identification; how to use binoculars, guides and apps; types of bird safety and ways to bird safely; and the importance of inclusion and allyship in birding and the outdoors. We’ll spend time outside putting your learning to quick use.

Our route outside will consist of flat, paved concrete and asphalt trails. Gendered restrooms will be available. Snacks, coffee, and tea will be provided.

No binoculars? No problem! We have plenty of loaners to spare.

Co-founded by Wake Audubon and Field Inclusive, Inc., in partnership with City of Raleigh Parks, our mission is to provide safe, equitable and accessible outdoor experiences for everyone.

Note: Participation may be capped due to space restrictions, at which time notice of a wait list will be added to the top of the registration form. Please continue to register to join the waitlist. Should we receive cancellations, we’ll right away invite those on waitlist to confirm in the order registrations were received.

Reach Wake Audubon board member, Equity, Diversity, Inclusion and Belonging co-chair and Beginning Birding program manager Rick LaRose at rlarose.was@gmail.com with any questions.

We look forward to you beginning to bird with us on March 14!

Source: Wake Audubon

title: Peter Francisco Commemoration Ceremony
description:
Peter Francisco (1760–1831) was a Portuguese-born giant of the American Revolution, famed for his incredible strength and bravery in battles like Camden and Guilford Courthouse. George Washington reportedly called him “a One-Man Army” and he was perhaps the most famous private soldier of the Revolutionary War.

Celebrated on March 15 in Virginia, Peter Francisco Day honors the legendary bravery at the 1781 Battle of Guilford Courthouse, where Peter fought valiantly against British forces and is remembered on the American Cavalry Monument.

Join us on March 14 in Greensboro, NC as we remember and honor Peter's bravery 250 years later.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: GGC Adventure Series: Lake Raleigh Woods Trek
description:
Back for another year of inspiring adventures in nature, this season of the Greenway Gear Collective Adventure Series will feature Adventure Race themed outings.
Each event will focus on one of the disciplines of adventure racing: traditionally mountain biking, orienteering (map and compass navigation), and paddling (canoe or kayak) and will take place at or around Lake Raleigh. Beginners or veterans alike will be in excellent hands with each adventure led by Debra and Jeff Rezeli, experts with over 11 years of adventure racing experience.
Register for each event here.

For those who love a goal to build towards...
The series will build skills in advance of a local practice 3-hour adventure race in May and the option to register and participate in a 5-hour adventure race hosted by Broad Run Offroad on June 13 & 14 at Lake Anna State Park in Spotsylvania, VA.
For more information on adventure racing, check out the US Adventure Racing Association website.

Source: NC State University
