title: "Her Heart is Slowly Breaking:" a Women's History Tour of Stagville - 2026
description:
Explore the resistance, resilience, love, and labor of enslaved women on one of the largest plantations in North Carolina.

This March, visit Historic Stagville for a special guided tour of the Bennehan House and grounds featuring the stories of enslaved women from Stagville. This tour highlights the lives of Phoebe Bennehan, Anna Bell, Emma Turner Henderson, and more. Their personal stories, reconstructed with careful research, illuminate the experiences of countless women who endured bondage in North Carolina. 

This tour will be offered each Saturday in March, at 11 am, in recognition of Women's History Month.

This tour is intended for adult visitors. It includes content about violence, sexual violence, and family separation. Tours will last about 1 hour. The tour will include walking and standing, both indoors and outdoors, including walking over grass, gravel, and uneven surfaces.

Space is limited. Register now to reserve your space! Tickets are $10 per person plus tax, payable by card when you check-in for the tour on site.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Durham Farmers' Market
location: Durham Central Park, 501 Foster Street, Durham, NC, 27701, United States
description:
The Durham Farmers’ Market is a community of farmers, growers and crafters. We are strongly committed to local products: every item you see at the market was produced by the people selling it, and it all comes from no more than 70 miles away. 
The Durham Farmers’ Market open Saturdays mornings for local produce, flowers, crafts and more! The Wednesday Market is open from 3-6pm Wednesdays, Mid-April through Mid-October 
If you’d like more information about this week’s vendor list, SNAP benefits and map, visit durhamfarmersmarket.com 

We are happy to offer Double Bucks to our SNAP clients. This means is a SNAP client has $10, they receive $20 in tokens to spend at the winter market.

Estamos muy contentos de ofrecer Double Bucks a nuestros clientes de SNAP. Esto significa que si un cliente de SNAP gasta $ 10, recibirá $ 20 en tokens para gastar en productos frescos.


Additionally, we offer a cash match program for other qualifying folks. To receive this benefit, simply bring cash to the info table. Then, we’ll double the amount with tokens. For example, $10 in cash equals $20 in tokens.

También ofrecemos un programa de contrapartida en efectivo para nuestros beneficiarios de SNAP que no tienen beneficios durante el mes, clientes de WIC y miembros de la comunidad que viven en viviendas públicas. Para recibir este beneficio, simplemente traiga efectivo a la tabla de información y duplicaremos la cantidad con tokens. Por ejemplo, $ 10 en efectivo equivalen a $ 20 en fichas.

Source: Durham Central Park

Yoga In Nature™, NC
**SPRING IS ALMOST HERE, so join Yoga In Nature ™** as we do an **ALL LEVELS** vinyasa flow to yin yoga practice, at this beautiful location, facing the lake. Modifications provided. **Beginners welcome**. Connect with nature with all of your senses to find calm and peace within as we practice yoga. Yoga heals. Nature heals. Yoga In Nature.
**Note that location is NOT in the gravel parking lot, but in the open field:)**

BRING YOUR OWN YOGA MAT, towel, water bottle, and block (if you use one), sunscreen, insect repellent (seasonal). You may also want to bring an old towel or liner for under your mat, if the ground is wet. We will meet in the open field area near the parking lot. $15/person Accepting Venmo @Darlene-Genander or PayPal dgenander@yogainnature.com or Zelle or cash

Lake Crabtree County Park, past the entrance booth, at the open field, near volleyball courts and Old Beech Nature Trail... first right after you enter the park.(If you get to the entrance where there are boat rentals and launch area you've gone too far).
Lake Crabtree County Park, 1400 Aviation Parkway, Morrisville

Advance ticket purchase is strongly recommended. For members of the museum, it is strongly encouraged to reserve tickets in advance using your membership number.

Each individual passenger will receive two drink tickets to be redeemed from our selection of wine and beer in either the cocktail area or on the train. Additional drinks can also be purchased for an additional cost.

title: Deep Sky Astronomy
location: Haw River State Park - Iron Ore Belt Access
description:
This event is free to attend, but registration is requested. 

Join local astronomers with the Greensboro Astronomy Club as we observe the night skies over the Iron Ore Belt Access. Attendees may expect to see closer-than-typical views of the moon, planets, star clusters, and other celestial objects subject to change with time of year and local sky darkness.

Telescopes and viewing equipment will be set up on site but you may wish to bring your own binoculars or telescope, plus a chair or blanket for seating. Dress for the weather. Flashlights & headlamps should have a red-light option or filter to protect your night vision.

Skywatching sessions may be cancelled at the last minute for weather. Please register at the Register link so you can be emailed in the event of cancellation.

Program equipment and instruction provided by members of the Greensboro Astronomy Club, which meet the third Friday of each month at the Greensboro Science Center. Learn more about their organization here: 

https://greensboroastronomyclub.org/

Star-gazing Etiquette:

Please use a red light at the observing session and keep any light pointed at the ground. As your eyes adapt, a light is not needed at all.Pease do not touch any telescopes or other equipment unless permission is given and form a orderly line behind each telescope. Please do not allow children or pets to run around the observing area. Pets must be on a leash no longer than 6 feet at all times. This is to protect others' safety and the equipment.Stock photo © Pexels / Lucas Pezeta

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: ERA - Guided Wildflower Hike - Willie Duke's Bluff
location: Penny's Bend, Old Oxford Rd, Durham, NC 27712, USA
description:
Registration is required - Tickets drop on February 1st at 8:00am!
Price: $4
*Ticket prices directly support the work of the Eno River Association. Thank you for your support!

This hike is somewhat difficult and will be off trail, with some bushwhacking and one steep climb. This usually requires about three hours. If there have been recent rains, parts of the trail may be muddy. The hike will lead you to a noteworthy natural area called Willie Duke’s Bluff where you see outstanding displays of spring wildflowers, including some that are rare and unusual in our area of the Piedmont. The site boasts a showy display of spring ephemerals, with extensive areas of Dutchman’s Breeches (Dicentra cucullaria), along with the rare Eastern False Rue Anemone or Isopyrum (Enemion biternatum) and numerous other wildflowers, including Bloodroot (Sanguinaria canadensis), and both Southern or Dimpled Troutlily (Erythronium umbilicatum), and its northern, tetraploid counterpart (E. americanum). The shrub layer consists of Spicebush (Lindera benzoin), Pawpaw (Asimina triloba), and Painted Buckeye (Aesculus sylvatica), which will be in various stages of flowering.

Wear sturdy shoes and long pants, and bring gloves in case you feel inclined to pull out any invasive Chinese privet seedlings that you might encounter. You will also learn some history and geology along the way.

Please feel free to bring water and snacks. Well-behaved dogs are welcome as long as they are under your control and on a 6-foot leash.

This event is rain or shine. We will contact you if severe weather is expected that would cause us to cancel the hike.

If your plans change and you are unable to attend the hike, please contact education@enoriver.org to cancel your registration so that we may offer your spot(s) to our waitlist.


Directions: Coming from the west, take Duke Street North from I-85 (Exit 176). Turn right on Murray Avenue (sign to the Museum of Life and Science), go until it reaches Roxboro Street, turn left and look for the brown sign to Stagville. [Coming from the east, you can take Roxboro Street directly from I-85.] Turn right here on Old Oxford Road. Go about three miles until Old Oxford crosses the Eno. Immediately after the bridge, turn left on Snowhill Road. Penny’s Bend parking lot will be on the left immediately after you turn.

Source: Eno River Association

title: Relational Leadership @ Carolina Spring Four-Day Institute
description:
Relational Leadership @ Carolina offers the Relational Leadership Institute as a professional development program that helps people build teams and organizational cultures that prioritize connection, engagement and well-being. Join the community of 500+ leaders who have participated since 2019!

 

The Spring 2026 Four-Day Institute meets 8:30 a.m. - 4:30 p.m. each day, in person at the Health Sciences Library: 

Monday, March 16

Tuesday, March 17

Thursday, March 26

Friday, March 27

 

The series consists of 4 in-person sessions of 8 hours each. Each session includes The curriculum includes a combination of large and small group interactions to move through the four domains of Relational Leadership: manage self; foster teamwork; coach and develop; and accelerate change. Participants will complete asynchronous assignments between sessions, including skills practice and individual reflections on curricular content. The total time commitment for participants is 30 hours. Each session builds on the next, making attendance at all 4 dates a requirement to participate. 

 

Questions? Contact Josh Hinson: qhinson@email.unc.edu

 

Spots are limited, registration required.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: The Art and Science of Plant Care
description:
Caring for plants is both an art and a science — part intuition, part know-how. Every gardener, from beginner to expert, faces the same essential questions: When should I prune? How much should I water? What’s the best way to plant, fertilize or repot? In this class, Bryce Lane will bring decades of horticultural expertise to demystify these everyday tasks, showing you not just what to do but why it works.

Over eight weeks, you’ll explore the fundamental practices that keep gardens thriving, learning how to perform each one with confidence and purpose. You’ll uncover the science behind good technique — understanding how soil, water, nutrients and plant biology interact — while also developing the practical judgment that comes only with experience.

Each session will focus on one key aspect of plant care, building a complete toolkit for growing healthier, more resilient plants in any garden setting.

title: Plug and Play: A Guide to Planting Perennial Plugs (virtual)
description:
Most gardeners are familiar with planting container-grown perennials, but using plugs requires a shift in mindset and technique. These young starter plants, grown in trays instead of pots, offer distinct advantages: they are cost-effective, easier to plant and establish quickly. They are ideal for large areas, slopes and under trees. However, not every gardener is familiar with plugs. Planting them successfully takes a bit of practical know-how that even experienced gardeners will appreciate refining. Join Shannon Currey, education and outreach at Izel Native Plant, to learn the pros and cons of plugs, when they’re most appropriate and best practices for handling, planting and managing them. With these essentials, you’ll be planting like a pro! 
Fee: Free; registration required. 
Location: Zoom. The recording will be shared with all registrants. 
Accessibility: This will be a virtual program that takes place on Zoom with the option to enable closed captioning.

Source: Sarah P. Duke Gardens

title: *VIRTUAL* SF/F Group

Durham Writers Group
**Zoom Info Below Description**

This sub-group focuses on Science Fiction and Fantasy, so if you have anything that falls under that category — be it short story, poem, novel-in-progress or screenplay — then come! We'd love to hear from you.

Our format allows each reader 15 minutes to present their work... followed by approximately 20 minutes of feedback from the other attendees. To ensure a fair opportunity to respond, each attendee is limited to 1 minute of feedback time. (We usually get through three readers.)

If a reader elects to post their work in advance (NOT a requirement!), members will be able to access that work at our Google Group:

We ask all members to provide a warning, both on the Google Group and during the meeting, if their story features content that some readers might find upsetting. This includes descriptions of sexual violence.

**[Register for the Zoom](https://voxel51.com/events/vibe-coding-production-ready-computer-vision-pipelines-hands-on-workshop-march-18-2026)**

Plugins enable you to customize the open-source [FiftyOne computer vision app](https://docs.voxel51.com/index.html) to match your exact workflow by easily incorporating data annotation, curation, model evaluation and inference.

We'll demonstrate how FiftyOne Skills and the MCP Server can streamline the journey from prototype to production-ready pipelines, keeping your development flow intact.

Perfect for open-source contributors, researchers, and enterprise teams seeking hands-on experience. All participants receive slides, notebooks, and access to GitHub repositories and videos from the workshop.

title: AI Infrastructure That Scales: Foundations for Real-World Deployment
description:
Data Science Raleigh
Experimentation is easy. Real-world deployment? That’s where the infrastructure proves its worth.

In this session, we’ll go beyond prototypes and pilot programs to explore what it really takes to build AI infrastructure that holds up under production demands. From GPU scheduling and model orchestration to observability, governance, and scaling compute across hybrid environments—this discussion is for teams ready to move past the lab and into sustained delivery.

Our panel of leaders will break down architectural trade-offs, emerging best practices, and the organizational realities of supporting production-grade AI.

**What You'll Learn:**

1️⃣ **Foundational Stack Components:** What your AI infrastructure needs to support scale, speed, and stability in production.

2️⃣ **Deployment Realities:** Insights into latency, availability, compliance, and lifecycle management when shipping AI to production.

3️⃣**Infrastructure as Collaboration:** How infra, ML, and product teams can align on goals, budgets, and tooling without bottlenecks.Engage live with founders and builders shaping the future of autonomous enterprise solutions.

Panelists to be announced soon.

**[Register here](https://hubs.ly/Q03VWZMN0)**

Source: Meetup: Data Science Raleigh

title: Invasive Plant Removal at CHJEEP
location: Carroll Howard Johnson Environmental Park, 301 Wagstaff Rd, Fuquay-Varina, NC 27526, USA
description:
Volunteers Needed for Invasive Plant Removal at Carroll Howard Johnson Environmental Education Park (CHJEEP) on Thursday, MARCH 19, 2026, 9 - 11 am

Location is 301 Wagstaff Rd., Fuquay-Varina 27526

Leader: Jim Hunsberger, jim.hunsberger@gmail.com

Please join Wake Audubon volunteers and help with invasive plant removal at CHJEEP. This helps the birds and other wildlife.

We will meet in the parking lot of CHJEEP.

NOTE: Must be 18 years old or older, close-toed shoes required.  Bring hand tools and buckets (or borrow from town supplied tools), water, bug spray, sunscreen, gloves, safety glasses, wear a hat, long pants, and long-sleeved shirt.

Town staff will be on hand with a debris trailer. They will use targeted herbicide treatments as necessary after we remove the plants (thus, we don't have to struggle to dig out the roots).

Thanks for helping to improve the flora of this lovely park! "The focus of this 28-acre park is environmental education. Carroll Howard Johnson Environmental Education Park was originally a 20-acre tract of land donated to the Town of Fuquay-Varina in 1992 by the late Mayor Alfred Johnson and his wife Carroll Howard Johnson. Eight acres were donated by Horace Tart in 1998, enlarging the park to its current 28 acres.

Get back to nature at the Carroll Howard Johnson Environmental Education Park. Explore the 2-mile nature trail and uncover the natural treasures in Fuquay-Varina. Crossing beautiful overlooks and natural bridges, visitors will find a path of wooded splendor, local flora and fauna, and many species of birds that highlight the everyday wonders of Fuquay-Varina’s nature."

Thanks for helping out!

(Rain date is Thursday March 26)

title: Webinar: SMARTER NC
description:
Join NC State Industry Extension Services for a webinar that will focus on smart manufacturing and the opportunities available through a federally funded grant for small and medium-sized manufacturers in North Carolina who are ready to adopt technology. The webinar's goal is to provide targeted technical assistance to small- to medium-sized manufacturers to increase awareness of, access to and implementation of innovative smart manufacturing technologies. The benefits of smart manufacturing are:

Improved efficiency: Smart factories can monitor equipment performance and automate complex processes, improving accuracy and reducing human error.Increased productivity: Smart factories can use data to identify issues, such as when a machine slows down production and then use artificial intelligence systems to resolve the issues.Long-term cost savings: Smart factories can use predictive maintenance to identify potential problems early and address them at a convenient time, which can save money.Greater flexibility: Smart factories can scale production quickly to meet changing demand and can customize products to meet specific customer needs.You can complete a short application to find out if your company is ready to participate in the program. For more information about the webinar, visit the NC State Industry Extension Services' website.

title: To Preserve the Blessings of Liberty: State Constitutions of North Carolina
description:
Join the Museum of the Albemarle on Thursday, Mar. 19 from 1–4 p.m. for a unique One Day Wonder opportunity to view North Carolina’s historic constitutions. The Museum of the Albemarle, a part of the Division of State History Museums, Office of Archives and History, is an agency of the North Carolina Department of Natural and Cultural Resources.

 

Since the first state constitution was adopted in 1776, North Carolina leaders have rewritten the constitution twice and added more than 100 amendments. This special one-day-only exhibit provides an overview of the three state constitutions and their significant amendments that served to redefine the meaning of citizenship in North Carolina and who could participate in the political process. The exhibit features the 1776 State Constitution and Declaration of Rights, the 1868 State Constitution, and a letter from John Adams commonly known as “Thoughts on Government.” The exhibit also includes archivists from the State Archives of North Carolina who will accompany the materials and interact with visitors.

 

America 250 NC is North Carolina’s commemoration of the United States’ 250th anniversary and is led by the N.C. Department of Natural and Cultural Resources. For more information about America 250 NC, visit america250.nc.gov.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: March 19 - Women in AI Meetup
description:
Raleigh AI, Machine Learning and Computer Vision Meetup
Hear talks from experts on the latest topics in AI, ML, and computer vision on March 19th.

**Date and Location**

Mar 19, 2026
9 - 11 AM Pacific
Online. **[Register for Zoom!](https://voxel51.com/events/women-in-ai-meetup-march-19-2026)**

**Towards Reliable Clinical AI: Evaluating Factuality, Robustness, and Real-World Performance of Large Language Models**

Large language models are increasingly deployed in clinical settings, but their reliability remains uncertain—they hallucinate facts, behave inconsistently across instruction phrasings, and struggle with evolving medical terminology. In my talk, I address methods to systematically evaluate clinical LLM reliability across four dimensions aligned with how healthcare professionals actually work: verifying concrete facts (FactEHR), ensuring stable guidance across instruction variations (instruction sensitivity study showing up to 0.6 AUROC variation), integrating up-to-date knowledge (BEACON improving biomedical NER by 15%), and assessing real patient conversations (PATIENT-EVAL revealing models abandon safety warnings when patients seek reassurance). These contributions establish evaluation standards spanning factuality, robustness, knowledge integration, and patient-centered communication, charting a path toward clinical AI that is safer, more equitable, and more trustworthy.

*About the Speaker*

[Monica Munnangi](https://www.linkedin.com/in/monicamunnangi/) is a doctoral student at the Khoury College of Computer Sciences at Northeastern University, advised by Saiph Savage. Her doctoral research, which she began in 2021 and expects to complete in 2026, focuses on multi-modal machine learning for healthcare. After being introduced to artificial intelligence and machine learning during her undergraduate studies, Munnangi earned her master’s degree from UMass Amherst.

**Neural BRDFs: Learning Compact Representations for Material Appearance**

Accurately modeling how light interacts with real-world materials remains a central challenge in rendering. Bidirectional Reflectance Distribution Functions (BRDFs) describe how materials reflect light as a function of viewing and lighting directions. Creating realistic digital materials has traditionally required choosing between fast parametric models that can't capture real-world complexity, or massive measured BRDFs that are expensive to acquire and store. Neural BRDFs address this challenge by learning continuous reflectance functions from data, exploiting directional correlations and symmetry to achieve significant compression while maintaining rendering quality. In this talk, we examine how neural networks can encode complex material behavior compactly, why this matters for rendering and material capture, and how neural BRDFs fit into the broader evolution toward data-driven graphics.

*About the Speaker*

[Manushree Gangwar](https://www.linkedin.com/in/manushreegangwar/) is a Machine Learning Engineer at Voxel51 working on data-centric visual AI. She holds an MS in Computer Science from Columbia University and has previously worked in robotics, autonomous driving, and AR/VR, with a focus on scene understanding and 3D reconstruction.

**Supercharging AI agents with evaluations**

Reliable deployment of AI agents depends on rigorous evaluation, which must shift from a nice-to-have QA step to a core engineering discipline. Robust evaluation is essential for safety, predictability, misuse resistance, and sustained user trust. To meet this bar, Evals must be deeply integrated into the agent development lifecycle. This talk will outline how simulation-based testing—using high-fidelity, controllable environments—provides the next generation of evaluation infrastructure for production-ready AI agents.

*About the Speaker*

[Priya Venkat](https://www.linkedin.com/in/priya26/), PhD, is a Senior AI Manager at Intuit, where she leads teams that build and scale ML and Agentic AI systems for finance. Her work integrates cutting-edge agentic workflows and robust evaluation systems to drive business impact while ensuring AI safety and reliability. Priya is a strong advocate of responsible AI, and actively mentors the next generation of AI scientists and engineers.

**Language Diffusion Models**

Autoregressive models (ARMs) are widely regarded as the cornerstone of large language models (LLMs). Challenge this notion by introducing LLaDA, a diffusion model trained from scratch under the pre-training and supervised fine-tuning (SFT) paradigm. LLaDA models distributions through a forward data masking process and a reverse process, parameterized by a vanilla Transformer to predict masked tokens. Optimizing a likelihood bound provides a principled generative approach for probabilistic inference. Across extensive benchmarks, LLaDA demonstrates strong scalability, outperforming self-constructed ARM baselines. Remarkably, LLaDA 8B is competitive with strong LLMs like LLaMA3 8B in in-context learning and, after SFT, exhibits impressive instruction-following abilities in case studies such as multi-turn dialogue.

*About the Speaker*

[Jayita Bhattacharyya](https://www.linkedin.com/in/jayita-bhattacharyya) is a AI ML Nerd with a blend of technical speaking & hackathon wizardry! Applying tech to solve real-world problems. The work focus these days is on generative AI. Helping software teams incorporate AI into transforming software engineering.

Source: Meetup: Raleigh AI, ML & Computer Vision

title: Hallowed Ground Lantern Tour
description:
The New Bern Historical Society invites you to an exciting storytelling event, the Hallowed Ground Lantern Tour, March 19, 20 & 21, 6-9pm. New Bern Battlefield Park, site of the first Battle of New Bern, hosts this intriguing event. The tour takes you on a guided, lantern-lit walk through the wooded battlefield trails, where spirits of real characters from New Bern's past will share their very human and inspiring stories of courage and conviction.   

As you visit, you will hear, a firsthand account about the daring raid to capture a Union gunboat, about those who fled and those who stayed in New Bern after the battle, from nursing nuns from New York who came to help the wounded, and about maritime involvement in the battle. That’s just to name a few.

Pre-paid reservations are required with specific day & arrival time. Tickets are $16 for Historical Society adult members, students, and active-duty military; $19 adult non-members. Space is limited. Reservations are available beginning February 4th at www.NewBernHistorical.org/tickets . Not suitable for children under 7 or those with difficulty walking.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: CSA Triangle March Meetup - Sponsored by Tines
description:
Cloud Security Alliance Triangle Chapter
Automating the Cloud Controls Matrix: From Deterministic Audits to AI Agents

Modernizing GRC by evolving static risk workflows into intelligent AI agents that map security alerts directly to CSA standards

Summary of Presentation:

Despite the rise of AI, "manual work remains stubbornly high" for security teams. This session demonstrates how to bridge the gap between CSA Cloud Auditing (CCAK) and practical automation by building a three-stage GRC pipeline in Tines:
1\. The Foundation \(Deterministic\): We begin by ingesting raw cloud alerts and creating a standardized "Risk Register using Tines Records"\, ensuring every violation is captured without manual entry\.
2\. The Intelligence \(AI Agent\): We upgrade the workflow with an AI Agent action\. Because "Agents shouldn’t be a black box"\, we explicitly instruct it to map alerts to the Cloud Controls Matrix’s "197 control objectives" and recommend remediation\.
3\. The Interaction \(AI Chatbot\): We conclude by deploying an "AI interaction layer"\. This allows auditors to query their compliance data using natural language \(e\.g\.\, "Show me all GDPR risks"\)\, effectively "unlocking AI’s full value" for the audit process

Source: Meetup: Cloud Security Alliance Triangle

location: North Carolina Botanical Garden, 100 Old Mason Farm Road, Chapel Hill, NC, 27517, United States
description:
Register Here

Grades: 1st-3rd
Date: Friday, March 20
Time: 9:00 AM – 3:00 PM  *Drop-off: 8:45 – 9:00 AM; Pick-up 3:00 – 3:15 PM
Location: North Carolina Botanical Garden
Fee: $75 ($68 Household & above Members)
School Districts: Chapel Hill-Carrboro 
  
School’s out for a teacher workday? Get your child outdoors and into nature at the Garden! Prepare to dig in and cook up some fun! In this tasty camp, young chefs will explore how plants grow and discover the delicious ingredients that come straight from the garden. Campers will taste fresh veggies and learn simple, kid-friendly recipes. The camp day will include garden explorations, creative crafts, and story time that celebrates the joy of growing and sharing food. From seed to snack, it’s a day full of flavor and fun in the garden! 
Led by Garden environmental educators, School’s Out Camps feature a blend of indoor and outdoor learning and loads of fun in a small group setting! 
  
Register Here

title: 10 Strategies for Improving Your Finances
description:
The current economic climate brings both challenges and opportunities from a financial perspective. You may wonder during these challenging times: “What should I be most careful about” and “What should my family and I work towards?” The 10 financial tips discussed in this workshop will get you on the road to financial well-being during challenging times.

 

Workshop Objectives
At the end of this workshop, you will be able to:
Identify the most pressing/immediate financial steps to take in your life
• Describe why an emergency fund is an absolute necessity
• Identify how to categorize types of expenses
• Describe your current financial position by putting it on paper
Describe steps to help you through economic troubles
• Describe how to begin paying down debts
• Identify ways to improve your credit score
Describe ways to build long-term plans for your financial health
• Describe how to evaluate your insurance coverage
• Identify how to build or refine your retirement plans

 

Click on Carolina Talent registration link and select the “Request” button to automatically enroll.

title: Hallowed Ground Lantern Tour
description:
The New Bern Historical Society invites you to an exciting storytelling event, the Hallowed Ground Lantern Tour, March 19, 20 & 21, 6-9pm. New Bern Battlefield Park, site of the first Battle of New Bern, hosts this intriguing event. The tour takes you on a guided, lantern-lit walk through the wooded battlefield trails, where spirits of real characters from New Bern's past will share their very human and inspiring stories of courage and conviction.   

As you visit, you will hear, a firsthand account about the daring raid to capture a Union gunboat, about those who fled and those who stayed in New Bern after the battle, from nursing nuns from New York who came to help the wounded, and about maritime involvement in the battle. That’s just to name a few.

Pre-paid reservations are required with specific day & arrival time. Tickets are $16 for Historical Society adult members, students, and active-duty military; $19 adult non-members. Space is limited. Reservations are available beginning February 4th at www.NewBernHistorical.org/tickets . Not suitable for children under 7 or those with difficulty walking.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Remember the Ladies: A Living History Experience
description:
Remember the Ladies — A Living History Experience

Museum of the Waxhaws • Waxhaw, NC
March 21 • 10:00 AM – 4:00 PM

On March 21st, from 10 AM to 4 PM, the Museum of the Waxhaws in Waxhaw, NC will host “Remember the Ladies: A Living History Experience,” an immersive event celebrating the extraordinary women who helped shape America. Through first and thid person interpretation and interactive storytelling, guests will step into the past and meet the women whose courage, intellect, and determination influenced generations.

 Abigail Adams’ famous call to “remember the ladies” serves as the event’s guiding theme, echoed throughout the day as performers illuminate the stories of women whose contributions are too often overlooked.

In addition to the living history presentations, visitors can enjoy a vibrant outdoor marketplace on the museum grounds. Women-owned businesses, artisans, and makers will be onsite offering handcrafted goods, art, specialty items, and more. Food vendors will also be available on the outdoor field, providing a variety of delicious options for guests to enjoy throughout the day.

With engaging activities, meaningful conversations, local vendors, and lively performances, this event offers something for all ages. Come spend the day with us as we honor the women of the past, support the women of today, and celebrate the ongoing legacy of resilience and inspiration.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: "Her Heart is Slowly Breaking:" a Women's History Tour of Stagville - 2026
description:
Explore the resistance, resilience, love, and labor of enslaved women on one of the largest plantations in North Carolina.

This March, visit Historic Stagville for a special guided tour of the Bennehan House and grounds featuring the stories of enslaved women from Stagville. This tour highlights the lives of Phoebe Bennehan, Anna Bell, Emma Turner Henderson, and more. Their personal stories, reconstructed with careful research, illuminate the experiences of countless women who endured bondage in North Carolina. 

This tour will be offered each Saturday in March, at 11 am, in recognition of Women's History Month.

This tour is intended for adult visitors. It includes content about violence, sexual violence, and family separation. Tours will last about 1 hour. The tour will include walking and standing, both indoors and outdoors, including walking over grass, gravel, and uneven surfaces.

Space is limited. Register now to reserve your space! Tickets are $10 per person plus tax, payable by card when you check-in for the tour on site.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Durham Farmers' Market
location: Durham Central Park, 501 Foster Street, Durham, NC, 27701, United States
description:
The Durham Farmers’ Market is a community of farmers, growers and crafters. We are strongly committed to local products: every item you see at the market was produced by the people selling it, and it all comes from no more than 70 miles away. 
The Durham Farmers’ Market open Saturdays mornings for local produce, flowers, crafts and more! The Wednesday Market is open from 3-6pm Wednesdays, Mid-April through Mid-October 
If you’d like more information about this week’s vendor list, SNAP benefits and map, visit durhamfarmersmarket.com 

We are happy to offer Double Bucks to our SNAP clients. This means is a SNAP client has $10, they receive $20 in tokens to spend at the winter market.

Estamos muy contentos de ofrecer Double Bucks a nuestros clientes de SNAP. Esto significa que si un cliente de SNAP gasta $ 10, recibirá $ 20 en tokens para gastar en productos frescos.


Additionally, we offer a cash match program for other qualifying folks. To receive this benefit, simply bring cash to the info table. Then, we’ll double the amount with tokens. For example, $10 in cash equals $20 in tokens.

También ofrecemos un programa de contrapartida en efectivo para nuestros beneficiarios de SNAP que no tienen beneficios durante el mes, clientes de WIC y miembros de la comunidad que viven en viviendas públicas. Para recibir este beneficio, simplemente traiga efectivo a la tabla de información y duplicaremos la cantidad con tokens. Por ejemplo, $ 10 en efectivo equivalen a $ 20 en fichas.

Source: Durham Central Park

title: Curating Change: The Art of Activism in Education
description:
we are invites you to join for their 10th Annual Let’s Talk Racism Conference! This year, the theme is Curating Change: The Art of Activism in Education. The conference will be held in Durham at North Carolina Central University on Saturday, March 21, 2026, and will provide an opportunity for educators, parents, students and community members to discuss creative ways of challenging racial inequities in our schools. 
The purpose of this event is to give K-12 educators and pre-service teachers an opportunity to engage in sessions centered on building liberatory, culturally affirming learning spaces that dismantle systemic racism in schools and beyond. CEU certificates will be provided for participating educators. While educators are the target audience, we are welcomes all community members to participate. 
The planning collaborative is thrilled to announce Keith Knight as their keynote speaker. Knight is an award-winning cartoonist, musician, and educator whose work has been lauded for its sharp wit, political insight, and ability to blend humor with hard truths. Best known for his comic strips The K Chronicles, (th)ink, and The Knight Life, Knight has spent decades using comics as a lens to examine race, class, identity, and the absurdities of everyday life. 
To register, visit www.LetsTalkRacism.com.

Source: Resilient Durham NC

title: ERA - Creek Week at the Confluence Nature Fun Day
description:
Join the Eno River Association for a day of hands-on, nature-based discovery as we celebrate Orange County Creek Week! Splash through one of the Eno’s tributaries with us as we catch and identify macroinvertebrates and other fascinating creek critters. Additional activities will include short hikes, arts and crafts, and insect investigations. Come ready to explore, learn, and get a little muddy as we celebrate our local waterways! 

This event is FREE and registration is NOT required. Drop by anytime between noon and 4pm. All ages welcome. 

Restrooms are available on-site. Two accessible parking spaces connect the paved sidewalk to the pavilion. At least one activity will take place in the paved pavilion. 

Questions? Email education@enoriver.org for more information about this event.

Source: Eno River Association

description:

The presentation is free, and books will be available for purchase.

The presentation is a great way to learn about the history of wildflowers and celebrate America's 250th anniversary.  

About America 250 NC

America 250 NC is North Carolina's commemoration of the United States' 250th anniversary and is led by the N.C. Department of Natural and Cultural Resources. For more information about America 250 NC, visit america250.nc.gov.

title: ERA - Guided Wildflower Hike - Flat River
location: Flat River Waterfowl Impoundment, 5094 Old Oxford Rd, Durham, NC 27712, USA
description:
Registration is required - Tickets drop on February 1st at 8:00am!
Price: $4
*Ticket prices directly support the work of the Eno River Association. Thank you for your support!


The destination is a section of alluvial levee forest in the bend of the Flat River. The hike starts and ends along the gravel access roads of the food plot sub-impoundments in the floodplain of the Flat River above Falls Lake. We will walk about a half of a mile before entering the woods. Once in the woods there is no defined trail, but the terrain is relatively flat and the vegetation will be growing in and we will do a bit of bushwhacking. This site is one of the significant natural heritage sites recorded on Corps of Engineers land at Falls Lake. The shrub layer consists of spicebush, pawpaw, and painted buckeye, which will be in various stages of flowering. The forest also boasts one of the more expansive populations of Dutchman's breeches and False Rue-anemone in the region. Wear sturdy shoes and long pants, and bring gloves if you are inclined to pull out any invasive Chinese privet seedlings we are likely to encounter.

During the hike we’ll talk at length about the bedrock geology, soils and soil chemistry, geomorphology and fluvial processes, and cultural history of the site, which also happens to straddle the Indian Trading Path where it crosses the Flat at a natural ford.

This hike will take approximately two hours (sometimes less, sometimes more). Please feel free to bring water and snacks. Wear comfortable, weather appropriate clothing and shoes. Well-behaved dogs are welcome as long as they are under your control and on a 6 foot leash.

This event is rain or shine. We will contact you if severe weather is expected that would cause us to cancel the hike.

If your plans change and you are unable to attend the hike, please contact education@enoriver.org to cancel your registration so that we may offer your spot(s) to our waitlist.

Directions: We will meet at the Wildlife Subimpoundment parking lot on Old Oxford Highway on the right before Lake Michie Dam Road. Here are directions to the Sub-impoundment parking lot. GPS: 36.12778422345468, -78.83267593425103

title: ERA - Guided Wildflower Hike - Penny's Bend
location: Penny's Bend, Old Oxford Rd, Durham, NC 27712, USA
description:
Registration is required - Tickets drop on February 1st at 8:00am!
Price: $4
*Ticket prices directly support the work of the Eno River Association. Thank you for your support!


This trail passes through open fields, deep forests, and rocky outcrops in less than two miles. Easy to moderate walking with one short, steep stretch that rewards with a bluff-top view of the river. Penny’s Bend is a horseshoe bend in the river formed by diabase rock. The underlying diabase here makes the soil basic, supporting plants unusual to the Piedmont. Spring wildflowers abound, including spectacular displays of Dutchman’s Breeches some years. If there have been recent rains, parts of the trail may be muddy and a walking stick is helpful. Link to a map of the trails at Penny’s Bend: http://enotrails.com/pennys-bend-area.htm


This hike will take approximately two hours (sometimes less, sometimes more). Please feel free to bring water and snacks. Wear comfortable, weather appropriate clothing and shoes. Well-behaved dogs are welcome as long as they are under your control and on a 6 foot leash.

This event is rain or shine. We will contact you if severe weather is expected that would cause us to cancel the hike.

If your plans change and you are unable to attend the hike, please contact education@enoriver.org to cancel your registration so that we may offer your spot(s) to our waitlist.


Directions: Coming from the west, take Duke Street North from I-85 (Exit 176). Turn right on Murray Avenue (sign to the Museum of Life and Science), go until it reaches Roxboro Street, turn left and look for the brown sign to Stagville. [Coming from the east, you can take Roxboro Street directly from I-85.] Turn right here on Old Oxford Road. Go about three miles until Old Oxford crosses the Eno. title: Landscapes of Freedom: Connecting Stories from Price Park to the Guilford College Woods
description:
Explore three different visions and representative eras in the history of our land: the early 18th century, the American Revolution, and the early 19th century with a presentation and update about current conservation efforts, programming, and new research relating to the history of this land. This program will go beyond the walls with a guided walk from the library to Guilford's Witness Tree with time for reflection and learning together in community. A partnership between Greensboro Public Library and Guilford College, this project is supported through a grant from America 250 NC, a program of the NC Department of Natural and Cultural Resources and is the second of three related programs held at Greensboro sites in Spring 2026. To register, email melanie.buckingham@greensboro-nc.gov

description:
Burnout is a growing concern for many employers, as it can impact morale, employee retention, work productivity and more. Join Learning and Organizational Development (L&OD) for a training session that will introduce leaders to strategies that can help them prevent burnout from impacting the workforce. This training will help you:

title: AI for Agents Workshop
description:
All Things AI (Live)
**Every AI agent is a delegation decision. This workshop teaches you how to make those decisions well.**

[To purchase tickets, visit [https://2026.allthingsai.org/register](https://2026.allthingsai.org/register) workshop tickets also include access to the All Things AI conference on March 24th. ***Price increases after Tuesday, March 17 so sign-up early and save $100*** ]

Many organizations have experimented with AI Agents. Far fewer have moved confidently into sustained, responsible execution.
As teams progress from early pilots to real-world deployment, leaders often encounter the same challenges: impressive prototypes that stall before production, uncertainty about where agents actually add value, late-breaking security and governance concerns, and misalignment between business and technical stakeholders about what “success” should look like. Too often, these issues surface only after cost, complexity, or risk have already compounded.
This workshop helps leaders make the shift from experimentation to execution—not by pushing agents everywhere, but by providing a clear blueprint for **when agents make sense, when they don’t, and how to make sound decisions when autonomy is on the table**.

***

#### **The Outcome: Better Decisions, Earlier**

By the end of this session, participants will have more than an overview of AI Agents. They will leave with a **practical decision-making framework** they can apply immediately to real initiatives.
You’ll be able to:

* determine whether an agent is appropriate for a given problem—or whether a copilot or traditional automation is the better choice
* evaluate agent proposals with a clear understanding of autonomy, risk, and tradeoffs
* anticipate the organizational, architectural, and governance factors that separate successful deployments from stalled experiments
* identify common failure modes early—while they are still inexpensive to address

The result is clearer judgment about **what to delegate to agents, what to constrain, and what should remain human**.

***

#### **What the Blueprint Covers**

In this intensive workshop, business and technical leaders will work through a practical blueprint for AI Agent success, grounded in real-world constraints and leadership realities.
Key topics include:

* understanding degrees of agency and how they change cost, risk, and accountability
* distinguishing agents from copilots and traditional automation—and why that distinction matters
* identifying use cases where agents consistently create value, and scenarios where they introduce unnecessary fragility
* recognizing common pitfalls that derail agent initiatives, from over-delegation to hidden operational complexity
* aligning organizational readiness, security, and governance with the level of autonomy being introduced

Participants will also receive a high-level technical orientation to the AI Agent ecosystem, including platforms, Model Context Protocol (MCP), and model selection tradeoffs. This includes a balanced discussion of the benefits and risks of using Small Language Models (SLMs) in agentic workflows, particularly when autonomy and tool access are involved.

***

#### **What You’ll Leave With**

Participants will leave with:

* A clear framework for deciding **if and when** AI Agents should be used
* A practical blueprint outlining the conditions required for agent success—and the signals that indicate trouble
* A realistic understanding of the cost, complexity, and operational demands of agent-based systems
* Clear guidance for incorporating security, governance, and human oversight from the start
* A shared language that aligns business and technical leaders around the same decision criteria

***

#### **Who This Is For**

This workshop is designed for business and technical leaders responsible for turning AI experimentation into operational reality, including:

* Leaders driving digital, AI, or transformation initiatives (e.g., Chief Digital Officers, Heads of AI, Transformation and Digital Strategy leaders)
* Technology and architecture leaders accountable for execution and scale (e.g., CTOs, CIOs, VPs of Engineering, Enterprise and Solution Architects)
* Product and innovation leaders shaping AI-enabled capabilities (e.g., CPOs, Heads of Product, Innovation and Emerging Technology leaders)
* Security, risk, and governance leaders involved in overseeing autonomous or AI-driven systems (e.g., CISOs, Responsible AI and Risk leaders)

This session is especially valuable for leaders who sit at the intersection of strategy and execution—those expected to decide **when AI Agents should be used, how much authority they should have, and how to govern them responsibly**.

[To purchase tickets, visit [https://2026.allthingsai.org/register](https://2026.allthingsai.org/register) workshop tickets also include access to the All Things AI conference on March 24th. ***Price increases after Tuesday, March 17 so sign-up early and save $100*** ]

Source: Meetup: All Things AI

title: AI for Business Professionals Workshop
description:
All Things AI (Live)
**Overview**
In just one day, transform the way you work with the Artificially Intelligent Operating System for Professionals.
This hands-on training equips business professionals with the practical skills to master generative AI tools, accelerate productivity, and stay ahead in an AI-driven economy.
You won’t just learn *what* AI can do. You’ll learn *how* to use it to do more, faster—with less friction and more clarity.

*[To purchase tickets, visit [https://2026.allthingsai.org/register](https://2026.allthingsai.org/register) workshop tickets also include access to the All Things AI conference on March 24th. Price increases after Tuesday, March 17 so sign-up early and save $100 ]*

**What You’ll Learn**

* **Master ChatGPT**

Understand how it works, when to trust it, and how to prompt it for precision, insight, and speed.
* **Compare Leading Chatbot Platforms: Claude vs. Gemini**

See how Claude, Gemini (Google DeepMind) differ in philosophy, capability, and integration
* **Deploy Your Own AI Agents**

Learn how agent-based systems can automate knowledge work and create leverage in sales, marketing, and operations.
* **Create Your Own Productivity Playbook**

Apply what you’ve learned to your own role, with frameworks for using AI daily and staying ahead of change.

This course is built for knowledge workers, managers, and business leaders—not AI researchers. No jargon. Just results.
**Who Should Attend**

* Professionals seeking a competitive edge
* Teams aiming to integrate AI into their daily workflows
* Leaders who want to confidently drive AI strategy across their organizations

**By the end of the day, you’ll:**

* Understand how large language models like ChatGPT work and how to apply them safely
* Be fluent in prompting best practices and conversational design
* Use Claude, ChatGPT, and Gemini strategically based on business fit
* Deploy AI agents to offload repetitive tasks
* Walk away with a customized AI action plan tailored to your work

**Be an AI Leader**
AI isn’t coming. It’s already reshaping your industry.
But the advantage doesn’t go to the biggest company. It goes to the team that learns the fastest.
This course gives you that advantage.

**[To purchase tickets, visit [https://2026.allthingsai.org/register](https://2026.allthingsai.org/register) workshop tickets also include access to the All Things AI conference on March 24th. Price increases after Tuesday, March 17 so sign-up early and save $100 ]**

title: All Things AI 2026
description:
All Things Open RTP Meetup
We invite you to join us at All Things AI 2026. We've partnered with [The Artificially Intelligent Enterprise (AIE) Network](https://theaie.net/) to bring you this event, and we're very excited! More than 1,600 from all over the world attended last March (2025), and it was a tremendous success.

**What is it?**
All Things AI is an AI practitioners and users conference and community focused on technologies, processes, and people. The event is designed to provide world-class educational and networking opportunities to attendees.

**[Website](https://2026.allthingsai.org/)**

**Format:**
**Monday, March 23**
Training day with multiple paid workshops being hosted: **AI for DevOps**, **AIOS Workshop For Business Professionals**, and **AI for Agents**. A number of free workshops will be added soon, to include Major League Hacking's AI Roadshow.
***\*note, separate registration is required for paid and free workshops/sessions.***
***\*\*A paid workshop registration on Monday DOES include Tuesday registration.***

**Tuesday, March 24**
Traditional conference day with morning keynotes, lunchtime AI Deep Thought (Lightning) Talks, and 30-minute sessions across 7 tracks: **AI Builders**, **AI Engineers**, **AI Users**, **AI Executives**, **AI Governance**, **Security & Compliance**, **AI in the Enterprise (Transformation & Infrastructure)**, and **Case Study / Demo**.
***\*note, separate registration is required for Tuesday***

[See v 1.0 of the schedule here](https://2026.allthingsai.org/schedule)

**Speakers:**
Includes some of the most well-known AI experts in the world from companies like AWS, IBM, Meta, GitHub, Block, Fidelity Investments, Truist, AuthO/Okta, Netflix, Visa, Apple, Intuit, Mistral AI, and more.
[See all speakers here](https://2026.allthingsai.org/speakers)

**Food & Beverages:**
Lunch (boxed lunch and drink) is included with paid registration for Monday and Tuesday. Multiple restaurants are available and easily accessible in downtown Durham around the conference venue.

**Registration:**
We've worked hard to keep registration costs low and the event accessible. [Check out the registration page here](https://2026.allthingsai.org/register).

**Scholarships & Discounts:**
We understand personal situations and ability to pay varies, so we've worked with partners to make a variety of scholarships and discounts available. [See what's available here](https://2026.allthingsai.org/scholarships-discounts).

Questions? Contact us at **info@allthingsopen.org**.

title: The Morbid Zoo: Reevaluating Academia for the Internet Age
description:
In 2019, YouTube creator Mariana Colín started building her film analysis YouTube channel, The Morbid Zoo, as an exercise in developing the video essay format as a legitimate mode of academic publishing. Since then, her videos have been viewed over 9 million times. YouTube is accessible and customizable, offering a way to engage directly with a nonacademic audience. However, it is also isolating, biased toward particular kinds of engagement; it is also deeply politically fraught. In this talk, Colín will share what she’s discovered about social media’s academic use — its successes, its failures and its possible futures.

Source: NC State University

title: How To Get Started in Research Workshop
description:
Are you interested in research opportunities as an undergraduate student? If so, join the Office of Undergraduate Research during its weekly Zoom workshops that cover a range of commonly asked questions regarding how to find undergraduate research opportunities and how to get started. A Q&A session will be held at the end of the workshop.

Source: NC State University

title: The Art and Science of Plant Care
description:
Caring for plants is both an art and a science — part intuition, part know-how. Every gardener, from beginner to expert, faces the same essential questions: When should I prune? How much should I water? What’s the best way to plant, fertilize or repot? In this class, Bryce Lane will bring decades of horticultural expertise to demystify these everyday tasks, showing you not just what to do but why it works.

Over eight weeks, you’ll explore the fundamental practices that keep gardens thriving, learning how to perform each one with confidence and purpose. You’ll uncover the science behind good technique — understanding how soil, water, nutrients and plant biology interact — while also developing the practical judgment that comes only with experience.

Each session will focus on one key aspect of plant care, building a complete toolkit for growing healthier, more resilient plants in any garden setting.

Source: NC State University

title: Civic Hacking for Affordable Housing
description:
Code with the Carolinas - Triangle
Join volunteers at Code with the Carolinas as we help the [National Zoning Atlas](https://www.zoningatlas.org/) (NZA) team include North Carolina and South Carolina in their nationwide zoning atlas. "The National Zoning Atlas aims to depict key aspects of zoning codes in an online, user-friendly map." The Atlas aims to provide data for better solutions in transportation, environmental, and especially affordable housing policy.

Affordable housing proponents have long recognized zoning policies as barriers to affordable housing. To improve zoning policies, we first need to better understand the current state of zoning across the United States. Code with the Carolinas is helping this cause by joining the National Zoning Atlas to gather zoning data for North and South Carolina.

This is a multi-dimensional project grounded in data science with an end-goal of contributing to a nationally influential dataset. Our current work session activities focus on internet search and integrating data from multiple sources. The project as a whole has occasional opportunities for U/X and outreach and opportunities to learn about machine learning and natural language processing through the work of the NZA team. Volunteering on this project will provide excellent exposure to the foundations of civic data science, with a focus on GIS data.

Even if you're new to this project and/or civic tech volunteering, you're welcome to join the meeting. Visitors are always welcome and no technical skills are needed. You can learn more about the project on our [Slack Workspace](https://join.slack.com/t/codeforthecarolinas/shared_invite/zt-1kxuwu05x-3KxOpkOYjAuN5yuOAH8ROg) in the #project-zoning-atlas channel.

Meetings start with brief introductions. New volunteers are offered a personal orientation, often in a breakout room, while experienced volunteers get right to work. By the end of the session, both groups of volunteers are working together. We also contribute to the project through asynchronous work and informal work sessions.

Meetings are on the Jitsi platform and the link is provided before each meeting. If you will be joining on mobile, install the Jitsi app in advance [https://jitsi.org/downloads/](https://jitsi.org/downloads/) .

Learn more at [codewiththecarolinas.org](codeforthecarolinas.org) or reach out to info@codewiththecarolinas.org

All activities of Code with the Carolinas, a project of [Social Good Fund](https://www.socialgoodfund.org/), follow our [Code of Conduct](https://share.mailbox.org/ajax/share/0d32d5f905f8fd49d5e80395f8fd47f2b59ce3ef8b335f72/1/8/Nzg/NzgvMTkx) and are subject to this [Volunteer Waiver of Liability](https://share.mailbox.org/ajax/share/06dd62200e6b28426b137e0e6b2848fb901487014f72cd16/1/8/Nzg/NzgvMTE2).

description:

Jan. 22 from noon to 2 p.m. in the LGBTQ Pride Center at Talley Student UnionJoin us for a meet and greet and introduction to Song in a Weary Throat.Feb. 5 from noon to 2 p.m. in the African Cultural Center Library at the Witherspoon Student CenterWe will discuss chapters 1-3 and 7 and 8.Feb. 24 from noon to 2 p.m. in Multicultural Student Affairs at Talley Student UnionWe will discuss chapters 9, 11, 15, 16 and 19.March 24 from noon to 2 p.m. in the Women’s Center at Talley Student UnionWe will discuss chapters 20-22, 24-25 and 26. title: Goldston America 250 Film Series
description:
Join the Chatham Community Library for this Goldston America 250 Film Series, hosted every fourth Tuesday, January-December 2026, 4pm-6pm. America 250’s mission is to honor and commemorate the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence, marking America’s Semiquincentennial. The Goldston Library will screen the following documentaries and films:

Tue, Jan 27, 4pm-6pm The Congress, Ken Burns.Tue, Feb 24, 4pm-6pm Becoming Frederick Douglass, Stanley Nelson and Nicole London.Tue, Mar 24, 4pm-6pm Rachel Carson: The Woman Who Launched the Modern Environmental Movement, Michelle Ferrari.Tue, Apr 28, 4pm-6pm Thomas Jefferson: A View from the Mountain, Martin Doblmeier.Tue, May 26, 4pm-6pm The Address, Ken Burns.Tue, Jun 23, 4pm-6pm The Brooklyn Bridge, Ken Burns.Tue, Jul 28, 4pm-6pm The Statue of Liberty, Ken Burns.Tue, Aug 25, 4pm-6pm American Coup: Wilmington 1898, Yoruba Richen and Brad Lichtenstein.Tue, Sep 22, 4pm-6pm How it Feels to be Free, Yoruba Richen.Tue, Oct 27, 4pm-6pm 80 Years Later, Celine Parreñas Shimizu.Tue, Nov 24, 4pm-6pm Gather, Sanjay Rawal.Tue, Dec 22, 4pm-6pm Women of World War II: The Untold Stories, Eli Brown.This FREE, family-friendly event is open to the public. No registration is required. The event will take place indoors in the Goldston Library. The Goldston Library is ADA-compliant, including wheelchair-accessible parking, entrances, seating, common spaces, walkways, and restrooms. Free parking is available outside the library. Pets are not allowed - please leave your furry friends at home.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Mosses of Duke Forest
description:
Spend an afternoon in Duke Forest with Blanka Aguero, bryophyte data manager at the Duke University Herbarium, learning about the common mosses of North Carolina woods. Learn about the biology of mosses and liverworts and gain basic moss identification skills as you explore a world beneath your feet.  Look for a separate program led by Blanka about the mosses of Duke Gardens on May 12. 
Fee: $22; 20% discount for Duke Gardens members with discount code. 
Location: Duke Forest; driving directions will be included in a program reminder email sent the week before the program. Parking is free and carpooling is encouraged.   
Accessibility: This will be a small group program that takes place outdoors and traveling on unpaved trails with some uneven surfaces.

Source: Sarah P. Duke Gardens

title: Global Film Series: Okko’s Inn
location: James B. Hunt Jr. Library, Auditorium
description:
The Global Film Series will offer a screening of Okko’s Inn.

After losing her parents in a car accident, Okko goes to live in the countryside with her grandmother, who runs a traditional Japanese inn built on top of an ancient spring said to have healing waters. While she goes about her chores and prepares to become the inn’s next caretaker, Okko discovers some spirits live there that only she can see — not scary ones but welcoming ghosts who keep her company, play games and help her navigate her new environment. The inn’s motto is that it welcomes all and will reject none, and this is soon put to the test as a string of new guests challenge Okko’s ability to be a gracious host. But ultimately, Okko discovers that dedicating herself to others becomes the key to taking care of herself.

The film's runtime is 1 hour, 34 minutes. The movie is in Japanese with English subtitles. 

The Global Film Series is a collaboration between the NC State University Libraries and NC State’s Office of Global Engagement. This screening is in partnership with NC State’s Women’s Center in celebration of Women’s History Month.

Source: NC State University

title: Ackland Film Forum: "Crooklyn" (Spike Lee, 1994)
location: Varsity Theatre, 123 E. Franklin Street, Chapel Hill, NC, 27514, United States
description:
Set in 1970s Brooklyn, Crooklyn recounts childhood from the perspective of nine-year-old Troy Carmichael (Zelda Harris), whose coming of age unfolds within the rhythms of Black family life, neighborhood culture, and social constraint. The film balances warmth and humor with moments of rupture, revealing how maturity often arrives through confrontation with authority, injustice, and grief. Lee presents growing up as both deeply personal and inseparable from place, race, and community—an education shaped as much by environment as by experience. 
  
The film will be introduced by Daelena Tinnin-Gadson, Assistant Professor of Black Film Studies and African American Literature. 
This film will be screened at 7:30 p.m. at the Varsity Theatre (123 East Franklin Street, Chapel Hill, NC 27514). Tickets are free, but must be reserved on the Ackland’s webpage. Register below. UNC-Chapel Hill students can receive CLE credit for attending by scanning the QR code at the event. 
  
About the Series:

title: *IN-PERSON* SF/F Group
description:
Durham Writers Group
We will be at the People's Solidarity Hub at 1809 Chapel Hill Rd, Durham. This venue does not serve food or drink, but feel free to bring your own. There is a kitchenette for our use, but be sure to clean up afterwards. The space might be a little cozy; please consider masking or staying home if you have a respiratory ailment.

This sub-group focuses on Speculative Fiction, including Science Fiction, Fantasy and Horror. If you have anything that falls under that category — be it short story, poem, novel-in-progress or screenplay — then come! We'd love to hear from you.

Our format allows each reader 15 minutes to present their work aloud, followed by approximately 20 minutes of feedback from the other attendees. To ensure fairness, each attendee is limited to 1 minute of Initial Feedback time. During that period, the author remains silent. Next, we have a 5 minute Free-For-All discussion about the work -- then the author may speak. (We usually get through three readers.)

Though not required, in order to receive more in-depth feed-back, readers may post their work in advance on our Google Group:
https://groups.google.com/d/forum/durham-sff-writers-group

We ask that participants keep their comments constructive and respectful, focusing on what works or doesn't work in the piece.

We also ask that readers provide a warning, both on the Google Group and during the meeting, if their story features content that some readers might find upsetting. This includes descriptions of violence or sexual content.

Readers are:
•
•
•

Backup Readers are:
•
•
•

Deep Backup:
•

***

***We meet every Tuesday at the same time, but alternate between In-Person*** ***and on Zoom. Members may attend both formats, if desired, but readers will be listed separately under the In-Person or Zoom weeks.***

Source: Meetup: Durham Writers Group

title: Travel CHINA like a local! Virtual QnA [x-posted]
description:
Raleigh & Triangle Activities Meetup Group
Putting out feelers for curious, cooperative 'comrades' to explore quiet corners of Old Cathay! Trip date TBD - waiting for airfares to come down.

This will happen on Google Meet.

**CHECK THE COMMENTS FOR MEETING LINK!**

[Comment if you are able to log onto the link but don't see me - in the past Google has let two meetings with the same link open, each person thinking the other didn't show up. So comment here and we'll see if we can fix it. :-) ]

I've been traveling to China for 27 years. Join me for a unique, off the beaten track culture immersion adventure!

Comfort NOT guaranteed! LOTS of walking! This trip is NOT for everyone but everyone who has come with me so far has LOVED it!

Itinerary NOT guaranteed so as to maximize experience! Spontaneous private zheng concert in a riverside pavilion? Let's stop and enjoy! Weather is forecast to be rain in the mountains? Let's go to the ancient village instead.

Costs currently unknown but should be under $100/day for ALL in-country necessities: food, lodging, entrance fees, ground transport. Whatever price I end up quoting will NOT include transport to/from China, alcohol, upgrades to lodging\*, upgrades to in-country transport\*.

You can do it cheaper with a big box tour. If strict time schedules, overpriced shopping, industrial restaurant food, and being kept away from locals is good enough for you than that's your best bet. If unique, real China, great food, insider knowledge with eye for western comforts\*\*, and turn on a dime\*\*\* [a mao?] escapades are for you than come with me!

Only seven people! Small and 'nimble'\*\*\*!

Have you already been to China? Already have seen the Forbidden City and Great Wall? No worries! Big box tours do NOT go where I go!

Have you never been to China and NEED to see the big sights? No problem! I can create an optional 3 day add-on for the Great Wall, Forbidden City, Temple of Heaven, and other Beijing highlights. AND I can take you to hidden gems few big tours touch.

Let's dialog! Looking for like minded people so everyone's on the same page. Don't want to put hard-core shoppers with shop-hating history buffs, or long distance hikers with casual strollers. Just a more practical way to go. If enough interest I can lead TWO trips, each with its own emphasis. I reserve the right to group/accept/deny as I see fit. [I only want happiness! Sometimes that means saying 'maybe next time'.]

Go to Jan Tu Tours on FB and browse the photo albums to get a hint of what one might see. No guarantees of ANYTHING! China changes very quickly.

\*Where available - LOTS of things NOT available off the beaten track. I said 'adventure'!

\*\*Sometimes western comforts are just not there. Deep in the countryside villages rarely have western toilets.

\*\*\*Quick change of plans is relative in China; western expectations are best set aside and an embrace the new/unknown/surprise attitude is highly recommended. But that's what a cultural adventure is all about!

Source: Meetup: Raleigh & Triangle Activities

title: Ackland Film Forum: "Crooklyn" (Spike Lee, 1994)
location: Varsity Theatre, 123 E. Franklin Street, Chapel Hill, NC, 27514, United States
description:
Set in 1970s Brooklyn, Crooklyn recounts childhood from the perspective of nine-year-old Troy Carmichael (Zelda Harris), whose coming of age unfolds within the rhythms of Black family life, neighborhood culture, and social constraint. The film balances warmth and humor with moments of rupture, revealing how maturity often arrives through confrontation with authority, injustice, and grief. Lee presents growing up as both deeply personal and inseparable from place, race, and community—an education shaped as much by environment as by experience. 
  
The film will be introduced by Daelena Tinnin-Gadson, Assistant Professor of Black Film Studies and African American Literature. 
This film will be screened at 7:30 p.m. at the Varsity Theatre (123 East Franklin Street, Chapel Hill, NC 27514). Tickets are free, but must be reserved on the Ackland’s webpage. Register below. UNC-Chapel Hill students can receive CLE credit for attending by scanning the QR code at the event. 
  
About the Series: 
Join the Ackland Film Forum this spring for Growing Up, Looking Back, a series that accompanies the Ackland exhibition Bill Bamberger: Boys Will Be Men. This semester’s series highlights the filmgoing experience by using three local movie theaters as its venues. 
The Ackland Film Forum is co-organized by the Ackland Art Museum and UNC Film Studies, housed in the UNC-Chapel Hill Department of English and Comparative Literature.

title: Avoiding Burnout: Self-Assessment Methods and Strategies for Self-Care
description:
Workplace burnout is at an all-time high, with one recent study reporting more than 42% of the workforce to be experiencing components of burnout. This session will dive in the components of burnout, create reflection opportunities for participants to assess their burnout levels, and provide helpful options for pro-active self-care. Participants will reflect on their “why” or their inner motivation for doing the work they are doing and how to better connect their why to their everyday work to become happier and healthier versions of themselves.

 

Workshop Objectives
This training will help you:
• Describe factors that increase the likelihood that burnout may become a problem
• Identify signals that indicate burnout is beginning
• Reflect on their inner motivation for completing their role
• Initiate a new self-care plan that includes healthy boundaries

 

Click on Carolina Talent registration link and select the “Request” button to automatically enroll.

description:

The program brings community members together monthly at the museum to discuss books, focusing on works by Black writers or featuring Black subjects, including fiction and non-fiction. Discussions will use questions to facilitate conversation.

"Mama Day" by Gloria Naylor
Wednesday, Feb. 25

Wednesday, April 22
 "A Visitation of Spirits" by Randall Kenan
Wednesday, June 24

Wednesday, Aug. 26

title: Wednesday night meditation circle
description:
Durham Plum Village Meditation Circle
Join us for a meditation circle in the Plum Village tradition of Buddhist teacher Thich Nhat Hanh. We will practice a short seated meditation (10 minutes), walking meditation (10 minutes), dharma share on a topic of mindfulness by a fellow practitioner, group dharma sharing, and singing. We actively welcome and affirm BIPOC and queer people and seek to hold an inclusive space for all.

**Please note: Our location has changed to the Durham Friends Meetinghouse building in the Dogwood Room at 404 Alexander Ave, Durham, NC 27705**

The space has accessible parking, entrances, and gender neutral bathrooms. Chairs are available, and we encourage you to bring a cushion with you if you have one.

Our group is spirited, compassionate, and eager to learn mindfulness practices in community with one another. We have a suggested $0-5 donation to cover the cost of the space, with excess donations put toward group materials like spare cushions.

Please consider donating to our group on Venmo: [@DurhamPlumVillageMeditation](https://account.venmo.com/u/durhamplumvillagemeditation)

If you would like to be on our sangha email list, please reach out to durhamplumvillagemeditation@gmail.com

description:

Fresh into the spring season, enjoy the tranquil morning songs of our feathered friends while walking along the unmarked Mayo Meadows trail. Meeting location is at the Mayo River Bridge Kayak Launch (3100-3110 US-220 BUS, Stoneville, NC 27048) parking lot. Please bring outdoor shoes, binoculars, camera, and a flash light.

title: Bald Eagle Search Paddle with Two Sisters Adventure Company
description:
Join Two Sisters Adventure Company for a Bald Eagle Search Paddle at Jordan Lake State Recreation Area, hosted on select dates throughout 2026. Jordan Lake is one of the best Bald Eagle viewing locations in the region. You will paddle past multiple nesting areas in search of our majestic national bird. While sightings are not guaranteed, Bald Eagles are most common in the areas they visit. Your guide will help you identify and answer questions about Bald Eagles and other birds in the area. All participants should have basic kayaking skills, due to the duration on the water this trip is considered intermediate. Pre-registration is required. Participants will launch from the Farrington Point Access. The trip will last approximately 4 hours. Trips will take place on the following dates:

Thu, Mar 26, 9am-1pm.
Sun, Apr 26, 8:30am-12:30pm.
Sat, May 9, 8am-12pm.
Sat, May 30, 8am-12pm.
Sun, Jun 7, 8am-12pm.

Two Sisters works with all guests to make trips as accessible as possible. Please contact them with any specific accessibility requests so they can ensure they have all the necessary equipment and staff. Free parking is available at the Farrington Point Canoe Launch. No pets are allowed. The cost is $60 per person, and pre-registration is required. Single-person kayaks are provided. Participants ages 15 and older are welcome.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events. See more Chatham Sports Alliance events.

Two Sisters acknowledges that the land on which this camp takes place is the ancestral land of the Skaruhreh/Tuscarora, Lumbee, Mánu: Yį Įsuwą (Catawba), Occaneechi, Shakori, and Cheraw Nations. As a part of their mission, they honor and respect the history and significance this land holds for these Nations’ past, present, and future. To find out more about the Native People and Lands where you live and recreate, visit this map.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Wilmington Ladies Tea Walk 251st Commemoration
description:
The Burgwin-Wright House, the oldest and largest historic site in Wilmington, is partnering with the Wilmington Ladies Tea Walk chapter to commemorate the 251st anniversary of the Wilmington Tea Party. Never heard of it? That's OK! The lesser known but still influential moment in history was one of the last local acts of resistance against the Crown in the Cape Fear prior to the start of the American Revolution in the spring of 1775.

At the event, guests will be able to explore the Burgwin-Wright House Gardens, drink tea, hear brief words from a few local historic experts and organizations, and then join in a procession to the riverfront where tea will be burned in solidarity with this act of revolution at the eve of war. Registration is REQUIRED. Please call 910-762-0570 to register or with any questions!

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Research Up Close: Plant Sciences Tour
description:
Take a closer look at the research of the N.C. Plant Sciences Initiative, a blooming innovation hub alchemizing cutting-edge technology with one of the oldest and most important fields of study in human history: agriculture and plant science. You'll get to explore the beautiful building that is (green) housing the Plant Sciences Initiative's work and meet a robot whose love of plant photography may help farmers across the globe.

This educational experience is a fun peek into some of the most hands-on and relevant research experiences on campus. Learn how data that lives deep in the weeds can be fruitful not just for scientists but for the food that ends up on your plate and how researchers are attempting to revolutionize the way we understand and care for the plants around us.

Slots are limited, so please register to attend the tour.

Source: NC State University

description:

The weekly series takes place at The Corner, an outdoor venue at Main Campus and Research drives.  The lineup for the six- week concert series is available on the WKNC website. The concert series is free and open to the public. Bring your lunch or grab a bite at one of the food trucks often parked across the street.

NC State students interested in performing at Local Lunch Live should email the WKNC events director at wknc-events@ncsu.edu and include their available dates.

Source: NC State University

title: Cognitive Interviewing in Survey Research
description:
Cognitive interviewing in survey research is a tool that allows researchers to improve survey questions and questionnaires by better understanding how respondents understand and respond to the questions they are being asked. Data gathered through cognitive interviews help researchers identify and remedy issues with their questionnaires. This short course provides participants with
fundamentals on where cognitive interviews fit in the survey process and on how to design, conduct, and analyze cognitive interviews. Participants will have the opportunity to practice specific cognitive interviewing techniques, including think-alouds, probing, and observation. Participants will also learn about revising survey questions based on interpreting cognitive interview results and about the research on which cognitive interview practices are based.

Course Goals:
By the end of the course, participants will be able to:
1. Understand what cognitive interviews are and their use in survey research
2. Be able to prepare for and conduct cognitive interviews
3. Improve survey questionnaires and survey items based on cognitive interview data

Registration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill
