description:
Join Ackland educators for a lively half-hour look at a small handful of artworks. These engaging conversational tours offer a closer look at and new perspectives on works on view at the Museum. Today’s tour looks at Color Concentrated: A Salon-Style Show from the Robertson Collection. 
This is a free, walk-in event – no RSVP required. 
This event is part of UNC–Chapel Hill’s Campus Life Experience (CLE) program. Students who attend can scan the QR code provided at the event to receive CLE credit.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Terrain Dance Project Concert: Themes of Gathering
description:
NC State’s Terrain Dance Project will present Themes of Gathering, a collection of new site-specific choreographic works at The Corner on Centennial Campus at 2 p.m. April 17 and 7 p.m. April 18. The Terrain Dance Project is a site-specific dance company dedicated to the creation and performance of choreographed and improvised dance works in nontraditional spaces, including dance film projects. 

Co-director Amy Love Beasley and guest artists Anabelle Scarborough and NC State senior Annabelle Sharp will present new works by collaborating with crop sciences at NC State, assembling interdisciplinary work and investigating identities.

If there is inclement weather on the scheduled performance dates, the performances will take place April 19 at 2 and 7 p.m. 

Admission is free.

Source: NC State University

title: Dungeons & Dragons
description:
Join the Women's Center for Dungeons & Dragons. Whether you're a seasoned pro or new to the game, join us to explore magical realms, craft powerful characters and tell epic stories. Together, we'll roll the dice and create unforgettable adventures in a supportive and empowering environment. Let's dive in and shape our destinies.

Source: NC State University

title: Faculty Council
description:
Location: 1001 Kerr Hall

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Mapping Instincts
location: Frank Thompson Hall - Kennedy-McIlwee Studio Theatre
description:
In 1998, the neuroscientist Jaak Panksepp published a book classifying seven primary affective systems or, more simply, emotional developmental states. Mapping Instincts is our collective exploration of these concepts at play in our bodies and minds. Directed by Mia Self.

Source: NC State University

title: The Importance of Being Earnest by Oscar Wilde
description:
The Importance of Being Earnest, a Trivial Comedy for Serious People, is Oscar Wilde’s comedic play, which satirizes the conventions and manners of the late 19th century. Best friends Jack and Algernon each adopt fictional identities to escape social obligations. The plot unfolds with mistaken identities, romantic entanglements, clever wordplay and humorous social commentary.

The play's director is Danica Jenelle Jackson.

Source: NC State University

title: Let's Go Fishing!
location: Lake James State Park-Catawba River Access
description:
Join us for a relaxing morning fishing program at Lake James State Park – Catawba River Access, perfect for families and first-time anglers alike! Bring your kids, your favorite fishing rods, and any tackle you have—we’ll also have a limited number of rods and tackle available to loan.

We’ll meet at the picnic shelter, then head together to the jetty, where there’s plenty of space to spread out and fish. Spend the morning enjoying the calm water, learning a few fishing tips, and sharing quality time with loved ones while making lasting memories—plus, you just might reel in a fish or two!

Whether you’re teaching your child to fish for the first time or simply enjoying a peaceful morning outdoors, this program is a great way to connect with nature and each other.

All ages welcome. No experience necessary! All NCWRC Laws must be followed such as having a valid NC fishing license.🎣

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Volunteer Stewardship Workday
description: Source: Eno River Association

title: Celebrating Our Colonial Roots - Online Plant Sale
location: Pick up 5/1/26 at Greenhouses behind Building N
description:
The Brunswick County Master Gardeners Volunteer Association will hold an online plant sale starting on April 17, 2026 and running until April 24, 2026 with pick up day on May 1, 2026. This event celebrates the important colonial history of Brunswick County  through education on herbs, flowers, vines, shrubs and small trees which thrive here. Plants featured are those which our Colonial ancestors would have encountered along our coast and the Cape Fear River which are native to our region and support pollinators. Also featured will be plants from seeds which colonists brought with them from Europe and plants which recognize the contributions and life celebrations of the Gullah Geechee people who were enslaved in Africa to work the rice plantations along the Cape Fear River. This online plant sale celebrates the cultural traditions  found in gardening in our coastal region of the State.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Sachets in the Historical Park
description:
Plants and flowers have their own language and different combinations of them can be used to send messages in secret. Used for medicine, hygiene, and bug repellents during the American Revolution, come to the Historical Park and create your own sweet-smelling sachet. Our costumed interpreters will show you how. FREE. All ages welcome. Drop-in.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Out of the Darkness Campus Walk at UNC Chapel Hill
description:
The UNC Chapel Hill Out of the Darkness Campus Walk brings students, faculty, and community members together to honor loved ones, support one another, and build connection around mental health and suicide prevention. It’s a meaningful opportunity for students to show up for their peers, raise awareness, and help create a more caring campus community. The walk is also a fundraising event, with proceeds supporting the American Foundation for Suicide Prevention’s work in education, advocacy, research, and programs for those affected by suicide.

 

Registration starts at 10:00 AM ET, with the walk starting at 11:00 AM ET. The walk will take place on UNC Chapel Hill Campus.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Hidden Battleship Tour
description:
Hidden Battleship is for the explorer at heart! Join us for an afternoon on a unique, behind-the-scenes tour of unrestored areas on the Battleship. Organized into small groups, the participants are led to areas in the bow, third deck, and below, and the superstructure, including all the way to the very top! This program requires climbing ladders, crossing high hatches, and going through tight/confined spaces. The tour is limited to ages 16 and older.

2026 Dates

► January 24
► February 28
► March 28
► April 18
► November 14

11 am – 5 pm; $75 (plus tax) per participant. This program always sells out, so get your Hidden Battleship ticket now! This program is for ages 16 and older.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: GGC Adventure Series: Lake Raleigh Paddle
description:
Back for another year of inspiring adventures in nature, this season of the Greenway Gear Collective Adventure Series will feature Adventure Race themed outings.
Each event will focus on one of the disciplines of adventure racing: traditionally mountain biking, orienteering (map and compass navigation), and paddling (canoe or kayak) and will take place at or around Lake Raleigh. Beginners or veterans alike will be in excellent hands with each adventure led by Debra and Jeff Rezeli, experts with over 11 years of adventure racing experience.
Register for each event here.

For those who love a goal to build towards...
The series will build skills in advance of a local practice 3-hour adventure race in May and the option to register and participate in a 5-hour adventure race hosted by Broad Run Offroad on June 13 & 14 at Lake Anna State Park in Spotsylvania, VA.
For more information on adventure racing, check out the US Adventure Racing Association website.

Source: NC State University

title: Yoga In Nature™ ALL LEVELS YOGA at For Garden's Sake
description:
Yoga In Nature™, NC
**So excited to be back and offer another Yoga In Nature™ event at For Garden's Sake!!!** ***\*$25/person paid at signup in advance to secure your spot***\*.\* \*\*\*Pay by Venmo @Darlene-Genander (0862 if asked for 4 digits) or by PayPal dgenander@yogainnature.com Message me for Zelle or Cash options.

Come join us in the open field alongside the pond for a 60 minute vinyasa flow to yin practice for **ALL LEVELS and first timers.** We will gather as a community in a yoga practice that will focus on flowing with our breath as we move our bodies and connect with nature, being guided with all o four senses. No experience necessary, just an open mind:) We will plant seeds for our growth on and off our mats. You will also receive a small gift at this event!

Bring a friend! Gift someone special who loves yoga and/or plants. Stay for hot tea following the practice. Wander the grounds of the garden center's indoor and outdoor plants, shrubs and trees for your own home or inspiration. Also, take a look at their potting shed and visit with the goats and ducks on the property.

Bring your own yoga mat and/or towel, water bottle, and whatever you may need for your practice. Sunscreen, if needed, as we will be in open field under the sun.

Tentative rain date will be April 19, if needed. If there is a rain date, and you are unable to make it, you will be reimbursed.

Source: Meetup: Yoga In Nature NC

title: Creative Minds Market
description:
The Creative Minds Market is back this spring. This artisan market is more than just a collection of tents with cute gifts: It is a sweet celebration of local creativity featuring a variety of live music, food trucks, interactive demonstrations and local art and artisanal goods. Come out to browse, try your hand at the pottery wheel, have your tarot cards read and do plenty more.

Source: NC State University

title: Stand-Up Paddleboard Yoga
description:
Experience the serenity of stand-up paddleboard yoga at Lake Raleigh on NC State's Centennial Campus. Practice yoga on stand-up paddleboards amidst the breathtaking backdrop of a spring evening on the lake. This beginner-friendly activity does not require prior yoga or paddleboarding experience, making it ideal for all. Equipment, instruction and tranquil time on the water are provided.

Source: NC State University

title: The Student Art Sale
description:
Liven up your space or gift original art by supporting NC State's talented student artists at the Student Art Sale.

Since 2015, Arts NC State has hosted its annual art sale event, showcasing the talent and creativity of students.  The art sale welcomes submissions from all students, whether they study engineering, chemistry, media art design technology or any other field, making the event one of the nation's premier university art showcases. Every purchase at the art sale empowers students, fueling their artistic journey. Since its start, our art sale event has contributed over $100,000 to student artists, making a real impact on their lives and careers.

Join us in supporting and investing in the next generation of artists whose talents transcend disciplines.

The art sale will be held at the Gregg Museum of Art & Design.

The museum has limited parking. We strongly encourage guests to carpool or walk to the museum. Please view available parking options before your visit to the museum. ﻿

Source: NC State University

title: Discover Tryon Palace: Outlander
location: Tryon Palace Historic Sites and Gardens
description:
Step into Tryon Palace and explore Diana Gabaldon’s award-winning Outlander series. Learn about the lives of the fictional Jamie and Claire Fraser, their family and friends, and interactions with historical figures and events in the tumultuous period of the American Revolution.

Tour covers storylines from Outlander books 4 – 8 and the Starz Outlander seasons 4 – 8. (For those not current on the books or show, there will be spoilers for these books and seasons.)

Tour begins at 301 George Street, across from the Tryon Palace Main Gates. Ticket holders should check in at the Waystation ticketing desk no later than 3:30 p.m.

title: Climbing at The High Ropes Course
description:
Challenge yourself on an exhilarating high ropes course nestled within NC State University’s scenic Schenck Forest. Set among towering trees, this course offers a unique outdoor experience designed to test your limits, build confidence and give you a taste of adventure. Suspended high above the forest floor, you'll navigate a series of thrilling obstacles and zip lines, all while surrounded by the natural beauty of Schenck Forest. Perfect for adventure seekers of all skill levels, this adventure promises an unforgettable day of achievement, connection and fun in a beautiful woodland setting.

location: 4214 Highland Farm Rd, Hillsborough, NC 27278, USA
description:

Join us to learn how to repair or embellish your garments! Bring a garment and volunteers will guide you through the hand mending process using supplies provided by the sponsor –  Circular Triangle https://www.circulartriangle.org/.  And it’s free! Source: Eno River Association

title: Emerging Designers Textile Showcase
description:
The Emerging Designers Textile howcase highlights the work of senior textile design students in the fashion and textile design (FTD) program at the Wilson College of Textiles, celebrating the culmination of a semester-long capstone experience rooted in exploration, experimentation and refinement. Designers navigate the balance between creative freedom and creative discipline while leveraging access to state-of-the-art labs and studios. Collections span home textiles, apparel, fiber art and more. 

The Emerging Designers Textile Showcase will be held at the Textiles Campus on Centennial Campus.

The Textile Showcase Opening is on Sunday, April 19, from 3 to 5 p.m. The event is open to the public and free for all.

The Textile Showcase will also be open:
- Monday, April 20, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.
- Tuesday, April 21, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.
- Wednesday, April 22, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.

title: Gettin’ daggity with it: Using DAGs as Tools for Variable Selection
description:
Ever pondered whether to include a variable in an analysis – is the variable necessary, will its inclusion/exclusion introduce bias in the analysis?  Why is the variable important anyways – is it a mediator, a moderator and a confounder some combination of these???

This course introduces how to incorporate DAGs (Directed Acyclic Graphs) in analysis planning to help think through what variables to collect and use (or refrain from using) in an analysis.

Topics include:

Introducing the structure of DAGs and the rules for using them to guide variable selectionA deep dive into the types of variable relations captured in DAGs with emphasis on mediation, moderation, effect modification, confounding and colliders and their potential to introduce bias in analysisHands on example of how to create and evaluate DAGs in R using the package daggityUse of DAGs may help inform data collection and analytical plans in ways that enhance reproducibility.

Course prerequisites: None. Knowledge of regression analysis and R is helpful but not required.

Registration and fee (refundable for UNCCH students) are required for Zoom link access.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

description:
The Office of Undergraduate Research can help students create research posters. Join us at one of our research poster workshops to help you get ready to showcase your hard work on and off campus.

title: Free Yoga
location: Partners I – NC State University, Suite 2580
description:
Take a break from your day and enjoy a free yoga class on Centennial Campus. Classes are held every weekday, except when the university is closed, from 12:15 to 1:05 p.m. The classes are open to everyone, and registration is not required. Please bring your own mat.

Source: NC State University

title: Italian Club End-of-the-Semester Potluck-Dinner
description:
Join the Italian Club and Italian Honor Society in the Department of World Languages and Cultures for our end-of-the-semester potluck dinner. We've planned a relaxed evening to celebrate the end of the term, enjoy good food and an opportunity for students to meet and connect with the Italian student community at NC State. Bring a dish to share, including Italian-inspired food, and come connect with friends, club members and new faces. The dinner is open to all. You don't need to speak Italian to attend.

Source: NC State University

title: The Art and Science of Plant Care
description:
Caring for plants is both an art and a science — part intuition, part know-how. Every gardener, from beginner to expert, faces the same essential questions: When should I prune? How much should I water? What’s the best way to plant, fertilize or repot? In this class, Bryce Lane will bring decades of horticultural expertise to demystify these everyday tasks, showing you not just what to do but why it works.

Over eight weeks, you’ll explore the fundamental practices that keep gardens thriving, learning how to perform each one with confidence and purpose. You’ll uncover the science behind good technique — understanding how soil, water, nutrients and plant biology interact — while also developing the practical judgment that comes only with experience.

Each session will focus on one key aspect of plant care, building a complete toolkit for growing healthier, more resilient plants in any garden setting.

Source: NC State University

title: Civic Hacking for Affordable Housing
description:
Code with the Carolinas - Triangle
Join volunteers at Code with the Carolinas as we help the [National Zoning Atlas](https://www.zoningatlas.org/) (NZA) team include North Carolina and South Carolina in their nationwide zoning atlas. "The National Zoning Atlas aims to depict key aspects of zoning codes in an online, user-friendly map." The Atlas aims to provide data for better solutions in transportation, environmental, and especially affordable housing policy.

Affordable housing proponents have long recognized zoning policies as barriers to affordable housing. To improve zoning policies, we first need to better understand the current state of zoning across the United States. Code with the Carolinas is helping this cause by joining the National Zoning Atlas to gather zoning data for North and South Carolina.

This is a multi-dimensional project grounded in data science with an end-goal of contributing to a nationally influential dataset. Our current work session activities focus on internet search and integrating data from multiple sources. The project as a whole has occasional opportunities for U/X and outreach and opportunities to learn about machine learning and natural language processing through the work of the NZA team. Volunteering on this project will provide excellent exposure to the foundations of civic data science, with a focus on GIS data.

Even if you're new to this project and/or civic tech volunteering, you're welcome to join the meeting. Visitors are always welcome and no technical skills are needed. You can learn more about the project on our [Slack Workspace](https://join.slack.com/t/codeforthecarolinas/shared_invite/zt-1kxuwu05x-3KxOpkOYjAuN5yuOAH8ROg) in the #project-zoning-atlas channel.

Meetings start with brief introductions. New volunteers are offered a personal orientation, often in a breakout room, while experienced volunteers get right to work. By the end of the session, both groups of volunteers are working together. We also contribute to the project through asynchronous work and informal work sessions.

Meetings are on the Jitsi platform and the link is provided before each meeting. If you will be joining on mobile, install the Jitsi app in advance [https://jitsi.org/downloads/](https://jitsi.org/downloads/) .

Learn more at [codewiththecarolinas.org](codeforthecarolinas.org) or reach out to info@codewiththecarolinas.org

All activities of Code with the Carolinas, a project of [Social Good Fund](https://www.socialgoodfund.org/), follow our [Code of Conduct](https://share.mailbox.org/ajax/share/0d32d5f905f8fd49d5e80395f8fd47f2b59ce3ef8b335f72/1/8/Nzg/NzgvMTkx) and are subject to this [Volunteer Waiver of Liability](https://share.mailbox.org/ajax/share/06dd62200e6b28426b137e0e6b2848fb901487014f72cd16/1/8/Nzg/NzgvMTE2).

Source: Meetup: Code with the Carolinas

title: Celebration of Sustainability
description:
Join NC State for a celebration of sustainability accomplishments on Tuesday, April 21, 2026. This annual event honors the people, projects and progress that advance sustainability at NC State.

The celebration will include a Sustainability Showcase starting at 8:30 a.m. where you can browse student displays on sustainability-related projects.  Students,  student organizations, departments and researchers are invited to share their sustainability-focused research and projects in a science-fair style format. Light refreshments will be served during this time. 

Reserve your Sustainability Showcase Spot Here 

A recognition program will start by 9:30 a.m. and include an announcement of NC State Sustainability Awards winners and NC State Sustainability Fund grant recipients. Following the program at 10:15 a.m., please stay for informal networking. 

RSVP to attend the Celebration Here
This celebration is one of the hallmark events of NC State's Earth Month and is hosted by the NC State Sustainability Council, Climate and Sustainability Academy and the University Sustainability Office.

Source: NC State University

title: Sustainability Showcase
description:
The Sustainability Showcase invites NC State students, student organizations, departments and researchers to share their sustainability-focused research and projects in a science-fair style format.

 

Kicking off NC State’s Celebration of Sustainability, the showcase offers attendees the chance to engage directly with presenters, explore innovative work happening across campus and connect with the people advancing sustainability before the Celebration’s formal program begins at 9:30 a.m.

 

The campus community is invited to display their work and/or attend this event. Please RSVP by April 7:

Reserve your Sustainability Showcase Spot HereRSVP to attend the Celebration Here 

Sponsored by the NC State University Sustainability Council, the Climate and Sustainability Academy and the University Sustainability Office, this event highlights the depth and impact of sustainability efforts across the university.

Source: NC State University

title: Celebrating Our Colonial Roots - Online Plant Sale
location: Pick up 5/1/26 at Greenhouses behind Building N
description:
The Brunswick County Master Gardeners Volunteer Association will hold an online plant sale starting on April 17, 2026 and running until April 24, 2026 with pick up day on May 1, 2026. This event celebrates the important colonial history of Brunswick County  through education on herbs, flowers, vines, shrubs and small trees which thrive here. Plants featured are those which our Colonial ancestors would have encountered along our coast and the Cape Fear River which are native to our region and support pollinators. Also featured will be plants from seeds which colonists brought with them from Europe and plants which recognize the contributions and life celebrations of the Gullah Geechee people who were enslaved in Africa to work the rice plantations along the Cape Fear River. This online plant sale celebrates the cultural traditions  found in gardening in our coastal region of the State.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: "Human-in-the-Loop” Thematic Analysis: Using R to Apply Current Recommendations for Incorporating LLMs into Qualitative Research
description:
Do you want to explore current research recommendations in the literature on incorporating LLMs into qualitative/mixed methods data analysis, or are you interested in implementing LLMs into your qualitative/mixed methods workflow?  If so, this short course is designed for you!

In this course we will examine current recommendations from the literature regarding integrating AI (specifically LLMs) into the process of qualitative coding.  Acknowledging that a wide range of qualitative approaches exist, all examples and recommendations in this course will be based on the 6 Phase Thematic Analysis Framework proposed by Braun & Clarke 2006 to simplify the course scope.

No perquisites in qualitative methods or coding are required for this course – just bring your computer & your curiosity!

In the course we will:

Review the qualitative approach of Thematic Analysis using the Braun & Clarke FrameworkGet a high-level, very big picture understanding of LLMs, what they are & how they generate “natural language”Examine current recommendations in the literature on incorporating LLMs in Thematic AnalysisDo hands-on activities in R that implement some of the current recommendations using the Braun & Clarke Framework. We will compare our results to published results generated by all human coders using the same dataRegistration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Climate and Sustainability EduJam
description:
The Climate and Sustainability Academy invites you to the Climate and Sustainability EduJam, a networking and tabling expo for anyone involved in climate and sustainability education at NC State. Whether you teach, research or create learning experiences, join us to connect with people and share ideas to strengthen climate and sustainability education at our university.

This is your chance to:

Showcase your courses, programs or curricular resources at a tableMeet peers and share ideas with others teaching or working in climate and sustainabilityDisplay a slide in our rotating slideshow, including QR codes or links so guests can follow up with youIf you would like to participate in Edujam, complete the interest form.

This event will immediately follow the Celebration of Sustainability event.

title: Faculty and Staff Walking Club
description:
Join your colleagues for a lovely walk down to the NC State greenway. We'll meet outside the Starbucks at Talley Student Union and walk down the greenway to Pullen Park and back. The route is approximately 1.4 miles. All are welcome to participate.

title: *IN-PERSON* SF/F Group
description:
Durham Writers Group
We will be at the People's Solidarity Hub at 1809 Chapel Hill Rd, Durham. This venue does not serve food or drink, but feel free to bring your own. There is a kitchenette for our use, but be sure to clean up afterwards. The space might be a little cozy; please consider masking or staying home if you have a respiratory ailment.

This sub-group focuses on Speculative Fiction, including Science Fiction, Fantasy and Horror. If you have anything that falls under that category — be it short story, poem, novel-in-progress or screenplay — then come! We'd love to hear from you.

Our format allows each reader 15 minutes to present their work aloud, followed by approximately 20 minutes of feedback from the other attendees. To ensure fairness, each attendee is limited to 1 minute of Initial Feedback time. During that period, the author remains silent. Next, we have a 5 minute Free-For-All discussion about the work -- then the author may speak. (We usually get through three readers.)

Though not required, in order to receive more in-depth feed-back, readers may post their work in advance on our Google Group:
https://groups.google.com/d/forum/durham-sff-writers-group

We ask that participants keep their comments constructive and respectful, focusing on what works or doesn't work in the piece.

We also ask that readers provide a warning, both on the Google Group and during the meeting, if their story features content that some readers might find upsetting. This includes descriptions of violence or sexual content.

Readers are:
•
•
•

Backup Readers are:
•
•
•

Deep Backup:
•

***

***We meet every Tuesday at the same time, but alternate between In-Person*** ***and on Zoom. Members may attend both formats, if desired, but readers will be listed separately under the In-Person or Zoom weeks.***

Source: Meetup: Durham Writers Group

title: Last Week of Spring Semester
description:
Lab tests, semester project reports and presentations are permissible during the final week of classes. Papers and homework may have a due date during the final week of classes only if scheduled in the syllabus. However, in order for students to prepare for final examinations, faculty members may not assign other tests, quizzes or additional papers during the final week of classes. Assignments should not have a due date during the final exam period unless the assignment constitutes a part of the final exam. Exceptions to this policy must be approved in advance by the department head and the dean of the college involved. Students should contact the appropriate instructor or department head if they believe an assignment is not in compliance with this regulation.

Source: NC State University

title: Emerging Designers Textile Showcase
description:
The Emerging Designers Textile howcase highlights the work of senior textile design students in the fashion and textile design (FTD) program at the Wilson College of Textiles, celebrating the culmination of a semester-long capstone experience rooted in exploration, experimentation and refinement. Designers navigate the balance between creative freedom and creative discipline while leveraging access to state-of-the-art labs and studios. Collections span home textiles, apparel, fiber art and more. 

The Emerging Designers Textile Showcase will be held at the Textiles Campus on Centennial Campus.

The Textile Showcase Opening is on Sunday, April 19, from 3 to 5 p.m. The event is open to the public and free for all.

The Textile Showcase will also be open:
- Monday, April 20, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.
- Tuesday, April 21, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.
- Wednesday, April 22, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.

title: Earth Day Ag Showcase at the Small Farm Unit
description:
The Center for Environmental Farming Systems is proud to host an Earth Day celebration at the Small Farm Unit at the Cherry Research Farm in Goldsboro. Families, students and community members are welcome to attend and explore hands-on activities that connect farming, environmental technology and health.

A special highlight of this year’s event will be the N.C. A&T Innovation Bus, a state-of-the-art mobile learning space that will showcase cutting-edge technology, agriculture and innovation for youth and adults.

The Small Farm Unit is adjacent to the O'Berry Neuro-Medical Treatment Center, which is located at 400 Old Smithfield Road (NC-581) in Goldsboro.

description:

Schedule your appointment and learn more about the mobile service on the barber shop's website.

Source: NC State University

title: Centennial SoundBites: Live Music and Lunch
description:
Take a lunch break and soak in the sounds of local artists at Centennial SoundBites, a relaxing lunchtime music series featuring 321 Coffee, local food trucks and some incredible local artists. Whether you come for the tunes, the food, the coffee or just to take a moment and enjoy yourself, we've got you covered.

You'll discover a new performer every Wednesday afternoon with artist coordination by Oak City Music Collective. We'll feature a range of fresh sounds from local solo and duet projects from the Triangle and beyond.

Free parking is available at the Oval West Parking Deck. To park there for free, validate your license plate using our QR code upon arrival.

Source: NC State University

title: Centennial Visioneers Toastmasters
description:
Toastmasters is a diverse and fun club focused on helping our members grow by improving their public speaking and leadership skills in a supportive, encouraging environment. Meetings are at 321 Coffee on Centennial campus in their Confernece Room 2 and guests are always welcome to visit. Come see what all the hype is about!

For more information about our club and how being a member can benefit you, please contact our VP of Public Relations, Keisha Demps. Be sure to check out the Toastmasters International website, too.

Source: NC State University

title: Balancing Work and Life
description:
Using the philosophy that “those who are happy at home perform better on the job,” this workshop was developed for those who feel burdened with too many responsibilities and without enough time for personal enjoyment. This workshop will help participants explore and define home responsibilities, identify career requirements and prioritize leisure time. The resulting better balance will help achieve more in one’s career and at home.

 

Workshop Objectives
At the end of this workshop, you will be able to:
Identify the components of a balanced lifestyle
• Describe the concept of balance
• Identify what is out of balance in your life
• Describe how notions of balance have changed over time in your life and historically
• Identify the relationship between stress and balance
Identify and explore the balance between home responsibilities, career requirements
and leisure activities
• Describe how to create your own balance diagram
• Identify the right questions to achieve balance
• Describe the role of prioritization, limit setting and time management to balancing work and life
• Identify tips and suggestions on how to achieve balance
• Identify a personalized action plan to achieve balance in your life

 

Click on Carolina Talent registration link and select the “Request” button to automatically enroll.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

location: Partners I – NC State University, Suite 2580

title: Artful Introspection: Explore Identity, Creativity and Growth
description:
Join Prevention Services for Artful Introspection, a mindful, creative series for exploring who you are and where you’re headed. Through crafting activities, such as comic strips and the Wheel of Life, you’ll build emotional awareness, connect with yourself and others and reflect on personal growth. Each 75-minute session will introduce a practical skill rooted in mindfulness, identity exploration and reflection. You’ll leave feeling more grounded, more connected and equipped with tools to support your growth. Crafting experience is not required.

Source: NC State University

title: 🌍Earth Day!🌍
location: Lake James State Park- Paddy's Creek Beach Access
description:
Come celebrate Earth Day with the Rangers at Lake James State Park!

Join us for a meaningful afternoon of service and fun as we work together to care for our park. In honor of Earth Day, we’ll be picking up litter around the Paddy’s Creek Swim Beach and nearby picnic areas to help keep Lake James beautiful for everyone to enjoy.

After our cleanup, stick around for a round of “Oh, Deer,” an engaging and interactive game that explores wildlife survival.

We will meet at 3:30 PM in the Paddy’s Creek day-use area at the swim beach. All tools and personal protective equipment (PPE) will be provided. All ages are welcome to join.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Greater Good Textile Group Clothing Swap
description:
Bring your unwanted clothes, shoes, and accessories and swap item for item, or purchase items for $1 each. Please no undergarments, socks, or jewelry. Remember to bring clean items in good condition.

The clothing swap will be held from 4:30–7 p.m., with drop-off from 4:30–5:30 p.m. and the swap from 6–7 p.m.

Source: NC State University

title: Femme Making Night
description:
Femme Making Night provides an opportunity for femme-identifying individuals and their allies to connect and create. All are welcome to participate. Join us for evenings of creativity, collaboration and the chance to work on projects alongside a supportive community. Whether you’re exploring new techniques or refining your skills, our workshops are designed to inspire and empower.

Source: NC State University

title: Dr. M.T. Pope House Presents: Evelyn's Book Club
description:
This program honors Evelyn Pope by reading books. 

Evelyn, a college librarian born in 1908 and died in 1995, loved a variety of books from The Adventures of Tom Sawyer to Shakespeare and James Baldwin. The program brings community members together monthly at the museum to discuss books, focusing on works by Black writers or featuring Black subjects, including fiction and non-fiction. Discussions will use questions to facilitate conversation.

"Mama Day" by Gloria Naylor
Wednesday, Feb. 25
 "The Black Angels: The Untold Story of the Nurses Who Helped Cure Tuberculosis" by Maria Smilios
Wednesday, April 22
 "A Visitation of Spirits" by Randall Kenan
Wednesday, June 24
 "Becoming Lunsford Lane: The Lives of an American Aeneas" by Craig Friend
Wednesday, Aug. 26
 "Ring Shout" by P. Dejeli Clark
Thursday, Oct. 29Registration opens Jan. 23.  An optional book bundle will be available to purchase at registration. Books can be picked up at the Dr. M.T. Pope House Museum.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Second Chance Initiative Meeting
description:
The Second Chance Initiative will meet throughout the spring semester. The mission of the initiative is to raise awareness and foster dialogue about prison education initiatives and challenges faced by justice-impaired individuals while addressing systematic barriers through collaboration with our communities.

The weekly series takes place at The Corner, an outdoor venue at Main Campus and Research drives.  The lineup for the six- week concert series is available on the WKNC website. The concert series is free and open to the public. Bring your lunch or grab a bite at one of the food trucks often parked across the street.

NC State students interested in performing at Local Lunch Live should email the WKNC events director at wknc-events@ncsu.edu and include their available dates.

title: Crafting and Connecting
description:
Join the Women's Center and the Counseling Center at a communal healing space for students to make crafts and connect with peers. Counselors will be available for students to meet with individually if desired and to help students process emotions and seek support. The space will be available on a first-come, first-served basis for the first 20 folks to arrive.

Source: NC State University

title: Institutional Biosafety Committee Meetings
description:
The Institutional Biosafety Committee (IBC) invites the NC State community to attend our virtual meetings. The IBC provides assurance that the potential impacts associated with the intended use of biological organisms at NC State have been appropriately evaluated.

To receive the meeting link and additional meeting details, please contact Brenda L. Mickens at (919) 515-4190.

Source: NC State University

title: Century of Designers: From Worth to the World
location: Wilson College of Textiles 1020 Main Campus Drive, Raleigh, Room 2225 (Convocation Center)
description:
A celebration of creativity and growth among sophomore fashion design students in the fashion and textile design program at the Wilson College of Textiles, showcasing their first capsule collections. Each collection is inspired by iconic designers from the past century and reinterpreted through decade-specific research, pattern-making, and construction techniques. The pop-up museum highlights emerging designers’ work and shows how historical influences are given a fresh, modern perspective.

This event is free and open to the public!

Source: NC State University

title: Centennial Campus Running Club: Wolves on the Run
description:
Wolves on the Run is a running and walking club open to all. Join your colleagues and friends for a social run or walk on Centennial Campus. We meet at the dock at Lake Raleigh.

Source: NC State University

title: Jenkins MBA Virtual Information Session
description:
Join the NC State Jenkins MBA program for a virtual information session that will explain how the program can help you achieve your personal and professional goals. During the session, you’ll:

Get an overview of our flexible program formats, innovative curriculum and graduate certificatesLearn about the admissions process, application tips and key deadlinesHear insights from program staff and MBA studentsHave a chance to ask questionsWhether you’re just beginning your MBA search or finalizing your decision, this session is a great opportunity to find out if the Jenkins MBA is the right fit for you.

Source: NC State University

title: MBA Career Coaches: Ask Us Anything
description:
Join the Jenkins MBA career coaches for an Ask Us Anything session designed to support your career. Bring your questions about job search strategy, networking, interviews and navigating different career paths. The coaches will share guidance, insights and practical tips to help you move forward with confidence.

Source: NC State University

title: Flow Together: Stories of Water, Sustainability, and Mobility
location: Frank Thompson Hall - Kennedy-McIlwee Studio Theatre, Kennedy-McIlwee Studio Theatre
description:
Join the Department of Performing Arts and Technology in a sharing of works hosted by the Dance Repertory & Performance Spring '26’ Cohort.  Featuring works by Assistant Teaching Professor Brianna Forbes, Guest Artist Bernadine Fields, Southern Durham High’s Dance Company, Student choreographer Jordan Kaplan, and more!

 

This performance and its complementary community initiative Flow Together: Community Dance and Water Sustainability, is made possible by an Arts and Science Grant from the Data Science and AI Academy, along with the Office of Interdisciplinary Programs and Arts NC State.

Source: NC State University

title: Art2Wear: Symbiosis
description:
Art2Wear continues its traditions by pushing fashion and form in its 2026 production: Symbiosis. Symbiosis works to integrate designers' understanding of interactions, push and pulls, constraints and appendages. Whether ancient interactions between humanity and nature or emerging engagements with technologies, this year explores polarities in interactions to showcase the impact of forces and the world’s curation when things come together.

Art2Wear will be showcased at the Gregg Museum of Art & Design. 

This year, there are multiple showtimes for Art2Wear:

7-9 pm on April 234-6 pm on April 247-9 pm on April 24What is Art2Wear?

Art2WearTM (A2W) is an educational event where students gain experience by coordinating and producing an annual wearable art production. Young designers are challenged to imagine, create, and inspire by expressing their point of view through wearable art. This highly anticipated show fuses the talents of several departments in the College of Design and beyond, exposing student designers to the broader field of wearable art, digital media production, and fashion. A2W attracts attendees from all over the Triangle by encouraging participation through engaging the student body, the Raleigh community, and the broader design industry.

Source: NC State University

title: Carolina Ballet: Celebration of America
description:
Program:

In the GrayPauseAmerican in ParisIntermissionStars and StripesThis April, we proudly present Celebration of America, a spirited program honoring the 250th anniversary of the founding of the United States. Through three compelling works and the vitality of live music, we reflect on the nation’s cultural spirit, artistic legacy, and complex identity.

Sponsored by: The John William Pope Foundation

Performances

Thursday, April 23rd, 7:30pmFriday, April 24th, 7:30pmSaturday, April 25th, 2pmSaturday, April 25th, 7:30pmSunday, April 26th, 2pm

Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

The exhibit will run from Feb. 17, 2026 to May 30, 2026. The museum is open Tues-Sat, 10-4. Admission is free. Check out kingsmountainmuseum.org or call 704-739-1019 for more information.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: How To Get Started in Research Workshop
description:
Are you interested in research opportunities as an undergraduate student? If so, join the Office of Undergraduate Research during its weekly Zoom workshops that cover a range of commonly asked questions regarding how to find undergraduate research opportunities and how to get started. A Q&A session will be held at the end of the workshop.

Source: NC State University

title: NC State Earth Day Cleanup
description:
Come volunteer and celebrate Earth Month by spending a few hours beautifying Lake Raleigh, a 75-acre lake amid a 96-acre protected forest, April 24. Earth Day is April 22.

Volunteer tasks will include collecting litter along greenway trails, natural trails and Lake Raleigh.

Training and volunteering: All volunteers must attend a safety training session at 10 a.m. You can decide how long to volunteer. The clean-up effort will conclude by noon.

Where to join us and park: You can join the volunteer effort at either of the following locations:

The Lake Raleigh fishing pier: If you plan to walk or ride a bike or the bus from campus, consider meeting us at the fishing pier. Paid parking is available at the Poulton parking lot on Partners Way.The Park Alumni Center: The center's address is 2450 Alumni Drive in Raleigh, and parking there is free.What to bring: Volunteers must wear close-toed shoes. Please bring water in a reusable water bottle so you can stay hydrated. All other materials and supplies, such as gloves, will be provided.

If you have questions about the clean-up effort, send an email to sustainability@ncsu.edu.

Source: NC State University

title: Data Visualization for Social Science Research (Online)
description:
This course introduces modern visual data exploration and communication methods to social scientists with limited prior experience. Students will learn to effectively present data to diverse audiences across multiple formats. The course utilizes the R programming language, RStudio development environment, and the tidyverse suite of R packages—with particular emphasis on ggplot2—for data processing and visualization.

Students will develop skills to confidently explore data descriptively, communicate findings to both academic and general audiences, and refine model results for presentations and publications. The course emphasizes both clarity and aesthetic considerations in data visualization, while incorporating best practices for practical, efficient, and reproducible workflows. Through a unified toolset, students will learn to display visualizations effectively across web platforms, academic papers, reports, and presentations. Registration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Free Yoga
location: Partners I – NC State University, Suite 2580
description:
Take a break from your day and enjoy a free yoga class on Centennial Campus. Classes are held every weekday, except when the university is closed, from 12:15 to 1:05 p.m. The classes are open to everyone, and registration is not required. Please bring your own mat.

Source: NC State University

title: Fab Friday
description:
Do you love hearing about current events and a variety of topics? Are you looking for a way to build your leadership skills and show off your creativity? If so, the Fabulous Fridays series hosted by the Women's Center is for you. Join your peers and build community through storytelling, discussion, interactive activities and more.

Source: NC State University

title: Tour: A Closer Look at "Color Concentrated"
description:
Join Ackland educators for a lively half-hour look at a small handful of artworks. These engaging conversational tours offer a closer look at and new perspectives on works on view at the Museum. Today’s tour looks at Color Concentrated: A Salon-Style Show from the Robertson Collection. 
This is a free, walk-in event – no RSVP required. 
This event is part of UNC–Chapel Hill’s Campus Life Experience (CLE) program. Students who attend can scan the QR code provided at the event to receive CLE credit.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Dungeons & Dragons
description:
Join the Women's Center for Dungeons & Dragons. Whether you're a seasoned pro or new to the game, join us to explore magical realms, craft powerful characters and tell epic stories. Together, we'll roll the dice and create unforgettable adventures in a supportive and empowering environment. Let's dive in and shape our destinies.

Source: NC State University

title: Art2Wear: Symbiosis
description:
Art2Wear continues its traditions by pushing fashion and form in its 2026 production: Symbiosis. Symbiosis works to integrate designers' understanding of interactions, push and pulls, constraints and appendages. Whether ancient interactions between humanity and nature or emerging engagements with technologies, this year explores polarities in interactions to showcase the impact of forces and the world’s curation when things come together.

Art2Wear will be showcased at the Gregg Museum of Art & Design. 

This year, there are multiple showtimes for Art2Wear:

7-9 pm on April 234-6 pm on April 247-9 pm on April 24What is Art2Wear?

Art2WearTM (A2W) is an educational event where students gain experience by coordinating and producing an annual wearable art production. Young designers are challenged to imagine, create, and inspire by expressing their point of view through wearable art. This highly anticipated show fuses the talents of several departments in the College of Design and beyond, exposing student designers to the broader field of wearable art, digital media production, and fashion. A2W attracts attendees from all over the Triangle by encouraging participation through engaging the student body, the Raleigh community, and the broader design industry.

Source: NC State University

title: Statewide Star Party:  Mission to the Moon
description:
Join the Hammocks Beach staff as we host the NC SciFest Star Party Event:  "Mission to the Moon".  This is an after hours event filled with a variety of hands-on space-themed activities for all ages. Families can build and test their own Moon landing modules, launch stomp rockets, and construct creative Moon bases while learning about engineering and life in space. Visitors can explore the night sky through telescopes, listen to cultural sky stories during Storytelling Under the Stars, and try challenges like the Rover Maze, Lunar Twister, and Lunar Bean Bag Toss. Additional rotating activities from NC SciFest offer quick STEM experiences throughout the event. Together, these stations blend science, imagination, and exploration to inspire curiosity about our universe.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Comedic Improvisational Alliance
location: Frank Thompson Hall - Kennedy-McIlwee Studio Theatre
description:
NC State's oldest and only improv troupe, the CIA, presents a night of improv comedy where every scene and joke is without a script

Improv is a form of theatre where there is no script and the scenes are made up on the spot by the players. Improvised if you will.

CIA has been around for over ten years as NC State's premiere and only Improv Comedy troupe.

location: Frank Thompson Hall - Kennedy-McIlwee Studio Theatre

Enjoy crafts that bring the night sky down to Earth and stargaze to see wondrous constellations, far far away galaxies, and other celestial bodies.

Our Star Party will happen rain or shine; however, many activities are weather dependent.

Enjoy crafts that let you hold the sky in your hands and stargaze to see the celestial bodies that orbit above our heads. description:

title: 2026 Falls Lake Youth Fishing Tournament
location: Beaverdam Lake - Falls Lake State Recreation Area
description:
Join us at Falls Lake State Recreation Area - Beaverdam Lake access, as we host our 9th annual youth fishing tournament! Ages 5 - 13 are welcome to participate for a chance to win prizes. We will also have free interactive environmental education opportunities and some fun freebees to take home from North Carolina State Parks. Bait will be provided at this event and although we do encourage participants to bring their own fishing poles, we do have some that can be borrowed (while supplies last). Registration is required and can be completed by calling the main office at (984)867-8000 or emailing us at Falls.Lake@ncparks.gov

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Between the Devil and the Deep Blue Sea: Sailors and Tar Workers in the 18th Century
description:
Join us for a living history event that will provide a comprehensive view of maritime history within the region, provide context for naval stores production along the lower Cape Fear, and provide interpretations of eighteenth century trades that are relevant to maritime history and sailing. It will contextualize the role of the naval stores industry in Brunswick's development as a major colonial port. This is a free event for all ages.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Daniel Davenport Festival - Celebrating a Revolutionary War Soldier
description:
Mark your calendars for April 25th, 2025 for the first official Washington County event in 2026 to commemorate America's 250th anniversary! The America 250 NC Washington County 250th Committee and the Washington County Historical Society at the Daniel Davenport Festival have come together to commemorate the lives of Revolutionary War Soldiers.

There will be living history demonstrations, including ropemaking, examples of soldiers' rations and their equipment, camp cooking, and others. Period musicians will provide musical performances. Other presentations include medicine during the American Revolution, and the Tyrrell County Men who served in the American Revolution, since Washington County was not officially established until 1799.

Tours of the main house and its assorted buildings, which illustrate 18th-century life, including a corn crib, smokehouse, and a building for the loom, have been arranged. The Homestead is on the National Register of Historic Places. It is a rare but fine example of a late 18th-century yeoman farmer's dwelling, and it remains in nearly original condition, despite the fact that the descendants of Davenport lived in the house until the mid-1970s without making any modern improvements. A truly unique gem in the region.

The Sons of the American Revolution are holding a recognition and wreath-laying ceremony, including information about Daniel Davenport's six-month service in the NC 5th Regiment and his legacy in Washington County, at 2:00 pm. Local school children will sing as part of the ceremony.

Please note: The celebration festival is free, but the food truck on site is not. In addition, the Homestead does not have a specific address. It is located on Mount Tabor Road in Creswell on the corner of State Route 1143 and 1146. If coming from the direction of Creswell, it is on the road to the right after a sharp curve at the Mount Tabor Free Will Baptist Church. You can also use Google Maps, Davenport Homestead, Creswell, NC. It will take you there. Please email Chris Barber with any questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Legends & Landmarks: Paintings and Drawings by James C. Horton
description:
In commemoration of America's 250th, the Bellamy Mansion Museum is hosting an art exhibition by local artist James C. Horton, which includes over 40 original paintings and drawings that highlight historic scenes and places from around the region and country that help tell America's story. Visitors can view the exhibit free of charge any time the museum is open (M-Sun. 10 am-4 pm). Please stop by the Carriage ​House Visitor Center to gain admission. Art is available for purchase and an Artist's Reception will be held on February 27th (6-8pm). Visit bellamymansion.org/exhibits for more information or email info@bellamymansion.org if you have questions.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Road to Revolution
description:
A Festival of Living History, Games, Music and a Wreath Laying Ceremony to honor Daniel Davenport.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Road to Revolution: Daniel Davenport
description:
Washington County 250 will sponsor an event at the Davenport Homestead, intersection of Mt. Tabor Rd. and Anold Hill Rd.,  Creswell, NC 27928 on Saturday April 25, 2026 from 10 AM till 3 PM. The Homestead, built by Daniel Davenport after his return from his six month enlistment in the 5th NC will be the scene of living histories, a house tour, and period music.  The DAR and SAR will sponsor a Wreath Laying Ceremony to honor Daniel Davenport at a monument on the grounds.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution
description:
KMHM is excited to present Women at the Edge of War: Carolina Piedmont's Heroines of the American Revolution. This exhibit highlights the daily courage and civic work of women in the Carolinas, whose efforts were essential to Revolutionary resistance and survival on the southern frontier.

title: 24th Annual Birdhouse Competition
description:
It's that time of year again.  Join the JC Raulston Arboretum for the 24th Annual Birdhouse Competition. What better way is there to celebrate the return of spring? If you love nature, birds and unique garden art, then this is the competition for you. Get out your sketch pad, paints and toolbox to start building your creation today. Whether you join as a competitor or come to enjoy the creations, the competition will surely be an experience you'll never forget.

Registration for competitors is open.

Source: NC State University

title: Raulston Blooms! and Plant Sale
description:
Kick off the spring season with birds, bugs and Raulston Blooms!  Bring the whole family to this outdoor festival at the JC Raulston Arboretum to enjoy food, a plant sale and a maker's market.

Admission to the event includes access to the plant sale. The last tickets will be sold at 2:30 p.m. on the event day.

Source: NC State University

title: "Protected us from all harm" - The American War for Independence in Wachovia
description:
Come learn about the threats the revolutionary conflict brought to the Moravian settlements of Wachovia through living history, a panel discussion with experts, and a re-creation of the first peace celebration. Admission is FREE!

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Uneasy Peace: 161st Anniversary Commemoration
description:
Join us to commemorate the surrender negotiations at Bennett Place that led to the largest surrender of the American Civil War. Learn more about how Generals Johnston and Sherman's three meetings at the Bennetts' home reflected the broader national debate over how to reunite the nation & remake the United States without slavery. Explore how veterans, civilians, and freed people alike experienced and thought about the end of the American Civil War and what would come next.

This program includes several costumed interpretation events and displays.

 Additional details and event schedule are forthcoming. Tickets must be purchased on site the day of the event.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Bluebird NestBox Walk & Talk
location: Haw River State Park - The Summit Access
description:
The 2026 NCSciFest theme is "Science Matters" and we're excited to talk about eleven years of bluebird conservation lessons learned by staff & volunteers at Haw River State Park. Meet in the courtyard outside of the Main Lodge (building closest to flagpole) for a talk about the history of bluebird conservation followed by an easy hike around Lake Loop (0.7 miles) to view several different styles of nestboxes and look for baby birds. Please bring comfortable walking shoes for a natural-surface travel (packed dirt or gravel) and water/snacks as needed. Don't miss out on this opportunity to connect with nature and expand your knowledge of the local wildlife as we celebrate science in the outdoors!

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Earth Fair OBX
description:
Come celebrate Earth Day (week) with the Coastal Environmental Educators Network and friends.  The event will bring together many Outer Banks and regional organizations that offer environmental education opportunities and services to the community.  Share your love for the natural world and check out our fun, free, and informative exhibits and activities for kids.

title: Emerging Designers Runway Show
location: Talley Student Union, Piedmont / Mountains Ballroom
description:
The Emerging Designers Runway Show marks the culmination of four years of fashion design education in the fashion and textile design (FTD) program at NC State University. This year’s showcase highlights the transformation of concept into craftsmanship, as graduating designers explore form, function and identity through collections developed during their capstone course. From refined ready-to-wear to bold avant-garde expressions, the work reflects both individual vision and technical mastery shaped in the studios and labs of the Wilson College of Textiles.

The Emerging Designers Runway Show will be showcased at Talley Student Union.

Doors open at 6:30 p.m. Runway show is at 7 p.m.

title: Statewide Star Party: Salmon Creek State Natural Area
description:
Join us on a "Mission to the Moon," with hands-on activities and night-sky viewing in beautiful Bertie County! We'll meet at Bertie Beach on the Chowan River, which features a large open field with an expansive view of the night sky. Start off with some hands-on activities to learn about the Moon while we wait for dark, and then we will look at the sky through telescopes.

Several community partners will be participating as well, including members of local astronomy clubs.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Bald Eagle Search Paddle with Two Sisters Adventure Company
description:
Join Two Sisters Adventure Company for a Bald Eagle Search Paddle at Jordan Lake State Recreation Area, hosted on select dates throughout 2026. Jordan Lake is one of the best Bald Eagle viewing locations in the region. You will paddle past multiple nesting areas in search of our majestic national bird. While sightings are not guaranteed, Bald Eagles are most common in the areas they visit. Your guide will help you identify and answer questions about Bald Eagles and other birds in the area. All participants should have basic kayaking skills, due to the duration on the water this trip is considered intermediate. Pre-registration is required. Participants will launch from the Farrington Point Access. The trip will last approximately 4 hours. Trips will take place on the following dates:

Thu, Mar 26, 9am-1pm.Sun, Apr 26, 8:30am-12:30pm.Sat, May 9, 8am-12pm.Sat, May 30, 8am-12pm.Sun, Jun 7, 8am-12pm.Two Sisters works with all guests to make trips as accessible as possible. Please contact them with any specific accessibility requests so they can ensure they have all the necessary equipment and staff. Free parking is available at the Farrington Point Canoe Launch. No pets are allowed. The cost is $60 per person, and pre-registration is required. Single-person kayaks are provided. Participants ages 15 and older are welcome.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events. See more Chatham Sports Alliance events.

Two Sisters acknowledges that the land on which this camp takes place is the ancestral land of the Skaruhreh/Tuscarora, Lumbee, Mánu: Yį Įsuwą (Catawba), Occaneechi, Shakori, and Cheraw Nations. As a part of their mission, they honor and respect the history and significance this land holds for these Nations’ past, present, and future. To find out more about the Native People and Lands where you live and recreate, visit this map.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Last Week of Spring Semester
description:
Lab tests, semester project reports and presentations are permissible during the final week of classes. Papers and homework may have a due date during the final week of classes only if scheduled in the syllabus. However, in order for students to prepare for final examinations, faculty members may not assign other tests, quizzes or additional papers during the final week of classes. Assignments should not have a due date during the final exam period unless the assignment constitutes a part of the final exam. Exceptions to this policy must be approved in advance by the department head and the dean of the college involved. Students should contact the appropriate instructor or department head if they believe an assignment is not in compliance with this regulation.

Source: NC State University

title: Take a Beat
description:
Visit The Corner for a special down-tempo performance by DJ Lauren Bartek. Her sets are known and loved for their clarity and mindfulness, but this one is especially made for a midday moment of ease, sharing a meal and enjoying the sun.

Source: NC State University

title: Free Yoga
location: Partners I – NC State University, Suite 2580
description:
Take a break from your day and enjoy a free yoga class on Centennial Campus. Classes are held every weekday, except when the university is closed, from 12:15 to 1:05 p.m. The classes are open to everyone, and registration is not required. Please bring your own mat.

title: How To Get Started in Research Workshop
description:
Are you interested in research opportunities as an undergraduate student? If so, join the Office of Undergraduate Research during its weekly Zoom workshops that cover a range of commonly asked questions regarding how to find undergraduate research opportunities and how to get started. A Q&A session will be held at the end of the workshop.

title: Annual Carolina Speech Competition: Hosted by the Program for Public Discourse
description:
The Program for Public Discourse invites undergraduates across the university to audition for a slot to compete in our annual Carolina Speech Competition. This year’s theme will be “Tackling the Issues of Our Day.” Participants will present original five-minute speeches around that theme as they compete for cash prizes of up to $500. If interested in competing or simply learning more, please contact Kevin Marinelli for additional details.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: The Art and Science of Plant Care
description:
Caring for plants is both an art and a science — part intuition, part know-how. Every gardener, from beginner to expert, faces the same essential questions: When should I prune? How much should I water? What’s the best way to plant, fertilize or repot? In this class, Bryce Lane will bring decades of horticultural expertise to demystify these everyday tasks, showing you not just what to do but why it works.

Over eight weeks, you’ll explore the fundamental practices that keep gardens thriving, learning how to perform each one with confidence and purpose. You’ll uncover the science behind good technique — understanding how soil, water, nutrients and plant biology interact — while also developing the practical judgment that comes only with experience.

Each session will focus on one key aspect of plant care, building a complete toolkit for growing healthier, more resilient plants in any garden setting.

Source: NC State University

title: Last Week of Spring Semester
description:
Lab tests, semester project reports and presentations are permissible during the final week of classes. Papers and homework may have a due date during the final week of classes only if scheduled in the syllabus. However, in order for students to prepare for final examinations, faculty members may not assign other tests, quizzes or additional papers during the final week of classes. Assignments should not have a due date during the final exam period unless the assignment constitutes a part of the final exam. Exceptions to this policy must be approved in advance by the department head and the dean of the college involved. Students should contact the appropriate instructor or department head if they believe an assignment is not in compliance with this regulation.

Source: NC State University

title: Goldston America 250 Film Series
description:
Join the Chatham Community Library for this Goldston America 250 Film Series, hosted every fourth Tuesday, January-December 2026, 4pm-6pm. America 250’s mission is to honor and commemorate the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence, marking America’s Semiquincentennial. The Goldston Library will screen the following documentaries and films:

Tue, Jan 27, 4pm-6pm The Congress, Ken Burns.
Tue, Feb 24, 4pm-6pm Becoming Frederick Douglass, Stanley Nelson and Nicole London.
Tue, Mar 24, 4pm-6pm Rachel Carson: The Woman Who Launched the Modern Environmental Movement, Michelle Ferrari.
Tue, Apr 28, 4pm-6pm Thomas Jefferson: A View from the Mountain, Martin Doblmeier.
Tue, May 26, 4pm-6pm The Address, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jun 23, 4pm-6pm The Brooklyn Bridge, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jul 28, 4pm-6pm The Statue of Liberty, Ken Burns.
Tue, Aug 25, 4pm-6pm American Coup: Wilmington 1898, Yoruba Richen and Brad Lichtenstein.
Tue, Sep 22, 4pm-6pm How it Feels to be Free, Yoruba Richen.
Tue, Oct 27, 4pm-6pm 80 Years Later, Celine Parreñas Shimizu.
Tue, Nov 24, 4pm-6pm Gather, Sanjay Rawal.
Tue, Dec 22, 4pm-6pm Women of World War II: The Untold Stories, Eli Brown.

This FREE, family-friendly event is open to the public. No registration is required. The event will take place indoors in the Goldston Library. The Goldston Library is ADA-compliant, including wheelchair-accessible parking, entrances, seating, common spaces, walkways, and restrooms. Free parking is available outside the library. Pets are not allowed - please leave your furry friends at home.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events.

title: Relaxation “Micro-Moments” and Winding Down Techniques
description:
The problem with most attempts to adopt stress-management or self-care routines is that they require time, effort and planning. The reality for many people who have stressful jobs is that they are too physically exhausted and mentally depleted by the end of the day to initiate activities commonly recommended to reduce stress in their lives. The trick is to intervene via multiple “micro-moments” of relaxation or mindful practices which only take 15 to 60 seconds. These moments of relaxation help bring stress levels down during the workday and interrupt the steady escalation of stress that creates physical and mental exhaustion. Also addressed: simple winding-down routines that can end the day in a calming, mindful way.

 

Workshop Objectives
This training will help you:
• Describe how stress escalates through the day and leads to exhaustion
• Consider whether your present stress reduction habits may be adding to your overall stress
• Understand how simple short moments of relaxation throughout the day can permit you reduce stress and
conserve energy
• Practice brief mindful moments of relaxation and learn how to integrate these moments into your workday
• Understand the value of winding-down routines that foster a sense of safety and personal control.

title: Getting Proper about Prompting:  An Introduction to Prompt Engineering for Social Science and Survey Research
description:
Take a glance through recent news or social media and you would be hard-pressed not to see mentions of chatbots and artificial intelligence (AI) methods aimed at generating text, images and other content.  Recent work by Eloundou and colleagues (2023) explored the potential impact of these types of generative AI on labor markets, and survey research, specifically was among the top two most impacted industries.  Professor Andrew Ng has been cited as saying “AI won’t replace human workers, but ‘people that use it will replace people that don’t.’”  Much of the way researchers in the social sciences and survey research are incorporating AI into their workflow involves some type of prompting.  Prompt Engineering approaches along with more nuanced fine tuning approaches are being used and refined to better incorporate more robust approaches for AI incorporation into the research process.  In this shortcourse we will provide an overview of the emerging field of prompt engineering and illustrate how a prompt engineering approach and problem specification mindset can be useful for maximizing the utility of large language models, specifically, within social science.  Concepts and experimental approaches will be illustrated using several real-world, grounded and published work.  The shortcourse also incorporates an experiential component that encourages participants to apply basic concepts that we cover in the course in real-time as we work on exercises together in the later part of the course. Registration and fee (refundable for students) are required for Zoom link access.

Join the crowds May 1-2, 2026 from 10am to 4pm.  Soak up the history in 10 enchanting homes in 2 historic neighborhoods.

title: Basics of Estate Planning
description:
Although most people think estate planning is for just the elderly, it is actually important to everyone else, too—especially for those with minor children, substantial assets or unusual circumstances. Estate planning can allow one to make decisions on who receives his or her estate, make arrangements for disability, medical care and guardianship for minor children. Properly done, estate planning can remove many burdens from surviving family members during a stressful time.

 

Workshop Objectives
At the end of this workshop, you will be able to:
Define estate planning
• Describe the most common goals in the estate planning process
• Identify important tools used in estate planning, such as wills, trusts, advance directives and more
Describe the tax implications of estate planning
• Identify who is responsible for paying estate taxes
• Describe the taxes involved in the settlement of an estate
Identify key action steps
• Describe financial and other steps to take to plan your estate

title: Bearing Witness with Nature-Based Art: A Grief Journey with Gaza
location: Onsite at Duke Gardens – directions to follow
description:
Please join us for a pop-up exhibit and artist talk with The Witness about their evolving art practice that centers around themes of identity, belonging, grief and sorrow. The Witness will share how applying images to fresh leaves and paper has allowed them to process the immense reactions and sorrow that emerged from witnessing the suffering and erasure in Gaza. They will share how their nature-based art has changed in response to the seasons and a need for stronger creative expression. This talk offers an intimate view into their art practice and the stories around it.
