title: Civic Hacking for Affordable Housing
description:
Code with the Carolinas - Triangle
Join volunteers at Code with the Carolinas as we help the [National Zoning Atlas](https://www.zoningatlas.org/) (NZA) team include North Carolina and South Carolina in their nationwide zoning atlas. "The National Zoning Atlas aims to depict key aspects of zoning codes in an online, user-friendly map." The Atlas aims to provide data for better solutions in transportation, environmental, and especially affordable housing policy.

Affordable housing proponents have long recognized zoning policies as barriers to affordable housing. To improve zoning policies, we first need to better understand the current state of zoning across the United States. Code with the Carolinas is helping this cause by joining the National Zoning Atlas to gather zoning data for North and South Carolina.

This is a multi-dimensional project grounded in data science with an end-goal of contributing to a nationally influential dataset. Our current work session activities focus on internet search and integrating data from multiple sources. The project as a whole has occasional opportunities for U/X and outreach and opportunities to learn about machine learning and natural language processing through the work of the NZA team. Volunteering on this project will provide excellent exposure to the foundations of civic data science, with a focus on GIS data.

Even if you're new to this project and/or civic tech volunteering, you're welcome to join the meeting. Visitors are always welcome and no technical skills are needed. You can learn more about the project on our [Slack Workspace](https://join.slack.com/t/codeforthecarolinas/shared_invite/zt-1kxuwu05x-3KxOpkOYjAuN5yuOAH8ROg) in the #project-zoning-atlas channel.

Meetings start with brief introductions. New volunteers are offered a personal orientation, often in a breakout room, while experienced volunteers get right to work. By the end of the session, both groups of volunteers are working together. We also contribute to the project through asynchronous work and informal work sessions.

Meetings are on the Jitsi platform and the link is provided before each meeting. If you will be joining on mobile, install the Jitsi app in advance [https://jitsi.org/downloads/](https://jitsi.org/downloads/) .

Learn more at [codewiththecarolinas.org](codeforthecarolinas.org) or reach out to info@codewiththecarolinas.org

All activities of Code with the Carolinas, a project of [Social Good Fund](https://www.socialgoodfund.org/), follow our [Code of Conduct](https://share.mailbox.org/ajax/share/0d32d5f905f8fd49d5e80395f8fd47f2b59ce3ef8b335f72/1/8/Nzg/NzgvMTkx) and are subject to this [Volunteer Waiver of Liability](https://share.mailbox.org/ajax/share/06dd62200e6b28426b137e0e6b2848fb901487014f72cd16/1/8/Nzg/NzgvMTE2).

title: Mental Health Awareness for Leaders
description:
Managing individuals who may be struggling with stress, anxiety, depression and other mental health concerns can be a difficult balancing act. Your role is to manage performance and to bring out the best in your workforce, but accomplishing this often requires you to express concern and support when employees struggle emotionally. Managers often feel uncomfortable in this aspect of their role and may lack the important skills of “emotional management.” This course covers ways employees may present their distress and offers insights and strategies on forging supportive empathic alliances within the role of manager. The session also identifies common mistakes managers make in responding to employees in distress and explains communication skills that express support and convey positive expectancy. Participants are also given information on how to refer employees to the Employee Assistance Program.

 

Workshop Objectives
By the end of this workshop, you will:
• Understand the universality of mental health issues in the workplace
• Recognize the most common symptoms of mental illness
• Identify the most common unhelpful reactions to symptoms, why they occur and how to avoid them
• Identify ways of expressing compassion and developing an alliance with distressed employees
• Reduce the stigma associated mental illness and promote ways of supporting one another in the workplace
• Recognize the warning signs of suicide
• Identify support services and resources for all leaders and employees

 

Click on Carolina Talent registration link and select the “Request” button to automatically enroll.

title: Bald Eagle Search Paddle with Two Sisters Adventure Company
description:
Join Two Sisters Adventure Company for a Bald Eagle Search Paddle at Jordan Lake State Recreation Area, hosted on select dates throughout 2026. Jordan Lake is one of the best Bald Eagle viewing locations in the region. You will paddle past multiple nesting areas in search of our majestic national bird. While sightings are not guaranteed, Bald Eagles are most common in the areas they visit. Your guide will help you identify and answer questions about Bald Eagles and other birds in the area. All participants should have basic kayaking skills, due to the duration on the water this trip is considered intermediate. Pre-registration is required. Participants will launch from the Farrington Point Access. The trip will last approximately 4 hours. Trips will take place on the following dates:

Thu, Mar 26, 9am-1pm.
Sun, Apr 26, 8:30am-12:30pm.
Sat, May 9, 8am-12pm.
Sat, May 30, 8am-12pm.
Sun, Jun 7, 8am-12pm.

Two Sisters works with all guests to make trips as accessible as possible. Please contact them with any specific accessibility requests so they can ensure they have all the necessary equipment and staff. Free parking is available at the Farrington Point Canoe Launch. No pets are allowed. The cost is $60 per person, and pre-registration is required. Single-person kayaks are provided. Participants ages 15 and older are welcome.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events. See more Chatham Sports Alliance events.

Two Sisters acknowledges that the land on which this camp takes place is the ancestral land of the Skaruhreh/Tuscarora, Lumbee, Mánu: Yį Įsuwą (Catawba), Occaneechi, Shakori, and Cheraw Nations. As a part of their mission, they honor and respect the history and significance this land holds for these Nations’ past, present, and future. To find out more about the Native People and Lands where you live and recreate, visit this map.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Cherry Point Air Show
location: Marine Corps Air Station Cherry Point
description:
As the nation celebrates 250 years of American independence, the 2026 show will aim to honor our heritage with a powerful display of airpower, patriotic unity, and national pride.

“The MCAS Cherry Point Air Show is more than an aviation event, it’s a celebration of American excellence and a tribute to the strength, innovation, and freedom our nation has stood for over two and a half centuries,” said Col. Brendan “Cletus” Burks, commanding officer of MCAS Cherry Point. “In partnership with 2nd Marine Aircraft Wing and our community, we are proud to host a world-class event that reflects the professionalism of our Marines and the enduring bond we share with Eastern North Carolina.”

Headlining the 2026 event is the return of the legendary U.S. Navy Blue Angels, joined by an exciting lineup of military and civilian acts that continue to inspire and captivate. Fan-favorite performances such as the jet truck, parachute jump team, and aerobatic pilots like Randy Ball, RJ Gritter and Tom Larkin are already slated to return.

As always, the air show will be free and open to the public, with general admission and parking offered at no cost. Premium seating options will also be available for those seeking upgraded amenities. Visitors can expect an immersive experience filled with aerial demonstrations, aircraft static displays, food vendors, and interactive exhibits for guests of all ages.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Reed Gold Mine Mining In Society Merit Badge
description:
Registered Scouts will have the opportunity to complete all requirements needed to earn the “Mining in Society” merit badge at Reed Gold Mine’s merit badge workshop.

The workshop begins with a PowerPoint presentation and class time to finish the sections of the “Mining in Society” merit badge workbook. After completing the in-class portion, Scouts will be taken on a guided tour of the underground mine and learn about Reed Gold Mine’s history and learn more about the gold mining process. Following that, weather permitting, Scouts will be able to pan for gold in the outdoor panning area.

There is a $15 registration fee per Scout, which includes the cost of the workshop, tour, and one panning ticket (weather permitting). Adult leaders and chaperones who wish to pan with their Scouts can purchase a panning ticket in the gift shop. Panning tickets are sold on a first come, first served basis and are $4.00 after tax. Adult leaders and chaperones may also buy a tour ticket if they’re interested in going on the guided tour of the underground mine. Tour tickets are $5.00 for adults 13 and older.

In 2026, “Mining in Society” merit badge workshops will be offered May 9, June 13, July 11, August 8, September 12, October 10, and November 14. Each workshop begins at 10:00 am and runs until 2:00 pm and is limited to 60 participants.

Registration form- https://tinyurl.com/5ubvkkkc

For more information and to schedule, contact Reed Gold Mine’s Education Coordinator, Logan Stamper. He can be reached by email at logan.stamper@dncr.nc.gov or by phone at (704) 721-4653.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Revolutionary Women in the Historical Park
description:
Women contributed a lot during the American Revolution. They raised money, protested, provided direct support to troops, and even fought in battle. Join us as our costumed interpreters demonstrate some of the activities that women did for the war effort. Visitors will be able to learn about 18th century gardening, laundering, open hearth cooking, and more. FREE. All ages welcome. Drop-in.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Road to Yorktown: Living History Day
description:
Historic Halifax’s Road to Yorktown explores how North Carolina’s commitment to American Independence as expressed in the April 12th, 1776, “Halifax Resolves” was challenged with the arrival of the British Army in the spring of 1781. Costumed reenactors, military camps and historic weapons demonstrations bring this period of North Carolina's history to life. Free.

title: Learning to Relax
description:
Stress is experienced in the body as tension. To manage stress we have several choices: reduce or eliminate the stressor, think about the stressor differently so it no longer causes tension or change the way our body reacts to stress. The course will address the third option through exploring a variety of relaxation techniques to calm the body and mind. The class will allow participants to learn and experience several simple relaxation tools such as progressive muscle relaxation, abdominal relaxation breathing.

 

Workshop Objectives
At the end of this workshop, you will be able to:
Identify the benefits of relaxation
• Lowering blood pressure
• Reducing muscle tension and chronic pain
• Reducing anger and frustration
• Improving concentration and creativity
Recognize the steps to perform several different relaxation methods such as:
• Cultivating tension awareness
• Progressive muscle relaxation
• Abdominal or diaphragmatic breathing
• Using sound and voice to relax
• Laughter
• Visualization

 

Click on Carolina Talent registration link and select the “Request” button to automatically enroll.

title: Ranger Workshop - Wildflower Walk
description:
Join us on a Wildflower Walk along Upper Boone Fork Trail at Grandfather Mountain State Park where you will learn how to ID common flowering species found in the Blue Ridge Mountains. This easy-moderate 1.0 mile out and back hike requires sturdy hiking boots and water. Although we won't hike great distances, we will be out in the elements the entire time, so please dress accordingly. The Southern Appalachian Mountains provide for a stunning array of native wildflowers and we look forward to sharing this natural beauty with you! We will meet at Boone Fork Parking Area (mile post 299.9 on the Blue Ridge Parkway, GPS:Ê36.1200, -81.7813). There are NO bathrooms. This is a Ranger Workshop with The Town of Seven Devils.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Context Layer: The Emerging Stack for Context-Aware AI
description:
Data Science Raleigh
As enterprises push AI into production, context isn’t a luxury—it’s a requirement. Whether you're mitigating hallucinations, aligning responses with brand and policy guidelines, or ensuring traceable, compliant outcomes, context-aware architecture is becoming foundational to trustworthy AI.

This webinar explores the “context layer”—the emerging stack of tools, techniques, and workflows that inject dynamic, domain-specific intelligence into AI systems. We’ll examine how leading teams are designing for retrieval-augmented generation (RAG), grounding, memory, and orchestration to ensure outputs reflect the right data, tone, and constraints at the right time.

**What You'll Learn:**

1️⃣ **Architecting the Context Layer:** What the emerging stack looks like—from vector databases and memory systems to orchestration layers and policy enforcement.

2️⃣ **Reducing Hallucinations:** How context-aware design helps constrain generative outputs to known, verifiable sources.

3️⃣ **Boosting Trust & Alignment:** Techniques for integrating domain-specific knowledge, tone, and compliance rules directly into AI interactions.

4️⃣ **From Static to Dynamic Context:** When to use retrieval, when to use memory, and how to balance both for adaptive, scalable systems.

**[Register here](https://hubs.ly/Q042cLJx0)**

Source: Meetup: Data Science Raleigh

title: Jenkins MBA Virtual Information Session
description:
Join the NC State Jenkins MBA program for a virtual information session that will explain how the program can help you achieve your personal and professional goals. During the session, you’ll:

Get an overview of our flexible program formats, innovative curriculum and graduate certificatesLearn about the admissions process, application tips and key deadlinesHear insights from program staff and MBA studentsHave a chance to ask questionsWhether you’re just beginning your MBA search or finalizing your decision, this session is a great opportunity to find out if the Jenkins MBA is the right fit for you.

Source: NC State University

title: Monthly Welcome, Community, and Project Meeting
description:
Code with the Carolinas - Triangle
Code with the Carolinas is a community of people working together as civic tech volunteers to improve wellbeing in North and South Carolina, and we invite you to join us for our biweekly online meetings!
Our meetings start with introductions, updates on old and new business, and status reports on current projects, emphasizing how you can get involved. All are welcome and no technical skills are needed.

**Typical Agenda**
Introductions
Organizational Updates
Project updates

* Active projects like Zoning Atlas
* Proposal development for new projects

Meetings are on the Jitsi platform and the link is provided before each meeting. If you will be joining on mobile, install the Jitsi app in advance [https://jitsi.org/downloads/](https://jitsi.org/downloads/) If you joined on mobile and your audio isn't working, it might be because you joined through a browser and not through the app.

Learn more at [[codewiththecarolinas.org](http://codewiththecarolinas.org/)]([http://codeforthecarolinas.org](http://codeforthecarolinas.org/)), [join our Slack](https://join.slack.com/t/codewiththecarolinas/shared_invite/zt-3i6ptx0pz-raH_7Zx4sX0wFUkYM9w3Zw), or reach out to [info@codewiththecarolinas.org](http://info@codewiththecarolinas.org/)

All activities of Code with the Carolinas, a project of [Social Good Fund](https://www.socialgoodfund.org/), follow our [Code of Conduct](https://share.mailbox.org/ajax/share/0d32d5f905f8fd49d5e80395f8fd47f2b59ce3ef8b335f72/1/8/Nzg/NzgvMTkx) and are subject to this [Volunteer Waiver of Liability](https://share.mailbox.org/ajax/share/06dd62200e6b28426b137e0e6b2848fb901487014f72cd16/1/8/Nzg/NzgvMTE2).

title: Building Resilient Supply Chains
description:
Are you struggling to find reliable domestic suppliers? If so, attend a webinar hosted by NC State Industry Expansion Solutions to learn a better way. Finding the right supplier is crucial for reducing risk, ensuring product quality and building a resilient business, especially in the face of fluctuating global trade policies. This webinar will introduce a powerful tool: the North Carolina Manufacturing Extension Partnership’s supplier program. Attendees will learn how to connect with vetted domestic suppliers who can help them streamline their operations, drive growth and build a more resilient supply chain. Discover the types of opportunities available and how to access our supplier sourcing and matching services. You should attend the webinar if you are a manufacturer with:

Extended lead times and increased frustration with your current supply chainExcess capacity and is seeking new business opportunitiesVisit the Industry Expansion Solutions website for more information.

Source: NC State University

title: Siler City History Club
description:
Join the Chatham County Historical Association for the Siler City History Club on every second Thursday of the month, 10:30am-11:30am at First Baptist Church. The Chatham County Historical Association needs your help in learning about the rich and colorful history of Siler City! They have facts and figures, but they need to hear your own memories of Siler to really understand one of Chatham County’s most important cities. Come share your memories, stories, photos, mementos, and other Siler City treasures. Light refreshments will be served. This event is free, and everyone is welcome! No registration is required.

This event takes place indoors. First Baptist Church in Siler City is ADA-accessible. No pets allowed. Please leave your furry friends at home. Free parking is available next to the church.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events. See more events hosted by The Chatham Historical Association.

title: The Five Pillars of Personal Finance
description:
The United Stated Department of the Treasury has proposed a set of financial core competencies that will be used to
establish a clear understanding about what all adults should know regarding the basic concepts of financial literacy. The
five core concept areas identified are:
• Earning
• Spending
• Saving
• Borrowing
• Protecting against risk
This session covers the basics (or essentials) of each area and describes practical skills needed to competently address (or
manage) their personal finances.

 

Workshop Objectives
At the end of this workshop, you will be able to:
• Understand your paycheck in detail, including its relation to benefits and taxes
• Develop a spending plan, track spending habits, develop a strategy to live within your means
• Define a personal savings plan, understand the applicability of different types of financial accounts, and the personal financial risk associated with savings and investment vehicles
• Understand the cost of borrowing and how to secure the best types of credit for the need
• Recognize the need to protect against risk through appropriate insurance vehicles and how to protect your identity against possible fraud and scams.

 

Click on Carolina Talent registration link and select the “Request” button to automatically enroll.

description:

Buy Tickets 
This year marks the North Carolina Botanical Garden and Foundation’s 60th anniversary—a milestone of six decades of conservation, education, and connection to the natural world. From protecting native plants to inspiring generations of visitors, the Garden’s impact has grown because of a dedicated community of supporters. title: Battle of Alamance Reenactment: 255th Anniversary Commemoration
description:
In May 1771, an armed band of backcountry farmers known as the Regulators clashed with Royal Governor William Tryon’s North Carolina militia on the very ground now preserved as the Alamance Battleground State Historic Site. 

This spring, join us as we honor the 255th anniversary with a special reenactment and commemoration. Mark your calendars and stay tuned for details on how you can experience history brought vividly to life.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Old Hillsborough Road Market
description:
James and Nancy Bennett lived along the Hillsborough Road, a major throughway between the county seat of Hillsborough and the state capital of Raleigh. They made money by selling goods & services to passers-by on the roadway.

On May 16, Bennett Place State Historic Site brings back that entrepreneurial, small-business spirit with the Old Hillsborough Road Market. Shop local craft, retail, and food vendors while exploring our historic site! The program also features historic trades demonstrations and free ranger-talks in the Bennett home.

 

Vendors wanted! Please contact us for more information about registration requirements.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: GGC Adventure Series: Practice Adventure Race
description:
Back for another year of inspiring adventures in nature, this season of the Greenway Gear Collective Adventure Series will feature Adventure Race themed outings.
Each event will focus on one of the disciplines of adventure racing: traditionally mountain biking, orienteering (map and compass navigation), and paddling (canoe or kayak) and will take place at or around Lake Raleigh. Beginners or veterans alike will be in excellent hands with each adventure led by Debra and Jeff Rezeli, experts with over 11 years of adventure racing experience.
Register for each event here.

For those who love a goal to build towards...
The series will build skills in advance of a local practice 3-hour adventure race in May and the option to register and participate in a 5-hour adventure race hosted by Broad Run Offroad on June 13 & 14 at Lake Anna State Park in Spotsylvania, VA.
For more information on adventure racing, check out the US Adventure Racing Association website.

Source: NC State University

title: Making Herbarium Specimens for Science and Art
location: Onsite at Duke Gardens – directions to follow
description:
This interactive program led by Scott LaGreca, Paul J. Kramer Plant Collections Manager at Duke Gardens, will combine the scientific and artistic aspects of plant specimen preservation. Participants will learn the process of creating herbarium specimens, from plant collection and pressing to proper mounting techniques, including exploration of historical practices. Through hands-on activities, attendees will gain an appreciation for both the scientific and aesthetic value of preserved plant specimens in museum collections, and everyone will leave with a prepared plant specimen from the Duke Gardens plant collection. 
Location: Onsite at Duke Gardens. Meeting location will be included in a program reminder email sent the week before the program. 
Fee: $44, 20% discount with Duke Gardens members’ discount code 
Parking: Fees apply. 
Accessibility: This program will take place seated indoors, in a location accessible by fully paved paths.

Source: Sarah P. Duke Gardens

title: Discover Tryon Palace: Outlander
location: Tryon Palace Historic Sites and Gardens
description:
Step into Tryon Palace and explore Diana Gabaldon’s award-winning Outlander series. Learn about the lives of the fictional Jamie and Claire Fraser, their family and friends, and interactions with historical figures and events in the tumultuous period of the American Revolution.

Tour covers storylines from Outlander books 4 – 8 and the Starz Outlander seasons 4 – 8. (For those not current on the books or show, there will be spoilers for these books and seasons.)

Tour begins at 301 George Street, across from the Tryon Palace Main Gates. Ticket holders should check in at the Waystation ticketing desk no later than 3:30 p.m.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Deep Sky Astronomy
location: Haw River State Park - Iron Ore Belt Access
description:
This event is free to attend, but registration is requested. 

Join local astronomers with the Greensboro Astronomy Club as we observe the night skies over the Iron Ore Belt Access. Attendees may expect to see closer-than-typical views of the moon, planets, star clusters, and other celestial objects subject to change with time of year and local sky darkness.

Telescopes and viewing equipment will be set up on site but you may wish to bring your own binoculars or telescope, plus a chair or blanket for seating. Dress for the weather. Flashlights & headlamps should have a red-light option or filter to protect your night vision.

Skywatching sessions may be cancelled at the last minute for weather. Please register at the Register link so you can be emailed in the event of cancellation.

Program equipment and instruction provided by members of the Greensboro Astronomy Club, which meet the third Friday of each month at the Greensboro Science Center. Learn more about their organization here: 

https://greensboroastronomyclub.org/

Star-gazing Etiquette:

Please use a red light at the observing session and keep any light pointed at the ground. As your eyes adapt, a light is not needed at all.Pease do not touch any telescopes or other equipment unless permission is given and form a orderly line behind each telescope. Please do not allow children or pets to run around the observing area. Pets must be on a leash no longer than 6 feet at all times. This is to protect others' safety and the equipment.Stock photo © Pexels / Lucas Pezeta

Source: NC Cultural Resources

All materials will be provided for each participant to create an herbal face mist to take home.

title: Civic Hacking for Affordable Housing
description:
Code with the Carolinas - Triangle
Join volunteers at Code with the Carolinas as we help the [National Zoning Atlas](https://www.zoningatlas.org/) (NZA) team include North Carolina and South Carolina in their nationwide zoning atlas. "The National Zoning Atlas aims to depict key aspects of zoning codes in an online, user-friendly map." The Atlas aims to provide data for better solutions in transportation, environmental, and especially affordable housing policy.

Affordable housing proponents have long recognized zoning policies as barriers to affordable housing. To improve zoning policies, we first need to better understand the current state of zoning across the United States. Code with the Carolinas is helping this cause by joining the National Zoning Atlas to gather zoning data for North and South Carolina.

This is a multi-dimensional project grounded in data science with an end-goal of contributing to a nationally influential dataset. Our current work session activities focus on internet search and integrating data from multiple sources. The project as a whole has occasional opportunities for U/X and outreach and opportunities to learn about machine learning and natural language processing through the work of the NZA team. Volunteering on this project will provide excellent exposure to the foundations of civic data science, with a focus on GIS data.

Even if you're new to this project and/or civic tech volunteering, you're welcome to join the meeting. Visitors are always welcome and no technical skills are needed. You can learn more about the project on our [Slack Workspace](https://join.slack.com/t/codeforthecarolinas/shared_invite/zt-1kxuwu05x-3KxOpkOYjAuN5yuOAH8ROg) in the #project-zoning-atlas channel.

Meetings start with brief introductions. New volunteers are offered a personal orientation, often in a breakout room, while experienced volunteers get right to work. By the end of the session, both groups of volunteers are working together. We also contribute to the project through asynchronous work and informal work sessions.

Meetings are on the Jitsi platform and the link is provided before each meeting. If you will be joining on mobile, install the Jitsi app in advance [https://jitsi.org/downloads/](https://jitsi.org/downloads/) .

Learn more at [codewiththecarolinas.org](codeforthecarolinas.org) or reach out to info@codewiththecarolinas.org

All activities of Code with the Carolinas, a project of [Social Good Fund](https://www.socialgoodfund.org/), follow our [Code of Conduct](https://share.mailbox.org/ajax/share/0d32d5f905f8fd49d5e80395f8fd47f2b59ce3ef8b335f72/1/8/Nzg/NzgvMTkx) and are subject to this [Volunteer Waiver of Liability](https://share.mailbox.org/ajax/share/06dd62200e6b28426b137e0e6b2848fb901487014f72cd16/1/8/Nzg/NzgvMTE2).

title: Responding to Narcissism
description:
Have you ever wondered why your relationship has changed from feeling perfect to full of criticism and devaluation? Do you feel like you are walking on eggshells? This training will demystify narcissism and discuss its deep impact on relationships. Additionally, this session will help you understand the stages of narcissism, common manipulation maneuvers and solutions for responding and healing. Key skills addressed will be setting boundaries, staying calm, and managing the conversation.

Workshop Objectives:

• Define narcissism
• Recognize the two faces of narcissistic behavior
• Understand the relationship cycle
• Identify common manipulation tactics
• Navigate the path to healing and empowerment

title: Plein Air Watercolor: Exploring Greens in the Landscape
location: Onsite at Duke Gardens – directions to follow
description:
Join us for a watercolor plein air painting workshop set amid the lush beauty of the public garden with artist Ryann Carey.   This class focuses on capturing the many shades and subtleties of green found in nature. Students will learn how to mix naturalistic greens and create depth and variation within a monochromatic landscape. All levels welcome; bring your own materials.  Suggested supply list includes: basic multicolor paint set, palette or plastic plate, brushes, water container, paper towel or rag, watercolor paper or block (of a size that is comfortable for you without a table), pencil, eraser, tape (if not using a block) and optional painting board. 
Fee: $58 (materials not included); 20% discount for Duke Gardens members with discount code. 
Parking: Fees apply. 
Location: Onsite at Duke Gardens. Meeting location will be included in a program reminder email sent the week before the program.
 
Accessibility: This will be a small group program that takes place outdoors and traveling on a combination of paved and unpaved paths with some uneven surfaces and moderate inclines. You will be responsible for carrying your own supplies.

title: Forest Bathing Walk
location: Onsite at Duke Gardens – directions to follow
description:
Come discover the regenerative power of mindful engagement with nature with certified forest therapy guide Stephanie Campbell. The Japanese tradition of Shinrin-Yoku, forest bathing, is a practice using all your senses to connect with nature. Many studies have found it to help decrease stress, increase immune system functioning and improve concentration, creativity and mood. In a slow-paced, two-hour session, Stephanie will offer a sequence of gentle invitations designed to help you immerse yourself in a deeper connection with nature, ending with a forest-based tea. 
Fee: $32; 20% discount for Duke Gardens members with discount code.

title: Goldston America 250 Film Series
description:
Join the Chatham Community Library for this Goldston America 250 Film Series, hosted every fourth Tuesday, January-December 2026, 4pm-6pm. America 250’s mission is to honor and commemorate the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence, marking America’s Semiquincentennial. The Goldston Library will screen the following documentaries and films:

Tue, Jan 27, 4pm-6pm The Congress, Ken Burns.
Tue, Feb 24, 4pm-6pm Becoming Frederick Douglass, Stanley Nelson and Nicole London.
Tue, Mar 24, 4pm-6pm Rachel Carson: The Woman Who Launched the Modern Environmental Movement, Michelle Ferrari.
Tue, Apr 28, 4pm-6pm Thomas Jefferson: A View from the Mountain, Martin Doblmeier.
Tue, May 26, 4pm-6pm The Address, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jun 23, 4pm-6pm The Brooklyn Bridge, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jul 28, 4pm-6pm The Statue of Liberty, Ken Burns.
Tue, Aug 25, 4pm-6pm American Coup: Wilmington 1898, Yoruba Richen and Brad Lichtenstein.
Tue, Sep 22, 4pm-6pm How it Feels to be Free, Yoruba Richen.
Tue, Oct 27, 4pm-6pm 80 Years Later, Celine Parreñas Shimizu.
Tue, Nov 24, 4pm-6pm Gather, Sanjay Rawal.
Tue, Dec 22, 4pm-6pm Women of World War II: The Untold Stories, Eli Brown.

This FREE, family-friendly event is open to the public. No registration is required. The event will take place indoors in the Goldston Library. The Goldston Library is ADA-compliant, including wheelchair-accessible parking, entrances, seating, common spaces, walkways, and restrooms. Free parking is available outside the library. Pets are not allowed - please leave your furry friends at home.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Breathing Techniques to Relieve Stress and Improve Health
description:
Stress can compromise healthy breathing habits, but practicing breath work can reduce anxiety, encourage sleep, and in some cases, lower blood pressure. Participants will experience a variety of quick, easy breathing techniques during this course, and share back their results.

 

Workshop Objectives
Participants in this training will:
• Try a 60-Second Breathing Meditation
• Practice Box Breathing
• Experience 4-7-8 Breathing
• Review some other Intentional Breathing techniques

title: Dr. M.T. Pope House Presents: Evelyn's Book Club
description:
This program honors Evelyn Pope by reading books. 

Evelyn, a college librarian born in 1908 and died in 1995, loved a variety of books from The Adventures of Tom Sawyer to Shakespeare and James Baldwin. The program brings community members together monthly at the museum to discuss books, focusing on works by Black writers or featuring Black subjects, including fiction and non-fiction. Discussions will use questions to facilitate conversation.

"Mama Day" by Gloria Naylor
Wednesday, Feb. 25
 "The Black Angels: The Untold Story of the Nurses Who Helped Cure Tuberculosis" by Maria Smilios
Wednesday, April 22
 "A Visitation of Spirits" by Randall Kenan
Wednesday, June 24
 "Becoming Lunsford Lane: The Lives of an American Aeneas" by Craig Friend
Wednesday, Aug. 26
 "Ring Shout" by P. Dejeli Clark
Thursday, Oct. 29Registration opens Jan. 23.  An optional book bundle will be available to purchase at registration. Books can be picked up at the Dr. M.T. Pope House Museum.

title: Financial Planning for Life
description:
Financial goals are the specific long- and short-term objectives to be attained through financial planning and management efforts. Among personal financial goals are things such as 1) financial security 2) travel 3) education planning 4) retirement planning and 5) estate planning. Being able to succeed in reaching these goals requires a structure and plan with appropriate milestones, along with the ability to make adjustments along the way.

 

Workshop Objectives
At the end of this workshop, you will be able to:
• Understand the importance of having realistic financial goals clearly defined
• Recognize the importance of managing your finances to address these goals
• Develop achievable steps to stay on track
• Take appropriate action to monitor progress toward the goals and make adjustments as needed.

title: Bald Eagle Search Paddle with Two Sisters Adventure Company
description:
Join Two Sisters Adventure Company for a Bald Eagle Search Paddle at Jordan Lake State Recreation Area, hosted on select dates throughout 2026. Jordan Lake is one of the best Bald Eagle viewing locations in the region. You will paddle past multiple nesting areas in search of our majestic national bird. While sightings are not guaranteed, Bald Eagles are most common in the areas they visit. Your guide will help you identify and answer questions about Bald Eagles and other birds in the area. All participants should have basic kayaking skills, due to the duration on the water this trip is considered intermediate. Pre-registration is required. Participants will launch from the Farrington Point Access. The trip will last approximately 4 hours. Trips will take place on the following dates:

Thu, Mar 26, 9am-1pm.Sun, Apr 26, 8:30am-12:30pm.Sat, May 9, 8am-12pm.Sat, May 30, 8am-12pm.Sun, Jun 7, 8am-12pm.Two Sisters works with all guests to make trips as accessible as possible. Please contact them with any specific accessibility requests so they can ensure they have all the necessary equipment and staff. Free parking is available at the Farrington Point Canoe Launch. No pets are allowed. The cost is $60 per person, and pre-registration is required. Single-person kayaks are provided. Participants ages 15 and older are welcome.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events. See more Chatham Sports Alliance events.

Two Sisters acknowledges that the land on which this camp takes place is the ancestral land of the Skaruhreh/Tuscarora, Lumbee, Mánu: Yį Įsuwą (Catawba), Occaneechi, Shakori, and Cheraw Nations. As a part of their mission, they honor and respect the history and significance this land holds for these Nations’ past, present, and future. To find out more about the Native People and Lands where you live and recreate, visit this map.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Native Plant Solutions: Fall Forward Perennials
description:
Does your landscape look tired near the end of summer? Give yourself and the wildlife around you a boost with fall-forward perennials. At their peak during late summer and fall, these species have unique charms and an important ecological role. They give pollinators the resources they need before transitioning to the next stage of development. The superstars of autumn, asters and goldenrods, are keystone species that lend outsized support to food webs. They and other fall-forward plants extend the season visually and offer a rich tapestry of color and radiance optimized for the changing angle of the sun. Join Shannon Currey, education and outreach at Izel Native Plants, to learn more about lighting up your landscape with fall in mind! 
Fee: Free; registration required. 
Location: Zoom. The recording will be shared with all registrants. 
Accessibility: This will be a virtual program that takes place on Zoom with the option to enable closed captioning.

Source: Sarah P. Duke Gardens

title: Resiliency: Bouncing Back After a Setback
description:
Certain individuals appear to succeed against all odds. Despite severe hardships such as living through war, witnessing the death of a loved one, having a chronic illness, being a victim of abuse or dealing with unemployment, certain people not only adapt but actually thrive. These people possess a quality known as “resilience.” This workshop will examine the characteristics of resilience and discover ways to introduce greater resilience into our lives.

 

Workshop Objectives
At the end of this workshop, you will be able to:
Describe what resilience really is
• Describe the concept of resilience as it relates to children and adults
• Describe the characteristics of resilient people
• Describe how emotional control, self-awareness and strong relationships relate to resiliency
Identify your own resilient capacities
• Identify you unique resilient strengths and areas for development
• Recognize which situations are most stressful
Describe resilience building strategies
• Describe techniques to enhance resilience through changing your perception, taking decisive action and engaging in appropriate self-care.

 

Click on Carolina Talent registration link and select the “Request” button to automatically enroll.

title: Agentic AI in Action: 10-Minute Demo Spotlights from the Frontier Q2
description:
Data Science Raleigh
Explore the real-world impact of Agentic AI in our fast-paced, insight-packed virtual showcase. Each 10-minute session features a live demo from a leading innovator in the Agentic AI space—highlighting practical applications, dynamic workflows, and tangible business outcomes.

This isn't just another pitch session. It’s a curated look at how agent-based systems are driving intelligent automation, adaptive planning, and cross-functional orchestration across industries. You’ll meet the minds behind these technologies and see firsthand how they’re redefining what's possible in enterprise AI.

**What You'll Learn:**

1️⃣ **Autonomous Workflows:** See how agentic systems plan, coordinate, and execute complex tasks across tools and teams.

2️⃣ **Dynamic Decisioning:** Explore examples of contextual reasoning, goal alignment, and memory-enhanced agents in action.

3️⃣**Practical Integration:** Understand what it takes to embed agentic AI into your stack—without overhauling everything.

Engage live with founders and builders shaping the future of autonomous enterprise solutions.

You’re short on time but deep on curiosity. This format respects both—cutting straight to the tech and the teams behind it. No filler, no fluff. Just signal.

**[Register here](https://hubs.ly/Q042cVj20)**

title: Ashe County America 250th Celebration
description:
Come celebrate the 250th anniversary of the founding of the United States on the grounds of the Museum of Ashe County History.

On this day, set aside to celebrate, learn, and reflect, visitors will have the opportunity to chat with living historians about the American Revolution, see craft demonstrations, enjoy children's activities, and listen to historic lectures.

At 11 a.m. the Daniel Boone Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution will read the Declaration of Independence. Later that day, at 1 p.m., historian Michael C. Hardy will give a lecture on his newest book, "Western North Carolina and Eastern Tennessee and the American Revolution."

Visitors are encouraged to tour the exhibits within the Museum of Ashe County History to learn more about their local heritage.

This event is FREE and open to the public.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Almost Summer Tree Trek
location: Onsite at Duke Gardens – directions to follow
description:
Join tree expert Matt Archibald, ISA board-certified master arborist at Leaf & Limb, for a walk to wonder at the beauty of trees and learn fascinating facts about various species, their ecological importance and their role in our environment. 
Matt Archibald is a huge nerd for trees and nature. He is an ISA Board Certified Master Arborist, Tree Risk Assessment Qualified and a veteran in the industry for 12 years and counting. Coming from a rock-climbing background, Matt discovered his passion and purpose in life when he started learning about trees and their ever-expanding universe of information. The more we learn, the more we realize how little we know! 
Fee: $24; free for Duke Gardens members with discount code. 
Parking: Fees apply. 
Location: Onsite at Duke Gardens. Meeting location will be included in a program reminder email sent the week before the program. 
Accessibility: This will be a small group program that takes place outdoors traveling on a combination of paved and unpaved paths with some uneven surfaces and moderate inclines.

Source: Sarah P. Duke Gardens

title: Bald Eagle Search Paddle with Two Sisters Adventure Company
description:
Join Two Sisters Adventure Company for a Bald Eagle Search Paddle at Jordan Lake State Recreation Area, hosted on select dates throughout 2026. Jordan Lake is one of the best Bald Eagle viewing locations in the region. You will paddle past multiple nesting areas in search of our majestic national bird. While sightings are not guaranteed, Bald Eagles are most common in the areas they visit. Your guide will help you identify and answer questions about Bald Eagles and other birds in the area. All participants should have basic kayaking skills, due to the duration on the water this trip is considered intermediate. Pre-registration is required. Participants will launch from the Farrington Point Access. The trip will last approximately 4 hours. Trips will take place on the following dates:

Thu, Mar 26, 9am-1pm.Sun, Apr 26, 8:30am-12:30pm.Sat, May 9, 8am-12pm.Sat, May 30, 8am-12pm.Sun, Jun 7, 8am-12pm.Two Sisters works with all guests to make trips as accessible as possible. Please contact them with any specific accessibility requests so they can ensure they have all the necessary equipment and staff. Free parking is available at the Farrington Point Canoe Launch. No pets are allowed. The cost is $60 per person, and pre-registration is required. Single-person kayaks are provided. Participants ages 15 and older are welcome.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events. See more Chatham Sports Alliance events.

Two Sisters acknowledges that the land on which this camp takes place is the ancestral land of the Skaruhreh/Tuscarora, Lumbee, Mánu: Yį Įsuwą (Catawba), Occaneechi, Shakori, and Cheraw Nations. As a part of their mission, they honor and respect the history and significance this land holds for these Nations’ past, present, and future. To find out more about the Native People and Lands where you live and recreate, visit this map.

title: Flags of the American Revolution
description:
The 250th Anniversary of our great nation is upon us, and there are many aspects of our history that we may not know.   For example, our American flag has evolved and changed many times over the years.  Have you ever wondered what our very first flag looked like, and how and why it changed during the time of our American Revolution?  Members of the New Bern Chapter of the Sons of the American Revolution will display and share some of the exciting history behind our flag, as well as other interesting information, during their presentation on June 8, 2026, at 4:30 pm.  For more information, please contact us at 252-566-3772 or at lagrange@neuselibrary.org.

title: Mental Fitness for Optimal Brain Power
description:
For a long time, the scientific community believed we were born with a certain number of brain cells and neural pathways and that, once damaged, they could not be repaired. In reality, our brains are much more flexible. Depending on our lifestyle, we can weaken or destroy connections, or create new, stronger ones. Engaging regularly in certain behaviors and activities, like physical exercise, addressing mental health issues, meditation, and learning a new language or musical instrument, support new wiring and can make existing pathways stronger. Essentially, we can slow down or somewhat prevent cognitive decline by doing challenging mental exercises to keep our brains fit for optimal power.

 

Workshop Objectives
At the end of this workshop, you will be able to:
Identify traits of a healthy brain:
• The ability to learn new skills
• Judgment and intuition
• Memory and perception
Identify barriers to good brain health:
• Depression
• Chronic stress
• Unhealthy lifestyle
Identify methods for optimal cognitive health:
• Engaging in new skills and mentally challenging activities
• Meditation
• Physical exercise
• Brain training

title: Webinar: 7(a) Manufacturers’ Access to Revolving Credit Loans
description:
Join NC State Industry Expansion Solutions for a webinar that will focus on the Small Business Administration's (SBA) new 7(a) Manufacturers’ Access to Revolving Credit (MARC) Loans.

MARC is SBA’s first-ever loan program dedicated to supporting America’s small manufacturers, which make up 98% of all U.S. manufacturers. The program will offer working capital for small businesses engaged in manufacturing and is specifically designed to provide maximum flexibility and minimal red tape.

MARC complements the SBA’s core 7(a) and 504 loan programs, providing a flexible new line of credit to manufacturers and lenders. MARC loans can be used in combination with SBA and conventional commercial loans, making it a potent new tool in support of SBA's effort to reshore American industrial dominance.

Source: NC State University

title: Siler City History Club
description:
Join the Chatham County Historical Association for the Siler City History Club on every second Thursday of the month, 10:30am-11:30am at First Baptist Church. The Chatham County Historical Association needs your help in learning about the rich and colorful history of Siler City! They have facts and figures, but they need to hear your own memories of Siler to really understand one of Chatham County’s most important cities. Come share your memories, stories, photos, mementos, and other Siler City treasures. Light refreshments will be served. This event is free, and everyone is welcome! No registration is required.

This event takes place indoors. First Baptist Church in Siler City is ADA-accessible. No pets allowed. Please leave your furry friends at home. Free parking is available next to the church.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events. See more events hosted by The Chatham Historical Association.

title: Connecting Mind and Body for Healthy Living
description:
Your body responds to the way you think, feel and act. This is often called the “mind/body connection.” When you are stressed, anxious or upset, your body tries to tell you that something isn’t right. For example, high blood pressure might develop after a particularly stressful event, such as the death of a loved one. People with good emotional health are aware of their thoughts, feelings and behaviors. They have learned healthy ways to cope with the stress and problems that are a normal part of life. They feel good about themselves and have healthy relationships. Poor emotional health can weaken your body’s immune system, making you more likely to get colds and other infections during emotionally difficult times. Also, when you are feeling stressed, anxious or upset, you may not take care of your health as well as you should. You may not feel like exercising, eating nutritious foods or taking medicine that your doctor prescribes. Abuse of alcohol, tobacco or other drugs may also be a sign of poor emotional health.

 

Workshop Objectives
At the end of this workshop, you will be able to:
Identify the relationship between mind and body
• Describe how the body influences emotional and mental functioning
• Describe how our emotions, beliefs and self talk impact our body
• Identify symptoms of a possible mind/body disconnection
Identify ways to enhance the mind/body connection
• Describe methods for achieving balance in life
• Identify ways to express feelings appropriately
• Describe the importance of taking care of your health
• Describe ways to enhance awareness
Identify your personal action plan for mind/body connection
• Recognize the importance of consulting with your physician
• Describe which mind/body tools need to develop
• List outside resources for further help

title: Become a Certified Bike Safety Leader
description:
NC State Transportation is thrilled to host a three-day League Cycling Instructor (LCI) Seminar from June 19 to June 21, led by experienced League Cycling Coach Leta Highsmith. This intensive training empowers prospective educators to master the League of American Bicyclists’ Smart Cycling curriculum, preparing them to teach riders of all ages to navigate traffic confidently, handle their bikes safely and ride legally.

Participants must complete the Smart Cycling Complete class and purchase an individual League of American Bicyclists membership as prerequisites for the class.

Spaces are limited, so please register by May 21 to secure your spot for the seminar. Visit the NC State Transportation webpage for more information or contact Demar Bonnemere at demar_bonnemere@ncsu.edu  with any questions.

title: Goldston America 250 Film Series
description:
Join the Chatham Community Library for this Goldston America 250 Film Series, hosted every fourth Tuesday, January-December 2026, 4pm-6pm. America 250’s mission is to honor and commemorate the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence, marking America’s Semiquincentennial. The Goldston Library will screen the following documentaries and films:

Tue, Jan 27, 4pm-6pm The Congress, Ken Burns.
Tue, Feb 24, 4pm-6pm Becoming Frederick Douglass, Stanley Nelson and Nicole London.
Tue, Mar 24, 4pm-6pm Rachel Carson: The Woman Who Launched the Modern Environmental Movement, Michelle Ferrari.
Tue, Apr 28, 4pm-6pm Thomas Jefferson: A View from the Mountain, Martin Doblmeier.
Tue, May 26, 4pm-6pm The Address, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jun 23, 4pm-6pm The Brooklyn Bridge, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jul 28, 4pm-6pm The Statue of Liberty, Ken Burns.
Tue, Aug 25, 4pm-6pm American Coup: Wilmington 1898, Yoruba Richen and Brad Lichtenstein.
Tue, Sep 22, 4pm-6pm How it Feels to be Free, Yoruba Richen.
Tue, Oct 27, 4pm-6pm 80 Years Later, Celine Parreñas Shimizu.
Tue, Nov 24, 4pm-6pm Gather, Sanjay Rawal.
Tue, Dec 22, 4pm-6pm Women of World War II: The Untold Stories, Eli Brown.

This FREE, family-friendly event is open to the public. No registration is required. The event will take place indoors in the Goldston Library. The Goldston Library is ADA-compliant, including wheelchair-accessible parking, entrances, seating, common spaces, walkways, and restrooms. Free parking is available outside the library. Pets are not allowed - please leave your furry friends at home.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Supporting Employee Well-Being: What can you do as a manager?
description:
Organizations are investing in benefits to improve employee wellbeing, and taking on initiatives to foster a culture of wellbeing in the workplace. However, many employees still feel that their job is an obstacle to their wellbeing rather than a help. What can you do as a manager to shift that perception? This session will discuss practical ways to show employees that you and your organization support their wellbeing.

 

Workshop Objectives
This training will help you:
• Describe ways in which a manager can promote employee wellbeing
• Become an advocate for wellbeing resources available to your employees
• Have productive conversations with employees to address concerns that work is negatively impacting their wellbeing
• Lead by example in demonstrating that you place a high priority on your own wellbeing

 

Click on Carolina Talent registration link and select the “Request” button to automatically enroll.

Source: UNC Chapel Hill

title: Wildflower & Pollinator ID Hike
description:
In honor of National Pollinator Week, join a ranger at Boone Fork Parking Area (milepost 299.9 on the Blue Ridge Parkway) for a wildflower and pollinator ID hike along the Upper Boone Fork Trail. Learn how to ID some common blooming wildflower species of the high country, and some local pollinator species that keep those flowers blooming every year. 

This 1.5 mile easy hike does have some tree roots and rocks to walk over, so please wear appropriate hiking shoes and dress for the weather.

There are no bathrooms at Boone Fork Parking Area.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Midday Meander
location: Onsite at Duke Gardens – directions to follow
description:
Join Kavanah Anderson, director of learning and community engagement at Duke Gardens, for a conversational stroll in the garden that deepens your relationship with plants. Swap plant stories, dig into horticultural history, question what you know and practice multisensory observation on a playful amble through the Gardens that delights and disrupts your understanding of what a garden can be. Expect to learn from each other, share what you know and leave with more questions than you started with. 
Fee: Free; registration required. 
Parking: Parking fees apply. 
Location: Onsite at Duke Gardens. Meeting location will be included in a program reminder email sent before the program. 
Accessibility: This will be a small group program that takes place outdoors, and participants will travel on a combination of paved and unpaved paths with some uneven surfaces and moderate inclines.

Source: Sarah P. Duke Gardens

title: Dr. M.T. Pope House Presents: Evelyn's Book Club
description:
This program honors Evelyn Pope by reading books. 

Evelyn, a college librarian born in 1908 and died in 1995, loved a variety of books from The Adventures of Tom Sawyer to Shakespeare and James Baldwin. The program brings community members together monthly at the museum to discuss books, focusing on works by Black writers or featuring Black subjects, including fiction and non-fiction. Discussions will use questions to facilitate conversation.

"Mama Day" by Gloria Naylor
Wednesday, Feb. 25
 "The Black Angels: The Untold Story of the Nurses Who Helped Cure Tuberculosis" by Maria Smilios
Wednesday, April 22
 "A Visitation of Spirits" by Randall Kenan
Wednesday, June 24
 "Becoming Lunsford Lane: The Lives of an American Aeneas" by Craig Friend
Wednesday, Aug. 26
 "Ring Shout" by P. Dejeli Clark
Thursday, Oct. 29Registration opens Jan. 23.  An optional book bundle will be available to purchase at registration. Books can be picked up at the Dr. M.T. Pope House Museum.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Tours of the Moravian Archives Vault--America 250 Theme
description:
Join us for a tour of the Moravian Archives Vault featuring the collection materials from the Revolutionary War and early American History!

Guests will walk through the Archives Vault which contains millions of records from the settlement of the Moravians here in North Carolina in the 1750s on. Highlighted items will include correspondence from George Washington, the Fourth of July Proclamation, maps, congressional records and much, much more!

Learn about Moravian History and the creation of our nation while seeing how such collection materials are preserved for our posterity!

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Avery County Heritage Festival
description:
The Avery County Heritage Festival commemorates the history and heritage of our county including the genealogies of our Avery County families.  Traditional craftsmen will demonstrate pioneer life.  Entertainment is provided by local musicians playing traditional bluegrass and gospel selections.  Food and craft vendors will be onsite also.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Pioneer Heritage Festival in Waynesville, NC
description:
The Pioneer Heritage Festival will promote Haywood County's early pioneer history.  Heritage demonstrations will be held on the grounds of the Shelton House Museum with artisans showcasing the skills that were needed for daily living in the early 1800s.  Exhibits depicting North Carolina's role in the American Revolution will be on display in the Shelton House barn.  Members of SAR and DAR will be onsite to help visitors learn how to identify ancestors who fought in the American Revolution.  The Festival is free and includes food trucks, live music, activities for kids, and Shelton House Museum tours.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Chatham Celebrates America 250: Cumulative Celebration
description:
July 4, 2026, marks 250 years since the signing of the Declaration of Independence. Join Chatham Celebrates America 250 in recognizing the Semiquincentennial during our

July 4, 2026, marks 250 years since the signing of the Declaration of Independence. Join Chatham Celebrates America 250 in recognizing the Semiquincentennial during our Cumulative Celebration on Sat, Jun 27, 2026, 10am-2pm. Admission is free. Together, we’ll remember the events that have shaped our history, reflect on the present, and envision a promising future for the next generation.

Festivities will include live music and performances, food trucks, vendors, displays and demonstrations, activities for children, and much more. If you are interested in participating, volunteering, or getting involved in other ways, please contact Lindsay Ray at lindsay.ray@chathamcountync.gov or 919.545.8302.

This free, family-friendly event takes place indoors at the Chatham County Agriculture & Conference Center (CCACC). Shuttle services will be provided by Chatham Transit. CCACC is an ADA-compliant space, featuring wheelchair-accessible parking, entrances, shared spaces, and walkways. Since most of the festivities will take place indoors, this event will not be pet-friendly. Please leave your furry friends at home. Service animals are welcome.

See more America 250 events. Learn more on the Chatham Celebrates America 250 Microsite. See more events at the Chatham County Agriculture & Conference Center.

America 250 NC is North Carolina's commemoration planning organization responsible for leading the initiative and collaborating with various local, state, and federal partners.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: NCMA Community Day
description:
Celebrate Knowing the West and the America 250 commemoration with a free, family-friendly day of artmaking, performances, and community connection at the North Carolina Museum of Art. Enjoy hands-on art activities inspired by Western North Carolina craft traditions, live music, and creative demonstrations from regional artists. Explore the exhibition Knowing the West through guided tours, family-friendly activities, and opportunities to engage with artists and partners from across the state.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Independence Day Celebrations at Island Farm
description:
Celebrate Independence Day and the nation’s Semiquincentennial with Island Farm! On Saturday, July 4, 2026, from 9 a.m. until 3 p.m., Island Farm will host visitors to celebrate the holiday. Attendees are encouraged to bring a picnic lunch to enjoy on the Farm’s grassy lawn, and continue celebrations of the nation’s birth with musket-fire, traditional games, a reading of the Declaration of Independence, and much more.

A living history farm, Island Farm is a tangible glimpse into coastal history, and the realities of life on Roanoke Island in the mid-1800’s. Admission to the site is $11, and children 3 and under are admitted for free. The site is located at 1140 N US Highway 64, north of Manteo on Roanoke Island.

Island Farm is owned and operated by Outer Banks Conservationists, a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization founded in 1980 to protect important natural, cultural, and historic resources along North Carolina’s Outer Banks through education and conservation.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Independence Day
description:
Militia muster demonstration on the Courthouse Green at 9:30 Courthouse open for free from 11:00-2:00. Sign your very own copy of the Declaration of Independence.

title: July 4th Capitol Celebration, North Carolina State Capitol
description:
The gathering at the N.C. State Capitol will celebrate Independence Day and America’s Semiquincentennial. The free, fun-filled family event will feature musical performances, historic interpreters, hand-on activities and exhibits, a reading of the Declaration of Independence, and a naturalization ceremony, which is held each year at the Capitol. More information on this event will be announced soon.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Independence Day Celebration
description:
Celebrate Independence Day with the Museum of the Waxhaws from 12–4 PM as we honor America’s 250th anniversary in true patriotic fashion!

Watch for us in the Town of Waxhaw’s July 4th Parade, then follow us back to the museum for an afternoon filled with living history, special presentations, and hands-on demonstrations. Experience a powerful reading of the Declaration of Independence, enjoy kids’ crafts, and take part in family-friendly activities that bring our nation’s story to life.

There’s no better way to celebrate 250 years of freedom, sacrifice, and independence!

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Independence Day Celebration
description:
Musket firing, living-history demonstrations, and a special reading of the Declaration of Independence will combine to make this a Fourth of July to remember in the historic town of Halifax!  Continue the fun with the Town of Halifax’s celebration that afternoon and enjoy the annual fireworks display, at dark on the Halifax County Courthouse lawn. Free.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: City of Wilmington 4th of July Celebration
description:
City of Wilmington's family friendly event will include music featuring the Wilmington Symphony Orchestra, other entertainment, kids activities, food, fireworks & more!

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Fourth of July Symphony Pops Concert
description:
CELEBRATING MUSIC THROUGH 250 YEARS AND BEYOND!

Celebrate the Fourth of July with a spectacular family-friendly concert at the Live Oak Bank Pavilion, featuring the Wilmington Symphony Orchestra (WSO) and special guests.

Highlights of the evening include guest appearances, patriotic favorites, pops, classics, and spectacular fireworks display.

Fireworks will start at 9:00 p.m., launched from a barge at the convergence of the Cape Fear and Northeast Cape Fear Rivers, just north of the park. This concert is FREE to attend!

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Red, White, and Blue Bash
description:
Join the City of Sanford for a fun-filled evening at Red, White, and Blue Bash as we celebrate Independence Day in style! Enjoy live performances from incredible bands, indulge in a variety of tasty treats from local food trucks, and wrap up the night with a breathtaking fireworks show. It's an event for all ages, perfect for making memories with family and friends as we come together to honor freedom and enjoy the summer night!

Downtown Techies: Durham
Hey Techies!

We are so excited to see you all again! Heads up! for the summer months we are merging all of our events into an event once a month on the first Tuesday of every month!

Don't forget to RSVP for first round free!!

title: NC Public Librarian Certification Commission
location: State Library of North Carolina , M48
description:
The NC Public Librarian Certification Commission was formed in 1936 to set minimum standards for public librarians to protect and maintain public library resources, to assure professional management and administration of library services, to meet the personnel requirements for State Aid administered by the State Library of NC, and to guarantee the best possible public library service to all North Carolinians.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: NC Public Librarian Certification Commission Meeting
location: North Carolina State Library of Accessible Books and Library Services, Room 308
description:
NC Public Librarian Certification Commission Meeting

The North Carolina Public Librarian Certification Commission was formed in 1936 to set minimum standards for public librarians to protect and maintain public library resources, to assure professional management and administration of library services, to meet the personnel requirements for State Aid administered by the State Library of NC, and to guarantee the best possible public library service to all North Carolinians. Commission meetings are held quarterly to review applications and discuss Certification policies and procedures. 

For information about the NC Public Librarian Certification Commission, please visit https://slnc.info/PLCC.

July 10, 2026, 1:00 pm - 4:00 pm

title: Sunday Yoga at Trophy
description:
Outdoor Flow Yogis
**S﻿unday Yoga** classes take place monthly at [Trophy Brewing](https://www.trophybrewing.com/brewery-taproom)'s Maywood location. Join us inside the brewery or out on the lawn for a 60-minute yoga flow for all experience levels. Beginners welcome! Bring your mat and any props you like to use.

Registration includes one drink ticket, so stick around after class to enjoy a Trophy pint or non-alcoholic beverage and relax with the crew—great way to start your Sunday FUNday.

Cost: $22 cash/venmo at the door or reserve online [here](https://trophysundayyoga2026.eventbrite.com/).

title: Ranger Workshop - Stream Ecology
description:
Join us as we hike down to Otter Falls (1.2 miles round trip) to learn about how living and non-living things interact in mountain streams. What are all of those insects and other critters swimming and crawling through the creek? We will catch and identify what type of creature they are and what these species could tell us about water quality. Nets will be provided. Any participants wanting to get into the stream should bring clothes and shoes that can get wet and a towel to dry off. Make sure to bring water for the hike! No pets please. This is a Ranger Workshop with The Town of Seven Devils.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Institutional Biosafety Committee Meetings
description:
The Institutional Biosafety Committee (IBC) invites the NC State community to attend our virtual meetings. The IBC provides assurance that the potential impacts associated with the intended use of biological organisms at NC State have been appropriately evaluated.

To receive the meeting link and additional meeting details, please contact Brenda L. Mickens at (919) 515-4190.

Source: NC State University

title: Succession Planning Webinar
description:
Retirements, skills gaps, and turnover are hitting manufacturing and other industries harder than ever. Join NC State Industry Expansion Solutions for a webinar that will outline for employers how to map critical roles, capture institutional knowledge and build a pipeline of skilled workers. You'll learn practical tools and strategies to protect your operations and prepare your company’s next generation of leaders. You should attend the webinar if you are:

A manufacturing or other employer/ownerAn executiveA plant/training managerAn HR leader who needs to prepare for retirements, turnover and talent shortagesParticipants will learn to:

Identify and develop future leaders within your organizationRetain critical skills and knowledge before they walk out the doorCreate a succession plan that aligns with their business goals and growthAddress unique workforce challenges in manufacturing, including skills gaps and demographic shifts

Source: NC State University

location: Lake Norman State Park-Swim Beach Parking Lot
description:
Twinkle twinkle little stars, how I wonder what you look like? Piedmont Amateur Astronomers are coming out to the swim beach parking lot to show us the stars through their telescopes! Astronomy based games and crafts will be set up during the event. In the event of rain, this event will be held on the following Saturday. Meet at the swim beach parking lot.

title: Solar Astronomy
location: Haw River State Park - Iron Ore Belt Access
description:
Drop in between 1-3pm at The Iron Ore Belt Access to join Greensboro Astronomy Club members as we observe our planetÕs nearest star using special solar viewing equipment. Please dress for hot, sunny weather! NOTE: Program will be cancelled in the case of cloudy skies/rainy weather. Sign up at the Register link to be emailed in case of cancellation.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Discover Tryon Palace: Outlander
location: Tryon Palace Historic Sites and Gardens
description:
Step into Tryon Palace and explore Diana Gabaldon’s award-winning Outlander series. Learn about the lives of the fictional Jamie and Claire Fraser, their family and friends, and interactions with historical figures and events in the tumultuous period of the American Revolution.

Tour covers storylines from Outlander books 4 – 8 and the Starz Outlander seasons 4 – 8. (For those not current on the books or show, there will be spoilers for these books and seasons.)

Tour begins at 301 George Street, across from the Tryon Palace Main Gates. Ticket holders should check in at the Waystation ticketing desk no later than 3:30 p.m.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Alexander County Independence Celebration
description:
Mark your calendar for the Alexander County Independence Celebration on Saturday, July 18, at 7:00 p.m. with music and fireworks! The Extraordinaires will perform on the Rotary Performance Stage at Alexander County Courthouse Park. Fireworks will follow at approximately 9:30 p.m. at Alexander Central High School. Funded in part by an America 250 NC grant, a program of the NC Department of Natural & Cultural Resources.

title: Dr. M.T. Pope House Presents: Evelyn's Book Club
description:
This program honors Evelyn Pope by reading books. 

Evelyn, a college librarian born in 1908 and died in 1995, loved a variety of books from The Adventures of Tom Sawyer to Shakespeare and James Baldwin. The program brings community members together monthly at the museum to discuss books, focusing on works by Black writers or featuring Black subjects, including fiction and non-fiction. Discussions will use questions to facilitate conversation.

"Mama Day" by Gloria Naylor
Wednesday, Feb. 25
 "The Black Angels: The Untold Story of the Nurses Who Helped Cure Tuberculosis" by Maria Smilios
Wednesday, April 22
 "A Visitation of Spirits" by Randall Kenan
Wednesday, June 24
 "Becoming Lunsford Lane: The Lives of an American Aeneas" by Craig Friend
Wednesday, Aug. 26
 "Ring Shout" by P. Dejeli Clark
Thursday, Oct. 29Registration opens Jan. 23.  An optional book bundle will be available to purchase at registration. Books can be picked up at the Dr. M.T. Pope House Museum.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Getting Colonial Clean in the Historical Park
description:
How did colonists prepare their households for the seasons? What was bathing and hygiene like? How did soldiers clean their wool uniforms? How were plants and herbs used to freshen things up? Join our costumed interpreters as they demonstrate practices of cleanliness in the 18th and 19th centuries. FREE. All ages welcome. Drop-in.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Small Arms Demonstration 10:30am & 2:30pm
description:
Learn about one of the small arms (musket, flintlock, or rifle) that a soldier stationed at Fort Macon would have carried and used.

This will include a blank firing demonstration of the weapon.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: DEEP DIVE INTO HISTORY The Root of the Problem: 18th Century Dentistry
location: North Carolina Maritime Museum at Southport
description:
Join us as we delve into the enlightenment age of dentistry!

Without its 18th century foundations, dental chairs, porcelain teeth, modern dentures, and specific tools for dentists, oral care would be much worse! After this presentation, you’ll want to give your dentist and dental assistants a “plaque.”

Find out the Tooth, the Whole Tooth, and nothing by the Tooth on how our founding fathers took care of their oral hygiene and why we should be happy to have the dentists of today.

This event is part of the museum’s Deep Dive Into History series, programs designed to give visitors a deeper understanding of our shared past through costumed interpretation and hands-on learning. Each Deep Dive delves into a specific theme in Lower Cape Fear history. This event is FREE, but donations are always appreciated.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Tory War
description:
Have you heard of the Tory War? From 1780-81, Cumberland County and the surrounding region fell into a civil war between Tories and Patriots during the American Revolution. Learn the stories of courage and horror that took place in this formative period in the region's history!

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Goldston America 250 Film Series
description:
Join the Chatham Community Library for this Goldston America 250 Film Series, hosted every fourth Tuesday, January-December 2026, 4pm-6pm. America 250’s mission is to honor and commemorate the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence, marking America’s Semiquincentennial. The Goldston Library will screen the following documentaries and films:

Tue, Jan 27, 4pm-6pm The Congress, Ken Burns.
Tue, Feb 24, 4pm-6pm Becoming Frederick Douglass, Stanley Nelson and Nicole London.
Tue, Mar 24, 4pm-6pm Rachel Carson: The Woman Who Launched the Modern Environmental Movement, Michelle Ferrari.
Tue, Apr 28, 4pm-6pm Thomas Jefferson: A View from the Mountain, Martin Doblmeier.
Tue, May 26, 4pm-6pm The Address, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jun 23, 4pm-6pm The Brooklyn Bridge, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jul 28, 4pm-6pm The Statue of Liberty, Ken Burns.
Tue, Aug 25, 4pm-6pm American Coup: Wilmington 1898, Yoruba Richen and Brad Lichtenstein.
Tue, Sep 22, 4pm-6pm How it Feels to be Free, Yoruba Richen.
Tue, Oct 27, 4pm-6pm 80 Years Later, Celine Parreñas Shimizu.
Tue, Nov 24, 4pm-6pm Gather, Sanjay Rawal.
Tue, Dec 22, 4pm-6pm Women of World War II: The Untold Stories, Eli Brown.

This FREE, family-friendly event is open to the public. No registration is required. The event will take place indoors in the Goldston Library. The Goldston Library is ADA-compliant, including wheelchair-accessible parking, entrances, seating, common spaces, walkways, and restrooms. Free parking is available outside the library. Pets are not allowed - please leave your furry friends at home.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Dune Ranger Discovery Camp
description:
Calling all future Dune Rangers!  Join Ranger Austin and friends for a fun, educational, and adventurous three-day camp.  Explore maritime forests, paddle on the Roanoke Sound, climb the tallest active dune on the east coast, be creative with cool arts and crafts projects, play goofy games, help with stewardship projects, and make new friends.  At the end of the week, you will be an official Dune Ranger!  Our camp is supported by Friends of Jockey’s Ridge.  

July 29 - July 31, 2026       9:00am to 12:00pm daily

Open to grades 3-6.

Pre-registration is required.  Please email austin.paul@ncparks.gov to signup.  

The mission of the Dune Ranger Discovery Camp will focus on the following elements.

Provide educational opportunities for our youth (both local and visitors),

to promote stewardship and an appreciation for our natural areas,

to provide a safe place for our youth to interact with others and create friendships,

to promote an active lifestyle,

allow for creativity,

and to have fun.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: National Ranger Day, Touch-a-Truck!
description:
Come to Lake Norman's Visitor Center to see what our trucks look like! People will have a chance to step inside a Ranger's truck and see all the hats that Rangers wear on a day to day basis and we keep in our truck to protect our visitors and park. 

This event is to help celebrate World Ranger Day. 

 

Photo by J. Davidson: A park ranger's flat hat with a scenic sunrise fall view at Morrow Mountain State Park
