title: Ranger Walk & Talk
description:
In honor of World Ranger Day, join a ranger at Boone Fork Parking Area (milepost 299.9 on the Blue Ridge Parkway) for a short stroll along the Tanawha Trail. Learn what rangers do on a day-to-day basis, how we got our job, and feel free to ask us questions! This short, 1/4 mile easy hike ends at a beautiful bridge over the Boone Fork Creek. Feel free to continue your hike onto Grandfather Mountain State Park trails from here, or turn around and walk back with the Ranger. 

Please wear appropriate hiking shoes and dress for the weather.

There are no bathrooms at Boone Fork Parking Area.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Independence Comes to NC!
description:
Did you know that North Carolina’s first public reading of the Declaration of Independence took place in Halifax on August 1st, 1776?  Join historical interpreters as they reenact events surrounding the joyous news of American independence from Britain. At 12:00pm, see a reenactor portray Cornelius Harnett, President of the Council of Safety, read the Declaration for the first time in North Carolina. View a screening of The American Constitution, a new documentary film on the writing of the United States Constitution, which was partially filmed at Historic Halifax. Free.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

description:
Downtown Techies: Durham
Hey Techies!

We are so excited to see you all again! Heads up! for the summer months we are merging all of our events into an event once a month on the first Tuesday of every month!

Don't forget to RSVP for first round free!!

We will be resuming Downtown Durham events in September on the third Tuesday of every month. We would love your suggestions on venues! Just ping us.

Questions or suggestions?

Our digital door is always open at www.downtowntechies.com or @downtowntechies. Check out our events in Raleigh as well!

Meet, Drink and be TECHIE!

-Jake and Blake

Looking to get more connected to the local tech scene, opportunity or talent? Email us info@downtowntechies.com and we will make sure you find what you need!

title: Ranger Workshop - Backyard Birding
description:
Join us at The Park at Seven Devils for some backyard birding! Birding is an activity that can be done by anyone at any age. Most birders start out by identifying common birds found at their backyard bird feeders. During this workshop you will learn how to point out key characteristics, such as size, coloration, and activity, that can help you identify common backyard bird species, specifically species that visit bird feeders. By using applications like Audubon and Merlin, along with identification guides, you will be able to use those key characteristics to help you identify common species found here in the High Country. Binoculars are not required, but highly recommended, and there will be a quick lesson on how to properly use binoculars. This is a Ranger Workshop with The Town of Seven Devils.

title: Discover Tryon Palace: Outlander
location: Tryon Palace Historic Sites and Gardens
description:
Step into Tryon Palace and explore Diana Gabaldon’s award-winning Outlander series. Learn about the lives of the fictional Jamie and Claire Fraser, their family and friends, and interactions with historical figures and events in the tumultuous period of the American Revolution.

Tour covers storylines from Outlander books 4 – 8 and the Starz Outlander seasons 4 – 8. (For those not current on the books or show, there will be spoilers for these books and seasons.)

Tour begins at 301 George Street, across from the Tryon Palace Main Gates. Ticket holders should check in at the Waystation ticketing desk no later than 3:30 p.m.

title: Optimizing Operations: Benefits and Types of Work Measurement
description:
Join NC State Industry Expansion Solutions for a webinar that will explain how to become an expert in work measurements and the latest lean and continuous improvement tools. Work measurement is a foundational practice for improving efficiency and productivity. By systematically analyzing the time and effort required to perform tasks, organizations can achieve a variety of benefits:

Improved planning and scheduling: Accurate time standards allow for better resource allocation, project timelines and production scheduling.Enhanced cost control: By knowing the time it takes to produce a product or deliver a service, businesses can more accurately estimate costs, set prices and manage budgets.Performance evaluation: Work measurement provides a fair and objective basis for evaluating employee or team performance, setting realistic goals and identifying training needs.Process Improvement: By identifying and eliminating non-value-added time, organizations can streamline workflows, reduce waste and increase overall productivity.Informed decision-making: Data from work measurement provides a solid foundation for capital investment decisions, process redesign and outsourcing analyses.Who Should Attend the Webinar?

Anyone responsible for ensuring efficient, consistent plant operationsProduction and operations engineersPlant managersShop supervisorsForemenTechniciansLine workersLean and continuous improvement practitioners

title: Goldston America 250 Film Series
description:
Join the Chatham Community Library for this Goldston America 250 Film Series, hosted every fourth Tuesday, January-December 2026, 4pm-6pm. America 250’s mission is to honor and commemorate the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence, marking America’s Semiquincentennial. The Goldston Library will screen the following documentaries and films:

Tue, Jan 27, 4pm-6pm The Congress, Ken Burns.
Tue, Feb 24, 4pm-6pm Becoming Frederick Douglass, Stanley Nelson and Nicole London.
Tue, Mar 24, 4pm-6pm Rachel Carson: The Woman Who Launched the Modern Environmental Movement, Michelle Ferrari.
Tue, Apr 28, 4pm-6pm Thomas Jefferson: A View from the Mountain, Martin Doblmeier.
Tue, May 26, 4pm-6pm The Address, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jun 23, 4pm-6pm The Brooklyn Bridge, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jul 28, 4pm-6pm The Statue of Liberty, Ken Burns.
Tue, Aug 25, 4pm-6pm American Coup: Wilmington 1898, Yoruba Richen and Brad Lichtenstein.
Tue, Sep 22, 4pm-6pm How it Feels to be Free, Yoruba Richen.
Tue, Oct 27, 4pm-6pm 80 Years Later, Celine Parreñas Shimizu.
Tue, Nov 24, 4pm-6pm Gather, Sanjay Rawal.
Tue, Dec 22, 4pm-6pm Women of World War II: The Untold Stories, Eli Brown.

This FREE, family-friendly event is open to the public. No registration is required. The event will take place indoors in the Goldston Library. The Goldston Library is ADA-compliant, including wheelchair-accessible parking, entrances, seating, common spaces, walkways, and restrooms. Free parking is available outside the library. Pets are not allowed - please leave your furry friends at home.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Dr. M.T. Pope House Presents: Evelyn's Book Club
description:
This program honors Evelyn Pope by reading books. 

Evelyn, a college librarian born in 1908 and died in 1995, loved a variety of books from The Adventures of Tom Sawyer to Shakespeare and James Baldwin. The program brings community members together monthly at the museum to discuss books, focusing on works by Black writers or featuring Black subjects, including fiction and non-fiction. Discussions will use questions to facilitate conversation.

"Mama Day" by Gloria Naylor
Wednesday, Feb. 25
 "The Black Angels: The Untold Story of the Nurses Who Helped Cure Tuberculosis" by Maria Smilios
Wednesday, April 22
 "A Visitation of Spirits" by Randall Kenan
Wednesday, June 24
 "Becoming Lunsford Lane: The Lives of an American Aeneas" by Craig Friend
Wednesday, Aug. 26
 "Ring Shout" by P. Dejeli Clark
Thursday, Oct. 29Registration opens Jan. 23.  An optional book bundle will be available to purchase at registration. Books can be picked up at the Dr. M.T. Pope House Museum.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Anniversary of the New Bern Resolves
description:
*Save the Date* More Details Coming Soon! The New Bern Resolves constitute a significant chapter in the history of the American Revolution, reflecting the growing discontent of the colonies with British rule and their bold steps toward self-governance. Adopted on August 27, 1774, by 71 elected NC delegates to the First Provincial Congress in America, the New Bern Resolves represented an early, decisive expression of resistance to British policies and "The Intolerable Acts" (Boston Port/Trade Act, Massachusetts Government Act, Administration of Justice Act, and Quartering Acts) by calling for economic sanctions against Great Britain and its trading partners. As one of the earliest documented calls for solidarity among the colonies, the New Bern Resolves laid the groundwork for broader revolutionary movements.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

description:
Temple Theatre is one of North Carolina’s premier regional theatres, offering Broadway-quality productions in the heart of downtown Sanford. In September, Temple Theatre will present "1776: An American Musical," a stirring musical set in Philadelphia in 1776. 

Tickets range from $25 to $40 with discounts available for active military, Lee County educators and students, and groups of 10 or more. Visit templeshows.org or call 919-774-4512 for more information.

title: Education in the Historical Park
description:
Getting an education is more than “book learning” in school. How to build, craft, and care for things to teach others is a form of education too. Come see our costumed interpreters demonstrate some of the educational activities of the 18th and 19th centuries. FREE. All ages welcome. Drop-in.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Our Maritime Heritage. Living History at Bath –
description:
Celebrate the establishment of the Colonial Navy by the Continental Congress on September 13, 1775, with demonstrations of all things naval: ropemaking, signal flags, maps, naval stores, spinning and weaving, blacksmithing. Learn about Bath and its role in the naval life of the colony. Munitions demonstrations scheduled throughout the day.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Girl Scouts Love State Parks!
description:
It's year of America's 250th birthday and we are calling all Girl Scouts to celebrate! This year we will be going over different historical games that were popular 250 years ago. Girls will have a chance to play different games and friendly competitions will be had to see who has the best historical games skills!

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Deep Sky Astronomy
location: Haw River State Park - Iron Ore Belt Accesss
description:
This event is free to attend, but registration is requested. 

Join local astronomers with the Greensboro Astronomy Club as we observe the night skies over the Iron Ore Belt Access. Attendees may expect to see closer-than-typical views of the moon, planets, star clusters, and other celestial objects subject to change with time of year and local sky darkness.

Telescopes and viewing equipment will be set up on site but you may wish to bring your own binoculars or telescope, plus a chair or blanket for seating. Dress for the weather. Flashlights & headlamps should have a red-light option or filter to protect your night vision.

Skywatching sessions may be cancelled at the last minute for weather. Please register at the Register link so you can be emailed in the event of cancellation.

Program equipment and instruction provided by members of the Greensboro Astronomy Club, which meet the third Friday of each month at the Greensboro Science Center. Learn more about their organization here: 

https://greensboroastronomyclub.org/

Star-gazing Etiquette:

Please use a red light at the observing session and keep any light pointed at the ground. As your eyes adapt, a light is not needed at all.Pease do not touch any telescopes or other equipment unless permission is given and form a orderly line behind each telescope. Please do not allow children or pets to run around the observing area. Pets must be on a leash no longer than 6 feet at all times. This is to protect others' safety and the equipment.Stock photo © Pexels / Lucas Pezeta

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Webinar: Recruiting Veterans for Manufacturing Careers
description:
Are you a manufacturer struggling to find skilled workers to fill your open positions? If so, look no further than veterans. These highly trained individuals possess unique skills and qualities that make them ideal candidates for careers in manufacturing. Recruiting veterans for manufacturing careers is a win-win situation. They bring a wealth of experience, discipline and technical skills that can significantly benefit the industry.

NC State University Industry Expansion Solutions will host a webinar on recruiting veterans for manufacturing jobs. Participants will learn about:

The benefits of hiring veteransMilitary workforce basicsMilitary workforce impedimentsVeterans transition programsMilitary occupational specialties

To receive the meeting link and additional meeting details, please contact Brenda L. Mickens at (919) 515-4190.

Source: NC State University

title: Luminary & Freedom Stories
description:
Harriet Ann Daves recalled just how monumental Civil War surrenders were for her family: "When the surrender came my grandfather came to my mother and told her: 'Well, you are as free as I am.'"

Claiming freedom was not so straightforward for the 331,059 enslaved women, children, and men during the Civil War. Some took enormous risk to reach Union lines before the federal government made any promise of abolishing slavery. Others left their homes and plantations to follow Sherman's army as they marched through the southeast. Some believed home was where they already lived and worked and waited patiently for freedom to extend to them. Others still were lied to by their enslavers or moved away from the advancing U.S. Army so they would remain enslaved. Freedom came in different ways and at different times to enslaved people across the state.

One common thread unites these freedom stories: the defeat of the Confederate military ensured a new birth of freedom across the state and nation.

During this special luminary program, Bennett Place invites you to reflect on the end of the Civil War as a momentous step towards freedom for all Americans and the end of chattel slavery in the United States. Walk among 3,310 luminaries - one for every 1,000 enslaved people in North Carolina - and reflect on experiences of enslavement and freedom. Historians dot the path and share stories of people's pathways to freedom and life after slavery & the Civil War.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Stary Party
location: Lake Norman State Park- Swim Beach Parking Lot
description:

Astronomy based games and crafts will be set up during the event. In the event of rain, this event will be held on the following Saturday. Meet at the swim beach parking lot.

title: Discover Tryon Palace: Outlander
location: Tryon Palace Historic Sites and Gardens
description:
Step into Tryon Palace and explore Diana Gabaldon’s award-winning Outlander series. Learn about the lives of the fictional Jamie and Claire Fraser, their family and friends, and interactions with historical figures and events in the tumultuous period of the American Revolution.

Tour covers storylines from Outlander books 4 – 8 and the Starz Outlander seasons 4 – 8. (For those not current on the books or show, there will be spoilers for these books and seasons.)

Tour begins at 301 George Street, across from the Tryon Palace Main Gates. Ticket holders should check in at the Waystation ticketing desk no later than 3:30 p.m.

title: Goldston America 250 Film Series
description:
Join the Chatham Community Library for this Goldston America 250 Film Series, hosted every fourth Tuesday, January-December 2026, 4pm-6pm. America 250’s mission is to honor and commemorate the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence, marking America’s Semiquincentennial. The Goldston Library will screen the following documentaries and films:

Tue, Jan 27, 4pm-6pm The Congress, Ken Burns.
Tue, Feb 24, 4pm-6pm Becoming Frederick Douglass, Stanley Nelson and Nicole London.
Tue, Mar 24, 4pm-6pm Rachel Carson: The Woman Who Launched the Modern Environmental Movement, Michelle Ferrari.
Tue, Apr 28, 4pm-6pm Thomas Jefferson: A View from the Mountain, Martin Doblmeier.
Tue, May 26, 4pm-6pm The Address, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jun 23, 4pm-6pm The Brooklyn Bridge, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jul 28, 4pm-6pm The Statue of Liberty, Ken Burns.
Tue, Aug 25, 4pm-6pm American Coup: Wilmington 1898, Yoruba Richen and Brad Lichtenstein.
Tue, Sep 22, 4pm-6pm How it Feels to be Free, Yoruba Richen.
Tue, Oct 27, 4pm-6pm 80 Years Later, Celine Parreñas Shimizu.
Tue, Nov 24, 4pm-6pm Gather, Sanjay Rawal.
Tue, Dec 22, 4pm-6pm Women of World War II: The Untold Stories, Eli Brown.

This FREE, family-friendly event is open to the public. No registration is required. The event will take place indoors in the Goldston Library. The Goldston Library is ADA-compliant, including wheelchair-accessible parking, entrances, seating, common spaces, walkways, and restrooms. Free parking is available outside the library. Pets are not allowed - please leave your furry friends at home.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Dr. M.T. Pope House Presents: Evelyn's Book Club
description:
This program honors Evelyn Pope by reading books. 

Evelyn, a college librarian born in 1908 and died in 1995, loved a variety of books from The Adventures of Tom Sawyer to Shakespeare and James Baldwin. The program brings community members together monthly at the museum to discuss books, focusing on works by Black writers or featuring Black subjects, including fiction and non-fiction. Discussions will use questions to facilitate conversation.

"Mama Day" by Gloria Naylor
Wednesday, Feb. 25
 "The Black Angels: The Untold Story of the Nurses Who Helped Cure Tuberculosis" by Maria Smilios
Wednesday, April 22
 "A Visitation of Spirits" by Randall Kenan
Wednesday, June 24
 "Becoming Lunsford Lane: The Lives of an American Aeneas" by Craig Friend
Wednesday, Aug. 26
 "Ring Shout" by P. Dejeli Clark
Thursday, Oct. 29Registration opens Jan. 23.  An optional book bundle will be available to purchase at registration. Books can be picked up at the Dr. M.T. Pope House Museum.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

description:

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Carolina Blues: Indigo on the Cape Fear
location: North Carolina Maritime Museum at Southport
description:
Don’t be blue – we have lots of indigo for you! This subtropical plant was an incredibly important commodity in the Carolinas of the 18th century. We will be exploring the process used by skilled enslaved African labor to extract this valuable dye from the indigo plants - and delve into the science behind dye production. Visitors will have a chance to view and work an active fermentation vat, and dyeing demonstrations will occur throughout the course of the program. T-shirts will also be available for purchase for visitors to try their hand at resist dyeing.

This is a partnered program between Brunswick Town/Fort Anderson State Historic Site and the North Carolina Maritime Museum at Southport. In 2026, this event will be held at the North Carolina Maritime Museum at Southport.

This is an America 250 NC event.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Downtown Techies Durham and Raleigh MERGE FOR THE SUMMER!
description:
Downtown Techies: Durham
Hey Techies!

We are so excited to see you all again! Heads up! for the summer months we are merging all of our events into an event once a month on the first Tuesday of every month!

Don't forget to RSVP for first round free!!

We will be resuming Downtown Durham events in September on the third Tuesday of every month. We would love your suggestions on venues! Just ping us.

Questions or suggestions?

Our digital door is always open at www.downtowntechies.com or @downtowntechies. Check out our events in Raleigh as well!

Meet, Drink and be TECHIE!

-Jake and Blake

Looking to get more connected to the local tech scene, opportunity or talent? Email us info@downtowntechies.com and we will make sure you find what you need!

Source: Meetup: Downtown Techies Durham

title: NC State Writes: Celebrating the National Day on Writing
description:
Join the Campus Writing and Speaking Program (CWSP) on Monday, Oct. 20, for NC State Writes, a campuswide celebration of the National Day on Writing. From 9 a.m. to 2 p.m., stop by our pop-up writing stations at the D.H. Hill Jr. Library and Talley Student Union to:

Share your #WhyIWrite storyAdd a line to our collaborative Wolfpack poemTry quick-write prompts to spark creativityPick up free CWSP swagAt 12:30 p.m., join NC State Writes Together for a campuswide writing pause connecting students, faculty and staff through shared reflection and creativity. For 10 minutes, we'll all respond to this question: "What does being part of the Wolfpack mean to you?"

If you can’t join us in person, participate on social media by posting your own #WhyIWrite story with #WolfpackWrites.

All are welcome to participate — because at NC State, we all write.

Source: NC State University

description:

title: Goldston America 250 Film Series
description:
Join the Chatham Community Library for this Goldston America 250 Film Series, hosted every fourth Tuesday, January-December 2026, 4pm-6pm. America 250’s mission is to honor and commemorate the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence, marking America’s Semiquincentennial. The Goldston Library will screen the following documentaries and films:

Tue, Jan 27, 4pm-6pm The Congress, Ken Burns.
Tue, Feb 24, 4pm-6pm Becoming Frederick Douglass, Stanley Nelson and Nicole London.
Tue, Mar 24, 4pm-6pm Rachel Carson: The Woman Who Launched the Modern Environmental Movement, Michelle Ferrari.
Tue, Apr 28, 4pm-6pm Thomas Jefferson: A View from the Mountain, Martin Doblmeier.
Tue, May 26, 4pm-6pm The Address, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jun 23, 4pm-6pm The Brooklyn Bridge, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jul 28, 4pm-6pm The Statue of Liberty, Ken Burns.
Tue, Aug 25, 4pm-6pm American Coup: Wilmington 1898, Yoruba Richen and Brad Lichtenstein.
Tue, Sep 22, 4pm-6pm How it Feels to be Free, Yoruba Richen.
Tue, Oct 27, 4pm-6pm 80 Years Later, Celine Parreñas Shimizu.
Tue, Nov 24, 4pm-6pm Gather, Sanjay Rawal.
Tue, Dec 22, 4pm-6pm Women of World War II: The Untold Stories, Eli Brown.

This FREE, family-friendly event is open to the public. No registration is required. The event will take place indoors in the Goldston Library. The Goldston Library is ADA-compliant, including wheelchair-accessible parking, entrances, seating, common spaces, walkways, and restrooms. Free parking is available outside the library. Pets are not allowed - please leave your furry friends at home.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Ranger Workshop - Haunted High Country
description:
The High Country is filled with ghost stories and unexplained encounters. What stories have you been told? Come carve some Jack-o-Lanterns and share some spooky high country stories with us. This program will be at The Park at Seven Devils. This is a Ranger Workshop with The Town of Seven Devils. Limited spots, please email amelia.gallina@ncparks.gov to register by October 22nd.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Dr. M.T. Pope House Presents: Evelyn's Book Club
description:
This program honors Evelyn Pope by reading books. 

Evelyn, a college librarian born in 1908 and died in 1995, loved a variety of books from The Adventures of Tom Sawyer to Shakespeare and James Baldwin. The program brings community members together monthly at the museum to discuss books, focusing on works by Black writers or featuring Black subjects, including fiction and non-fiction. Discussions will use questions to facilitate conversation.

"Mama Day" by Gloria Naylor
Wednesday, Feb. 25
 "The Black Angels: The Untold Story of the Nurses Who Helped Cure Tuberculosis" by Maria Smilios
Wednesday, April 22
 "A Visitation of Spirits" by Randall Kenan
Wednesday, June 24
 "Becoming Lunsford Lane: The Lives of an American Aeneas" by Craig Friend
Wednesday, Aug. 26
 "Ring Shout" by P. Dejeli Clark
Thursday, Oct. 29Registration opens Jan. 23.  An optional book bundle will be available to purchase at registration. Books can be picked up at the Dr. M.T. Pope House Museum.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Downtown Techies Durham and Raleigh MERGE FOR THE SUMMER!
description:
Downtown Techies: Durham
Hey Techies!

We are so excited to see you all again! Heads up! for the summer months we are merging all of our events into an event once a month on the first Tuesday of every month!

Don't forget to RSVP for first round free!!

We will be resuming Downtown Durham events in September on the third Tuesday of every month. We would love your suggestions on venues! Just ping us.

Questions or suggestions?

Our digital door is always open at www.downtowntechies.com or @downtowntechies. Check out our events in Raleigh as well!

Meet, Drink and be TECHIE!

-Jake and Blake

Looking to get more connected to the local tech scene, opportunity or talent? Email us info@downtowntechies.com and we will make sure you find what you need!

Source: Meetup: Downtown Techies Durham

title: Homeschool Day at Reed Gold Mine
description:
Dive into a variety of STEAM displays and demonstrations across the site. The highlight of the day is a unique opportunity to step into the shoes of historic miners as you explore 450 feet of restored tunnels, 50 feet below the surface, in our underground mine.

Admission is $4.00 (plus tax) for ages 5 and up and children under 5 are free of charge. Cash and credit card payments inside the Visitor Center (we cannot accept American Express).

Gold panning will be offered, weather permitting, for an additional $4.00 per person (plus tax). 

Registration is not accepted for Homeschool Day.

description:

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: The Great Pumpkin Blowout
description:
Has that jack-o-lantern on your front porch outlived its usefulness? Dispose of him in a unique and rather explosive way by implementing the same technology used to detonate Civil War era torpedoes!
$10 fee per pumpkin and BYOP (bring your own pumpkin). It is free to watch, but YOU get to press the button to detonate if you bring your own! Pumpkins with minimal carving offer the best explosions, but we can work with all types.
Tickets can be purchased at the site on the day of the event.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Deep Sky Astronomy
location: Haw River State Park - Iron Ore Belt Access
description:
This event is free to attend, but registration is requested. 

Join local astronomers with the Greensboro Astronomy Club as we observe the night skies over the Iron Ore Belt Access. Attendees may expect to see closer-than-typical views of the moon, planets, star clusters, and other celestial objects subject to change with time of year and local sky darkness.

Telescopes and viewing equipment will be set up on site but you may wish to bring your own binoculars or telescope, plus a chair or blanket for seating. Dress for the weather. Flashlights & headlamps should have a red-light option or filter to protect your night vision.

Skywatching sessions may be cancelled at the last minute for weather. Please register at the Register link so you can be emailed in the event of cancellation.

Program equipment and instruction provided by members of the Greensboro Astronomy Club, which meet the third Friday of each month at the Greensboro Science Center. Learn more about their organization here: 

https://greensboroastronomyclub.org/

Star-gazing Etiquette:

Please use a red light at the observing session and keep any light pointed at the ground. As your eyes adapt, a light is not needed at all.Pease do not touch any telescopes or other equipment unless permission is given and form a orderly line behind each telescope. Please do not allow children or pets to run around the observing area. Pets must be on a leash no longer than 6 feet at all times. This is to protect others' safety and the equipment.Stock photo © Pexels / Lucas Pezeta

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Battleship North Carolina Pearl Harbor Day and Veterans Day Remembrances
description:
Pearl Harbor Day and Veterans Day Remembrances

 

Operating aboard Battleship NORTH CAROLINA, the Azalea Coast Radio Club hosts worldwide HAM radio operator events commemorating:  

The December 7, 1941 attack on Pearl HarborVeterans DayThe Battleship is NI4BK, and HAM operators may contact the ship via Voice, Digital, and Morse Code. NI4BK looks forward to hearing from YOU!

Radio operators making contact will receive a special postcard verifying the contact.

title: Hidden Battleship Tour
description:
Hidden Battleship is for the explorer at heart! Join us for an afternoon on a unique, behind-the-scenes tour of unrestored areas on the Battleship. Organized into small groups, the participants are led to areas in the bow, third deck, and below, and the superstructure, including all the way to the very top! This program requires climbing ladders, crossing high hatches, and going through tight/confined spaces. The tour is limited to ages 16 and older.

2026 Dates

► January 24
► February 28
► March 28
► April 18
► November 14

11 am – 5 pm; $75 (plus tax) per participant. This program always sells out, so get your Hidden Battleship ticket now! This program is for ages 16 and older.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Indigenous Cooking in the Historical Park
description:
Join us as we celebrate Native American Heritage Month with historic foodways! Our costumed interpreters will cook dishes and discuss historic methods of native cooking. Food samples are unavailable to the public. Demonstration only. FREE. All ages welcome. Drop-in.

title: Department of Defense Contracting and CMMC Webinar
description:
Cybersecurity Maturity Model Certification (CMMC) compliance is required for all Department of Defense contracts. NC State Industry Expansion Solutions will host a webinar on how to become CMMC compliant, how long it takes to become compliant and how much it costs. You should attend the webinar if your company is a Department of Defense contractor or plans to become a contractor. Participants will learn:

CMMC is a law, not an optional standard.CMMC certification is not an overnight project. CMMC certification is not an overnight project. You need to act quickly, or you will risk losing Department of Defense contracts.

title: Open Hearth Cooking Demonstration in the Historical Park
description:
Learn how early Americans prepared and cooked for large dinner parties like what most of us experience during the Thanksgiving holiday. Our costumed interpreters will demonstrate how to cook a fall harvest meal over an open hearth in the Hoggatt House. Food samples are unavailable to the public. Demonstration only. FREE. All ages welcome. Drop-in.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Discover Tryon Palace: Outlander
location: Tryon Palace Historic Sites and Gardens
description:
Step into Tryon Palace and explore Diana Gabaldon’s award-winning Outlander series. Learn about the lives of the fictional Jamie and Claire Fraser, their family and friends, and interactions with historical figures and events in the tumultuous period of the American Revolution.

Tour covers storylines from Outlander books 4 – 8 and the Starz Outlander seasons 4 – 8. (For those not current on the books or show, there will be spoilers for these books and seasons.)

Tour begins at 301 George Street, across from the Tryon Palace Main Gates. Ticket holders should check in at the Waystation ticketing desk no later than 3:30 p.m.

title: Downtown Techies Durham and Raleigh MERGE FOR THE SUMMER!
description:
Downtown Techies: Durham
Hey Techies!

We are so excited to see you all again! Heads up! for the summer months we are merging all of our events into an event once a month on the first Tuesday of every month!

Don't forget to RSVP for first round free!!

We will be resuming Downtown Durham events in September on the third Tuesday of every month. We would love your suggestions on venues! Just ping us.

Questions or suggestions?

Our digital door is always open at www.downtowntechies.com or @downtowntechies. Check out our events in Raleigh as well!

Meet, Drink and be TECHIE!

-Jake and Blake

Looking to get more connected to the local tech scene, opportunity or talent? Email us info@downtowntechies.com and we will make sure you find what you need!

Source: Meetup: Downtown Techies Durham

title: Yuletide by Lanternlight
description:
Experience an authentic Christmas of long ago in the warm glow of lantern light.  Enjoy homes, public buildings, and taverns decorated for the season with festive, all-natural décor.  Interactive historical vignettes will bring each building to life.  Enjoy a warm fire in the Tap Room tavern, just as guests did two hundred years ago! Tickets go on sale Nov. 1st.  

 

Fee, ticket required.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Santa at the Lake
description:
It's the 2nd Annual Santa at the Lake! Bring your Christmas wish lists, little ones, and fury friends for the perfect photo down at the Swim Beach with Santa! We have activities set up for kids and Friends of Lake Norman will be taking donations for sweet treats and warm drinks at our concessions stands.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Battleship North Carolina Pearl Harbor Day and Veterans Day Remembrances
description:
Pearl Harbor Day and Veterans Day Remembrances

 

Operating aboard Battleship NORTH CAROLINA, the Azalea Coast Radio Club hosts worldwide HAM radio operator events commemorating:  

The December 7, 1941 attack on Pearl HarborVeterans DayThe Battleship is NI4BK, and HAM operators may contact the ship via Voice, Digital, and Morse Code. NI4BK looks forward to hearing from YOU!

Radio operators making contact will receive a special postcard verifying the contact.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Christmas at Historic Bath
description:
Join us as we look at Christmas traditions during the colonial period in the Palmer Marsh House and into the early Victorian period in the Bonner House. Christmas décor of the time periods, vignettes, live music, and light refreshments. 

Use of Palmer-Marsh, Palmer Marsh yard, Bonner House and Kitchen

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: An 18th Century Christmas
description:
Join us once again this holiday season, as we explore how the American colonists celebrated Christmas. During the program, you can enjoy 18th-century-inspired refreshments in the Visitor Center, participate in traditional games, or try your hand at Moravian paper stars and other 18th-century crafts. The highlight of the evening will be an authentic
period candlelit service in the ruins of St. Philip's Anglican Church. The service will begin at 5:00pm and will conclude by 5:30pm. Tickets can be purchased at the gate on the day of.
$5 per person.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Ranger Workshop - Black Bears
description:
Become more Bear Wise and learn all about black bears physical features, behavioral patterns, and how they change with age. We will also learn about prevention methods for both backcountry and rural settings, alongside what to do if you encounter a bear in either setting. The Black Bear program will be held at The Seven Devils Community Center as part of their Ranger Workshop Series.

title: Scottish Faire in Historical Park
description:
Prepare to celebrate and enjoy festive Scottish traditions for New Year’s Eve (Hogmanay) and the Yule season. Enjoy speaking to Revolutionary soldiers of the NC Highland and 71st Regiments, listen to Gaelic music and storytelling, learn about tartan history and see traditional Hogmanay dishes made over an open fire, and more. We encourage you to dress in your family tartan or plaid! Food not available to the public. FREE. All ages welcome. Drop-in.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: National Wreaths Across America Day
description:
The local observance of National Wreaths Across America Day is planned for Saturday, December 19, at 12:00 noon at the Taylorsville Cemetery. Daughters of the American Revolution (DAR) – Carolina Emerald Chapter will host a Sons of the American Revolution musket volley as part of the event.

title: Goldston America 250 Film Series
description:
Join the Chatham Community Library for this Goldston America 250 Film Series, hosted every fourth Tuesday, January-December 2026, 4pm-6pm. America 250’s mission is to honor and commemorate the 250th anniversary of the signing of the Declaration of Independence, marking America’s Semiquincentennial. The Goldston Library will screen the following documentaries and films:

Tue, Jan 27, 4pm-6pm The Congress, Ken Burns.
Tue, Feb 24, 4pm-6pm Becoming Frederick Douglass, Stanley Nelson and Nicole London.
Tue, Mar 24, 4pm-6pm Rachel Carson: The Woman Who Launched the Modern Environmental Movement, Michelle Ferrari.
Tue, Apr 28, 4pm-6pm Thomas Jefferson: A View from the Mountain, Martin Doblmeier.
Tue, May 26, 4pm-6pm The Address, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jun 23, 4pm-6pm The Brooklyn Bridge, Ken Burns.
Tue, Jul 28, 4pm-6pm The Statue of Liberty, Ken Burns.
Tue, Aug 25, 4pm-6pm American Coup: Wilmington 1898, Yoruba Richen and Brad Lichtenstein.
Tue, Sep 22, 4pm-6pm How it Feels to be Free, Yoruba Richen.
Tue, Oct 27, 4pm-6pm 80 Years Later, Celine Parreñas Shimizu.
Tue, Nov 24, 4pm-6pm Gather, Sanjay Rawal.
Tue, Dec 22, 4pm-6pm Women of World War II: The Untold Stories, Eli Brown.

This FREE, family-friendly event is open to the public. No registration is required. The event will take place indoors in the Goldston Library. The Goldston Library is ADA-compliant, including wheelchair-accessible parking, entrances, seating, common spaces, walkways, and restrooms. Free parking is available outside the library. Pets are not allowed - please leave your furry friends at home.

This event is part of our Chatham Celebrates America 250 initiative. See more America 250 events.

Source: NC Cultural Resources

title: Building an AI powered, global scale messaging system with XMPP &Deep Learning
description:
Triangle AI Meetup
This talk is an in-depth look at XMPP, the open standard for real-time messaging, and how to build a global scale, AI enhanced messaging system using XMPP. We’ll explore EJabberD, the massively scalable, open-source XMPP server that powers in-game chat for Eve Online, and examine how to: combine XMPP with WebRTC for real-time audio/video calling, add AIML to build helpful chatbots, and how to incorporate Deep Learning to categorize messages in real-time. After the talk, you’ll know how to use XMPP and Ejabberd to build anything from a help-desk chatops application, to a globe spanning in-game messaging system.

Source: Meetup: Triangle AI
